PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to the fact that:
the Australian Broadcasting Corporation intends to transmit television programs into Asia

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales

PARA.EMPHASIS: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. Dear Senator Loosley
I refer to your letter of 5 November 1992 to the Attorney-General concerning the increase in fees contained in the Marriage Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1992 No 294.
As I have responsibility for matters relating to the Marriage Regulations, I provide the following comments in respect of the increases in the prescribed fees to which you refer.

In the recent review of the fees contained in the Fifth Schedule of the Marriage Regulations, the State and Territory Registrars of Births, Deaths and Marriages were invited to provide comments and suggestions on the fees, for consideration. The Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages, Canberra who also has the function of Registrar of Overseas Marriages, requested an increase for three different fees.
These increases were as follows:

Item 4: Increase from $12.00 to $18.00. This is a fee payable for searches in the Register of Foreign Marriages and the issue of a copy of an entry. Fees for similar matters throughout all Registries range from $15.00 to $27.00.

Item 5: Increase from $8.00 to $15.00. This is a fee payable for searches in the Register of Foreign Marriages and issue of an extract of an entry. Fees for similar matters range from $10.00 to $17.00.

Item 10: Increase from $12.00 to $18.00. This is the fee payable for issuing a copy of a document received under subsection 85(1) (document issued to the couple in the country of marriage). Fees for similar matters range from $15.00 to $27.00.

The above fees were last increased in 1988 (for the review period of January 1986 to December 1987). I consider the increases sought to be appropriate to reflect the fees payable for similar searches and issue of documents throughout all Registries of Births, Deaths and Marriages.

The increases from $30.00 to $40.00 relates to the fee payable at the lodgement of the Notice of Intended Marriage (Item 11) with the civil or registry marriage celebrant. This fee is one part of the normal, or common, fee payable to solemnise a civil marriage. The common fee comprises $40.00 (Notice of Intended Marriage—increased from $30.00 to $40.00); $65.00 (solemnisations of marriage—fee unchanged) and $20.00 (travel fee for first 30 kilometres travelled by celebrant—increased from $18.00 to $20.00). The common fee, previously $113.00, has therefore been increased to $125.00, an increase of $12.00, or 10.6%, which compares with the increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) of 6.7% (for period January 1990-December 1991)
I trust the above comments clarify the reasons for the recent increases contained in the Marriage Regulations.
Yours sincerely
PETER DUNCAN

SPEECH.PARA: Senator S. Loosley
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee,
Regulations and Ordinances

CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Steve

Thank you for your letter of 5 November 1992 in which you ask several questions in relation to the Form NH20, which is approved by the disallowable instrument made under paragraph 40AA(6)(ce) of the National Health Act 1953 ("the Act").

The information which is collected on the NH20 is, as you have surmised, necessary for the reconciliation of actual expenditure against Commonwealth nursing home benefit advanced under the Act, as well as verification of claims for benefit.
Subsection 61(1) of the Act requires proprietors of approved nursing homes to keep such records as would enable claims for Commonwealth benefits to be verified.

Information collected on the NH20 is subject to the secrecy provision contained in section 135A of the Act, which precludes the disclosure, to any person, of any information with respect to the affairs of a third person, acquired in the performance of duties, or in the exercise of powers or functions, under the Act. The only persons who have access to the information are persons performing such duties, or exercising such powers or functions under the Act. Severe penalties are applicable for breaches of section 135A.

I can assure you that the collection of NH20 information is carried out in accordance with the Information Privacy Principles under the Privacy Act 1988. The information is collected for a lawful purpose, that is, to enable the reconciliation of expenditure against claims for Commonwealth benefit, and the verification of those claims. Paragraph 40AA(6)(ce) of the Act provides that it is a condition of the approval of a nursing home that the proprietor submits information relating to the employment of nursing and personal care staff in a form approved by the Secretary of the Department.

The detailed nature of the information required by the form is necessary to identify specific actual costs incurred by the proprietor of a nursing home in relation to nursing and personal care staff and other cost reimbursed expenditure.

The information which is collected does not exceed that which is necessary for the purposes of reconciliation and verification, and the reasons for its collection are clearly set out on the form. I hope that this will be of assistance to the Committee.
Your sincerely,
Peter Staples

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stephen Loosley
Chairman Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Steve,

Thank you for your letter of 5 November 1992 about Locally Engaged Staff (LES) Determinations 1992/18, 1992/22 and 1992/27. I refer also to LES Determination 1992/31 which, together with the other three determinations, was the subject of notice of motion of disallowance in the Senate given on 25 November 1992.
I would like to comment first on some general features of the policy which underpins determination of salary and conditions of employment for LES.

The overall aim is to maintain current LES provisions with reference to another reputable employer who provides up-todate employment arrangements. In the great majority of countries, pay and conditions norms are adopted by reference to United States practice.

As a matter of policy, the Government wants to ensure that LES, who are largely nationals of countries in which Australia is represented, are treated appropriately according to local law and good employer practice in those countries.

These determinations apply only to staff who are employed outside Australia and who in many cases are not native English speakers. Relying on local law and employer practice calls up the system with which LES are most familiar. This process supports the Committee's aims of ensuring clarity of and access to the law by those directly affected, and provides better protection for their rights than if their full conditions of employment were set out in English in Australia and subject only to Australian courts.
LES thereby remain subject to local employment codes and can litigate in local courts if necessary; I understand that Australia does not claim immunity from litigation on LES employment matters.
I attach a report provided by the Department which provides background information on the four determinations queried by the Committee.

I accept that there may be some ambiguity in the determinations in question. To remove this ambiguity, a new LES amending determination (1992/38) has been made and is attached for the Committee's information.

LES Determination 1992/18 (Malta salaries) could be read as adopting Maltese law as in force from time to time. However within two months of its commencement the clause in question was repealed by LES Determination 1992/22, which put in its place a modification of the normal authority for automatic adjustment of Malta salaries. The modification does not adopt Maltese law, but prescribes a change to the adjustment process when the benchmark salaries of United States employees are increased as a result of the operation of Maltese law. The amending determination includes a clause to ensure that this change is made effective from the date of commencement of LES Determination 1992/18.

The purpose of the redundancy conditions inserted by LES Determination 1992/27 (Czechoslovakia) was to provide for LES to enjoy redundancy entitlements consistent with local law as in force at the date of commencement of the determination.

The amendments made by LES Determination 1992/38 specify that the redundancy entitlements referred to are those in force in local law on that date. As the Embassy has now closed, the Czechoslovakian provisions are redundant and will be repealed.

Similarly, LES Determination 1992/31 (Ireland redundancy conditions) was also made to deal with a specific excess staff situation. The Department has amended the provision to limit the scope of the reference to Irish law to the date on which LES Determination 1992/31 became effective.
Yours fraternally
Peter Cook

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon Neal Blewett MP
Minister for Social Security
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Neal
I refer to Statutory Instrument No. 46 of 1992 under s.1315 of the Social Security Act 1991, considered by the Committee of 12 November 1992.
The instrument sets out the guidelines under which the Secretary may give a certificate for the disclosure of information about a person.

It provides that information may be disclosed where the information cannot reasonably be obtained from another source and the person seeking it has an interest in obtaining it. It then prescribes the circumstances in which information may be released. In brief these are where there is an imminent threat to life or health; where the disclosure is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the protection of the public revenue; or, in specified circumstances, where the disclosure concerns a deceased person, a missing person or an abducted person.

The Committee noted that Parliament took the conferral of the power to make such a determination very seriously for, most unusually, s.1315(3) provides that a determination does not take effect until the determination `is no longer liable to be disallowed, or to be deemed to be disallowed'. Thus it is particularly appropriate that the Committee should take its usual care in scrutinising the instrument.

The disclosure provision in clause 2(2) relating to the criminal law, pecuniary penalties or public revenue is very widely drawn and would, in theory, seem to cover everything from murder to unpaid parking fines. Nevertheless, despite this wide ambit, the Explanatory Statement does appear at first to indicate that it is a power that would be used only in serious cases when it states that:
`Typical offences concern murder, armed robbery, drugs, child abuse, and the abduction of children'.
However, it does then go on to mention, for example, the use of the provision:
`to pursue a person who damages Commonwealth property in an altercation with the Department to recover compensation from the person'.

This confirms our view that the provision is very wide and we seek your detailed advice. For instance, if personal information was requested about a person who had not paid a parking fine, would the information be provided? If not, what criteria are used to decide whether to release the information?

Finally, the Committee noted that the Explanatory Statement mentions that the provisions are `aligned with' or `reflect' Information Privacy Principle 11, or are `constructed with Information Privacy Principle 11 of the Privacy Act 1988 in mind'. Given this emphasis, we ask whether the Privacy Commissioner was specifically consulted about the instrument and, if so, whether its terms have the Commissioner's approval.
Yours sincerely
Stephen Loosley
Chairman

PARA.TAB: 17 November 1992

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stephen Loosley
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Stephen

I refer to your letter of 12 November 1992 about Statutory Instrument No 46 of 1992 under section 1315 of the Social Security Act 1991. You took the view that clause 2(2) of the instrument was very wide and sought my detailed advice.

The instrument applies where the Secretary of my Department (or a delegate) is considering whether to release personal information about a person to someone else in a situation where it may be necessary in the public interest to release that information. This is the "public interest" test in paragraph 1314(1)(a) of the Act. It is a severe test which is not readily met.

The social security legislation has always had this test and its use has been carefully guarded over many years. There is now an additional element that must be met. A condition in the instrument under section 1315 must also be satisfied.

It is important to recognise that meeting one of those conditions in clause 2 of the instrument is not enough to enable the release of information. Clause 1 of the instrument must be satisfied and it must still be that the release is necessary in the public interest.

In the example you mention of a person who had not paid a parking fine, it may be that the condition in clause 2(2) of the instrument would be met. However, it is difficult to see that the release of any information about that person (such as his or her whereabouts) would be necessary in the public interest. I do not think that this could happen. It has not happened in the past.

In addition, it is unlikely that clause 1 of the instrument would be satisfied eg information about the whereabouts of the offender could be obtained from the relevant licensing authority (see clause 1(1)(a)).
The criteria used in deciding whether to release information are:
Is it necessary in the public interest that the information be released?
Is clause 1 of the instrument satisfied?
Is a condition mentioned in clause 2 of the instrument met?
Each of these criteria must be satisfied.

The criteria are strict. The first, as mentioned above, is a severe test which is not readily met. The second test limits the scope of the public interest test, and the third test is a further limit which reflects current Commonwealth privacy legislation.
You also asked whether the Privacy Commissioner was specifically consulted about the instrument and, if so, whether its terms have his approval.

The Commissioner was specifically consulted about the instrument by my Department. A copy of the relevant correspondence is attached for your information. You will see that the Commissioner had some reservations about clause 2(2) and the Department's response to that.

I also take the power to make this determination very seriously and I welcome the Committee's scrutiny of it. However, the situation which obtained when the power to make the instrument was introduced into the Act has changed, as the attached correspondence describes. The original instrument being replaced now has much less scope than it first had. The instrument the Committee is considering should be seen in this larger context.
Against this background, I believe that the instrument strikes a reasonable balance between what is in the public interest and the need for the confidentiality of personal information.
Yours sincerely
NEAL BLEWETT

Dear Stephen

I refer to your letter of 30 November 1992 about Statutory Instrument No 46 of 1992 under section 1315 of the Social Security Act 1991. You asked for further information on three matters to assist the Committee.
First, as requested, a copy of the letter of 13 August 1992 from Mr Ross to the Privacy Commissioner is attached.
Second, the instructions to departmental staff are under review to ensure that they correctly reflect what the Government has approved and what the Department and other agencies do in practice.
This review includes giving effect to the suggestions made by the Privacy Commissioner in his letter to the Secretary of 4 September 1992.

The Secretary will be seeking the Privacy Commissioner's views when a draft instrument comes out of the review, as indicated in the Secretary's letter to the Privacy Commissioner of 21 September 1992.

Third, the suggestion made by the Privacy Commissioner that case examples be incorporated into the determination was taken into consideration. This refers to item (2) of clause 2 of the instrument. He made that suggestion so that the boundaries of intended practice would match the boundaries set by law.

The provision being referred to is in identical terms to Information Privacy Principle 11(1)(e) of the Privacy Act 1988. This suggestion was interpreted as requiring the generality of item (2) of clause 2 to be replaced by more specific items rather than retaining item (2) of clause 2 and incorporating examples.

The Secretary dealt with this issue in his letter of 21 September 1992 when he explained the need for the general item and said that he thought it was reasonable to leave the item more open-ended and to see how it works in practice.

There has been little difficulty in practice with IPP 11(1)(e) although you may be aware that there have been differences between the Privacy Commissioner and the Attorney-General's Department about its interpretation.
I doubt if these differences have any significance for this instrument, and it does seem a sensible approach to see how the instrument works in practice.
Yours sincerely
DAVID SlMMONS

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator McMullan, on behalf of Senator Collins) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of amendments to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983. These amendments are intended to:
Enhance accountability arrangements for the ABC;
Improve administrative arrangements under the Act; and
Reflect changes to the arrangements for the transmission of ABC programs.
There are, in addition, a number of minor technical amendments to the ABC Act.
I now turn to the detail of the Bill.

Although the ABC is primarily budget funded and the Parliament can scrutinise the ABC's activities through the details of its appropriation, the ABC is also involved in some commercial activities, in relation to which there is a need for more stringent accountability arrangements.

These commercial activities, which include the production, licensing and sales of program related products, are authorised by the ABC Act or implicit within the ABC's charter. Although the ABC is subject to the Trade Practices Act and to most State regulatory controls, it enjoys some competitive advantages over private businesses, including: exemptions from State and Commonwealth taxes, (except sales tax and customs duty on goods for resale); exemptions from many corporate regulatory requirements; access to publicly funded infrastructure; and free radio and television promotions.
The potential problems with the ABC involvement in competitive business activities are:

That under the protection of public ownership and subsidy, the ABC may deter private businesses from entering a particular market, or may unfairly disadvantage any business which is in that market; and

That those budget funded activities, which have traditionally been considered the prime functions of the ABC, such as its free to air television and radio services may suffer from the ABC's involvement in non-traditional commercial and semi-commercial activities

To minimise the risk to taxpayer's funds, detriment to the quality of free to air programming and to address concerns about the ABC's competitive advantage, this Bill will apply more rigorous financial accountability requirements. The amendments will apply new corporate planning and annual reporting requirements for the ABC embracing all of its functions and are consistent with provisions already approved by parliament as part of the Special Broadcasting Services Act 1991.

Under the proposed arrangements, the ABC will be required to include in its corporate plan, its objectives and overall strategies for fulfilling its functions. The plan will also have to include forecasts of revenue and expenditure (including capital expenditure and borrowings), as well as performance indicators, for all authorised businesses in which the ABC participates.

In addition to the corporate planning requirements, the ABC Board will be required to include in its annual report, an assessment of the extent to which its operations have achieved the corporate plan objectives and to disclose the particulars of business activities carried out during the year, including those conducted through subsidiary companies or joint ventures.

The Government will monitor the effects of these amendments and if it considers that they do not resolve the problem of unfair competition or that commercial activities are imposing undue risk to funds appropriated for charter purposes, the government will consider the need for further legislation.
The Bill contains a number of minor amendments which are intended to enhance the administrative efficiency of the ABC.

The first of these deal with the transfer of responsibility for some routine administrative decisions from the ABC Board to the corporation. These include decisions about the publishing of journals, making of sound recordings etc, and setting charges for these items. I believe that it is entirely appropriate that the board should not be required, by the legislation, to be involved in what are clearly routine administrative matters for which officers of the ABC are responsible on a daily basis.

The board will retain ultimate responsibility for determining what constitutes an advertisement, for the purposes of the Act, and for the annual report of the ABC, but the Bill amends the Act to make it clear that the board does not have to be involved in the day-to-day administration of these activities.

The Bill also contains an amendment to modify the existing provisions allowing the ABC to enter into hedging contracts. The purpose of this amendment is to clarify that the ABC can enter into hedging contracts or other arrangements, in relation to borrowings approved by the Treasurer, in the absence of ministerial guidelines. The ABC act currently empowers the ABC to enter into hedging contracts and enables the Minister to issue guidelines governing ABC involvement in hedging contracts. To date there has been no need to develop guidelines but there has been some uncertainty about whether the ABC can enter into hedging arrangements in the absence of guidelines.

The amendment provides clarification that the ABC can enter into hedging contracts or arrangements in the absence of guidelines but retains the power of the Minister to determine guidelines, if the Minister considers it necessary.

The final administrative amendment deals with the determination of recreation leave entitlements for the managing director of the ABC. This is consequential to an amendment to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 which empowered the Remuneration Tribunal to determine standard recreation leave entitlements for all full-time public office holders. The objective was to ensure the same formal recreation leave entitlements for these office holders as their equivalents in the Australian Public Service. The amendment to the ABC Act provides that the Remuneration Tribunal will determine the recreation leave entitlements for the managing director of the ABC.

It is the responsibility of the Minister for Transport and Communications to provide facilities for the transmission of national broadcasting services. In July of this year, the National Transmission Agency was established with the specific purpose of providing, operating and maintaining the Commonwealth network of transmission facilities.

Initially the National Transmission Agency is operating as a separate cost centre within the Department of Transport and Communications. Its conversion to a government business enterprise will be considered by government next year. In view of the establishment of the National Transmission Agency, the Bill amends the ABC act to remove the provision for the Minister to transfer to the ABC, technical equipment and land relating to transmitting stations used for the purpose of broadcasting the programs of the ABC to the public. The Bill also enables the ABC to arrange for the delivery of its programs to the public.
Finally, the Bill contains some minor technical amendments to the ABC Act.

The first of these is intended to correct an anomaly in the ABC Act which has occurred in the drafting of provisions in the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1992. These provisions, unintentionally, preclude the ABC from charging for subscription services which have been declared to be national services under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. The proposed amendment corrects the anomaly and thereby provides scope for the Minister for Transport and Communications to allow the ABC to operate services, the costs of which are met in full, or part by the audience, through subscriptions. It is envisaged that this provision would only be used in special circumstances and that most subscription services that may be offered by the ABC would be subject to the same regulatory regime as other commercial services under the Broadcasting Services Act.

The Bill also amends the ABC Act to simplify and update the technical provisions along the lines of those included in the Special Broadcasting Service Act. These amendments are necessary because the current provisions in the ABC act are based on archaic concepts no longer used in broadcasting legislation.
The Bill also amends the ABC Act to make its provisions non-gender specific in line with current drafting policy.

The amendments in the Bill will not alter the costs or revenues of the Commonwealth. They do not require the application of additional resources by the ABC to meet its obligations or to comply with its establishment and management responsibilities.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (RESOLUTION OF BOYCOTTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 to repeal sections 45D and 45E, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act which prohibit secondary boycotts and agreements giving effect to secondary boycotts were introduced into the Trade Practices Act by the Fraser Government. Section 45D has operated since 1977 and Section 45E since 1980.

During the entire period of its existence, section 45D has not been widely accepted as a provision concerned with competition—rather it has become more a weapon directed at the industrial relations activities of trade unions under the guise of competition policy. The Fraser Government amended section 45D in 1978 and 1980 to broaden its application against union activities. In addition, during 1980, section 45E was introduced into the Trade Practices Act. Section 45D commonly operates to prohibit boycott situations arising from a refusal by employees to handle goods intended for a third party for the purpose of pressuring the third party to accede to certain demands. Section 45E supplements that provision by prohibiting contracts, arrangements or understandings between a union and another person to prevent or hinder the supply of goods or services to, or their acquisition from, a third party.

Sections 45D and 45E have been the subject of considerable controversy since their introduction. The essential concern of the trade practices legislation is to promote fair trading and free competition. On the other hand, the real purpose of sections 45D and 45E is to prohibit union activity which usually has little or no detrimental effect on competition or fair trading. In the context of legislation dealing with trade practices matters, the sections provide unrealistic sanctions to be applied against unions in relation to their industrial activities.

The principal objective of any regulation in the area of secondary boycotts must be the speedy, fair and effective resolution of the underlying dispute. This is not achieved by the legislative prohibition of secondary boycott activity. Indeed, provisions such as sections 45D and 45E may only serve to exacerbate a dispute and resort to them may result in a worsened industrial relations climate not only between the parties, but in the relevant industry as a whole The special characteristics of industry disputes demand that they be handled by expert bodies under our industrial machinery rather than under trade practices legislation which is not designed to resolve the underlying issues which give rise to the boycott activity.

Action under the Trade Practices Act in respect of secondary boycott disputes is neither the most appropriate course for resolution of the dispute nor necessarily a particularly quick or effective course of action. In some cases the issuing of injunctions under the Trade Practices Act has even exacerbated disputes.

In 1984, the Hawke Government moved to change the arrangements to deal with secondary boycotts, through the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1984 and the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984. The intention was to repeal sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and to replace them with a more effective mechanism for dealing with secondary boycotts under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
At the time, Senator Button, introducing the Bills into the Senate said:

The Government's position is absolutely plain—the Government does not, in any way, condone the industrial tactic of a secondary boycott. However, the Government does not believe that such action is so different in nature to other forms of union and employee action in support of their industrial claims that it should be singled out to be dealt with under the Trade Practices Act, rather than through the established industrial channels.

The Government is concerned about the possible effect of the remedies of penalties and damages which are available under the Trade Practices Act for contraventions of Sections 45D and 45E. These are potentially highly disruptive to Australia's industrial relations. Their application, where boycotts occur, is unlikely to lead to the effective or satisfactory resolution of a dispute.

Following our repeal of these Sections, the Government is not proposing to leave a void in the handling of such disputes. Let no-one underestimate our concern at the impact of these disputes. What the Government is proposing is an alternative mechanism whereby such disputes can be dealt with, in the first instance, through the established industrial relations machinery. Such a course of action will ensure that boycott matters are dealt with effectively and speedily through the tribunal best qualified to deal with them.

Accordingly, the Government proposes that, upon the repeal of Sections 45D and 45E, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be able to deal with such disputes where a federally registered union or its members, or work under a federal award is involved. We believe this should also apply where these boycott disputes do not concern strictly industrial issues. The Commission should be able to bring the parties together to see if they can settle their differences.

We propose to allow the Commission to conciliate in relation to these disputes. This is similar to what exists at the moment, but with a significant improvement. Instead of the delays under the present arrangements which require the initiation of Federal Court proceedings under Section 45D or 45E, anyone involved in or affected by a boycott dispute will be able to notify the Commission immediately, and the Commission will also be able to act of its own motion. These matters should be dealt with as quickly as possible by the Commission and provision is to be made to ensure that this will be done.

The legislation will enable the Commission to deal with boycott disputes in relation to both industrial matters and non-industrial issues. Industrial matters will be the same as those which the Commission can deal with in its normal jurisdiction except that they will not require a particular employment relationship. Security of employment which sometimes gives rise to boycott disputes will be included as an industrial matter for the purposes of the Commission's jurisdiction under this legislation.

We do not believe that the Commission should be asked to deal with boycott disputes over non-industrial issues if it cannot play any useful part in their resolution. Provision will therefore be made to require the Commission to make a threshold judgement as to whether it will be able to resolve the dispute or bring about an end to the industrial action. It may be unrealistic, for example, to expect the Commission to play a role in overcoming a boycott which has an explicitly political basis, such as a ban in protest against aspects of Government policy.
I have quoted extensively from Senator Button's 1984 speech because this Bill is written in exactly the same terms and is put forward for the same reasons.
The only variation arises from the fact that the amendments are now to the Trade Practices Act and the Industrial Relations Act which has replaced the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
The views expressed by the Government in 1984 are widely shared.
ACTU policy states:
Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act prohibit a wide range of legitimate industrial action by unions, members and officials. They should be repealed at the earliest possible opportunity.

The Trade Practices Act is a totally unacceptable vehicle through which to attempt to regulate the legitimate industrial activities of trade unions. The Act should be used only for promoting free competition and fair trading by business enterprises.

The Section 45D actions that have been taken against unions clearly demonstrate that the Trade Practices Act is not merely useless in settling industrial disputes but is positively harmful. The special characteristics of industrial disputes demand that they be dealt with under industrial legislation and not by recourse to the Trade Practices Act.

The so-called conciliation procedures provided under the Industrial Relations Act in respect of Section 45D and 45E disputes are a sham. They are intended merely to facilitate the enforcement of those sections and do not provide a genuine opportunity for the industrial relations merits of a dispute to be examined and an acceptable resolution sought.
The ILO in a Direct Request to the Australian Government in 1991, relating to Convention No. 87, Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, has had this to say:

In its 1989 direct request the Committee noted that Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act 1974, rendered unlawful a wide range of boycott activity and most, if not all, sympathy action. The Committee considers that both of these forms of industrial action should be permissible in certain circumstances. For example, it should be possible to impose boycotts in relation to health and safety disputes on construction sites where there are several different employers. It should be permissible for workers to have recourse to sympathetic action where the initial strike in respect of which such action is taken is itself a legitimate exercise of the right to strike. These considerations led the Committee to ask the Government to provide information as to the practical application of Section 45D and its associated provisions, and to indicate whether it had any plans to amend the 1974 Act so as to bring it into conformity with the requirements of the Convention.

The Committee remains of the view that Section 45D and its associated provisions render unlawful certain forms of industrial action which ought to be permissible. Accordingly, it calls upon the Government again to take steps to bring this legislation into full conformity with the requirements of the Convention.
The Trade Practices Commission itself, in its fourth Annual Report (1978) said:

The Commission would propose to limit court proceedings it might bring to cases affecting competition . . . because it is probably more appropriate that the right of private action or the Minister's right to bring proceedings should be exercised in cases not affecting competition. The Commission is a competition authority and it would seem desirable to avoid, where competition is not affected, getting involved in industrial disputes where the ultimate decisions as to the continuing or settling cases may need to be taken by companies on commercial grounds or the government on political grounds.

When first requested by the ILO to deal with the problem it saw posed by sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, the Government responded by pointing out that its attempt to repeal the provisions in 1984 was defeated in the Senate where the Government did not have control. It also cited `strenuous opposition' by major employer groups and the Parliamentary Opposition.

At this point, late in 1992, the Government faces an entirely different situation. Because of a change in the policy of the Australian Democrats, the Government will now have no difficulty in gaining passage of repeal measures through the Senate. Another change is the distinctly turbulent industrial relations climate with the advent of conservative State Governments—especially the Kennett Government in Victoria—and the strong promotion of similar highly deregulated industrial relations policies by the Federal coalition. In this climate, it is surely more vital than ever that appropriate secondary boycott provisions are in place.

A further and very recent disturbing element is a decision in Western Australia against the BLF in which a ruling was given that the union had acted against section 45D in mounting a picket—in spite of that picket being entirely peaceful and that the union had instructed the union officials not to stop anyone from crossing the picket nor direct or request anyone not to cross.
In its conclusion the court said:

Contemporary usage of the term picket does carry implications of direction and threat of sanction to those who seek to enter a site or premises the subject of the picket. While the threat of sanction remains albeit unspoken the possibility of characterising the use of the picket as hindering or preventing of supply is also present.
Surely this judgement effectively denies the right to peacefully picket. Such a situation must not be tolerated.
In his conclusion to the debate in the Hawke Government amendments in 1984, Senator Button said:

The place for dealing with industrial disputes is not in the hands of the Trade Practices Commission. We have said that on numerous occasions and we will say it again in the course of dealing with this legislation. It is a matter which was in the Labor platform well before we came to Government. It has been a consistent position.
The consistency was not evident when, on 15 December 1992, I put the provisions of this Bill as amendments to an Industrial Relations Bill in the Senate and the Government failed to support them.

Instead the Government referred the amendments to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training inquiry on the effect of the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974 on industrial relations in Australia. That inquiry was set up on 12 October 1992 on a motion of the Australian Democrats and has a reporting date of 31 May 1993.

Hence, we have the current situation in which the Australian Democrats, a party with a policy to repeal sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, provided for the ALP Government, also with a policy of repeal, a vehicle which has been used by the Government to avoid the opportunity provided by my amendments to enact that very policy.
Also in his concluding speech in 1984, Senator Button claimed a `fundamental difference of attitude to the way in which industrial relations in this country should be handled'.

Given the Government's failure to repeal sections 45D and 45E on 16 December 1992, and the Democrats' provision of the escape route for the Government on that occasion, it is difficult to see that difference between any of the parties on this question.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Motion (by Senator McMullan, on behalf of Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1992 will amend the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. The Bill contains amendments to the Act to give effect to recommendations of the Report of the Review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill will also amend the Act to provide for mediation and to provide that documents may be lodged by electronic means.

The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature and makes minor technical amendments to the Act. None of the amendments concern major policy proposals or sensitive policy issues. They are explained in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the Bill.
It is expected that the proposed amendments will not have any financial impact.

In January 1990 the Act was amended, by the Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Act 1989, to provide that the President of the Tribunal is responsible for managing the administrative affairs of the Tribunal. Similar amendments were made to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 and the Family Law Act 1975 to provide that the Chief Justices of the Federal and Family Courts are responsible for the administrative affairs of their respective courts. The process by which the heads of jurisdiction are responsible for the administration of a court or tribunal is known as separate administration.

Following the commencement of separate administration it was agreed that the operations of the Tribunal should be reviewed to assess the delivery of services by the Tribunal and the effectiveness and efficiency of the Tribunal's existing administrative operational arrangements and structures. The Review was conducted by representatives of the Tribunal, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance. Similar reviews were undertaken in the Federal Court of Australia and the Family Court of Australia.

The Review was deferred until the new President, the Hon Justice O'Connor, had the opportunity of familiarising herself with the operations of the Tribunal. Justice O'Connor was appointed as President in June 1990 following the death of the former President, the Hon Mr Justice Hartigan.

The Review was undertaken between October 1990 and November 1991. The Report of the Review made some 200 recommendations for reform. Many of those recommendations related to the internal operation of the Tribunal and have been implemented by the President of the Tribunal. The review also made a number of recommendations for amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act.

The proposed amendments are directed at streamlining the procedures of the Tribunal and clarifying the powers of the Tribunal in procedural matters. The amendments will enable the Tribunal to operate more flexibly and will assist the Tribunal to achieve maximum efficiency.

The amendments to section 20 of the Act will provide a clearer statement of the President's role and functions in relation to the arrangement of business of the Tribunal and will provide that the President may give directions as to the procedures to be followed generally in proceeding in the Tribunal and in particular to enable directions that members shall sit at particular places.

At present, subject to any provision to the contrary contained in an enactment conferring jurisdiction on the Tribunal, the Tribunal may be constituted in any one of the 5 ways as listed in section 21. Clause 6 will amend section 21 to provide for 2 additional combination of members, 3 Deputy Presidents or 2 Deputy Presidents and a non-presidential member. This will give the President greater flexibility in constituting the Tribunal in important or complex cases.

Section 29 of the Act specifies the manner of applying for a review. Clause 9 will amend section 29 to provide for an address for service where an applicant has failed to provide an address for service in the application. This will ensure that the processing of such applications is not unduly delayed by uncertainty as to the appropriate address for service.

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in Angus Fire Armour Pty Ltd v Collector of Customs (1988) 83 ALR 449 the Court held that, on the proper construction of section 29, an application to the Tribunal for a review of a decision is validly lodged notwithstanding the failure of the applicant to pay the application fee prescribed by the Regulations. In these circumstances, although the application would be deemed to be validly lodged, there would be no obligation on the Tribunal to process the application. Clause 10 will insert new section 29A which provides that an application is not taken to be lodged unless the prescribed fee has been paid.

The Tribunal currently makes extensive use of directions hearings. Section 33 of the Act provides for the procedure to be followed by the Tribunal. Clause 11 will amend section 33 to give formal recognition to directions hearings and to provide that a member convening a directions hearing may give such directions as are considered necessary, at any time in relation to any procedural matter, whether or not the President has expressly authorised the person to give directions.

Section 34 of the Act provides for conferences to be held. The Tribunal has developed the practice of convening preliminary conferences to determine the matters in issue prior to the hearing. As a significant proportion of cases are resolved at the preliminary conference this practice has proved an effective means of dealing with the workload of the Tribunal. Clause 12 will amend section 34 by giving the President a discretion to determine whether or not a conference should be held. It will also amend subsection 34(1) by deleting the reference to consideration of the material lodged so that the President may direct the holding of a conference without doing so. These amendments should further enhance the use of preliminary conferences.

Subsection 34(2) provides that where the parties reach an agreement at a preliminary conference, the Tribunal must, subject to certain procedural requirements, make a decision in accordance with the terms of that agreement. The Bill inserts new section 42C which will replace subsection 34(2). This section gives the Tribunal a discretion to decline to make a decision in terms of the agreement if it appears to the Tribunal that it is appropriate to do so.

This discretion is consistent with the role of the Tribunal to review decisions on their merits and to substitute its decision for that of the decision maker. In making a decision the Tribunal, in effect, stands in the shoes of the decision maker. It is inconsistent with the role of the Tribunal to require it to make a decision adopting the terms of an agreement between the parties where it considers that, in the circumstances of the case, the agreement would not result in the correct or preferable decision being made.

In 1991 the Tribunal began to consider the introduction of mediation as an alternative dispute resolution mechanism. A feasibility study recommended that participation should be voluntary, that mediation should be confidential, that cases should be selected on the basis of their suitability for mediation, that mediation should be conducted by suitably trained and accredited mediators and that there should be on-going evaluation of the mediation process.

A pilot program was introduced in September 1991 and has been extensively evaluated. The result of the evaluation is that the Tribunal has extended the scope of the program. Further extension of the program is expected following further evaluation.

In mediation, a neutral third person assists the parties to arrive at their own solution to their dispute. The essence of mediation is that the parties are empowered to produce the result that is best suited to their own circumstances. In the Tribunal, mediation provides an efficient and cost effective method for the resolution of many disputes.

The Government supports the availability of a greater choice of methods of dispute resolution and to this end has already provided the legislative framework for mediation and arbitration to be provided in the Federal Court and in the Family Court. The Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Act 1991 amended the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 to provide a framework for those courts to develop alternative forms of dispute resolution, in particular mediation and arbitration. The Act amended the Family Law Act and the Federal Court Act to allow those courts to refer suitable matters to mediation and arbitration and to make rules of court defining the procedure to be followed.
This Bill provides a similar legislative framework to facilitate the use of mediation in the Tribunal.

The Tribunal actively encourages the use of mediation. However, it recognises that not all cases are suitable for mediation, such as those where the matter in dispute is of sufficient public importance for a decision to be made by the Tribunal on the merits of the case, or where there is a degree of animosity between the parties which would inhibit the mediation process. The Tribunal has developed procedures to ensure that only suitable matters are referred for mediation. Mediations are conducted only by members or staff who have been accredited as mediators.

The Tribunal has made extensive use of the telephone for hearings, parts of hearings and for conferences. Clause 15 of the Bill will insert section 35A which expressly provides that the Tribunal may allow a person to participate in proceedings by telephone, closed circuit television and any other means of communication. This provision will also allow persons to participate by means of video conference.

Clause 18 of the Bill will amend section 42A to expand the Tribunal's powers to dismiss applications. The new powers to dismiss matters include the power to dismiss matters for delay in pursuing the application, where there is no reviewable decision, and for failure to appear at a directions hearing or mediation. Section 42A will also expressly provide where a matter has been dismissed the applicant may apply for a reinstatement.

At present there is no power for the Tribunal to dismiss an application that is frivolous or vexatious. Such matters, although few in number, are very resource intensive and divert resources away from legitimate applications. The new dismissal powers will also include the power to dismiss an application which is frivolous or vexatious.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
