DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the management and operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, together with the 15 volumes of the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have my tabling statement incorporated in Hansard and to continue my remarks at a later hour of this day.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The report I have just tabled follows an inquiry which actively occupied the Committee for about twelve months. It is the result of a reference supported by a majority in the Senate for reasons set out at the beginning of the report. There had been significant problems and controversies within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in recent years and some senators wished to satisfy themselves that necessary corrective action had been taken. They felt that the normal Senate procedures for the scrutiny of estimates and annual reports did not provide sufficient opportunity to do that.

The inquiry therefore was essentially reactive. The Committee provided opportunities for critics of DFAT, both internal and external, to put their cases and for the Department to respond. As a result, this document does not purport to be a complete review of the management and operations of the Department. Rather, it describes the Committee's review of and conclusions on the particular matters raised with it by various interested parties.

I wish to stress that, wherever possible, the Committee sought empirical evidence on the issues raised with it rather than opinions, anecdotes or gossip. In many cases the criticisms of the Department's performance shrank in scope and significance when confronted with that approach.
The general conclusion to the report, which the Deputy Chair of the Committee, Senator Watson, and I prepared jointly late last week, points to three broad themes in the Committee's conclusions.

The first is that there has been extensive and rapid change in DFAT in recent years. This is clearly part of the explanation for the apparently high level of complaints and disputation during that period. Aspects of DFAT's management of change can be criticised. Many of the Committee's specific criticisms are of this type. But it is clear that the changes have been large and rapid and DFAT must be given credit for the progress it has made.

The second broad theme of the report is that the changes should not be reversed. The Committee concluded that, as well as facing the effects of the major general public service changes of recent years, DFAT has also moved from a reliance on personal relationships in many of its management systems towards more formal managerial systems. The former Secretary to the Department, Richard Woolcott, told the Committee that the Department he had joined in 1950 had been more like an extended family than a department of state. It was clear to the Committee that the paternalistic management style of the old Department of Foreign Affairs still has its supporters. It was equally clear that the day for that management style has passed.

The third broad theme of the report is that the most serious faults that DFAT's critics were able to expose to this independent external review were relatively minor. The Committee's recommendations relate mainly to housekeeping matters. Its criticisms of DFAT do not go to any major aspect of the department's management and operations.

It is true that further publicity was given to past failings, including some from the recent past. Other failings were exposed for the first time but many of these also had occurred under management systems which have since been reformed. Evidence of current or continuing problems was less prominent.

The Committee noted that the incidence of management failure in DFAT described in the report should remind the Department not to be complacent. DFAT should continue to make rigorous efforts to improve its administration and should be continually alert to areas of potential regression or management failure. Nevertheless, the report should not be interpreted as being severely critical of DFAT.

There are thirty-three specific recommendations in the report. Many, as I have already noted, relate to minor administrative matters. However, I will comment briefly on some of the more significant recommendations.

The Committee devoted a considerable amount of time and effort to investigating a large number of claims made by a small group of former and current officers of DFAT who called themselves the DFAT Reform Group. Many of these claims had been made previously and investigated by DFAT, the Auditor-General and the Australian Federal Police. As had been the case in the previous investigations, the Committee found little of substance in the Reform Group claims and has recommended that no Commonwealth investigative or administrative review agency inquire into any further allegations from this source unless and until substantive evidence is provided to support the allegations.

The Committee heard extensive argument about what has clearly been an unhappy amalgamation of the former Promotion Australia into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Committee concluded that much of the problem stems from a lack of clarity in the objectives in Australia's overseas public relations activities. The Committee has recommended that the objectives be clarified and that, if the Government decides to retain a specialist public relations capacity within DFAT, it do so in such a way as to maintain a viable core of specialisation within a single branch.

The difficulties sometimes associated with overseas service were brought home to the Committee by several graphic examples. The report contains a recommendation that DFAT consolidate its staff welfare initiatives into a separate sub-program directly answerable to the appropriate Deputy Secretary position.

Many of the Committee's recommendations and a large part of the report are related to conditions of service issues. One important recommendation in this area is a proposal that responsibility for the setting and administration of overseas conditions of service be transferred from the Department of Industrial Relations to an independent body within the Industrial Relations portfolio but comprising members drawn from the overseas operating agencies, the Department of Finance and the Department of Industrial Relations. This should have the effect of removing some delays in the consideration of conditions of service issues, especially those relating to individual cases, and of incorporating a greater degree of first hand experience of overseas service in the decision-making process.

The Committee has also recommended that the Government expedite consideration of and action on a range of specific measures to alleviate the real and increasing problems faced by foreign service spouses.

The Committee noted that DFAT has made recent improvements to its system of administering representation funding. The Committee has recommended that the possibility of further reforms be reviewed jointly by DFAT and the Department of Finance. The aim should be to replace as large a proportion as possible of the present representation advances with direct payments or with reimbursement of expenses as they occur.

The opportunity to profit through the purchase of cars free of duty has led to some notable scandals in Australia's diplomatic service. The Committee has recommended that Australian Government officers and their dependants overseas be prevented from purchasing cars duty-free but be permitted to lease cars from the Australian Government or to have access to government cars for private use subject to a contribution towards the cost of that use.

Recent developments in DFAT have highlighted anomalies in the public service disciplinary provisions as they apply to heads of mission. The Committee has recommended that the Public Service Act be amended to ensure that the standard public service disciplinary procedures apply to heads of diplomatic missions and posts. The Committee has also recommended that public service disciplinary proceedings be public at least to the extent of the fact that charges have been laid, their nature and the outcome.

The Committee has acknowledged the additional workload that this inquiry has placed on DFAT. However, it believes that the inquiry acted as a catalyst for the reaching of satisfactory outcomes to some issues facing the Department and brought other matters of concern to light. Other issues placed on the agenda by the recommendations in the report are also worthy of attention.

It would be unfortunate if the cumulative effect of descriptions of minor faults that make up a large part of the report were to produce an excessively adverse impression. The Committee in fact received laudatory comments on DFAT from many organisations that deal with the Department and received no complaints about the efficiency, effectiveness and integrity of most areas of its operations.

In previous reports, the Committee has commented favourably on the general high standard of the Australian Public service. Nothing that it has seen of the management and operations of DFAT in this inquiry has caused it to doubt the general validity of that position.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on lot feeding in Australia, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Beef cattle feedlots are one of the fastest growing of all agricultural industries. The industry represents a significant value adding process for livestock, and in 1992 gross value of production is estimated at over $800m, with 70 per cent of production destined for overseas markets. The industry makes a notable contribution to Australia's export performance and there is also strong evidence indicating that feedlots confer economic benefits on other Australian industries, particularly the grains industry, and to rural and regional affairs.

PARA.TAB: This industry, however, cannot be assessed merely on its economic contribution. Feedlots are intensive production systems involving as many as 30,000 head of cattle confined in pens and fed a grain based diet for 70 to 300 days. As intensive animal production systems, feedlots have the potential to cause significant environmental and animal welfare problems; and it is on this basis that the Committee considers that feedlots must be properly regulated, ecologically sustainable, and sensitive and responsive to Committee concerns.

The report that I have just tabled contains 27 recommendations or major conclusions on how these objectives might be achieved. They cover the regulations and controls relating to the establishment and management of feedlots, their economic, social and environmental impact, and implications for animal welfare.

Today I would like to address five major issues raised in the report. First, it should be recognised that feedlotting is a relatively new practice in Australia and one that is growing. In 1984, there were about 24,000 cattle in feedlots. In May 1992, there were approximately 325,000 cattle in feedlots with capacities greater than 500 head. It has been estimated that half as many cattle again were in smaller feedlots, including opportunity feedlots.

As a result of this rapid growth, the Committee was told that the Commonwealth, State and local government authorities have been left behind in their role of developing appropriate laws and regulations for feedlots. The Committee is pleased to note that recently Commonwealth and State governments have begun to address this problem by the development and the publication of the national guidelines for beef cattle feedlots in Australia.

The guidelines provide a framework in which State and Territory governments can develop detailed legislative arrangements for the control of feedlots, thereby safeguarding their environment, the local and wider community and the welfare of the animals themselves. The Committee encourages State and Territory governments to introduce proper controls for the establishment and the management of feedlots.

In reviewing the current situation, the Committee found that some States had developed comprehensive controls that are contained in specific legislation which provides a clear and consistent framework in which the industry should operate. In other States, a one-stop shop has not been developed and six or seven State government departments and five or more Acts of Parliament may be relevant to the establishment and operation of a feedlot. Given that the feedlot industry is expanding, the Committee reached the conclusion that the States should develop specific and comprehensive legislation for those feedlots.

The second matter I wish to address also relates to differing approaches between the States to feedlots. During the inquiry the Committee heard that in New South Wales regulations governing feedlots apply to operations of 400 head or more, while in Queensland the figure is 50 head; and in the other States no capacity limit is applied. The Committee considers that this lack of uniformity is unsatisfactory and that a uniform definition based on 50 head or more should be adopted by all States and Territories. This approach would not only achieve consistency but also extend control to smaller feedlots. This is important, as the Committee was told that the cumulative effect of many small scale feedlots that are unregulated could be much greater than that of some large scale feedlots that are well regulated.

The third matter I wish to raise relates to the environment. When it is realised that one 450-kilogram steer produces about 29 kilograms of wet manure and urine per day, the potential for feedlots, small or large, to have an adverse environmental effect becomes apparent. In this regard, the Committee notes a recent report entitled An investigation of nutrient pollution in the Murray-Darling Basin river system, which found that nutrient balances in the basin river system provided no obvious indication of any substantial pollution from feedlots. However, the Committee also notes that the report recognised that this finding was based on very limited and inconclusive data.

The Committee received several submissions raising concerns about the welfare of animals in feedlots. For example, the Australian and New Zealand Federation of Animal Societies told the Committee that its feedlots are unnatural, the close confinement of cattle results in physical and behavioural problems and they should be banned. The RSPCA Australia does not object to feedlots, but is opposed to the confinement of animals in circumstances that unreasonably restrict their movements and normal behavioural patterns. The Society is adamant that beef cattle feedlots should be thoroughly regulated and licensed.

The Committee rejects the view that feedlots should be prohibited and recognises them as a legitimate husbandry tool. This conclusion, however, is qualified by the need for high standards to be applied to all facets of feedlot operations in order to ensure the health and welfare of cattle. In response to the need for these high standards, the Committee's report addresses and makes recommendations on several issues including heat stress, the provision of shade and shelter, the use of chicken litter as feed, the size of pens and veterinary supervision.

Finally, throughout this report the Committee recognises that the proper siting and management of feedlots is fundamental, not only to the long term success of the industry but also to the public's confidence in the industry. The Committee's report acknowledges that the industry is making its concerted effort to improve the industry's standing and standards by its participation in the formulation of the national guidelines and its support for Ausmeat feedlot accreditation schemes. The Committee supports these initiatives but is of the view that the credibility of this industry would be enhanced if every feedlot proved itself to be a responsible corporate citizen in the management of a human food resource and the environment. I commend the Committee's report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I would like to say that I believe this report, Beef cattle feedlots in Australia, is an impressive and authoritative document because it is very timely in its delivery. I think it is solid in its content and I think it is commendable for the speed with which our Committee has produced it. It is just over 12 months ago that we got the reference for this inquiry, and we have had some 89 public hearings, 44 witnesses and various inspections. A lot of the credit for the speed and thoroughness of this inquiry must go to the secretariat staff, who would have been amongst the busiest in this Parliament, if not the busiest. This year we have had something in the order of 92 meetings and we have held inquiries in just about every State, including sitting on weekends which we did the weekend before last in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: If the Federal Government uses the report, it should and can provide a cohesive blueprint for any industry like the feedlot industry that is essential for the future prosperity of our rural industries and commodities. We accept that it is difficult to provide national guidelines given the varying climate and geographic variances, however, it can provide a more comprehensive approach to the feedlot industry.

The value of feedlots cannot be disputed. That has already been mentioned by the Chairman of the Committee and that has to be taken into consideration when examining the industry. The industry, of course, is a significant value adding process for livestock. It had a gross value of production in 1992 estimated at $800m, with over 70 per cent of that production destined for overseas markets. I am quite sure even the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, would agree that that overseas income is very necessary and would be welcomed in the budget of any country.

However, being mindful of the terms of reference, we also examined critically the environmental and animal welfare aspects of the industry. The terms of reference specified that the Committee inquire into the regulations and controls relating to the establishment and management of feedlots; the economic, social and environmental impact of feedlots; and the implications for animal welfare. I believe that we achieved a lot in those areas. In moving through the recommendations briefly, I should highlight some of the more significant ones. It is important to realise the extent of the feedlot industry in its rapid development since it began in the early 1970s. I think that a little of the criticism of the feedlot industry has been due to the fact that some of the feedlots that were set up many years ago do not quite have the standards that are required for feedlots being built at the moment.

Grain feeding of beef started at that stage during a major drought. It was really a backstop feedlot industry that started off here in Australia. But the capacity of our feedlots and the turn-off from our feedlots have grown dramatically from 200,000 head in 1975 to a current annual turn-off of 700,000 to 800,000 and a predicted turn-off in 1995 of something like 1.1 million cattle. It should be remembered that 70 per cent of those cattle are being exported, and that is very important if we want to keep the industry running in a proper and efficient manner.

Because of the size of the industry and its rapid growth, national guidelines need to be established. They are more a framework for the industry, but I think some witnesses expressed the view that they needed legislative teeth. Our view on this matter and our recommendations were that the national guidelines for beef cattle feedlots in Australia should provide a useful framework against which State and Territory governments can operate and develop detailed legislative and administrative arrangements. We considered that the proper siting and sound management of feedlots were fundamental in achieving a responsible feedlot industry. I think that is well understood by people in the industry at the moment.

Some people were concerned about what happens with the amount of foreign investment in the Australian industry. We noted the concerns of the Cattle Council of Australia about the increase in the investment threshold from $3m to $50m and associated monitoring procedures of the Foreign Investment Review Board. We said that we welcome the advice of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that, as well as commenting on foreign investment proposals of over $50m, the Department is also notified of proposals over $3m to enable it to monitor the level of foreign investment in the meat and livestock industry and in the individual enterprises. That being the case, it does keep some control. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, being the Chairman of the Committee, that was an area of concern.

Obviously, in that area, the problem for a lot of people was getting the markets at the other end, and some of the foreign investment did help in getting those markets. That is something that needs to be looked at in the future. I think that Australia needs to get out and trade a bit more on its own. If it can do so, that will be of benefit to Australia as well.

As far as management and training are concerned, we believe that the larger feedlots were definitely professionally managed. Their level of husbandry and stockmanship was of an excellent standard. I think it would pass the utmost scrutiny of anyone with reservations about the industry. They have to have good management and good husbandry to be successful. I do not think that the same could be said for all the smaller feedlots, some of which were set up many years ago. They will continue to be a source of concern while they are outside regulatory control.

There were a lot of differing views concerning shade, and we commend the people who are doing trials on shade. The behavioural problems of beef cattle in feedlots and problems associated with excessive heat in Queensland areas really need to be looked at, and will be looked at in the future. The Chairman of the Committee has already mentioned environmental aspects. There are a lot of liquid wastes from feedlots, including urine, wash waters and run-off during rainfall, et cetera, and that is an area that has to be looked at. But properly sited and properly run feedlots are something that Australia needs. They will be of great benefit to Australian primary industries in the future and for our export income. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to compliment the staff of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on the amount of work they have put in at the meetings we have had in 1992; they had a huge workload. I particularly compliment you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and the Deputy Chairman of that Committee for the amount of time you both have put into this report.

PARA.TAB: Having been a member of the former committee on animal welfare, I have never ceased to be amazed by the dogged determination of these animal liberationists. In this particular case we had reports given to us about why they were against lot feeding. We would pick up the paper the next day and see they were against intensive piggeries. The next day one would see that they were against intensive poultry production. In fact, they were against just about anything to do with animal husbandry in this country. We have to try to get a balance in Australia about our livestock production. In this inquiry plenty of evidence was given to us about the importance of beef production and, in particular, the huge increase in the amount of export beef through the lot feeding systems in Australia and the amount of money they bring in as valuable foreign exchange. So we have to keep things in perspective. This particular report strikes a very good balance, and the recommendations and guidelines strike a very important balance between industry expectations, the environment and animal welfare problems.

At a recent inquiry we were looking at youth unemployment. I have to say that some of the conditions and some of the pressures on young people are far greater than those on some of the cattle we saw in lot feeding. At least the cattle and pigs have a guaranteed amount of feed every day, which is more than can be said for some of the young unemployed people, people who are out of work and homeless youth around Australia. Perhaps members of the animal liberation movement could divert their attention to spending their energies on looking after some of the less advantaged of the human species in our nation at present. We can do without some of the extravagances of the radical animal liberation movement in Australia. I think we have to be a little more practical. It is a very comprehensive report and I commend all those who were involved with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like also to make some brief comments in terms of—
—There are no such things as brief comments from you.
—At least I can give a straight answer to a straight question. That is more than the Minister can do.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Call the Minister to order. I got on my feet and before I even said anything he was interrupting.
—Order! Senator Crane, I did call `Order!', and that means everyone.

—I would also like to make some brief comments. In terms of the importance of this report, I regret there is not more time available. I want to join with all other members of the Committee who, I understand, thanked and congratulated the people involved, particularly Neil Bessell and company.

PARA.TAB: This report, I think, is a very important document in pulling together a value added component of an industry which is going to grow significantly in Australia over the next few years. Not only will it be a model in pulling together the information for beef cattle feedlots; it also has an enormous amount of information, in terms of livestock in general, which will set, if you like, the principles for guidelines that are required for an industry such as this. We have also seen that the product that comes from feedlots is significantly more valuable to the Australian community than cattle that are run on grass and farmed in the traditional manner.
I am not going to go into a lot of the detail of the report, because that is there for everybody to read, but I would just like to refer to page 15. One of the conclusions there says:
On the basis of evidence presented during the inquiry, the Committee considers that the beef cattle feedlot sector is a growing and increasingly important part of the Australian beef industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It then goes into estimates of the value, and the fact that 70 per cent of production is destined for overseas markets. Of course, in our current position with our current account deficit, that is very important. I think this report should give encouragement not only to those people involved in the beef industry but also to other industries that are looking at going at least into first stage value adding. That is the real significance and importance of this report.

PARA.TAB: The other point that I would like to make concerns the animal welfare situation and how cattle, in particular, handle feedlots. Of course, that extends into other livestock as well. There has been much criticism but, provided the feedlots are up to the required standards, and given the choice, the animals themselves will always come to the troughs and eat the feed that is placed in them by whoever is running the feedlot. I saw that happen myself during the drought which we experienced a couple of years ago. We were feeding stock not for the purpose of on-selling them, but just for survival. But it is notable that even now, in very good seasonal conditions, those same stock, given the opportunity, will always get their feed from the feedlot troughs. A lot of propaganda has been put around about so-called stress on animals in these particular situations but, once that feed is put in the trough, the animals make a choice to walk out of a green paddock, with grass up to their knees, and eat what is provided to them.

Those are my comments at this stage on this report. I will just conclude by saying—as I said in my opening remarks—that this is a very important report in terms of setting the direction of, and pulling together the details we were able to collect for, that industry; and it will be beneficial, I believe, across the board for all value adding industries, particularly those in the first stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to endorse the comments that have been made about the level of work and the capacity of the staff of the secretariat of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. In carrying out the huge workload that was given to this Committee, the staff have been thoroughly competent in delivering a professional result.

PARA.TAB: As a member of the Committee I made some visits. I was not able to participate in all of the visits which took place, but in attending most of the visits which were conducted I was impressed by the professional attitude and the desire of the operators of some of the best feedlots to make their enterprise as effective and as efficient as possible. Regard was paid to the effect of the enterprise on the animals concerned, also to ensure that the effect on the surrounding countryside was as benign as possible. That applied to some operations, but we also observed some which could not be described in the preceding terms.

With regard to the terms of reference of the Committee, animal welfare considerations are instinctively brought into it because the arrangement by which the animals are kept cannot be described as a natural state of affairs. Instinctively, we ask if this is a desirable state of affairs, and that is where the difficulties begin. It is very difficult to assess an animal's appreciation of its status. It is impossible to deliver a questionnaire to the animals concerned. Although mention has been made already of a psychological analysis, it is pretty formidable to conduct a psychological analysis of the state of welfare of an animal.

It may appear that animals are not under stress if they are provided with feed and shade and reasonably comfortable conditions, but we know little of the opportunity of animals to follow their natural instincts when they are kept in conditions which are not natural. For example, the homogeneity of the age, and even the size, of the animals leads one to believe that the natural herding instincts of the cattle could not be pursued. The hierarchies of herds, the natural rhythm occurring in cattle herds, could not be applied there.

Of course, the question is: is any of this relevant? In measuring the actual health status of animals the Australian Veterinary Association, as stated in our report, considers that there are no veterinary or ethical problems associated with cattle being in reasonably close proximity in feedlots. Whatever parameters are used to consider whether the animal is in good health, whether it is diseased, whether it is short of feed or being fed the wrong food, those measurements can readily be made. But other measurements which may be necessary in the consideration of the full welfare of an animal cannot be made. The question of whether it is good for the animal's welfare is a question which is almost impossible to address.

It is not so with the question of the environmental impact of cattle feedlots. The intensive nature of such enterprises means that the effect is also intensive. That effect can be a huge and concentrated discharge of nutrients into our drainage systems. That effect can be direct pollution of the land or the water nearby. There can also be offensive smells generated, and all sorts of other offences. But it need not be so in a well planned and well administered feedlot. It is possible to arrange the drainage so that settling ponds and sedimentation are well catered for before there is any discharge into our drainage systems. It is possible to arrange drainage for the balance of water so that offensive smells are not generated. It is also possible regularly to clean and remove any surplus material from the site to a composting area where it is not generating offensive material. Whether that is done is another matter. The Committee found that in some instances the management of a site was such that there was little likelihood of pollutant material escaping. In other cases it was obvious that polluting material did escape the site and it had a huge effect on the surrounding countryside.

As has rightly been said earlier, the adoption of the national guidelines, which have already been prepared, will reduce the number of offensive sites, but the lack of coordination between national, State and local government means that this may take a lot longer than is desirable. I think that one of the most important things the Committee discovered was that the huge growth of the industry has meant that the regulating bodies are behind in being able to regulate the industry.

I am in a difficult situation. Instinctively, I feel that there is a lot wrong with herding cattle together in such a fashion. Most of my direct questions have been answered by the evidence we have collected, yet I still feel that it is not the right way to generate a profit. I agree that this is an industry that does generate considerable international monetary benefit for Australia, but there are lots of things that can be done to earn money and not all of them are right. Instinctively, I do not feel that this is right, even though the operators are doing their best to consider the welfare, as they determine it, of the animals involved.

The operators are doing their best not to have an adverse effect on the surrounding countryside, but I still feel that there is something wrong about it. Even though I am particularly partial to a decent steak, I would like to feel that my steak came from a well-fed angus standing in natural countryside. The cattle that are used in these sorts of enterprises may be contentedly standing about with expressions on their faces that we could interpret as meaning that they are not under stress but, instinctively, I do not feel that is so. However, we have in front of us a report that has attempted to address those problems. We have a report that has comprehensively examined the range of feedlots in Australia, and we have to acknowledge that attempts have been made. I endorse the report as it is. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 15 December.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 4, page 9, after the heading "Amendments of Schedule 4" insert the following amendment:
"1. Omit item 12, substitute:

PARA.TAB: `12Aids and appliances for people with disabilities, as prescribed by by-law—

TAB.TAB: Free'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that on Wednesday, 11 November 1992, I announced that the Government would provide concessional entry for imported baby marche shoes needed by children in their early years suffering from spina bifida. Today I am bringing forward this request for an amendment to the Bill to meet that commitment by modifying item 12 of part I of schedule 4 of the Customs Tariff Act 1987.

PARA.TAB: Currently, item 12 allows for the duty free importation of certain goods specially designed for the use of blind, deaf and dumb persons. The existing provisions will be amended by extending concessional entry to individuals with disabilities and to non-profit organisations that import such products but do not qualify for existing concessions. The guidelines for the operation of the new arrangements preclude the benefit extending to commercial operations, thereby retaining the intended scope of the government policy on concessions for the disabled. Details of the amendment have been included in a supplementary explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable senators.

I should add that this question of aids for the disabled was considered by the Industry Commission and somehow in the course of that consideration this issue was overlooked. It was drawn to my attention by Senator Herron and it is consequent upon his drawing the issue to our attention that this amendment is made. I commend the amendment to the Bill. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendment to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendment.

—The Australian Democrats strongly support this particular amendment which will make aids for disabled people cheaper. Over the years the Democrats have followed a policy of pressing for reductions in sales tax as well as tariffs for that particular purpose. I recall a successful amendment to remove customs tariffs from wheelchairs which I moved some 18 months ago and which the Government agreed to. The Australian Democrats fully support these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 together. Although they deal with slightly different subjects, the underlying principle is the same and it may be convenient to do so.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments to the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 9, page 3, line 6, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: 9.(1) All tariff classifications in Schedule 3 to the Principal Act where duty is ascertained by reference to Schedule 5, other than 0406.10.00, 0406.20.00, 0406.30.00, 0406.40.90, 0406.90.90 and classifications within Chapter 64 are amended by omitting all rates expressed to apply from a date.
(2) Schedule 3 of the Principal Act is further amended and Schedules 4 and 5 of that Act are amended as set out in Schedule 6.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule 6, proposed amendments of Schedule 3, pages 11 to 54, items 1 and 3 to 47, omit the items.
3.Schedule 6, page 58, proposed amendments of Schedule 5, omit the amendments, substitute the following amendments:

2.Omit items 21 and 22.".

SPEECH.PARA: When this matter was discussed during the debate on the second reading of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) pointed out that the reduction in employment and the high rate of bankruptcy in the TCF industries occurred some two or three years ago when the reduction in tariffs had only just begun and when the quantitative restrictions were still in place. That may be true, but people running businesses do anticipate the economic climate that they will have to face and, rather than wait to be made bankrupt, they make other arrangements. They move offshore—in other words, they export jobs—or they simply go out of business; they do not wait to be bankrupted by the Government's tariff reduction program. It is much more relevant to look—and I have put that on record before, too—at what is happening to the TCF industries. An industry which employed 120,000 people is now down to 76,000 in March 1992, and it anticipates that it will be down to 55,000 employees and probably fewer when the provisions of this Bill actually take effect.

PARA.TAB: Let me restate what this Bill proposes to do. It will remove all quantitative restrictions on TCF products, as well as putting in place the tariff reduction program that the Government has enunciated. It is the considered view of the industry that it will decimate what is left of that industry. I know that it has been argued that we cannot continue to make T-shirts when Chinese factories are able to pay less than $20 for a 48-hour week and when they do not have to cope with the sorts of environmental constraints, social constraints and work safety constraints that we impose on our manufacturers. The question arises: are we prepared to sink to their levels and are we prepared to throw on the scrap heap those people who are now currently in the industry?

The Minister cited the TCF Development Authority report in glowing terms, and I agree with him that a lot of worthwhile work is being done. However, there is no evidence that the people who are being retrenched in this industry are able to find alternative employment. The point was made by Mr Alan Trumble, the President of the TCF Council, that the majority of people working in the industry—and this is self-evident—are essentially semi-skilled, even unskilled, and very often have a poor command of English. It is, therefore, difficult for them to find other employment. We as a community have a choice: are we prepared to continue to pay a slightly higher price for TCF products that we purchase, or are we going to raise higher taxes to pay more unemployment benefits to pay people to do nothing, with all the destructive social consequences that this brings?

Mr Trumble also made a very telling point. He said that a lot of his work force and the work force of other people in other enterprises in the industry consist of migrants that have been brought to this country to do jobs that we Australians were not prepared to do, and are we now going to say to them, `You have done your job, we do not want you any more, we will throw you on the scrap heap'? It is for these reasons that I have moved these requested amendments, which will remove those provisions of the Bill which totally remove all quantitative restraints and which institute the tariff cutting program.

I should also stress—and it has been misrepresented to some extent by Senator Ferguson, speaking for the Opposition, and by the Minister—that we are not suggesting that we should have high tariff walls around Australia forever after. We appreciate that the industry must restructure, and that in time we must reduce manufacturing of products that can be done much more economically in other countries. What we are quarrelling with is the speed. What we are quarrelling with is the fact that it coincides with the current recession, which is deepening the economic problems of the industry and which is deepening the misery of the people concerned with it.

I believe it is a extremely insensitive step for the Government to implement at this point of time; and at this stage one might say that the only hope appears to be Dr Hewson, who on Friday is possibly going to reconsider the coalition's position on tariffs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the requested amendments put forward by Senator Spindler—but not because we do not have sympathy with the need for people to have occupations and so on. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) knows, I have had a very long and close association with the clothing, textile and footwear industries ever since I have been in this place, and I also know and respect Mr Trumble very much. But the plan is in progress and everybody understands where we are at. The comments of Senator Spindler do not take into account the fact that there are many successful businesses, as well as unsuccessful ones. They do not take into account the fact that the firms that have changed most have improved most and that there is still room for improvement in many areas.

PARA.TAB: I was somewhat surprised yesterday to receive a copy of the book put out by the Bonds company, in which Mr George Innes, whom I respect very greatly, quoted at great length a speech that I made in the Senate only a couple of years ago on the costs involved with industry in these areas, and the disadvantages that we suffer compared to some other countries. What it very much indicates is that we still have to get on with micro-economic change. We must get on and remove the obstacles that make it difficult. It is not just a matter of tariffs; it is not just a matter of the value of our currency; it is the whole package. What I refer to as the Spindler theory of certain demise cannot take over at this stage, because it will not produce the result that we all want to see: that is, a strong, vibrant and modern clothing, textile and footwear industry. We still can do this, but it is going to require to be brought forward, not by the textile industry and others on their own, but as part of an Australia wide package. All these businesses will then prosper and the people of Australia will prosper. But they will not prosper while ever we are fiddling around the edges trying to make exceptions. In this particular instance, the Opposition will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear the Government will not be supporting the amendment for reasons which I have indicated on a number of occasions. Senator Spindler and I have a different view about this matter and I just want to point to two things. Senator Spindler acknowledges that the large fall in employment in this industry took place before the effects of any new tariff reductions.
—But it is continuing, Minister.
—It is not. Look at the relative fall in employment. I do not know, perhaps the honourable senator does not accept the TCFDA report—
—But there are fewer people in it now, of course.

—Of course, exactly as there were following the 1983 recession. But its conclusions are that TCF employment declined by 11 per cent in 1990-91. Since this sharp drop, employment has continued to decline but at a much slower rate of just over 2 per cent. Now there are not many other industries which can point to those sorts of figures. I draw the attention of the honourable senator—as I have on numerous occasions—to the relatively low import ratio and the low export ratio of TCF products, compared with other industries. That is what restructuring in these industries is all about. I may sound brutal, but these arguments are always about these industries employing people who cannot get jobs in other industries because they are migrants, or because they are women. That is a terrible denigration of people who work in these industries.

PARA.TAB: We did a study at the time we came out of the 1983 recession and all these people got jobs in various other industries—with the hospitality industries, with cleaning and service firms of one kind or another—and that can happen again. It is a question of recovery in the Australian economy which will produce jobs. Senator Spindler keeps relying on Mr Alan Trumble, who has been the spokesman for these industries. In his own firm, Mr Alan Trumble is making investments, changing the product range he produces and employing more people.

Senator Spindler quotes Mr Trumble as saying that these things cannot happen. I do not know what he is on about. Senator Archer referred to Bonds. Bonds and Pacific Dunlop would not for a moment want a change in the program which has been announced. They are big employers in this industry. The Government does not accept this amendment for a variety of reasons which we have stated over time. I have just repeated some of those points, which seem to be facts which elude Senator Spindler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to make a couple of points that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) keeps misrepresenting. We want more time for the restructuring to be done—the restructuring that Mr Trumble and other manufacturers are doing. Unless we give them time, they simply will go to the wall and their people will be thrown out on the street. We are looking at a constructive way to do it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Archer's point that all industries must be treated the same is self-evidently false because all industries need specific treatment. We only have to look at the car industry plan, which is different from the TCF industry plan. We only need to look at the pharmaceutical industry, which needs different treatment from the dairy industry or the wheat industry. It is simply silly. To say that we must treat all of them in the same way is just ridiculous, and I think these facts should be taken into account.
Question put:
That the requests for amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to, subject to a request for an amendment.
