That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Corporate law reform has not been handled well in recent years. Since 1989 we have been faced with a series of Bills, all of them complex, most of them long, attempting to enact a national scheme of corporate regulation. We passed the Corporations Bill 1989, which contained almost 1,000 pages, and then the 300-page Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill, which was subsequently necessary when large parts of the former Act were found to be unconstitutional. The Bill implementing the Corporations Law was debated in the House of Representatives less than a week after its introduction in November 1990, with the guillotine allowing only 60 minutes of debate in total. It was then also guillotined through the Senate, with only an hour of debate after the second reading.

PARA.TAB: The Corporations Law has since been amended by the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1991, which was debated within a week of its introduction in 1991, with 40 minutes being allowed for debate. This was followed by the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which was guillotined after only 45 minutes of debate. The Corporations (Unlisted Property Trusts) Amendment Bill 1991 got just three minutes, and the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992 was also passed. Now we have another piece of legislation, a further 216 pages of so-called finetuning, and already the Corporate Law Reform Bill (No. 2) 1992 is on the table. So what we have had is a series of enormous Bills, debated inadequately under ridiculous time constraints, producing a highly complex and uncertain regulatory environment.

The Corporate Law Reform Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives last month and debated just one week later. The debate was guillotined again. This Bill also was dealt with for only 40 minutes in the House of Representatives. Only 40 minutes of debate were allowed for what was described by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) as `the most significant piece of legislation, in terms of Australia's corporate law, introduced in the life of this Parliament'. Under the time constraints that we have here today, it will not receive proper scrutiny in the Senate either. So the picture I paint in introducing the coalition's reaction to this legislation is one that is highly critical of the process of legislation in corporate law under this Government.

The Bill amends the Corporations Law and certain other legislation with respect to duties of officers of corporations, financial benefits to related parties of public companies, external administration of companies and the implementation of the clearing house subregister system. The amendments come about as a result of several reviews of the operations of the Corporations Law, notably the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the social and fiduciary duties and obligations of company directors—something to which I contributed some years ago; the Law Reform Commission's Report No. 45 on insolvency, otherwise known as the Harmer report; and the report on corporate financial transactions by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. It is a pity that after so much work through committee processes legislation receives so little proper scrutiny in the legislative chambers.

Let me deal firstly, however, with the director's duties part of the legislation. These amendments pick up some of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee I just mentioned. The duty of care currently required of company officers is, of course, set out in section 232(4) of the Corporations Law. It is an objective duty requiring an officer to exercise the degree of care and diligence that a reasonable person with that person's skills and knowledge would exercise.When the exposure draft of this Bill was released by the Attorney-General in February this year, it was proposed that that section be amended to provide a list of factors which a court would be required to take into account in determining whether a director had fulfilled his or her duties. The coalition and the business community strenuously objected to this approach, particularly in three respects.

Firstly, the objective standard of care to be imposed related to a director's knowledge, experience and competence. It was implied that a judge would not have to consider an individual director's circumstances when deciding whether he or she had fulfilled their duty of care. Effectively, this was an attempt to impose the same standard of skill for every director of every one of Australia's companies, which we regarded as a ludicrous proposal. The board should obviously comprise people with a range of skills and experience, and the level of skill required by a director of a major company may not be that which is required of a very small company.

Secondly, the listing of factors relevant to breach of duty really did not clarify what the content of the duty of care was supposed to be. Arguably, the list imposed substantive new duties on directors. There would have been pressure on directors to cover themselves with respect to every item on the checklist, which may well have distracted them from their duties as directors.

Thirdly, and most importantly, the proposed amendment did not introduce a business judgment rule; a proposal concerning which the coalition's enthusiastic report is shared by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. A business judgment rule, as developed in the United States, provides protection from prosecution for directors who make business judgments in good faith and with no personal interest in the transaction, and who have ensured that they are adequately informed about the subject of the decision.

The coalition welcomes the Minister's decision—as a result of comments received on the exposure draft of the Bill—to abandon the proposals for a checklist of factors and an objective standard of skill. The Bill as presently before us proposes instead to reword subsection 232(4) in order to confirm the present position, which is that a director is required to exercise the degree of care that a reasonable person would exercise.

The explanatory memorandum does state that it is up to the courts to develop an Australian equivalent of the business judgment rule; however, the coalition would have preferred that this Bill also introduce a statutory business judgment rule. The advantage of such a rule is that it provides certainty for directors. Corporate law should encourage, and afford broad protection to, informed business judgments in order to stimulate risk taking and innovation and to give directors the confidence to make commercial decisions on their true merits.

I move to the second part relating to civil penalty provisions. In relation to breaches of directors' duties, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended that criminal liability only apply where conduct is genuinely criminal in nature, and not where conduct is negligent. This Bill picks up that recommendation and decriminalises certain key directors' duties provisions including the duty to act honestly in subsection 232(2), the duty of care and diligence in subsection 232(4), and the duty not to make improper use of inside information in subsection 232(5). Breaches of these provisions will not attract criminal penalties unless they are committed with fraudulent or dishonest intent. Where a person contravenes one of these provisions a court will have the power to make a civil penalty order prohibiting the person from managing a corporation for a specified period, or to impose a pecuniary penalty of not more than $200,000, or both. It will usually be up to the Australian Securities Commission to make application for a civil penalty order.

The coalition is supporting these provisions because it believes that criminality should not attach to breaches of the law that involve no criminal intent. However, we do have concerns about the complexity of these provisions, particularly those that allow a court to bring a civil penalty finding as an alternative verdict when criminal proceedings have been commenced. It will be interesting to see the impact of the introduction of these civil penalty provisions on the recent dispute between the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions about their respective roles and responsibilities in the prosecution of corporate crime. The DPP, Mr Rozenes, expressed his concerns to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities on 7 September. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ASC will not devote sufficient resources to the identification, investigation and prosecution of corporate crime.

He also said that the DPP is not confident that all matters appropriate for prosecution as offences under the Corporations Law are being referred to it by the ASC. Last year, the corporate prosecutions budget of the DPP was significantly underspent by $1.5m, or 20 per cent of its total budget. Mr Rozenes said that the DPP was expecting far more work in the corporate area than it had received.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hartnell, during his time as head of the ASC, has been responsible for the ASC's change in emphasis to a commercial regulatory approach, relying on civil penalties instead of deterring corporate misconduct by punishment. Mr Hartnell has admitted that only three cases have been referred to the DPP in the 18 months since the new Corporations Law came into force. The DPP strongly objects to this allocation of resources to regulatory functions rather than criminal prosecutions. It sees this as a refusal of the ASC to play the role of corporate policeman, leaving a potentially serious gap in Australian regulation. The ASC is generally critical of the delays caused by the DPP in pursuing criminal prosecutions. The DPP, in turn, is critical of the standard of the briefs prepared by the ASC.

This is a situation where the Commonwealth's senior prosecutor has lost faith in the Commonwealth's commercial regulator. Yet it was not until the matter had been exposed by the media, as a result of a leak of correspondence between Mr Hartnell and Mr Rozenes, that the Attorney-General was forced to take an interest in the matter. We trust that these new provisions allowing for civil penalty orders will ameliorate the relationship between the ASC and the DPP.

I turn to the third of the important parts of this Bill, which concerns related party transactions. The coalition also has serious concerns about the provisions of the Bill which deal with such transactions. These amendments are being made in response to the corporate excesses of the 1980s, with the aim of preventing public companies from giving financial benefits to related parties, except in certain specified circumstances. In relation to those well known corporate failures, it is interesting to pursue the matter of the progress of the ASC into investigating what has become known as the big 16 cases. The ASC's expenditure on investigations into the so-called big 16 cases to 30 June 1992 was $4.7m. Mr Robinson of the ASC told the Senate Estimates Committee this year that 40 per cent of the ASC's total investigative resources have gone into those cases, and a significant number of them have been referred to the DPP. After several years of investigation and the expenditure of $4.7m there have, however, been convictions in relation to only two matters, Rothwells and Estate Mortgage.

While we appreciate that there are still a number of matters awaiting trial, this very slow rate of progress is a matter of great concern and it will continue to be monitored by the coalition. It is currently section 234 of the Corporations Law which deals with loans to directors. Pursuant to this Bill, section 234 will be repealed and replaced with a new part 3.2A, comprising 33 sections dealing with financial benefits to related parties of public companies. The provisions prohibit two types of related party transactions. The first prohibition is on a public company giving a financial benefit to a related party and the second is on a child entity of a public company giving a benefit to a related party of the public company. However, such transactions may proceed if they are approved by shareholders.

When this area of related party transactions was examined in 1989 by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, known as the Burrows committee, the Committee formed the view that legislation was required to deal with loans to related and connected companies and executive and intra-group remuneration. It believed that dishonest related party transactions were the cause of many of the corporate collapses of the 1980s and that complex legislation was necessary to prevent any recurrence. The Committee's suggestions were not well received, principally because many people, including the coalition and business groups, did not consider that the proposed sweeping reforms were justified.

When the Attorney-General released the exposure draft of this Bill in February this year, it contained 60 pages of legislation concerning related party transactions which attempted to address every possible situation that could arise. However, the Government did not put forward the justification for proposing extensive legislation nor the reason why existing laws were inadequate. Owing to the widespread criticism of these provisions in the exposure draft, the Attorney-General appointed a working party to simplify the provisions, and its proposals have been incorporated into the Bill we are now debating.

While the working party's changes do succeed in simplifying the provisions concerning related party transactions to some extent, the coalition is still concerned that there are deficiencies in this legislation and that there has been inadequate justification for the adoption of the extensive legislation path. Even in the explanatory memorandum it is acknowledged that dishonesty cannot be prevented by legislation and that lack of proper enforcement was a major problem with the existing legislation—the implication being that it is not new legislation that is required but proper enforcement of existing provisions.

In addition to our concerns about the desirability of the approach the Government has chosen, the coalition is concerned about the operation of these provisions. One of the features that concerns us is the prohibition in proposed paragraph 243G(1)(b) on an entity giving a financial benefit to a person indirectly, for example through interposed entities. This means that every transaction between unrelated parties will have to be reviewed to check whether there is any linkage higher up in the corporate chain.

The broad definition of related parties in clause 243F compounds the problem. It includes directors, their spouses, parents, children and directors of certain other entities. It extends to a public company's parent entity and sibling entities. That is quaint language. The combined effect of the indirect financial benefit extension and the breadth of the related party concept will mean that public companies will need to scrutinise every proposed transaction to ensure it does not breach the prohibitions contained in clause 243H. The need for such scrutiny will add considerably to transaction costs.

The Bill provides for a number of exemptions to the prohibitions on giving financial benefits to related parties. The so-called arm's length exemption in proposed section 243H will also create problems. It will allow a public company or a child entity to give a financial benefit on terms and conditions no more favourable to the related party than those on which it is reasonable to expect that the company would give the benefit if dealing with an unrelated party at arm's length. A transaction can therefore go ahead without the need for a shareholders meeting if it is justifiable on arm's length terms.

However, it is hard to see that this will change the situation which obtained in the 1980s, which the Government is trying to rectify. More prudent companies will still tend to rely on shareholders meetings where transactions involve related parties, whereas those with more cavalier attitudes will be able to avoid shareholders meetings by finding an adviser willing to state that a transaction is as favourable as one at arm's length.

Another exemption clause—clause 243Q—will also cause problems. It makes very detailed provision—albeit, thankfully, not quite as detailed as in the exposure draft—for the procedures to be followed to obtain the authorisation of shareholders to an otherwise prohibited transaction. These procedures will add considerably to business costs, particularly where a transaction between related companies is proposed for legitimate business reasons. Despite our concerns about these provisions, the coalition will not be moving to amend them at this stage because it considers that to do so would further confuse the already complex situation. However, it has also undertaken to monitor these closely when in government.

The second last area is that relating to insolvency reforms. I may well have to cover the last part in the committee stage because, with hundreds of pages of legislation before us, the time constraint agreed between the Democrats and the Government in this instance is simply unsatisfactory. (Extension of time granted)

I thank the Senate. On the last day of sitting the Government and the Australian Democrats are showing unusual tolerance. I want to mention insolvency reforms, and I will be brief. Part 4 of this Bill introduces amendments with respect to company insolvency as recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission's general insolvency inquiry, the Harmer report. Pursuant to the reforms contained in this Bill, the existing provisions in the Corporations Law with respect to the official management of insolvent companies will be repealed and replaced with a new part 5.3A, to provide for a voluntary scheme of administration of insolvent companies. There are also amendments to part 5.2, which deals with the duties and obligations of receivers, and proposals for new parts 5.4, 5.4A and 5.4B, with respect to winding up insolvency. The coalition welcomes these amendments as a significant improvement of the law, although it still has some reservations. One of those concerns is with respect to the amendments in proposed part 5.7B, which make it an offence for a director to permit a company to incur further debt while insolvent.

Proposed section 558G will alter the circumstances in which a director may be liable where the company incurs a debt. The current situation, as set out in subsection 592(1), is that it applies where there are reasonable grounds to expect that the company will not be able to pay its debts as and when they fall due. This amendment provides that the section will apply if, at the time of incurring the debt, there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the company is insolvent or would become insolvent. The effect of this amendment is to lower the threshold; a situation of some concern to the coalition. Company directors will be forced to resign as soon as any grounds of suspicion arise. This is a most onerous imposition on directors, particularly during this recession—the recession we had to have—when such suspicions arise easily and frequently.

The last part I wanted to mention very briefly is that relating to stock exchange settlement procedures. The reforms in part 5 of this Bill will enable the Australian Stock Exchange to introduce a new clearing house electronic subregister system, to be known by its acronym CHESS. This will make our Stock Exchange more competitive internationally, and by speeding up security settlements will reduce risk for investors. The new procedures will be of considerable benefit to Australian business and are therefore welcomed by the coalition.

On balance, therefore, despite our concerns with some of the provisions of this very large and complex Bill, the coalition will be supporting its passage. It recognises the vital role that legislation regulating corporate behaviour plays in the economy. That is why it has undertaken, when in government, to review the operation of corporate law in this country with the aim of making it simpler and clearer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992. This is a substantial Bill and, to some extent, the Australian Democrats share the concerns expressed by Senator Hill about the lack of time for debate in this chamber. Nevertheless, it must be acknowledged that a fairly substantial consultation process went on, not least through the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which examined the exposure draft of the Bill at some length and in some detail.

PARA.TAB: The Bill obviously arises out of community concerns that, during the 1980s, so-called corporate cowboys jeopardised, not only the savings of Australian middle and low income earners with which they were entrusted, but also the commercial reputation of Australian business overseas. In the debate between Mr Rozenes, the Director of Public Prosecutions, and Mr Hartnell, the Chairman of the ASC, the Democrats firmly come down on the side of the argument that we must, as far as possible, enforce our corporate laws through prosecution. It is clear that corporate offenders, if they are simply faced with a fine, will treat that as a business expense, just like a parking fine. What we must do is ensure that corporate crooks are prosecuted just as effectively as people who shoplift in one of our stores.

The Bill implements reforms to the Corporations Law in the areas of directors' duties, related party transactions, corporate insolvency laws and stock exchange settlement procedures. The Bill reflects the considerable influence which three major law reform reports have had on the Corporations Law. These are the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report entitled The social and fiduciary duties and obligations of company directors, the Australian Law Reform Commission report on its general insolvency inquiry and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee report on corporate financial transactions. In addition, there was an exhaustive consultative process undertaken with all interested parties, including corporate lawyers and business organisations, as I have already stated.

Regarding the area of directors' duties, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in its report, noted at the outset that any change in the regulation of directors' activities `must be warranted and a sensible balance must be found between measures necessary to promote corporate activity in a way which will be of benefit to all'. Clearly, the right of individual directors to exercise judgment and to take commercial risks must be balanced. The report dealt with the duties directors owe under company law to entities outside the company. In recent times the case law has imposed a duty on directors to creditors, and this was considered in chapter 5 of the report. The basis for this development is the closeness of the relationship between a company at the times of insolvency or near insolvency and its creditors. At these times, directors often will have dealt with the assets of creditors rather than the assets of company owners. The courts have decided that in those circumstances directors owe duties to creditors. In chapter 6 of the report the Committee considered the interests of entities other than the company, the shareholders and creditors, and the extent to which directors are entitled to take account of extrinsic factors in their decision making.

However, the main duty that directors owe is clearly to the shareholders of the company, and in this sense they are the trustees of the company's activity and assets. The duty of directors in taking particular decisions in the marketplace has continually been the subject of considerable debate and legislation.

Recommendation No. 2 of the report was that a business judgment rule be introduced into Australian company law to set the objective standard, as recommended by recommendation No. 1, for a director's duty of care. This rule is currently part of American jurisprudence, as Senator Hill has mentioned. The purpose of the rule is to provide special protection to directors who make informed business decisions, that is, directors who make a business judgment in good faith. I am not sure, however, that I agree with Senator Hill's comment that the introduction of such a rule would provide certainty. It seems to me that the rule does not remove the director's duty to act reasonably and with care, and that this would still be subject to determining a proper standard of conduct.

The Government, in its response to that recommendation in the report, said that it was not at this stage convinced that it is appropriate to introduce in isolation this one aspect of American jurisprudence into the Australian law on director's duties. The exposure draft of the Bill, which was released in February 1992, clearly indicated that the Government had decided that this rule would not be introduced.

The draft Bill did list a number of criteria which should be used in assessing whether a director has met the obligation which would otherwise be expressed in the business judgment rule, and the items listed include the following: information that the officer has required; the meetings that the officer has attended; how far the officer has exercised an act of discretion in the matters concerned; what the officer did to ensure that the corporation made adequate arrangements; what arrangements have been made to ensure that decisions made by one person on the corporation's behalf were, in fact, adequately monitored; and what arrangements were made to ensure that persons who have made decisions on the corporation's behalf had adequate information about the subject matter of the decisions.

These draft provisions met with considerable opposition from corporate lawyers and business organisations before hearings of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. This check list, as applied to directors, was dropped by the Government from the legislation. The Australian Democrats would actually not have objected to the check list being left in, believing that it would have set a reasonable standard for the behaviour of directors. I do not believe that the concerns expressed by corporate lawyers, and shared to a large extent by the Opposition, really would have eventuated.

It is interesting to see that in paragraph 83 of the explanatory memorandum the Government states that it considers that proposed subsection (4) does not change the law but merely confirms the present position. I believe that that is correct, and it is at the base of our position on this.

I now turn to related party transactions. This is a key area of reform in this Bill. The attempts to reform this particular area began in 1989, when the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee produced a discussion paper dealing with loans to related and connected companies and executive and intragroup remuneration. The Advisory Committee produced in 1991 a report containing draft legislation which again elicited considerable criticism. In response to such criticisms, the Government set up a part time working party to simplify the provisions, arriving at what is now before us in this Bill.

The provisions in the Bill essentially prohibit the giving of a financial benefit by a public company and its child entities to a related party of the public company unless that financial benefit is given to a related party on arm's length terms or if it is disclosed to and approved by a general meeting of shareholders. The Australian Democrats welcome these amendments as an important contribution to the regulation of dishonest transactions of the type that contributed so heavily to the corporate crashes of the 1980s.

I now turn to the corporate insolvency provisions in the Bill. The Bill adopts most of the 1988 Harmer report recommendations on insolvency. These recommendations were based on the concern that, in some cases, corporations were being placed into receivership or liquidation because of large accumulated debts but were either trading at a profit or could do so if properly restructured. The central change in the Bill in the area of corporate insolvency is the introduction of a mechanism to enable a corporation facing insolvency to appoint an independent administrator and to be protected from bankruptcy while a scheme of arrangement is developed. In other words, it offers a breather to companies facing solvency difficulties. At the same time, creditors would also receive protection under proposed section 436E, which requires an administrator to hold, within five days of his or her appointment, an initial meeting of creditors to decide whether to appoint a committee of creditors and/or remove and replace the administrator by resolution.

The Democrats welcome these amendments and regard the balance between providing a breathing space for companies facing solvency difficulties and the interests of creditors to have been properly addressed. However, on this point, we share the concerns expressed by the Opposition about the risk to the administrator of exposure to personal liability. I believe that this is an area that needs to be monitored and reviewed in the future.

The final key area of reform in the Bill relates to stock exchange settlement procedures. I advert only briefly to these amendments which will enable the Australian Stock Exchange to introduce a new clearing house electronic subregister system. The Government believes that this new system will enable Australia's stock exchange settlement procedures to continue to remain on par with the world's best and meet the standards of quick settlement that are demanded nowadays. The Australian Democrats believe that this provision is useful. We will monitor its performance and we welcome it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate for too long in this debate for, as Senator Spindler said, the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities has spent many days and hours reviewing the draft Corporate Law Reform Bill and taking evidence from a series of experts in the corporate law field, from business, commerce and academia. Furthermore, Senator Hill has quite thoroughly set out the Opposition's point of view.

PARA.TAB: However, there are a couple of matters that I want to raise in this debate. The first is that the hearings we held around Australia brought up a number of themes, whether we were in Brisbane, Perth, Sydney or Melbourne, and they were that there is still an overwhelming concern amongst the business community and amongst the corporate law fraternity that this corporate law, which came into being in January 1991, is far too complex and puts on business, at a time when we are trying to get out of a deep recession, enormous compliance costs that inhibit business in Australia.

Corporate law is not a sexy issue. It is not an issue that is ever going to be on the front page of Australian newspapers, except when there are spectacular corporate collapses or spectacular blues between the Director of Public Prosecutions and the head of the Australian Securities Commission. But it is a matter that affects the daily lives of Australians, even though they may not see it that way. If Australia's corporate law and regulations are to become more complex and impose more and more costs on doing business in Australia, it will cost Australians business opportunities. It will cost us in terms of competitiveness, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, and we will see companies being reluctant to enter into enterprises in Australia.

I think honourable senators from both sides of this chamber would share a strong commitment to the view that we need to see new enterprises being established in Australia. We need to ensure that the cost of doing business in Australia is not prohibitive. That, of course, relates to all areas of policy, be it taxation, broad regulations or, of course, very fundamentally, the Corporations Law. I think the Senate needs to consider the Corporations Law as part of the whole debate on regulation and the cost of doing business. We need to be very careful, when we are considering the corporate law reform process, that we are not, in the pursuit of the corporate misdemeanours of the 1980s, imposing enormous costs on the new businesses and new entrepreneurs that should emerge in the 1990s. There is a very fine balance to be reached. I commend the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities for the work that the Committee has been doing in enabling a broad range of views to come forward on these corporate law matters.

Senator Hill referred in his speech to consideration of the effectiveness of the ASC both as a regulator and as an investigator of corporate misdemeanours. I share the view expressed during the debate on the DPP-ASC conflagration that took place earlier this year. We do need carefully to monitor the Australian Securities Commission's performance in this area.

The Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities does have before it at the moment a reference to review the performance of the Australian Securities Commission in relation to the potential for insider trading in the Jupiters Casino bid in Brisbane earlier this year—a very serious matter and the sort of matter where our Committee can have a very positive role in ensuring that the Australian Securities Commission is doing the right thing, is being sensible and does not investigate matters in a less than satisfactory manner.

I still have quite serious concerns about whether or not the Australian Securities Commission has sensible resourcing and, indeed, allocation of resources to its investigations areas. As I review material relating to the Jupiters Casino matter, the allocation of resources and the management of the resources within the Australian Securities Commission, particularly in relation to this sort of investigation, lead me to believe that there are serious doubts about the Australian Securities Commission's role in this concern.

Of course, that is a matter that this Committee will pursue very vigorously in the coming months. Any wrongdoing in relation to the Jupiters Casino matter—the handling of it by the State Government, the matters relating to who had inside knowledge about the Jupiters Casino, the involvement by Daikyo Corporation, when Daikyo Corporation, indeed, had intended to pull out of that casino bid, and when that matter became public—will be a matter that our Committee gives very close scrutiny to over the coming months. Of course, the Senate will be informed of those deliberations when we report.

I want to conclude with one matter which was brought to my attention last week. I would like the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to give a response, if it is possible, in closing the second reading debate. A number of concerns have been raised with me by chartered accountants from Perth, Western Australia. There may well be concerns in the eastern capitals as well. I refer to the recent announcement of the Treasury as to when the priority of the Commissioner of Taxation in insolvency matters comes into effect and, also, the matter of when the insolvency provisions will actually come into effect.

There seems to be in Perth, Western Australia, some doubt as to whether it is 1 January, 1 July, or some other date. That matter seems to have eluded some of my constituents in Western Australia. This might be an appropriate time to give some certainty, because the effective date of these provisions coming into effect will clearly be important, particularly to practitioners in this area. Clearly, there is some uncertainty and I would like that to be cleared up. Having said all that, of course, the Opposition supports the passage of this Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I apologise to the chamber for not being here earlier but I thought Senator O'Chee was to speak. Senator Campbell apparently asked what the Government was doing about the Tax Commissioner's priority. Was that the question?
—I was asking when the insolvency provisions would come into effect.

—In mid-1993. There are regulations still to be drafted, apparently, and that is when they are expected to come into effect. I can answer the other question you did not ask, if you like, in more detail.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)
