SPEECH.PARA: The Government has moved some minor technical amendments during this committee stage of the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992. There are five significant and three consequential proposed amendments to the Bill. Four of these relate to the corporate insolvency provisions in part 4 of the Bill, while the remaining amendment is to the related party transaction provisions in part 3 of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Most of the amendments were proposed following a submission to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) made by Mr Ron Harmer, a distinguished Australian, on the day on which the Bill was debated in the House of Representatives. Mr Harmer, as honourable senators will know, was the principal author of the Australian Law Reform Commission's report in 1988 on its general insolvency inquiry, a report which is to be implemented by part 4 of the Bill. These amendments make technical refinements to a number of provisions in the Bill for the reasons set out in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. They reflect Mr Harmer's commitment to a project which has been a very lengthy one for him personally but one which I believe has, and will, yield very promising results for Australia.

I make particular mention only of the proposed amendment to the related party transaction provisions in part 3 of the Bill. The amendment will allow the Australian Securities Commission to exempt companies from compliance with proposed section 232A where that would be appropriate. Proposed section 232A establishes a prohibition on directors of public companies voting or being present at board meetings in relation to matters in which they have a material personal interest.

The section provides that, where as a result of the prohibition there is no quorum of disinterested directors, the matter must be considered by the company in general meeting. However, there may be circumstances where, for reasons of urgency or some other compelling reason, the matter should be dealt with by the directors even though the directors have a material personal interest in the matter. The new section 232B will therefore enable the Australian Securities Commission to conditionally exempt companies from the section 232A prohibition where the section might otherwise disadvantage the company. The amendment introduces an additional element of flexibility without detracting from the important principle, that conflicts of interest must be brought out in the open so that shareholders can be properly protected.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just take this opportunity to clarify that matter of when the insolvency provisions will come into effect. The Government has said that that will occur in about mid-1993. It does not have any specific date in mind at this stage. Perhaps it could suggest how it is going to advise the industry broadly of the date of coming into effect of those insolvency provisions in the Bill so that this matter of some uncertainty, which has been brought to my attention by a number of constituents, can be resolved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the intention of the Government to consult with industry groups, accountants, insolvency practitioners and so on, very extensively in relation to the regulations in the first few months of the coming year. We want to get them right, workable and in harmony with the intention of the Parliament. It is expected that that will take a period of some four to six months to conclude and then, of course, the regulations will be made—no doubt having been made disallowable instruments. Therefore, they would be subject to the scrutiny of this place and, I would have a guess, might be looked at by the parliamentary committee itself if there are any concerns. But it is the intention to get them right and that will involve a process of consultation which will be extensive. I know Senator Campbell is genuinely interested in this matter and I will undertake to keep him informed on the progress of those consultations.

PARA.TAB: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1992SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION LEVY BILL 1992SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Button:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a package of Bills dealing with the maritime industry. I will confine my remarks mainly to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1992 as I do not have time to deal with the allied Bills. This legislation is proposed to replace the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 and to create a new system of compensation for seafarers who are injured or killed in the course of their employment in the maritime industry. The Opposition supports the principle behind the legislation, that seafarers should have a rehabilitation and compensation system in keeping with contemporary community standards, as do members of the industry with whom we consulted very widely.

PARA.TAB: The review of the existing legislation followed the recommendations of Professor Harold Luntz in his review of seamen's compensation. The Government claims that its decision to reform seafarers' compensation along the lines of the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 was consequential to the Luntz review. This is not the case, because the selection of the CERC Act was the Government's own doing. The Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 is clearly out of date—it is 81 years old—and this was acknowledged by Professor Luntz in his review of seamen's compensation.

Professor Harold Luntz, who was the architect of the Workcare scheme in Victoria, recommended that compensation arrangements be on the basis of community standards. Cabinet then determined that this would be the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. The choice of the CERC Act was not necessarily that of the review, as suggested in the Government's explanatory memorandum, but was the Government's own selection. The Commonwealth justified setting the benefit standards at the CERC Act because this is the only other Federal compensation Act but it did not explain why an Act which relates only to Commonwealth public servants and some employees of statutory authorities and Commonwealth owned businesses and enterprises is appropriate as a community standard. I thought that anything to do with the Public Service was far above community standards, especially when the proposed legislation will cover only employees in private enterprise. It is not clear on what basis commonality has been determined other than the fact that they are both Federal Acts and the only Federal Acts dealing with rehabilitation and compensation.

There are major differences. The Navigation Act provides for a three months sick leave period, regardless of length of service, due to specific maritime requirements such as the need for complete recovery and fitness clearance to work on ships, especially for seafarers such as engineers, where the physical demands are specific. In the second reading speech in the other place when introducing the Bill, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Snowdon, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The rate of benefits payable to partially incapacitated employees who are able to work will be on a graduated scale.
It generally is in most industries. Mr Snowdon continued:

For these persons the combined total of compensation plus earnings will be between 75 per cent and 100 per cent of normal weekly earnings, depending on the number of hours that the employee actually works.
However, one cannot be at sea unless one is 100 per cent fit. When I refer to being at sea I mean working at sea, not necessarily on a pleasure craft or something like that.

PARA.TAB: Because of the nature of the work, seafarers cannot afford to be 74 per cent, 90 per cent or even 95 per cent fit. They must be 100 per cent fit if they are to be capable of going up and down ladders, working in confined spaces and lifting and carrying in the performance of their duties and at the same time retaining a sure footing in difficult and unsteady circumstances.

As I said, people cannot operate at sea under partial benefits because of their need to be 100 per cent fit. So these provisions lifted from the CERC Act are simply inappropriate. The CERC Act itself is subject to a review, currently under way, which will almost certainly lead to revisions in the level of and approach to benefits. It is not clear how the results of such a review will affect the provisions of this legislation that we are dealing with today. However, the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill basically ties the compensation and rehabilitation for seafarers to the CERC Act while the CERC Act itself is currently under review.

I would like to know what the position of the Seamen's Union will be if, under the CERC Act, which is under review, seamen have some of their compensation, or whatever, reduced. I would like to know what sort of action the Seamen's Union will take. I presume we will have a strike on our hands immediately. It might have been more logical to delay the implementation of this Bill until the completion of the CERC Act review and the recommendation from that review could have been taken into account in this legislation. If the CERC Act had been the basis for this legislation then the Parliament might, as a consequence, be back here debating amendments to this Bill—all because the Government decided to bring forward a Bill tied to a system that is currently under review. So this may be a very temporary new Act.

The Government has argued that existing Federal standards are the only ones that are appropriate for an industry that is not fixed to any one State. Indeed, the shipping industry in Australia locates its employees all over the place—from State to State, from international boundary to international boundary—in the course of carrying out their employment. The Commonwealth argues that, therefore, there is a need for the CERC Act to apply and that the Commonwealth should fix the terms and conditions of compensation and rehabilitation. The Commonwealth argues that there needs to be one set of standards established by the Commonwealth that overrides all State boundaries and State differences. It is typical of what this Government is doing in Victoria at the present moment. But this is not borne out by arrangements in the aviation industry, for example, where air crews are also habitually mobile outside their home jurisdictions for extended periods. Ansett air crews, for instance, are covered by home port jurisdiction even though they may be out of that jurisdiction for extended periods, and may be out of State jurisdiction of any sort. They could be on an international flight to New Zealand.

There is little apparent rationale for the choice of the CERC Act as the community standard. What I believe it does is to represent the penthouse level of standards for compensation, rather than the basement level. No-one says that any employees of any industry should have any compensation that is below community standards. If I can quickly find them, I will give honourable senators an idea of the figures from the CERC Act, as compared with a few others. Just picking figures out quickly, the lump sum paid to a spouse under the CERC Act is $139,321 plus other sums for their children, of course. Under the seamen's compensation agreement at the present moment it is $74,630. The figure for the Northern Territory is $80,449; for Western Australia, $83,336; for South Australia, $80,000; for Tasmania, $83,000-odd; for Queensland, $77,000; for Victoria, $108,000; and for New South Wales, $150,000. So the only State that is anywhere near the CERC Act is New South Wales. It can be seen that it is moving towards the penthouse level instead. Nor is it clear why it has not been possible to close off altogether the liability of the employers under common law.

Under the Act, the compensation will be payable by definite amounts on definite occasions, but there will still be some access to common law. One of the attractions of the arrangements in the first place is that they introduce certainty into compensation and make trauma and costliness of common law action unnecessary. It would be desirable to close off altogether that trauma and costliness. In common law action, settlements are delayed, often to the detriment of the claimant, and costs escalate, to the detriment of both claimant and employer. I could stand here and give honourable senators a lot of examples.

The Bill limits common law action for death and permanent injury to non-economic loss; for permanent injury it is capped but it is left as an option in the case of death. It would have been preferable to make the Bill comprehensive in its application. There are other specific matters that we were concerned about and which were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

The Opposition has accepted the explanation of the Government and departmental advisers, at the Committee's public hearing on 10 December, that in clause 26(2) the exclusion from compensation for self-inflicted injury includes death. If one looks at the explanatory memorandum, one sees that it has not been well defined. Clause 26(2) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Compensation is not payable for an intentionally self-inflicted injury.

But what it does not go on to specify is that that self-inflicted injury may have included a suicide. The Minister's second reading speech does not say that the provision is to exclude suicide at work. We have been assured by the Government advisers that suicide at work would be excluded but in clause 26(3), where it provides for compensation in the case of serious and wilful misconduct of employees, it says `other than a self-inflicted injury'. While we do take on board the Government's explanation, I believe that it should have been made clearer.

PARA.TAB: The apparent exclusion of suicide from this clause has caused the Opposition a lot of concern. I believe that, while recognising that the employer was not responsible for a minor circumstance, that should have been addressed. The Opposition made the point that it might have been helpful to all concerned if the explanatory memorandum had made the inclusion of death under clause 26(2) far clearer.

A similar problem arose for the Opposition regarding clause 26(3), where the exclusion of compensation to the employee for injury arising from the employee's own negligence is accepted but the employee or dependants are still eligible for compensation for the more serious case of permanent incapacitation or death. To hold an employer liable for something over which he has no control—indeed, `wilful misconduct' implies actions on the part of the employee contrary to the requirements or wishes of the employer—seems to me very unjust. The Government and the union representative at the Committee public hearing argued that the clause is a standard one in compensation legislation, both Federal and State. Senator Cook explained that at the time and I agree it is there. It is designed to protect the widows and dependants of workers when they are deprived of their support as a result of the wilful misconduct of the worker.

While the argument is that employees themselves suffer the consequences of temporary injuries, whereas their innocent dependants suffer the consequences later where there is death or permanent serious injury, the issue seems to be one of welfare rather than justice. The Opposition may not argue against the need to protect dependants from the consequences of wilful behaviour of the breadwinner but does question the justice of effectively holding the employer responsible. There is a manifest injustice in this, I believe. Including employment liability was justified on no better grounds than that it was the easiest way to protect the dependants. In no way can that be covered by workers liability, because insurance companies will not cover it, so it all lies at the feet of the employer.

At this stage of the legislation, because it is a general issue, the Opposition will not make an issue out of it. It should be dealt with in the context of compensation liability in general. It is one for the Opposition simply to take on board at this stage and once in government to look at in greater detail and in consultation with the States.

Social security covers cases where there is unemployment and sickness and in a host of other circumstances. I believe that where a breadwinner loses his life by wilful misconduct the case should be taken up by social security. In some cases we are in a happy situation where all the employees are employed by substantial employers who can cover such a situation. But in this award—and certainly in other awards—where you have an employer of not so substantive means then that employer could be sent to the wall. Then, of course, the other employees of that employer will finish up on compensation alongside the wife and children of the employee who lost his life by his own means. I believe this is a measure that the coalition government will be looking at.

Another matter of concern raised at the Committee public hearing concerned clause 97; in particular, the mandatory requirement for a safety net fund to reinsure for catastrophe with a liability of more than $1m. The safety net fund is run by employers to cover employees on industry training courses and those on roster when in transit from ship or a place of training and who may become liable for a catastrophe or an event which results in several expensive claims arising from a single accident.

There appears to have been inadequate consultation on this clause, which the industry claims was introduced without proper consultation with the employers' compensation agency. In the employers' view, it cuts across the exercise of a commercial judgment by the fund's administrators. It is at odds with the principle of industry and employer responsibility reflected elsewhere in the Bill.

In the Opposition's view the reserve powers to assume responsibility for safety net provisions are sufficient to safeguard the responsible commercial operation of the fund. Commercial responsibility should lie with employers and the industry until the Minister's reserve powers under the Bill become necessary, including the responsibility to access prudent levels of risk.

The Department argued from the position that the need for some level to trigger reinsurance was an assumed requirement and the industry representative at that inquiry indicated that the major objection to the Bill as it stands is the arbitrary setting of that level at $1m on the grounds that the industry is well able to withstand a higher level of risk and should, if the fund judges it to be commercially viable, be permitted to do so. The Opposition sympathises with this view and has, accordingly, drafted an amendment which, while still maintaining a requirement to reinsure, enables the level of prudence to be set in consultation with the industry and to be reassessed from time to time.

It may be that industry is well able to withstand a higher level of risk—and I have an example which I do not have time to give now—and the fund should have the commercial freedom to determine this. The Opposition will be moving an amendment in the spirit of finding a position that is acceptable to all and does not compromise the rights and freedoms of any participant. By setting a prescribed figure and requiring the Minister to consult with the industry before prescribing it, the industry will be able to put forward its case and the Minister will have the flexibility to react to changing economic circumstances which will include bringing that figure below $1m should he think it is fitting.

The Bill presents a laudable principle and noble motives that nevertheless show signs of arbitrary dealings which were not dispelled in the Committee's public hearing. The Cabinet decision to accept the CERC Act shows signs that that is not quite the way to go. The decision to adopt CERC certainly does not line up with community standards, but that is exactly what Cabinet decided. Explanations for the decision to adopt the CERC Act as the so-called community standard envisaged in the Luntz review are still needed.

There are still a lot of loose ends to be tied up, because the Bill was hastily put together and was pushed through the House of Representatives on 14 October. Why it was pushed through so quickly is not quite clear. The Opposition supports the principle and the intention of the Bill, but this is the first instance where the Government has imposed upon the private sector compensation and rehabilitation requirements that it uses for its own public sector. In other words, we have got the CERC Act pushed onto the private sector. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome this package of seafarers rehabilitation and compensation Bills, as do most people involved with the industry—if not because it is brilliantly comprehensive and implementable, then certainly because it is a blessed relief to see a Bill to replace the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911. The Seamen's Compensation Act 1911, even by its title, leads us to believe that the legislation we have before us today has been long in the waiting and, therefore, is welcomed, as I say, at least with relief.

PARA.TAB: The concerns that have been expressed by Senator Panizza regarding details and apparent inconsistencies are concerns which were drawn to the attention, firstly, of the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am a member. There were found to be several factors which needed to be addressed. I am satisfied that the Government has made a valiant effort to address those, and the subsequent hearing by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure also addressed some of the concerns that were expressed there. In fact, some of the concerns were ill-founded.

The Democrats have had represented to them the concerns of employees who would be affected by this and of industry representatives as well. Essentially, the case that has been put to us is connected with this sense of relief that at last legislation has been presented to Parliament to address the inadequacies of the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911.

Essentially, the case boils down to this: if a Bill is presented to Parliament to address the problems of that compensation Act, even if it is less than perfect it will be acceptable. I must say that I have some sympathy with that particular point of view. To emphasise the slight inadequacies of this legislation now and to refuse it passage on the grounds of those slight inadequacies would frustrate both the employees concerned and the industry itself, so, of course, we would not propose to oppose it on those grounds.

We would welcome ongoing attention to some of the details which are purported to be problems; and I will not here attempt to offer a solution. I doubt that that is my role, nor would it be capable of implementation at this stage. I have little to add other than to say that the case which was presented to us by the employees who would be affected overwhelmingly persuades us to support the legislation.

As to the depth of detail that Senator Panizza addressed, I can see merit in some of the claims that he made, but I believe that the criticisms are somewhat overstated. For example, the criticism that the CERC Act does not represent community standards can easily be demonstrated to be overstated by the fact that the administration of the CERC Act in this particular instance is not just a case of handing over without any modification what would apply to public servants operating in Canberra and assuming that that would be relevant to seafarers operating out of Whyalla, for example.

These assumptions are just a little too easy to make. In fact, they are governed by a Bill—an intensely modified and complicated Bill—which covers almost 80 pages with an explanatory memorandum of some 75 or so pages. It is not just a case of saying that the CERC Act applies to seafarers; there is considerable detail attached to how, when, where and what provisions and what is involved. At one stage there was a suggestion that the rehabilitation requirements, which are welcome and which have a much more modern attitude towards workers' compensation than there has been in the past, were a little more difficult when dealing with seafarers.

The term `able-bodied seaman' is not a quaint term but in fact a very practical description of what is required to go to sea; persons in wheelchairs or persons who are disabled physically are much harder to rehabilitate for seafaring jobs. That was a complaint which was registered early in the discussion with us. But in fact only a little imagination is required to see or to understand that rehabilitation can mean a lot more than adapting wheelchairs or other devices to help disabled people move about. Rehabilitation also means restructuring jobs and reconsidering what roles a person might perform. Counselling and other activities which help a person return to work of some sort are included in the description of rehabilitation. So even that initial criticism is one which has been addressed and which can be delivered through this Bill. I do not need to take any more time of the chamber to illustrate that the Democrats will be supporting the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to comment very briefly on the first amendment that the Liberal and National parties were intending to move and which we discussed in the committee hearing. I should say, of course, that I support everything that Senator Panizza said, and said very well, in relation to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill. We were considering moving an amendment to clause 26, subclause (2). We were convinced at the hearing that the legislation intended to say what in fact our amendment was proposing.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on record in this chamber, in case it is of some assistance when this matter is being dealt with by the parties involved at some future time, that I would have thought that a better wording for subclause (2) would have been, `Compensation is not payable for that injury if it is intentionally self-inflicted'. I think that would have been a clearer way of saying what the Government advisers indicated to us that subclause intended. But it appears from our committee hearing that we are all of a mind on what that means, and I simply rise in this debate to emphasise that again, should it be of assistance for people trying to interpret it at some time in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what we are confronted with on this Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill is unanimity in terms of the purpose of the Bill and a considered debate, with different weightings of importance attached to it, about one element of this Bill. That element was brought out in a committee hearing in which evidence was adduced from the employer organisation and the union as well as the Department concerning the status of people affected by death or significant disability in circumstances in which they may have contributed to those things themselves, or did contribute to those things themselves. We are also confronted by a consideration by the coalition of the provision in this legislation concerning catastrophe insurance and an effort by it, in a foreshadowed amendment in the committee stage, to provide another solution to the one the Bill provides to meet that problem.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I think that the real debate is over whether or not the proposed amendment on catastrophe insurance is satisfactory. If that debate is resolved, whichever way it is resolved, I think that the Bill is then satisfactory to the Senate. In those circumstances, I want to thank the contributors to this debate and members of the Committee for the role they played in examining this issue in detail and for the views they have put. It is true that I do not agree in all cases with the views that have been put. Nonetheless, I acknowledge that they have been put after some earnest consideration, that they do reflect genuinely held views and that they raise and deal with matters of some significance.

However, in terms of compensation payable to people who may have contributed or did contribute to significant disability or death in their own cases, I would say that the debate on that issue, while interesting, has perhaps not brought out this fundamental fact. The legislation we are proposing to deal with that is legislation copied from the previous Act. So we are continuing an existing principle; we are not inventing a new one. Additionally, I would say that all workers compensation Acts in the States reflect a principle of this type. They have not invented a new solution to it; they have persisted with the same solution that we are offering. The Acts in the States have remained consistent on this point, irrespective of what party was in government.

I recognise that, out of the inquiry process conducted by the Senate, there is an acceptance of this position now, albeit with the views put by Senator Panizza, which, I agree with Senator Macdonald, were well put. But I think that the material facts I have just put about the background and history of this probably round out a consideration as to why the Government and now the Opposition, too, support the proposition. In order to speed the consideration of this matter before the Senate, I will now conclude my remarks in the second reading stage. I will listen to what may be said on the motion to be moved by the Opposition on catastrophe insurance and I will reply to that argument in the committee stage. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I formally move the two amendments standing in my name, the Minister at the table, Senator Cook, did not mention what Senator Macdonald had to say in the second reading speech regarding subclause 26(2) in which he raised the point that, as we were assured at the inquiry, that does not include death. That subclause states:

SPEECH.PARA: Compensation is not payable for an intentionally self-inflicted injury.
Is the Minister going to agree with what his advisers said at the hearing, that that does not include paying for death or suicide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for the fact that I neglected to deal with that point in my second reading reply. I have sought further advice on this so that my answer can be not only what I believe but also be confirmed by what my official departmental advice assures me is the case, and I have been assured that wilfully self-inflicted injury resulting in death is not compensable under this Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that assurance. I seek leave to move both amendments and deal with them together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 97, page 63, subclause (1), line 33, omit "exceeds $1,000,000", substitute "is prescribed".
2.Clause 97, page 63, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:

"(1A) Before an amount is prescribed in accordance with this section, the Minister must consult with the Fund, the Australian National Maritime Association and the Australian Minerals and Metals Association as to the amount.".

The reason for moving that we take out the figure of $1m and insert a prescribed figure is as I stated in my speech at the second reading stage. I believe that $1m is not so great an amount for this sort of industry with the combination of various people and companies. I will give honourable senators an example of a catastrophe event. Let us say trainees are being taken to a training session. Suppose a coach carrying the trainees is involved in a serious collision and there are five dead and 10 totally incapacitated. The lump sum payout would be approximately 5 times $250,000 under common law, to the dependents of the dead; plus 10 times $100,000 under section 39(9) to the injured. A total lump sum of $2.25m spread over 2,000 berths in the industry at large is $1,012 per berth.

PARA.TAB: Compared with the total wage-salary bill of around $120,000 per berth, the risk of the industry being unable to meet such an immediate call to meet the liability is negligible. Of course, if there is a case of ongoing weekly payouts it would be much less per berth per year and the industry may well decide it could bear the immediate risk of lump sum pay-outs of around $2m but insure any excess. That, however, would be the commercial decision of the industry.

That is the reason we have moved these two amendments, and I thank the Australian Democrats for their intended support. The union representative told us at the inquiry that, after all, insuring in excess of $1m is cheap. But that may not be the case in five years time. I believe that if an industry can carry its own risk by its own cash reserves then it should not be forced into insurance in the lower figures.

By having a prescribed figure, which is covered in the amendments and added to in the second amendment, the Minister can, with consultation, move it either upwards or downwards. If the Minister or a particular government thinks that taking a risk of a million dollars is too high, in consultation they can bring the amount down. Of course, they would be doing so, as it says in the amendment, in consultation with the fund, the Australian National Maritime Association and the Australian Minerals and Metals Association. That is the reason that we have moved those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are convinced by the lucid argument of Senator Panizza on this matter and also by its inherent logic. To include a finite amount in legislation, we believe, has attached to it its own perils. As Senator Panizza said towards the end of his contribution, such provisions are becoming outdated rather rapidly and becoming irrelevant in certain particular circumstances.

PARA.TAB: I will just take a moment of the Committee's time to illustrate why, in relation to entirely unrelated legislation, I was reminded of that last night. At a dinner for the graduates of the University of Tasmanian I was sitting next to an experienced graduate in law who reminded me of the attempt in Tasmania to remove finite amounts defined in legislation and to replace them with indexes or coded amounts which increased or decreased as the value of money changed in society. It seems ludicrous that we still have in legislation finite amounts such as fines of #20, converted to $40, that are considered relevant. Those sorts of amounts might have been relevant in 1950 when they were first defined, but they have become irrelevant with the passage of time and the change in the value of money. Here we have $1m defined as being seemingly relevant at the moment but, as Senator Panizza has said, it is potentially irrelevant with the passage of only a few years.

The other explanation that Senator Panizza gave—of the capacity of the industry to meet its own costs in certain circumstances and in certain situations—has been accurately described and surely can also be accurately deliberated on in consultation with the Minister; and that is what is proposed in these amendments. We support the amendments for both those reasons. We believe they improve the legislation and expedite the fair and equitable delivery of what the legislation is trying to deliver. Therefore, we support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the arguments put forward by Senator Panizza and Senator Bell. The industry is made up of some of Australia's leading companies. They are well able to self-insure up to a reasonable amount, and the consequence to the industry of having some flexibility in the amount of self-insurance means that they save a considerable amount of money in premiums which they would otherwise have to pay to insurers. It is a saving to the industry, and in these days, I think, everyone recognises that the industry includes both employers and employees. It is for this reason, as well as for the reasons that Senator Panizza has very clearly pointed out, that we have moved these amendments.

PARA.TAB: At a slight tangent, and without being too pedantic, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook), in commenting on section 26, did confirm what Senator Panizza had asked him to confirm. He used the word `wilfully', whereas the Act refers to `intentionally'. There is a slight variation in law between `wilful' and `intentional', but I simply put on the record that I assume the Minister was meaning `intentionally' in the terms of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, can I make a valiant effort to try to wrap this up by quarter to one when we normally adjourn for lunch. The amendment that has been moved does not offend us, but we would obviously prefer our own position. That is not to say we will roll over or that it will go to a vote on the voices and we will concede at that point; but I will say these things. Firstly, consultations were engaged in. The employer organisations said they would consult an Australian insurance company and come back with a quote. Two months elapsed and they did not do that. We had the obligation to present the legislation. We have done that. Secondly, this sort of thing is typical of State and Territory compensation schemes and the level we are talking about—$1m—is typical of those two. We are not out of sync with the States and the Territories. Thirdly, the cost we are talking about here is frankly infinitesimal.
—Yes, for the moment.

—We can argue about whether infinitesimal is large or small in degree, but rather than actually going to quoting the figures, which would take a lot of time, let me rely on the assertion. If the amendment were to be carried, it has these defects which I am surprised the Democrats just accept. The proper name of the organisation is not the Australian minerals and metals association—there is no such organisation that I am aware of. The proper name is the Australian Mines and Metals Association.

PARA.TAB: The second defect is that this requires consultation in an industry with a long industrial tradition of only the employers. There is no provision here for consultation with the unions and, since the purpose of consultation is to try to get an agreed outcome, to exclude a major party that plays a significant role in this industry would be wrong. I would be more kindly disposed towards the amendment if it read `consultation with the fund, employers and unions' rather than named just the employers. I might even agree to it then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking up that point, the Minister did say the insurance is infinitesimal at the moment, but what I said earlier in my speech in the second reading debate was that that is at this stage, and that has got a big bearing. We do not know what insurance premiums are going to be in five or 10 years time. So I still believe that it is far cheaper if it is within the capabilities of the employers to carry their own. The Minister will have the power to prescribe whether to move the amount up or down, and I believe under certain circumstances he could bring it down if we had a few catastrophes one after the other. The Minister could say, `Those employers might not have the capability to pay out on another catastrophe so I will lower it to half a million dollars'. That is the reason behind our insertion of that clause.

—On the other matter that the Minister raised, I understood the employees' representative at the committee hearing was not terribly interested in that particular matter. It really is a matter between the employers, who have to pay the premiums, and the Government. As far as the employees are concerned, their only concern is whether they are in fact covered should a catastrophe occur.

PARA.TAB: By accepting the first amendment, I think the Government concedes, as we all do, that the employers are well able to cover the excess and it is really just a question of the Government insuring that it is not unreasonably high or unreasonably low and consulting with the employers who have to pay it so that they come to some agreement. As far as the employees are concerned, their principal concern is that they do get paid, and I think the Government and the employers would insure that with the raising or lowering of the amounts. As I say, whilst I do not think it was specifically put to Mr Byrne, he was there, he was participating very intelligently in the committee hearing and I do not think he was particularly concerned about the matter. In practice, no doubt the Government would give them a call.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter of public interest about affairs of the Liberal Party in South Australia which have come to light in the last few hours. First of all, it was reported in today's Adelaide Advertiser that in the Federal seat of Sturt the former Federal Liberal member for Adelaide, Mr Michael Pratt, has announced that he will be running against the endorsed Liberal candidate, Mr Pyne.

PARA.TAB: The same article in the Adelaide Advertiser indicates that Mr Wilson, the sitting member who lost endorsement, is also keeping his options open about running as an independent candidate against Mr Pyne. This is an astonishing development. Not only did the sitting member lose his endorsement but a former endorsed Liberal Party candidate and former sitting member for Adelaide is running against Mr Pyne; as well, the current sitting member is considering running.

Further information has come to light this morning in Adelaide. Mr Pratt obviously was contacted by the press when he announced that he was going to run as an independent and he was interviewed on radio this morning on the ABC program compered by Keith Conlon on radio 5AN. Not only did Mr Pratt confirm that he would be running for the seat of Sturt, but he went on to say that at a recent meeting of the State Council of the Liberal Party in South Australia there was a move to expel John Olsen from the Liberal Party. He said that the media had not picked this up. One of the reasons that these things are hard to pick up initially in South Australia is that the Liberal Party bans the media from attending its State Council meetings; it attempts to hold them in secret. But in this case Mr Pratt, a delegate to the council meeting, has spilled the beans that there is a move against John Olsen. When Mr Conlon, the compere, asked whether the move was by Brown supporters, Mr Pratt confirmed:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, it was moved on the floor. I guess they didn't get John, so I guess at some meeting they'll probably want to move to expel me . . .

We have an extraordinary situation. A former Leader of the Liberal Party in South Australia, a former senator in this place, went back hoping to be leader again but did not count properly and ended up being on the front bench only. He made an unsuccessful attempt recently to become deputy leader of the Liberal Party but failed again because he could not count. There is now a move by the Brown supporters, according to Mr Pratt, to expel John Olsen from the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is totally incorrect. Mr Pratt wasn't at the meeting. I was.
—I am only quoting. He was not at the meeting? All I am saying is that Mr Pratt—
—He may have said that, but I was at the meeting and it was false. It is wrong.

—I am sure that Senator Hill will get up and put the record straight, as far as he is aware of it, but I find it interesting that his party in the past was good enough to endorse Mr Pratt, it wallowed in the victory when he won the Adelaide by-election in 1988 as one of the new young bloods to regenerate the Liberal Party, but now, when he is running around dropping buckets on the Liberal Party, people do not want to know him. He said further in the interview:

SPEECH.PARA: Keith, I don't mind in life running and losing. I've won and lost in lots of contests. But, yeah, come back to that. In Fed Adelaide, to be rolled by an out of the Hill faction. You know, Robert Hill said, oh Pratty, they don't take too kindly to losers in the Liberal Party. This is after me taking Catley to an inch and Bob is absolutely relieved that I'm not running against him.

So he has fingered the Leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate as being part of the coup that knocked him off for preselection. Then Mr Pratt goes on to describe the endorsed Liberal candidate for Adelaide in the following terms:
To be rolled by an idiot vet who wants to, and I quote,
"stick glass rods up people's penises and crush them".
That is his description of the Liberal Party candidate for Adelaide.

PARA.TAB: One has to ask Mr Pratt the reason why he would describe the Liberal candidate as an idiot vet and say things like that. Mr Pratt was a Liberal Party member of Parliament, yet he goes around describing Liberal Party candidates in those terms on radio in Adelaide. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I mean he is a liability to Fed Adelaide and the Liberal Party. I mean, he's got that baggage hanging over him.
Then Mr Pratt, who stood for preselection of the State seat of Norwood, says:

Then to be rolled by a Labor traitor in Norwood, I think, hang on, is this what the Liberal Party is about and then to see "Curly" Wilson knocked off, because old "Curly", he's been rolled because he's too old. I'll write to everyone in the electorate of Sturt, and say, you're 59 years of age, your use by date has expired under the terms of the Liberal Party because they don't want you—at 60.
It is a pretty extraordinary attack being made on the Liberal Party in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party is going to get annihilated, and you are worried about it.

—Senator Macdonald is dead right. The Liberal Party, in all the polls in South Australia, has not looked better for a long, long time. But what are its members doing? They are brawling amongst themselves, running as independents and abusing each other. On the valedictory night when former Senator Olsen left the Senate, Opposition senators all said, `He goes back to lead the Liberal Party in South Australia to victory at the next State election'. He did not get the leadership or the deputy leadership.

PARA.TAB: He tried two weeks ago to become deputy leader. He went off and said to the then leader, Mr Ingerson, `I have got 11 votes out of 22 to be leader'. He forgot that he actually needed 12. It was one of the worst counting jobs ever seen. Then he discovered in the next two hours that his 11 votes had become 10. So he had to withdraw and they had to go around and resurrect Stephen Baker as deputy leader. This is the Party that Senator Macdonald is telling me is doing so well in South Australia, according to the polls. Its members are all brawling with each other and here we have the comment by Mr Pratt, the former sitting Liberal member for Adelaide, that there is a move by the Brown forces to expel Olsen from the Party. What is going on in South Australia?Mr Pratt is reported in the paper today as saying that zero tariffs mean zero jobs. That is his view about the tariff policy of the Liberal Party in South Australia. He knows the effect it will have on the car industry in South Australia. He also says in this interview:

SPEECH.PARA: I think by the . . . look, Joan Hall and Amanda Vanstone and Vicky Chapman were very good supporters of mine.
I suspect they will all be diving under the table today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not Senator Amanda Vanstone?

—Yes, Senator Amanda Vanstone. Vicky Chapman is the President of the Liberal Party in South Australia and Joan Hall is Steele Hall's spouse and an endorsed Liberal candidate in her own right for a State seat. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . they have marshalled together to roll a lot of people. Rob Nettle is now standing.

Rob Nettle is a former senior executive of the Chamber of Commerce in South Australia and a senior member of the Liberal Party, apparently. He is now running as the National Party candidate in Grey while living in Adelaide. Grey happens to be an outback rural seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happens in Queensland all the time.
—In South Australia it is a bit unusual to run as a candidate for an outback seat like Grey while living in the salubrious suburbs of Adelaide, but Mr Nettle is doing that for the National Party.
—Do you live in the salubrious suburbs of Adelaide?

—I live in an ordinary suburb of Adelaide called Magill. I will finish on the extraordinary events that are developing in the Liberal Party in South Australia by relating what Mr Pratt says about the Liberal candidate, Mr Pyne.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, and I don't think Sturt is ready for a 24 year old, live-at-home-with-Mum, young Liberal lawyer. So I'm very happy to . . . I mean it is someone else's line to say, `Back Pratt and you'll lose your dough'.
Then Mr Conlon interjected and Pratt went on to say:
That's not his line, he's not that smart. They hold $17,000, I know what money they've got. The party's leaking like a sieve.
Conlon asked:
How much money will you take to your independent campaign?
Pratt replied to that by saying:
It would be I think it's coming up to 10 o'clock you haven't got enough time to tell you that.

Pratt avoided that question. There has been an extraordinary series of events in the last 24 hours in Adelaide. We have Mr Pratt announcing that he is standing as an independent, Mr Wilson not ruling out that he will not stand as an independent against the endorsed candidate who rolled him in the Liberal Party preselection after Mr Wilson had been the sitting member for nearly a quarter of a century. According to Mr Pratt, Mr Hill or somebody else in the Brown faction is trying to expel Mr Olsen from the Liberal Party. Mr Pratt has identified Senator Vanstone, who is coming into the chamber now, as one of his supporters. Then he gets stuck into the Liberal candidate for Adelaide and uses the most extraordinary language describing the nature of that candidate and the Liberal candidate for Sturt.

PARA.TAB: It is an amazing performance and we in the Labor Party in South Australia look forward to the next federal election campaign with considerable interest as Mr Pratt continues with the wondrous campaign he is conducting which is obviously more against the Liberal Party, of which he has been a lifelong member, than the Labor Party.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL

—Does Senator Schacht know what the level of youth unemployment is in the southern suburbs of Adelaide? The level of youth unemployment is 55 per cent in the southern suburbs of Adelaide. PARA.TAB: In that environment, Senator Schacht comes in here to try to win a cheap political point, taking himself back into his glorious days as State secretary of the Labor Party in South Australia. Let us just put that aside for the moment and look at the real question facing South Australian voters. TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order!

—You will be defeated in the seat of Adelaide; you will be defeated in the new seat of Hindmarsh; you will be defeated in the seat of Grey. I do not think you would even have the nerve to get up here and test your credibility—

—The Government will be defeated in the seat of Grey, at the moment it would be defeated in the seat of Kingston—that is the seat where there is 55 per cent youth unemployment—and at the moment I believe the Government would be defeated in the seat of Makin as well. PARA.TAB: The Government does not deserve to hold those seats in South Australia and honourable senators opposite are demonstrating today why they do not deserve to hold those seats. Mention was made of David Lindsay, our candidate for the seat of Adelaide. He is a highly respected, competent leader of his profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I quoted what Mr Pratt said about the Liberal candidate for Adelaide. I did not say that—I quoted Mr Pratt.
—Senator Schacht, there is no point of order, but if you claim to have been misrepresented you may do so.

—He is a former president of the Veterinarians Association in South Australia; he was a vice-president of the association for professional leaders in Australia. He is a community leader, is well respected, well regarded and will make a fine member for Adelaide. PARA.TAB: Would honourable senators like me to tell them about some of the other excellent candidates we have standing at the forthcoming election as well? Martin Gordon, who will win the seat of Kingston, is an accountant, highly reputable and hard working. Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I said to the honourable senator, and he knows, that occasionally candidates who fail at preselections become disenchanted and say things that are unfortunate. He was unsuccessful in one preselection and also in another preselection, and, therefore, he has taken this course of action.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht cannot talk about independents in South Australia because there are three independents in the South Australian Parliament and two of them recently had to be bribed by being made Cabinet Ministers to ensure the Government of their vote. One of them was made Speaker of the Legislative Assembly in South Australia and the other two were given jobs in the Ministry to keep them quiet. That is the way Senator Schacht's show operates in South Australia, and the people of South Australia have woken up to it. They are sick of it in South Australia. They were sick of Bannon and he got out—and not too soon. He knew what was coming out in the Royal Commission, which was highly critical of his leadership of South Australia and his failures in relation to the bank. And people of South Australia do not see his successor as being any better, because he was in the South Australian Ministry at the time of the bank's failure as well.

That is why the Liberal Party in South Australia is so far ahead in the polls, because people are angry at the economic incompetence which has cost them so much. That is the background. The only other point I wanted to make is to correct Senator Schacht in relation to Mr Olsen. There was no move at our last State Council meeting to expel John Olsen; no move at all. Mr Pratt was not at the meeting, Senator Schacht was not at the meeting. I was at the meeting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the press there?
—The press was not there, no.
—A secret meeting.

—It is not normally our practice—does the Labor Party have them at its meetings?
—Yes, always.
—Always?
—Order! This is absolutely fascinating but I wonder whether the whole of the Senate might be included in the debate.
—We have nothing to hide. John Olsen is doing a fine job in the shadow ministry in South Australia, as he did a good job in this Senate—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I tell you what, they will make a lot better government in South Australia than Senator Schacht's lot are doing at the moment. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having spoken with Party Whips, I seek leave to table for discussion purposes a draft Bill relating to toxic chemicals, together with notes on the draft. I was going to seek leave to make a brief statement, but I would be happy to seek leave to incorporate some notes relevant to this Bill. If the Senate would be happy for me to incorporate those notes, that would expedite the business of the Senate.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection—
—Could you repeat that?
—Sorry. I am seeking leave to table a draft Bill that has been cleared with the Whips, but I am also seeking leave, because of circumstances, to incorporate my notes to that Bill.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: NOTES ON DRAFT TOXIC CHEMICALS (COMMUNITY RIGHT TO KNOW BILL) 1992.
This Bill gives legislative power to a Registrar to obtain from industries using toxic chemicals information pertaining to their use, storage, handling, transportation, recycling and manufacture.

This Bill will not only provide for a National inventory of all toxic chemicals currently in use in Australia, but also the information relating to the health and environmental effects of toxic chemical use, reports from industry of toxic chemical releases, the production and disposal of toxic chemicals, reports on the emergency procedures that are in place and reports on methods of reducing the use of toxic chemicals.
The most important and fundamental object of this legislation however, is that all this information is to be made freely available to the community through the Registrar.

It is stressed that this Bill by no means overrides any other Acts. It does however make a significant contribution to enabling the free access of information to the community. Like the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 and the National Occupational Health and Safety Act, this Legislation will encourage uniformity of regulation by the States and Territories—something which is well overdue.

It is through the recent experience of Coode Island in Melbourne, that we have been reminded of the urgent need for this Legislation. This experience highlights clearly the necessity for the formal dissemination of information concerning toxic chemicals.

Had this Legislation been in place before the Coode Island disaster, not only would the people of Melbourne's western suburbs have been properly informed as to the exact nature of the chemical release, but the emergency services, media and the rest of Melbourne threatened by the plume of toxic smoke would have been informed as to the health effects and emergency procedures to be put into place.
In fact the final report of the Independent Coode Island Review Panel (March 1992) recommended that,

PARA.TAB: "the government agree in principle to a legislated Community Right to Know to assist public understanding of hazardous materials and the production processes.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no such formal legislative power at either State or Federal level in place at present.

Currently if someone wants to obtain information about toxic chemicals they go through the State Environment Protection Authority using the F.O.I. Act. This process has developed an inertia all of its own as ordinary people are expected to negotiate a bureaucratic minefield. Quite often the information is decided on a case by case basis (NSW), or the information is hidden behind the veil of trade secrecy.

This Legislation should not be considered to be an extension of F.O.I. It goes further by establishing the doctrine that toxic chemical information affects the whole community and as such the community has the right to obtain such data. It will no longer be the privilege of those whose vested interest it is to keep this information out of the public gaze.

In my state of Victoria there are a number of Legislative provisions which limit information about chemicals to the public. For example information on the types and quantities of chemical products is not available except through The Dangerous Goods Act and Dangerous Goods (Storage and Handling) Regulations 1989 which require appropriate HAZCHEM signs displayed on site or during transportation of chemicals. This provision is solely to assist emergency services and not predicated on any public interest principles.

There is not enough information on these signs to adequately inform the public of emergency procedures or health effects in case of disaster. Other Victorian legislation deal only with very limited and specific aspects of chemical use eg. The Agricultural Preparations Act 1958.

The community Right To Know Bill would centralise all information pertaining to toxic chemicals. It would establish a collection point where the community can access information without the maze of bureaucratic red tape.

The Australian Chemical Industry Council (ACIC) proposes, under its Responsible Care Program, implementing Community Right To Know as part of their 10 codes of practice. Questions are raised however, as to the effectiveness of such a proposal when there are a number of qualifications which compromise its effectiveness.

First, certain aspects such as emergency planning would be limited to discussion in consultative panels with plant management. The extent to which the information is disseminated would be confined to these panels and not to the public.

Secondly, the right to know would be subject to certain protections of privacy and commercial confidentiality and as yet there are no safeguards against abuse of those limitations to cover-up information which if publicly available would be a cause for concern.
This Bill is aimed at ensuring that the public is assured of the Right to Know while protecting commercial interests within clearly defined limits.

This overview has briefly highlighted the inadequacies of the current procedure for the public to obtain information on toxic chemicals and the dangerous precedent of allowing the chemical industry to initiate their own Community Right To Know policy.
The major elements of the Bill include;

1)The establishment of a Registrar, who collects information, as contained in the Objects of the Act, from the chemical industry and makes that information available to the public upon request. This will be done through the creation of an on-line data base, available at local libraries, a 008 phone number or through application to the Registrar's office. Studies both in Australia and overseas have shown that the chemical industry is unwilling to respond directly to community requests for information. Through the establishment of an independent Registrar these barriers will be taken away.

Only recently thirty companies in Melbourne were surveyed asking for information. To the shame of the industry only eight even responded. Fifteen of those companies belonged to the Chemical Industry body which claims to have its finger on the pulse when it comes to community health and safety concerns. Again if we look at the chemical accidents in the western suburbs of Melbourne 60% (19 out of 32) of all incidents were perpetrated by ACIC members.
2)Provision of information about emergency procedures, health and environment effects and reports on releases of toxic chemicals for public perusal and comment.

Clearly the environment would benefit greatly from the introduction of this Legislation. As a result of the publicly accessible data base and telephone hotline, the public would be able to discover hitherto secret information about toxic releases from chemical facilities. Facilities would report toxic releases to air, water and land. Already in the United States since the introduction of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act in 1986,

PARA.TAB: "the national toxins release inventory indicate that releases of toxic chemicals have decreased approximately 20% on average since 1987. In the State of California, chemical companies have completely stopped emitting six hazardous chemicals and emissions have decreased for two-thirds of all chemicals for which data is available." (Adams, P and Ruchel M. Unlocking the Factory Door! The Community Demands the Right to Know. Report to the Coode Island Review Panel; Hazmag March 1992.)

SPEECH.PARA: 3)Public involvement throughout the process of implementing and developing the framework provided for in this Legislation. For example, the Registrar will, in consultation with industry and community bodies, develop codes of practice regarding the safe production and use of toxic chemicals.

Obviously industry self-regulation, although attempting to have the community's interests at heart, does not have the required commitment to work openly with the public. This Legislation would make the chemical industry more accountable to the community. Through the provisions in the Bill the public can find out what chemicals a business is using. The Legislation would guarantee public access to chemical information for use in emergency response, pollution prevention and/or control and local community information or action groups. The information would also be useful for land use planning, insurance, property transfer or any other public purpose.

I should alert the Senate to the fact that the Bill has been subject to many months of community consultation. I am indebted to Mr Matt Ruchel of the Hazardous Chemicals Group in particular for assistance with the research which went into the initial draft. Mr Simon McRae of the highly respected international environmental organisation Greenpeace has also played a leading role in assisting me with the Bill.

The task of preparing a Private Senator's Bill is a great challenge because by its very nature it has to be prepared without the massive resources and expertise available to Government. In the case of this Bill, I doubt if it would have been possible to present it in time for the end of our 1992 sittings without the help of a Social Work Student Mr Tom O'Donnell, who was on placement in my office from July until October. Tom played a key role in involving community organisations with preparation of the draft and receiving responses once that draft was circulated.

I have to inform the Senate that as a result of this very comprehensive consultative process a large number of suggestions have been made to my office for the improvement of this Bill. In particular, there have been proposals to tightly regulate the availability of commercial secrecy provision to ensure they are not used to avoid disclosure of information about chemicals to the Registrar. These proposals have been borrowed from other jurisdictions where they have been effective.

Due to the limited resources available to my office and the time required by many people who provided unpaid advice in relation to the Bill, as well as the Christmas rush of legislative work keeping the Clerks of this chamber very busy, it has not been possible to fully redraft the Bill to include this valuable input. It is my intention to seek inclusion of those points by way of amendments at the appropriate stage.

This Bill represents an important step forward in the protection of the health and safety of Australians and the environment in which we live. It is an attempt to bring us up to speed with other parts of the world where there is now a realisation that both the environment and the human race are gravely at risk of extinction if we fail to develop a sustainable approach to the way we live. I look forward to the public debate which this Bill aims to engender with the resultant response from the Labor and Coalition parties as they grapple with the community's expectation that they place the health and safety of people and their living environment ahead of the profits of the large corporations which have come to rely so heavily on the chemical industry. This conflict is not new. Indeed, in the next decade, I doubt there will be any other political dynamic which will so dominate the thinking, discussion and action of our nations body politic. I look forward to further community response to this draft of the Bill and to eventual introduction of a Bill which I hope will receive the support of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I want to raise is that of foreign investment in Australia. In particular, I wish to raise the question of the level of foreign ownership which is allowed in our print media. There is no legislative limit on the amount of foreign ownership allowed in Australian print media assets. There is a reserve power vested in the Treasurer to reject any proposal concerning foreign investment which is judged to be contrary to the national interest, but this national interest test is so nebulous as to be virtually meaningless. There is basically a total discretion with the Executive and no parliamentary or other control on the decisions.

PARA.TAB: Recent media reports indicate that the Foreign Investment Review Board is currently or will soon be considering an application to allow an increase in foreign ownership of the Fairfax group. Mr Conrad Black is apparently attempting to increase his holdings above 15 per cent and the United States investors are also apparently seeking approval to raise their 5 per cent non-voting interest. The Australian public is completely shut out of the decision making process in this matter. As we have argued here many times, the media is a special industry. It is intrinsic to modern life in so many ways and the impact of the media on our culture and on the nature of our country is immense. Not only are our views on so many subjects and especially the rest of the world influenced by the media, but the image of Australia and Australians which is projected to the world is inexorably linked to our media, especially print media.

It is for these reasons that the Democrats support legislation which limits the level of foreign ownership of print media. We have such legislative control over radio and television that we may ask why newspapers and magazines should be treated differently? Mr Bryan Frith, writing in yesterday's Australian newspaper, made an interesting point when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It must be presumed that Canadian publisher Mr Conrad Black would not seek formal approval to lift his stake in press group John Fairfax Holdings to 25 per cent unless he believed it would be forthcoming.

The office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is reported as saying that no guarantees have been given. I say to him that sure, we all know about the policy making processes in the Labor Party. Prime Minister Keating decides all policy at the moment, often as a result of a bet with Senator Schacht. Who in the Labor Party is left to care that Caucus set the current limit only one year ago.

PARA.TAB: It is important to remember that it is Mr Dawkins, and only he, as Treasurer, who has the power to refuse the application. Legally Mr Keating has no status whatsoever. Mr Dawkins is on record as opposing any increase above the current arrangements. I think it begs the question what exactly has changed which would justify any alteration. Why have investors decided that now, of all times, is the appropriate time to apply for an increased holding? Normally this period is not good for investment; there is a lot of uncertainty on the outcome of the election and hence on the commercial environment.

Surely it is inappropriate that media ownership policy is influenced by the stage of the electoral cycle. If the Treasurer wishes to stop the increase he simply has to say so publicly. I would contend that silence demonstrates a new flexibility on this issue which cannot be justified by recent events. What is needed is a whole new regime of regulation of foreign investment in Australia and to that end I seek leave to table for discussion purposes a draft Bill and an explanatory statement proposing to reform the current foreign investment review regime.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I seek leave to have the explanatory statement incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill concerns a matter of great importance for the longterm development and security of this country. It concerns the economic sovereignty of this nation and it concerns the standards which Australia imposes on the international investment community. This Bill is not anti-foreign investment, it is unashamedly pro good foreign investment.

The Bill proposes to fulfil a promise made by the former Treasurer, Mr Phillip Lynch, on 1 April 1976 in the House of Representatives when the Foreign Investment Review Board was established. He stated:
"Initially we will establish the Board by administrative action. It is proposed that it be given a statutory basis as soon as possible.

Mr President, more than 16 years later, that proposal has been ignored by all of the 5 subsequent Commonwealth Treasurers. This legislation proposes to remedy that inaction by establishing an independent statutory Foreign Investment Review Commission.

The Commission will take over the existing responsibilities of the Board and it will obtain enhanced powers and responsibilities. I will detail those later, however it is important to consider how an independent Commission will differ from the current arrangements.
The FIRB has close administrative arrangements with the Commonwealth Treasury. There is a branch of the Treasury, the Foreign Investment Branch, which provides services to the FIRB.

The Board's primary function is to assist the Government in administering foreign investment policy. The Board examines proposals by foreign interests to undertake direct investment in Australia and advises the Government on whether they satisfy the existing guidelines and hence should be approved. So, in essence, the FIRB is simply an advisory body—the Treasurer has the final say on foreign investment matters.

There has been criticism that the Board is captive to the Treasury, which is under the control of the Minister. Thus even though the Board may act independently, there is always the appearance of the Board being captive to Government and hence being subject to political interference in its deliberations.
This cloud could be lifted by granting the Board statutory independence and that is one of the effects of this Bill.

A criticism which is levelled at the Board is that it is a "toothless tiger". Even in the relatively rare circumstance where the Board advises the Treasurer to impose some conditions on a foreign investment proposal, and the Treasurer agrees to such conditions, then there is absolutely no follow up to ensure that the conditions have actually been honoured. That is, there is no compliance function routinely undertaken by the Board.

Clearly this will weaken the value of any conditions imposed on foreign investment and should be remedied. A broad example concerns the development of land. There is a general condition in foreign investment policy that foreign investors cannot speculate on urban land holdings. Accordingly, acquisition of vacant real estate for development is generally allowed where the development occurs within 12 months. There are many examples in Queensland where this requirement has been breached yet no action has been taken against the investors concerned.

Clause 6 of the Bill specifically provides that one of the functions of the Commission is to ensure compliance by foreign investors with decisions made with respect to foreign investment matters. This will ensure that voluntary compliance by investors improves, and that the proper auditing of the conditions applied to investments will ensure that involuntary compliance will also be improved.

The Bill proposes to grant to the Commission both the statutory duty to consider all reviewable submissions on foreign investment and more importantly to make decisions in respect of those submissions.

Currently it is a matter of administrative practice that reviewable investment proposals are submitted to the FIRB. There is no statutory obligation that this occur. The Bill mandates that the investor must submit his or her proposal to the Commission.

The Bill also proposes to depoliticise the process of approval by granting deliberative powers to the Commission. The current advisory role of the Board will be replaced by a Commission with a deliberative power.

There are numerous reasons for granting a deliberative role for the Commission. Firstly, in practice the Board's advice is generally relied on and is the de facto decision maker. I believe that this reality should be reflected in the legislation.

Secondly, under the current arrangements it is impossible to find out whether the Treasurer acts on the advice of the FIRB or completely ignores that advice. This lack of transparency means that it is impossible to discern whether decisions are made on economic grounds or on political grounds.

To overcome this problem, it is proposed that, although the Commission will be granted a deliberative power, a reserve power to override any decision of the Commission will be left with the Treasurer. That is, the final say will remain with the Minister. The Treasurer may reverse or alter any decision and attach any condition to any decision, however any such reversal or alteration of a decision must be in writing and must be published in the Gazette and tabled in both Houses of Parliament, with an explanatory statement, within 15 sitting days.
This system will enable the public to be aware of the original advice on any proposal and the changes imposed by the Treasurer and the reasons for those changes.

Schedule 1 of the Bill proposes to codify the principles which must be used by the Commission in determining applications for foreign investment into Australia. The first of these is the net economic benefit to Australia of the proposed investment.

This should not be a contentious matter. Surely it is reasonable that Australia says to the world—we welcome investment from outside this country as long as there is a clear economic benefit to Australia, and the investment is not against the national interest.

The Government amended the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 during the 1980's to remove the "net economic benefit" test and replaced it with the deliberately nebulous criterion of "not contrary to the public interest".
Clearly this is ludicrous. Why shouldn't the Treasurer have the power to reject a project because it doesn't provide any economic benefits?

The Commission will also have an important power concerning public enquiries into any aspect of foreign investment in Australia. The Treasurer, or either House of Parliament will have the power to refer any foreign investment matter to the Commission for enquiry and report.
