Mr Kerin will also be writing to relevant members of the incoming Clinton Administration, the US Congress and elsewhere to draw their attention to the significance of this report and to enable some concerted approaches on these policy issues to be made to the Chinese Government. If that is not enough to satisfy Senator Bishop about the relevance, utility and importance of this report, I do not know what is.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen reports of the appointment of a senior Japanese executive to the position of both President and Chief Executive Officer of Toyota Australia Ltd, which follows the appointment of a US citizen to head Ford Australia? In both cases, the outgoing chief executives were Australians. Does the Government agree with a report in today's business press that the changes at Toyota confirm a drift in recent times from Australian to foreign chief executives in the local car industry? Does the Government have any concerns about the replacement of Australians in these very senior positions in this vitally important industry in Australia?

—Toyota has announced the appointment of Mr Toyofumi Nakagawa as its new President and Chief Executive. He will succeed Mr Robert Johnston, who has been elevated to the position of Chairman of Toyota Australia and becomes the only non-Japanese chairman in any part of Toyota's international structure. Mr Johnston's appointment is a significant achievement and one that is justified by his enormous contribution to the automotive industry in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to meeting Mr Nakagawa, who comes to Australia with a wealth of experience in bringing new passenger motor vehicle plants into operation. This will be very useful at Altona, where the new Toyota plant is being built.

It is true that Ford's new President in Australia, Mr John Ogden, is an American. Let us not forget that his predecessor, Jac Nasser, an Australian, is now not only Chairman of Ford Europe but also Vice-President of Ford's parent company in the United States, where he holds the highest position ever achieved by an Australian in the international automotive industry.I have met Mr Ogden. He is now committed to Ford's future in Australia.

As I said earlier, the automotive industry is an international business. Increasingly, Australia is becoming more integrated into the international strategies of the major car companies, which is reflected in export figures from Australia. This means that sometimes the Australian arms of the international car makers will be headed by Australians and sometimes they will not.

The commitment of the car companies to Australia is far more important than the nationality of whoever happens to be our local chief executive at any particular time. The important factor in determining that commitment is the policy framework that the Government provides for the development of this industry. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 December, Senator Watson asked me a question as Minister representing the Treasurer relating to taxation determinations. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Button—On 14 December 1992, Senator Watson asked, the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

Since Taxation Determinations are only Tax Office conclusions, contain no analysis and at times can be misleading, has the Australian Taxation Office a process of further evaluating Taxation Determinations with more rigorous analysis together with supporting arguments such that all Determinations will ultimately become formal, public rulings?
The Treasurer has provided the following response:

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) introduced the Taxation Determinations system to complement the Taxation Rulings system. Taxation Determinations are designed to publish quickly the ATO's interpretive and administrative policy.

Taxation Determinations usually address only one particular taxation issue. They are not meant to give a comprehensive analysis of the overall impact of the law. Determinations do not usually contain a detailed analysis of the reasons for the ATO's conclusions. However, Determinations generally state briefly the essential reasons for the ATO's views, including, if relevant, the main legal authorities relied upon.
As with Rulings, the ATO circulates draft Determinations to professional bodies and makes them available to the public for comment before they are released as final Determinations.
In a few cases the ATO may issue a Taxation Ruling explaining more comprehensively the view taken in a Determination.

Like Taxation Rulings, Taxation Determinations are generally `public rulings' for the purposes of the income tax and fringe benefits tax laws. As public rulings they are legally binding on the Commissioner of Taxation.
The ATO continues to evaluate the Taxation Determinations process so as to ensure Determinations achieve their desired aim of helping to clarify the taxation law.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 December, Senator O'Chee sought advice and supporting documentation clarifying what knowledge Austrade and the Ambassador in Copenhagen had concerning a proposal by a Danish company for the major piggery investment in Australia that has been exercising the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I now table those documents, together with an index and guide to them, as requested by Senator O'Chee. As the index notes in the documents I am tabling, five of the 76 documents in question have been withheld either in whole or in part on commercial-in-confidence grounds. I have, however, acceded to a request that I have received from Senator Hill's office that he be able to view those documents on a confidential basis.

In tabling the documents, I wish to point out that they show clearly that the series of allegations made by Senator O'Chee, based on his extrapolations of the contents of the Austrade memo of 22 November 1990, are all entirely unfounded, and indeed erroneous. These documents clearly show government agencies going about the work that they are supposed to do in creating trade and commercial opportunities for Australia. There is no impropriety here, nor any suggestion that the connections that the Opposition is seeking to draw between Austrade and the Prime Minister's piggery interests exist.

Throughout the life of the project from 1989 to 1992, Austrade offered its investment facilitation services where appropriate. This involved monitoring the project in Denmark and in Australia. Austrade worked to optimise the chances of the project which represented an important investment for Australia and which promised to generate substantial export income. It was also a project which was enthusiastically supported by the domestic industry and by various State governments who were seeking to have the investment located in their State.

The documents clearly show that Austrade worked to facilitate the investment, but did not at any stage give any assurance regarding its—Austrade's—capacity to resolve the quarantine issue. This was clearly left in the hands of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. The documents also show that, contrary to Senator O'Chee's suggestion, Austrade did not receive any application from the Danish company seeking quarantine clearance for the import of pigs or genetic material.

The reports by Mr Landos of AQIS that Austrade and the Ambassador to Copenhagen, Mr Benson, knew details of the project in September 1990 and detailed these to him during his meeting with them in Copenhagen during that month, are borne out by these documents. Their knowledge of the project was perfectly natural, given this background of domestic interest and appears in Austrade reports back to Canberra in May and June 1990.

As I have previously advised the Senate on 10 September, the Austrade memo of 22 November 1990, which reported advice from the Danish company that `all technical, principally quarantine issues, are resolved' was simply that—a report of advice that he had received. The documents also show that when this report was received in Canberra, Austrade sought to clarify this point and was advised that AQIS had told the DPIE that protocols had not been signed because in fact they had not been developed. DPIE felt that the Danish company was presenting an optimistic gloss for the benefit of potential investors. This was accepted by Austrade.

Finally, it has also been suggested by Senator O'Chee that Austrade was acting in the belief that the potential Australian investor involved the Prime Minister's company. These documents clearly show that neither Austrade nor the Ambassador in Copenhagen knew of any such involvement until it became public knowledge earlier this year.
Mr President, this squalid little exercise by Senator O'Chee has proved manifestly ill-founded and I table the documents accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop asked me yesterday about details of Mr Boucher's appointment. I asked her to put that question on notice. She has not done so. I did, however, have drawn to my attention yesterday by Senator Bishop that she had asked some questions about this issue back on 3 November which I had undertook to reply to when documents became available.

PARA.TAB: Lest she further mislead the Senate or anybody else about the status of this matter, let me say by way of answer to her question yesterday that I have now checked what I undertook to do on 3 November. I undertook first of all to table the document about the terms and conditions of Mr Borthwick's appointment. I did so the following day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without any figures in it.
—Senator Bishop has had her figures subsequently.
—No, I have not had the figures subsequently.

—Well, Senator Bishop will get her figures, if that is what she is still yelping about. She can have them. There is no mystery about it. They are a matter of public legitimate interest and they will go on the public record if they have not been to the Senator's satisfaction.
—There are some people in your Department who have a better conscience than you.

—If Senator Bishop already knows what it is about, I will not bother to table it. As to Mr Boucher, I did not undertake to advise Senator Bishop or to table documents about the date of his appointment by the Executive Council, but I am now, out of the goodness of my heart, willing to tell her that he was formally appointed by the Executive Council on 23 November 1992.

That is the normal practice and that is the practice that will be followed again on this occasion.

In the sense that Mr Boucher does not take up the position until March, I do not expect it will be until some time early in the new year that the matter is addressed, in particular, when Mr Boucher returns from his present sick leave and is able to address this and other matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sick leave?

—I am told he is on sick leave at the moment. That gives Senator Bishop some joy, does it? There has been no suggestion of which I or my Department are aware that Mr Boucher will be treated on anything other than absolutely a standard basis so far as this appointment is concerned. In particular, there is no suggestion that he be paid at other than his present substantive rate of remuneration, which is the normal basis on which these ambassadorial appointments are made. If that is not enough to shut Senator Bishop up and satisfy her about the good faith with which I respond to her inquiries, that is her bad luck.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. That language might be appropriate for Senator Evans to use in certain forums in the Labor Party but certainly not in the Senate. I ask that he withdraw the remark; it is unsavoury language.
—If Senator Evans will withdraw it, it might improve the debate.
—Withdraw what?
—The words `shut up'. I am not going to go through the words I wrote down at Question Time that I regard as unparliamentary, but there were plenty.
—It was the way he said it.
—If it was the way I said it, Senator Crichton-Browne is probably right; there was malice in my heart, if not in my expression. Under those circumstances, I withdraw.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I was asked a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training by Senator Brownhill about the Commonwealth Employment Service. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard rather than read it. It establishes that there is no content to the question raised by Senator Brownhill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I was asked a question by Senator Parer in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator COOK—On Tuesday, Senator Parer asked me a question about school leavers and unemployment in my representative capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I will answer that question now.

As the Senator is aware, the Government publishes its official forecasts for employment and unemployment in the Budget which are updated by the Treasurer from time to time. These forecasts do not provide details of the teenage or any other sector of the labour market.

Of course, the flow of school leavers into the labour market will temporarily increase the non-seasonally adjusted unemployment numbers. However, when considering the labour market, the Government uses the Australian Bureau of Statistics' seasonally adjusted figures which eliminate the effect of such movements which occur at the same time each year.
The Government does not anticipate unemployment figures for teenagers will show any appreciable increase over the coming months.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago Senator Knowles asked me a question about Med-Network Systems Pty Ltd. I have provided the honourable senator with a copy of the answer and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Knowles asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 16 December 1992:

I wonder whether I will ever get an answer to that question. I wonder who formed the company, why it was formed and who the directors were. The answer that the Minister provided to me in writing said that MedNetwork is no longer owned by any of the original shareholders. That was not my question. I want to know who the original shareholders were, who the shareholders are today and whether Mr Lawrie Willett from the HIC happens to be one of them. Was this tendered for? If so, on what basis? How did the whole thing arise?
SENATOR TATE—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

MedNetwork Systems Pty Limited was formed by IBM (Australia) Limited, the Health Insurance Commission and the Australian Medical Publishing Company Limited. (The Australian Medical Publishing Company is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Australian Medical Association.) Each of these three organisations were shareholders in MedNetwork Systems Pty Limited.

The company was formed because the shareholders considered that it presented a commercial opportunity for the sale of computer equipment and software to members of the medical profession. The software included a communication module which would allow doctors who wished to transmit their direct bill claims data to HIC via a "store and retrieve" mailbox system. This system ensured that data transmitted by a doctor to HIC could not be accessed by any unauthorised person.
Messrs G. Nash and D. Docherty (nominated by IBM)
Messrs C.R. Wilcox and W.J. Locke (nominated by HIC)
Dr B. Shepherd (nominated by the Australian Medical Publishing Company).

Mr L.J. Willett, general manager of the Health Insurance Commission, was a director of MedNetwork Systems, nominated by the Health Insurance Commission, from 4 January 1991 to replace Mr Wilcox who had retired as general manager. Mr Willett is not and has never been a shareholder in MedNetwork Systems Pty Limited or Cloud 10 Computerware Limited which subsequently acquired ownership of the company.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALK.START.PARA: —Late yesterday following a statement by me in response to a question asked by Senator Hill earlier in the day, I made a statement to the Senate. In discussion on my statement, further questions were put to me by Senator Hill and Senator Crane. As I advised the Senate at the time, I have obtained further information from Mr Speaker and the Joint House Department. Quite a number of detailed questions were asked and I was going to table a list of them because it comes to five pages, but I believe Senator Hill wants them read out, so I propose to do that.

PARA.TAB: I became aware of the accident in a meeting with the Speaker a couple of days after the event. At that time he advised me that he was considering taking legal action. I did not become involved in the process, nor would it be appropriate for me to do so. I say to Senator Herron that I will look at the Hansard, but if he implied that I had some input into the amount paid to the Speaker, I reject that absolutely.

Furthermore, the Speaker advised me that he was keeping himself at arm's length from the matter. I leave it to the judgment of the head of the Department, for which I am either singly or jointly responsible, to seek my assistance or decision if that is required. The Secretary of the Joint House Department did not seek my intervention in this matter and has assured me that neither he nor his officers discussed this matter with the Speaker.

One of the questions raised by Senator Hill which I will mention at this stage is contained in the following questions. He asked: will the Department make available the legal opinions upon which the assessment of damages and liability was made? Oral advice from the Australian Government Solicitor's office is that this information is covered by legal professional privilege and to release it could provide possible litigants with information properly the property of the defendants and their solicitors. Nevertheless, I have offered to provide Senator Hill, on a confidential basis, with copies of the legal advisings to satisfy himself that proper process was followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did we know what the road conditions were and the conditions of travel?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am going to go through the questions and answers now. Senator Hill asked the following questions to which answers have been provided:

INTERJECT.PARA: Q.The accident occurred outside the parliamentary precinct. I might ask you whether that is correct.
A.Yes. The accident occurred in the Canberra suburb of Hughes.
Q.Was it an exercise bike?

A.No, the bike was not an exercise bike. It was a Strida fold-up bike which was purchased to be used by members, senators, their spouses and children, and staff of the Parliament for recreational riding.
Q.Was the bike assembled outside the building?
A.It was delivered in fold-up form to the Speaker and unfolded by him.
Q.What was the basis of the claim? Why was faulty equipment being used by the Speaker outside the precincts of Parliament? We would very much like to know the nature of the fault in this equipment.

A.The fault was that the frame of the bike collapsed when the Speaker rode over a pothole. The issue of the Commonwealth being negligent arose because Joint House Department officers were considered by the barrister engaged by the Australian Government Solicitor not to have exercised their duty of care. The barrister believed that Joint House staff had possession of a manual on the bike and information from safety officials in the ACT which was not passed on to users. The manual stated, `Do not ride over kerbs or through deep potholes' and `The maximum load for the bikes is 100 kilos'. Because the Speaker's weight was thought by Joint House staff to be in excess of 100 kilos, this information and any other instructions should have been brought to the Speaker's attention. The Department should also have advised that care should be taken in riding the bikes because of their method of construction and different centre of gravity from ordinary bikes.
Q.Who authorised the payment?

A.After receiving a recommendation from the Australian Government Solicitor the Secretary of the Joint House Department accepted the recommendation and authorised a settlement for the amount recommended, that is, $65,000.
Q.I thought that an accident which involved parliamentary equipment would have been brought to the attention of the Joint House Committee.

A.Following the accident—four Strida bikes were initially purchased—the equipment was removed from use. This action was taken by the Department prior to legal action being commenced. Equipment failures or breakdowns are not normally brought to the attention of the Committee. Legal matters go to the administrative functioning of the Department and are not matters for the Committee whose role is to advise the Presiding Officers on the provision of services and facilities to members of Parliament.
Q.Why did the Joint House Department annual report not state that it was the head of the Department, that is, the Speaker, who was being paid the damages?

A.It is not the practice to identify the recipient of personal injury claims for privacy reasons but the Department identified the quantum of each claim settled in 1991-92 in its annual report for accountability purposes.
Q.What was the injury for which damages were paid?
A.The Speaker suffered injuries to both hands, his right elbow and face. The statement of claim relating to the injury states:

TAB.TAB: (a)fracture of the right radial head;
(b)severe right ulnar nerve entrapment and chronic ulnar nerve compression requiring surgery;
(c)development of myositis ossificans of the elbow;
(d)bruising;
(e)lacerations and abrasions;
(f)shock

INTERJECT.PARA: Q.What medical advice was given? What was the assessment?

A.This was personal medical information which was available to the Commonwealth's legal advisers. It is not appropriate for privacy reasons to publicly disclose this information which they assessed and took into account when recommending a settlement figure.
Q.What was the legal advice that the departmental heads—the Presiding Officers—received?

A.The Presiding Officers, in their capacity as heads of the Joint House Department, neither sought nor received any access to the Commonwealth legal advice. This was an administrative matter handled by the Secretary of the Joint House Department.
Q.The question of contributory negligence has not been addressed.
A.This was not an issue in this case.
Q.Details of the contract of hire.

A.No formal contract exists. The use of health and recreation facilities by senators, members and staff who do not pay an annual membership fee incurs a hiring fee of $2 per use. The Speaker was not a member of the facilities and paid the hire fee.
Q.Who made the decision that the Australian Government Solicitor act for the Department?

A.In the normal course of events the Joint House Department seeks advice from the Australian Government Solicitor on damages claims. In this case the Secretary of the Department thought it doubly prudent—because the Speaker had made the claim—that the matter be handed over to the Australian Government Solicitor to ensure probity in the handling of the matter.
Q.I should also like to know why the settlement was paid by the Department of Finance and not by the Joint House Department.

A.The Secretary of the Joint House Department has corrected earlier advice which he inadvertently provided to the Speaker and President. A form authorising payment based on advice and instructions from the Australian Government Solicitor was forwarded to the Department of Finance who issued a cheque on behalf of the Commonwealth and debited the Joint House Department contingency fund which provides funds to pay for claims and damages.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane asked the following questions to which answers have been provided:

INTERJECT.PARA: Q.How much was the total claim? Was it fully paid?
A.The settlement negotiated by the Australian Government Solicitor was for $51,205.55 damages, plus $3,794.45 medical expenses, plus $10,000 legal expenses—a total of $65,000.
Q.Was court litigation involved or was it settled out of court?
A.After negotiations lasting 12 months the matter was settled out of court in November 1991 after the writ of summons had been issued in the ACT Supreme Court but before proceeding to hearing.
Q.What were the legal expenses incurred by the Speaker?
A.After examination of the Speaker's solicitors' claims for costs the Australian Government Solicitor endorsed a claim for $10,000.
Q.Were they met by the Commonwealth?
A.Yes. They were included in the $65,000 settlement.
Q.Were any other legal costs involved in this matter which were met by the Commonwealth?

A.The Commonwealth met its own legal costs. The Australian Government Solicitor, as was the practice in 1991, did not charge the Joint House Department for its own costs. The Australian Government Solicitor engaged a barrister and passed the cost of $500 on to the Joint House Department. To assist in the consideration of issues arising in the case the Joint House Department obtained expert technical advice on the bikes at a cost of approximately $800.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, what you have put before the Senate is extraordinary; it raises many questions in itself. But there is only one issue that I want to raise and put to you in light of what you have said. It seems that what you have said is that the fault of the Commonwealth was not to advise the Speaker that there was an effective weight limit on the use of these bicycles. I understand that a woman from the health centre was on duty when the Speaker, Mr McLeay, came in to hire the bike and she refused to let him have the bike because he was more than 100 kilograms in weight. I am further advised that the Speaker later, undeterred, went back to the health centre during the lunch break so that he could hire the bicycle from another person who was unaware of the weight limit. I am told that the woman who gave the first advice to Mr McLeay that it was not a bike that was suitable for him to use gave a statement of the incident to the lawyers concerned. I ask you, therefore: are you aware of that statement? Also, now that you have been through the file in detail, can you tell us whether there is such a statement on the file?

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot do that because I have not been through the file in detail at all. The questions and the answers were prepared by the head of the Joint House Department and the Speaker, and I will get Senator Hill an answer for this.
—But we have to come up with every single bit before you will go through the files.
—There was an issue raised by Senator Hill, and I will get an answer to it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would have thought that the matter raised by Senator Hill was of the utmost seriousness. It may even be a sufficient defence to preclude any payment. In those circumstances, I would ask you to very urgently consider what material ought to be made available publicly. For example, it was said that certain documents attract legal professional privilege, including one in respect of which I think you said it was claimed by the defendants. That is certainly not the usual understanding of the term. It is a privilege normally claimed by the plaintiff. In any event, I would have thought that both parties could waive that privilege; in other words, in the interests of the public and given that we are talking about public moneys, both parties ought to be prepared to make all relevant documents available, including the documentary evidence in support of the claim and the medical reports. On the basis of the evidence we have, certainly from the scant nature of the injuries as described by you—and I would have thought you would have been in a position to have at least tabled the writ, which is clearly a public document having been issued out of the Supreme Court—it is very hard indeed to see the basis of the claim. For example, did it contain a claim for future economic loss, for any loss of earnings or any other pecuniary loss? If not, is that all meant to constitute pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, which is a very nebulous concept—one which Senator Cooney would well know, because he used to make these sorts of outrageous claims on a regular basis—which needs to be very carefully and independently assessed on the basis of expert evidence?

PARA.TAB: We would want to know whether there was an independent investigator's report into the circumstances of the injury. For example, I note that you say that the bike was assembled by the Speaker. It may well be that he did not assemble it as he ought to have done. He may not have done up the nuts as tightly as they should have been done up. In those circumstances, it seems extraordinary that you can say that contributory negligence was not relevant. Indeed, the onus of proof being on him, I would have thought that there were considerable difficulties confronting any plaintiff in these circumstances to show that somehow it was the fault of those who did not bring certain matters to his attention. He ought to appreciate, presumably, what can and cannot be done in riding a bike of this sort; he ought to test it before he gets on board; and he generally ought to take account of his own physical condition.

More importantly, it is absolutely impossible for anyone to make a judgment about the ultimate merits of the action without looking at all the relevant documentation. As an outsider, to me it seems an extraordinarily high pay-out. Certainly I would be amazed if it could be recovered in the normal course of negotiations for an injury such as this. We do not know, for example, whether the injuries had been substantially resolved or whether there is any permanent disability. Senator Herron, no doubt, is in a much better position to comment on this than others. But if we are talking about severe ulna nerve entrapment, I would have thought that that is simply a matter of an operation to clear the entrapment, and it does not necessarily follow that there would be any residual damage. Therefore, to merely say that there was a fracture of a right radial nerve does not tell us a thing. Was it an undisplaced fracture? If so, was there any continuing injury? Unless we know those matters, of course there is no basis for suggesting that it is a serious claim.

A figure of $65,000, or $50,000, on the face of it, for pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life—as Senator Cooney would well know—is something that one would normally be looking at if one was permanently and severely disabled. None of us knows the extent to which Mr McLeay is disabled—other than in his conduct of proceedings in the House of Representatives—but presumably he does not need an elbow or a wrist to enforce order even if he was so minded.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —On this particular matter, again the Senate is setting itself up as a jury.
—Not at all.

—Senator Alston has made comments and an analysis about the medical circumstances of Mr McLeay's injury. He has said it here and he has done it here, where there are two issues to be determined: first, whether the correct process in all this matter was followed, and Mr President's role in that; and secondly, having gone through those processes and established whether they are right or wrong, whether the outcome was an appropriate outcome. I think they were the two questions raised by this debate. In terms of the role of the President, I think he has behaved quite properly.
—You are just miserable because you wouldn't be allowed to ride the bike.

—This is why we cannot take this matter seriously. We have all the snide comments from Senator Alston and Senator Patterson, and all the rest, who open their remarks here by saying, `This is a serious matter'. Then they just sit here making snide interjections about the matter which have no relevance to the matter.
—He was told not to ride it.

—The jury over here has brought in the verdict—but I am going back to the question of process. What would be the appropriate processes in this particular matter? The first question is: does Mr McLeay retain rights that everyone else in this building has, or is he excluded from that? I think the answer has to be that of course he retains those rights. Maybe this debate would not be occurring if it had been some other person in the building that went through the same circumstances. So we agree on one thing, I think, across this chamber: that he retains his rights.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, though, he is in a different position from everyone else in this building—we also acknowledge that. He is one of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he is on a bike.
—Another snide remark from Senator Knowles. Why don't you treat this issue seriously.
—I am, very seriously; it is taxpayers' money.
—Well, just be quiet and make your contribution later!
—Order!

—We have established the fact that Mr McLeay has the same right as anyone else in the building but he is not in the same position. He holds an office in this building which would mean that the handling of any such matter would be far more sensitive and complicated than for the average person in this building. I think that is the second thing to be conceded. Therefore, when Mr McLeay wishes to proceed with a claim for compensation, how should it be best dealt with? Certainly not by himself; certainly not by Mr President. I think that the Joint House Department was quite correct to refer this to the Government Solicitor. I think it was quite correct that the adjudication on this was made at that level with the President and Speaker at hand's length having no involvement in it whatsoever.
—Supposing he had been told he was too heavy for the bike.
—I know that someone with Senator Walters's concentration span would not—
—And lack of intellect.

—I am talking about the process, not the result of the adjudication. I am trying to establish the case that the proper processes were gone through. The third matter, of which I do not have enough knowledge to comment on, is whether it is a fair figure, whether they considered everything, and all the rest of it. I do support the fact that in the initial stage Mr President should release that information to Senator Hill. He will then be in a position to say that there is no cover-up or, if he thinks there has been a cover-up, to pursue that third and critical issue.

PARA.TAB: But Mr McLeay retains his rights. He is in a special position compared with others, which can hurt his rights. The proper processes were gone through. Whether the result is right or wrong, is another debate to be had—maybe today, maybe now. I wanted to establish those other processes. Mr President, I believe, acted within the highest propriety of this chamber.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Ray. There are two aspects that need to be covered here; one is the process. Mr President, I find it absolutely extraordinary that you can wash your hands of this thing. You are the joint head of the Joint House Department and you cannot say that the matter was handled at secretarial level. If you were not informed and you did not have a hand in it—and I accept that assurance—it was derelict of the Secretary not to inform you as joint head of the Department. That is the Nuremberg defence—`I didn't know it was going on'. Mr President, you do not have that right. You are joint head of the Department. So what Senator Ray said was absolutely correct: there is a matter of process and, within that process, you are responsible, Mr President, with the joint head. You are responsible for the expenditure of taxpayers' money, and you cannot wash your hands of this matter.

PARA.TAB: The second point that I wish to raise is the appropriateness, as Senator Ray has said. Mr President, I would like to cite to you the compensation paid in each State to the dependent spouse of somebody who is killed in an accident. In my own State of Queensland a $77,470 lump sum goes to the dependent spouse after death by accident; in Victoria it is $108,640; in New South Wales it is $150,000; in South Australia it is an $80,000 lump sum and 50 per cent of the deceased's average weekly earnings; in Western Australia it is an $83,376 lump sum; and in the Northern Territory it is an $80,449 lump sum. Those are the amounts that go to the dependent in the case of death, and here we have $65,000 for an injury to an elbow.

Mr President, I can assure you that, from a medical point of view, a displaced fracture of the head of the radius with entrapment of the nerve and myositis ossificans—and that is just a bit of calcification in the bruise around the injury—as Senator Alston has said, is a not uncommon occurrence in that sort of injury. It is remedied by a simple operation to pull the nerve out and, at the most, it will give 10 per cent disability. I would like to know how much disability occurred in this case. That has not been answered. But $65,000 for an injury of this nature is absolutely exorbitant, it has no relation to the injury concerned, and I believe that there should be expert advice sought on that matter.

So there are two aspects, Mr President, as Senator Ray quite rightly said: firstly, there is the process, and you are attempting to take no responsibility for the expenditure of this sum of taxpayers' funds; and, secondly, there is the appropriateness of the sum that was given.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what Senator Ray talked about is happening here: we are becoming a jury. I am a man who has great respect for Senator Herron, but I believe he has made judgments and statements on the basis of facts with which he is not equipped.
—We have just been told.

—That is not so. This is a matter which is very much to do with the assessment of compensation in a court. A process has to be gone through. Senator Alston knows this. I thought his speech was quite a brilliant defence address but I think I would have got the money nonetheless.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron read out figures that indicate the compensation a widow would get on the death of her husband. Senator Herron would probably find that that was under a compensation system. As I understand what has been done here, and as Senator Alston will tell the honourable senator, this is a common law action. It is a quite different issue. If there is a common law action, and if that action is justified, widows would get a lot more than the figures the honourable senator has quoted. Those figures—not that the honourable senator would have intended this—are quite an unfair reflection on what is a common law action.

We have to decide in this chamber whether we want to go into the exercise of deciding what is a fair figure or otherwise. We can, I think, quite properly look at the way in which that amount was assessed in terms of who did it, whether the proper people did it, and whether the proper process was gone through. That is something we can look at. That is the issue that the President has dealt with.

It would be wrong for somebody who knows Mr McLeay, on the basis that the President does, to assess this matter. The President has stayed clear of that. What we can do—and there is no problem about this; I think we are entitled to do so—is look at whether the proper people made the assessment. As I understand it, a barrister, whom I take to be competent in this field, and the Australian Government Solicitor looked at the issue. We can look at issues such as whether they are the proper people to make an assessment. But I think it is wrong for us to be talking about whether the figure is fair on the basis of the evidence that has been given to us, because we are not in possession of all the evidence.

The fact that taxpayers' money—that is, money from Consolidated Revenue—has been used in the settlement to the Speaker should not be a factor which leads us to assess whether, on the evidence, a fair figure has been reached. Taxpayers' funds are paid again and again to people who have been injured as a result of the Commonwealth's negligence. So I simply say this: let us get around to the real issue. As Senator Hill said on AM this morning and during this debate, let us look at the process, and if the process is right let it go at that. But it is wrong to go into what is really an exercise for a jury. So I would propose that we proceed in the way Senator Hill has suggested.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say with respect that it has only become apparent today, notwithstanding statements put out by Mr McLeay yesterday, that the final decision to settle at $65,000 was made by Mr McLeay's subordinate. It was made by Mike Bolton, the head of the Joint House Department. I do not reflect, nor would I reflect, on Mr Michael Bolton. The truth of the matter is that Mr McLeay is his boss. Anybody who has been on the Joint House Committee will know how much he is his boss. It is an intolerable situation for Mr Bolton to have to sit in judgment on what negotiations should take place, knowing that he was still in the employ of Mr McLeay.

PARA.TAB: At the very least, with respect, Mr President, I would have thought that Mr Bolton, so as to remove himself from a personal relationship, should have referred the matter to the Joint House Committee, which is made up of every political party in the Parliament. It is, we are always reminded by Mr McLeay, but an advisory body, an advisory committee. I can think of no better an occasion than that for the advice of that Committee to have been sought. I note, Mr President, that you observed that that Committee is responsible for offering advice only in respect of services, facilities and amenities for members and senators. I would have thought that the provision of a bicycle would have fitted perfectly into that category.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly if the bike is defective.
—Yes. I notice in an article in today's Canberra Times the standard comment when information is being backgrounded to a journalist:

PARA.TAB: It is understood. . .

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on:
. . . that Mr McLeay had been taking the bike, a collapsible model, on a trial run near Parliament House as part of a mooted program of politicians using such bikes for commuting.
I must say that that program is a well hidden secret. The article continues:
When he had bumped against a kerb, the bike had collapsed underneath him.

I am not suggesting that that information came from Mr McLeay, but I rather wonder who else would have been able to provide that information to a journalist for the Canberra Times. I note the dedication to service of Mr McLeay—he was undertaking this project on behalf of all of us on Anzac Day, a public holiday. I note the generous contribution his family made, because I understand that his son was also undertaking this pilot project.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, Senator Ray is quite right when he says that Mr McLeay does not abrogate any of his rights simply because he takes on the responsibilities of the Speaker, any more than you do and any more than any of us do when we assume any responsibilities. But when he is elevated to such a position, he is required to balance his rights with his responsibilities. He is simply not an ordinary employee who has injured himself as a result of the conduct of his employer. I do not make any judgments as to whether the facts as presented by Senator Hill as a question are right. But I would have thought that by any measure the ordinary, average, intelligent person, in taking a dismantled piece of equipment—unless that person had some particular skills—would have asked for the instructions. I am certain that any responsible officer of the Parliament, if told that their particular frame did not fit the bike, would not have continued to ask for the bike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of entering this debate because I thought that the position had been adequately presented by Senator Ray and Senator Cooney, but there is one point that I wish to add to this debate. We have checked one fact that has been raised that was new and that was not contained in your response, Mr President. It was an allegation that had not been heard by anyone on this side. I want to say for the record that the Speaker, Mr McLeay, absolutely and categorically denies the allegation that he had previously been advised by anybody that he should not take the bike and that it was not suitable for him. He even denies that he went down to the health centre to get the bike. The bike was delivered to his office. His advice to us is unequivocal—that no such advice was ever offered.
—Is there a statement from the woman involved?

—The honourable senator's fanatical attempt to put something on the record that will damage the Speaker is one of the very good reasons why the argument was put by Senator Ray and Senator Cooney that it is entirely inappropriate for people here to rise and purport to make quasi-judicial determinations about the nature of the decisions that have been made by the Australian Government Solicitor in this matter.
—Why have you kept it quiet and hidden it?
—Probably because we knew that people like Senator Knowles would leap into the gutter with it as soon as it became available—and every such fear has been proved 100 per cent plus.
—A judicious response—
—No, I understand the question and the response. I enjoyed the response absolutely.
—So you knew all along?
—No, it came as news to me when it was announced. But I enjoyed the opportunity to make that response.
—So you did know about it all the way along the line.
—Compounding ignorance with misleading is not helpful.

EMPHASIS.TAB: An incident having occurred in the Gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —The chamber is in grave danger of significantly abusing its responsibilities with regard to this matter on a day when many senators will soon be getting up and expressing serious concern about how late we are sitting and about how much business there is. Then we will have the rural senators getting up and saying, `Why are you dealing with the rural issues so late at night? It shows that the Government does not care about them'. I can hear all the speeches now. I think we might even hear one from Senator Herron, yet here he is getting up and pretending to be contributing in a serious, professional manner to what is merely another heap of rubbish on the smear trail. The only reason I got up to participate in this debate—although I have enjoyed the opportunity—is to say that the way that further allegation was dragged across the trail without checking—
—You have known about it all the way along the line.
—Ignorance is no excuse for Senator Knowles.
—Why was it covered up?

—Not in the slightest. It is absolutely clear that the Speaker categorically denies that, and it is important that we put it on the record before the accidental misleading could have been compounded by people taking it up and pursuing it further.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Mr President, pursuant to standing order 191, I wish to explain some material part of my speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood.
—I didn't refer to your speech.
—Yes, the honourable senator did.
—I was talking about Senator Hill.
—I have written down what the honourable senator said.
—Yes, Senator Alston. You have the right to make a speech now.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—What Senator McMullan said in referring to me was that I have been making fanatical efforts to put something on the record that would damage the Speaker.
—By way of interjection you did.
—It wasn't in your speech.
—The honourable senator is compounding the allegation, and that is why I want to clarify the position.
—It wasn't in your speech.
—I just want to explain this.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Senator Alston has used one part of the Standing Orders to make an explanation whereas in fact the intervention by Senator McMullan was to his interjection. There is nothing in the Standing Orders that allows Senator Alston to get up and explain his interjection or someone's response to it.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Nothing was said by Senator McMullan using those words to suggest that he was only referring to an interjection on my part. He made a broad statement, which clearly is taken to refer to my speech, and I therefore seek to respond to it.
—Order! I think Senator Ray is technically right, but I find it very difficult to remember every single thing that was said. That is the problem that I have.

—Before dealing with Senator Alston's right to speak on this matter, can I speak to the point of order? There was not the slightest doubt in the circumstances that I referred to a further question which Senator Alston sought to drag across the trail by way of interjection. If he wishes to have leave to explain why he made that interjection, we will give it. That is the only matter to which I was referring and, therefore, the only matter to which properly he might respond now. If he wants leave to explain why he made that interjection, we will give it to him.

—I am not in the position of remembering whether it was an interjection or whether it was part of his speech. I think that in the circumstances it might be better if your contribution were very brief, Senator Alston.

—I simply want to say that we are not seeking to prejudge anything. We seek for all of the relevant material to be put on the record, including material that will go to the matter raised by Senator Hill. It is impossible for anyone to make a sensible judgment not just on the process but also on the merits of the argument.

PARA.TAB: I say again that $50,000 for general damages, on the face of it, suggests a very generous award. We do not want to say that it was not something that could ever be given to someone by way of settlement. We simply say that, faced with what appears to be a very high offer, the Government ought to provide the material to substantiate and justify it. That includes the material that would refute the matter that Senator Hill raised. Senator Hill suggested that a statement was made by this woman to the effect that there had been a complaint and that, indeed, the Speaker went and saw someone else who was unaware of it.

In those circumstances, I would ask that you, Mr President, go through the file and make this material available by way of tabling so that proper and sensible judgments can be made about the merits of the claim.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Alston has asked questions of the President at this stage about these matters. I do not believe he should get an immediate response from the President. The President can go away and think about the points Senator Alston has made.

—Order! The time for the debate has expired. I have no details of the court case whatsoever, but the legal opinions upon which the assessment of damages and liability were made have been delivered to my office. I have not even had time to look at them, and I now have another meeting. However, before I look at them I will immediately give them to Senator Hill's office.
—Can a copy be made available to the Government?
—Yes.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: no-one was given an opportunity to take note of answers. We went straight into a noting of the President's statement.
—So what?
—If it is going to be interpreted that way, I am deliriously happy. That is a half an hour we have saved.
—At the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to censure the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins).
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator MacGibbon, at the request of Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion to censure the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) for his persistent failure to immediately investigate allegations of irregularities concerning the Civil Aviation Authority TAAATS contract and his inordinate delay in establishing the Macphee inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the most serious motion we can move against a Minister and it is not one we move lightly. The charge is that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) was clearly negligent in the discharge of his duties and his responsibilities as a Minister of the Crown when he was the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. A Minister is answerable for the actions of his Department—not in minute detail, but in the overall. He is clearly responsible for the efficiency and the drive of that Department in fulfilling its duties.

PARA.TAB: It cannot be pleaded in the case of this Minister that he was ignorant of the charges that the Department was not operating in an efficient manner. It is possible, of course, given the complexities of some departments, on some issues for a Minister to claim in perfectly good faith that he has no knowledge of maladministration. Therefore, he is not obliged to vicariously accept any shortcomings of any of the officers or servants in his Department. But this was not the case with Senator Collins. Senator Collins had much advice on numerous occasions that things were wrong with the CAA TAAATS contract and he did nothing about it.

During his period as Minister, the chief executive of the Civil Aviation Authority, a Mr Baldwin, was appointed. The Civil Aviation Authority, on the advice of Mr Baldwin, abandoned contracts that were in train worth $200m and incurred $48m in cancellation costs—a cost which was borne not by the Department but by the public of Australia. The Department under Mr Baldwin embarked on an ambitious, new, nationwide air traffic control system. As soon as it embarked on this, irregularities became apparent in the way the selection process was going to be handled. Those irregularities were small in the first instance, but they became of increasing number and of increasing importance.

A number of questions were asked on both sides of the Senate about the process being followed by the CAA in this matter. Those questions were asked by individual senators and they were asked also by the properly constituted authorities, the Senate Estimates Committee, and by the Joint Committee on Public Works. Senator Collins never answered those questions in a responsible way. Furthermore, he never instructed his Department, the Civil Aviation Authority, to answer the questions that were properly put to it in the Estimates committees. He never advised people such as Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards that Parliament is supreme and that when Parliament directs questions through a committee to the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority they, like all other public servants, have to answer those questions fully, honestly and comprehensively.

The questions that were put to Senator Collins in relation to the Civil Aviation Authority were not trivial questions; they were questions that senators were properly asking in the public interest. It is history now that an independent inquiry, the Macphee inquiry, which reported yesterday to the Senate, found that the worst fears of this chamber were confirmed, that we were dealing with gross professional incompetence in the Civil Aviation Authority in the way it handled the TAAATS contract. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, must feel particular pride about your part in the Public Works Committee in the way you sought the truth in the expenditure of public funds on this matter.

The Parliament was completely vindicated by the report for the actions of its members. I quote an independent source, Miss Verona Burgess of the Canberra Times, who in the paper today praised the determination of backbenchers of this Parliament in relation to this issue. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: They persisted that something was very smelly against absolute and categorical denials by the former Minister for Aviation, Bob Collins.

What we have before us in this report is a devastating record of professional incompetence. The matter for the Senate to come to a decision on is: what did Senator Collins do about it? Every senator who challenged in the form of a question the activities of the Civil Aviation Authority was vilified or denigrated by Senator Collins. If there was not an attack on the questioners, there was an unquestioning support for the actions of the Authority, a support for its officers, for its activities. We were told incessantly that they were making the best of decisions and that it was of the highest probity.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at some examples of the way Senator Collins dealt with questions. In an answer to me he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I trust that the newspaper that gave such prominence to Senator MacGibbon's totally false assertion will give similar prominence, having read the Hansard, to my correction.
On another occasion, Senator Collins said:
I must say that there are similarities between the nonsense that Senator MacGibbon has run consistently in this debate.
He also said:
I hope that I will actually have the opportunity of rebutting the nonsense that Senator MacGibbon has delivered ridiculous point by ridiculous point.
Senator Collins turned on Senator Lewis as he turned on Senator Macdonald, Senator O'Chee, Senator Bishop and anyone else who dared to raise a question. He said of Senator Lewis:
Senator Lewis has done extremely well with that question—every single thing he said, without exception, was wrong.
He said:
Senator Lewis demonstrated a fairly profound degree of ignorance on this question last week but he has just exceeded himself, if that is possible.
He also said:
I have already stated in Question Time this week for Senator O'Chee's benefit—and it was lost on him because he is obviously not interested in the truth on this issue . . .
He also said:
I am afraid that the substance of Senator Lewis's question is completely wrong.
Senator Collins also said this:
In answer to that silly interjection from Senator Macdonald.
He also said:
For God's sake, if you just belt up I will finish the bloody answer. It will take a lot less time without stupid interjections.
Senator Collins said this to Senator O'Chee:
Calm down, Chicken Little.
Also he said:
Senator O'Chee told this absolute whopper.
Finally, on the business of personal attacks, Senator Lewis asked Senator Collins on 2 April:
Mr President, I ask the Minister if he will tender his resignation when the things that I have asked him have been proven to be correct.
Senator Collins said:
Senator Lewis, you are a mug.
Senator Collins went on to say:
The rank hypocrisy of the Opposition on this question—and it is pretty rank—would be demonstrated by a very simple proposition.
So much for the personalities.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the way that Senator Collins defended the Civil Aviation Authority. He said on another occasion:

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of nonsense has been delivered in this debate about Thomson.
Then he said:

I want to get one thing absolutely clear. The officers of the CAA have been constantly vilified and defamed in print. I think it is outrageous that Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards were named in a newspaper the other day as having hijacked this matter and made decisions about it. They did nothing of the sort.
He said:

A number of claims have been made about irregularities, some of them quite extraordinary and defamatory, in aspects of the process followed by the CAA in relation to this project. There is no evidence to support any of those claims.
Further Senator Collins said:

On behalf of the Australian taxpayers, I am pleased to say that in extracting the best value for money it is a very sensible way to proceed. During this 18 week phase the CAA will have the opportunity of extracting from the preferred tenderer the maximum benefit to Australian industry.

We now come to the piece de resistance. This final quote, which typifies Senator Collins's approach to the discharge of his duties as a Minister of the Crown, comes from an Estimates committee hearing on 31 March. The question from a senator to the Minister was:
Is the Minister entitled to answer questions that he anticipates we will not ask, or is he there to answer the questions we ask?
The response from Senator Collins was:
I am here to do what I bloody well like, frankly.
So much for the way that Senator Collins has discharged his duties as a Minister.

PARA.TAB: Most senators in this chamber would never use the intemperate language that Senator Collins has used. But I defend his right to defend his position as a Minister defending his Department and the actions of his departmental officers. That is not the point at issue.

Senator Collins failed in the face of voluminous, repeated and informed questioning as to what was going on in the process being conducted by the Civil Aviation Authority. He dismissed those questions in the way that I have demonstrated with all those quotes from Hansard—and they form only a small sample. Senator Collins failed to demonstrate prudence and commonsense in finding out whether there was any substance in the questions that were being asked.

In Senator Collins's defence, he has made two points. We have heard him defend his actions on numerous occasions. First, he attacked me on the grounds that I had alleged corruption against officers of the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —And me.
—I made an interjection that I regret. I am quite happy to withdraw that I asked him on one occasion whether he—
—You said, `How many kickbacks have you had from Thomson?'.

—The interjection that I made about Senator Collins was, `What are you getting out of this?'. It was after he had demonstrated a particular point of irrelevance in his answer, and I apologise for it. It was an intemperate remark at the time.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with Senator Collins's general allegation that I have alleged corruption against the officers. I have never alleged that at any time. I will read out from Hansard the only time when I have referred to corruption in this Senate or outside. On 5 May in the Senate, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken an interest in many tenders since I have been in this place, and I have never seen a selection process conducted like this one. I say to my colleagues that I do not like what I see here. I do not see why the Parliament and the people of Australia should tolerate such a process for one moment.

PARA.TAB: On many occasions I have been aware that there are disappointments at the outcome of tenders. On occasions I have raised my concerns about the outcome of a selection process, but I have never before heard any criticism of the integrity of a selection process that the Commonwealth entered into, let alone any allegations of corruption.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the relevant words:
I am now hearing allegations of corruption throughout the aviation industry and in the wider community as to the way this tender was handled.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether those allegations are true. I have an open mind on the issue, but it is intolerable that the Parliament should find itself in this position where it is accountable at the end of the day for the funds involved.

SPEECH.PARA: It is perfectly true that there were many allegations in the general community about corruption, which led to my raising that as a concern. So Senator Collins's first defence is false.

PARA.TAB: His second defence could be aptly titled `The Bannon defence'; he did not want to know what was going on in the Department. Senator Collins has made great play in this place that he will not interfere in a commercial decision made by any of his departments. That is perfectly true—no Minister should do that—but it is absolutely beside the point. We are concerned about process—how the Department came to the decisions it did, not about the decisions themselves. That point seems to escape Senator Collins.

Senator Collins failed dismally to honour his obligations as a Minister. When he was told repeatedly that something was wrong with the process, he failed to investigate and to find out whether there was any substance to those claims or allegations. That is his crime, and that is where he fails as a Minister.

If we move back several hundred years and make a hypothetical case of Senator Collins being of noble birth and of an armorial family—one which had a coat of arms—the coat of arms of Senator Collins would have on it a dying, wounded water buffalo. He has been unintelligent, uncaring and irresponsible in his approach to his ministerial duties. Any criticism has been met by a bullying response without thinking about whether there might have been substance to it or whether it was in the public interest that questions were asked.

As a Minister and a member of the Executive, and therefore as someone who is accountable and answerable to the Parliament for the exercise of the great powers and privileges that he has as a Minister of the Crown, Senator Collins has failed to exercise those powers responsibly. He has failed the test of accountability before this Parliament, and that is why the Opposition moves to censure him today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the years, censure motions have become such degraded currency in Parliament that they are now worth nothing. I have to confess that I have added to that process myself—
—You don't take them seriously.

—I do not take this one seriously. I spent 10 years in opposition. I guess that I moved more censure motions against Ministers in my five years as leader than I have had hot dinners. This is a classic example of the degradation of the value of a censure motion, which is probably why Senator MacGibbon did not have much heart in his address. But I welcome this censure motion being brought on, because it will give me the opportunity today to place a few facts on the record that perhaps should be placed on the record. My involvement in the tender is not mentioned anywhere within the Macphee report. My remarks will perhaps put into context some of the statements made by Senator MacGibbon.

PARA.TAB: Senator MacGibbon said, when quoting me, that he was quoting just a few examples. That is certainly correct. He quoted from a few examples, but he quoted many of them out of any context whatsoever; they were not put into context at all. I have to say that I am pleased and appreciative—and I mean that sincerely—to hear Senator MacGibbon's apology to me today in the Parliament for his accusation that I had received corruptly kickbacks from Thomson in respect of how this project was managed.

I accept that apology in the spirit in which it was given and I am appreciative of it today. I am glad he has made it, because whatever I have said about this project in response to the comments made by Senator MacGibbon has been delivered in the context of, `Oh, well, I said some hard things'. The reason I said some hard things—and Parliament is not a sheltered workshop—is that some very hard things were being said, as Senator MacGibbon has now indicated, on the other side.

Not only has this been laid bare by the Macphee report, but also there is one huge hole in this censure motion. Mr Macphee was given the broadest terms of reference possible. Not only was he given the broadest terms of reference possible, but also the Minister made it clear in here—and was commended by Mr Macphee in the report for doing so—that if there was any restriction whatever on Mr Macphee's investigations, the terms of reference would be further modified so that Mr Macphee could investigate anything he liked.

It is stated in the report that Mr Macphee was given access to all of the Hansard records of all of the committees and all of the proceedings here in Parliament. It was absolutely open to Mr Macphee, and in fact it would have been obligatory upon him in investigating this matter, to have mentioned my role in the report should he think it necessary in terms of any dereliction of duty on my part, and certainly to have questioned me and spoken to me about the role that I played. It was totally open to him to do that—and Senator MacGibbon knows it—and he chose not to, and rightly. Nowhere does that appear in the report and until today I had not even met Mr Macphee. There is no censure or criticism of me here in the report, and rightly so.

I want to place a few facts on the record about my involvement. We have set up these government business enterprises deliberately at arm's length from the Government so that there will be no political involvement in the letting of substantial tenders. Those opposite can criticise and attack that process if they wish, but they cannot reasonably attack Ministers for complying with their statutory obligations under those processes and for not interfering in the tender process.

There is one thing I have no doubt about at all. I am here this afternoon debating this pathetic censure motion and being censured because I did not involve myself. Had I done so—had I directly interfered—there is no question whatsoever but that I would be in here being censured as Senator Bolkus was for interfering in a tender. Senators might like to refresh their memories from the Hansard of 13 May 1991 when Minister Bolkus was being attacked in here by his shadow opposite, Senator Parer. Senator Parer said:

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister that he. . . improperly intervened in the tender . . .
In fact, Senator Panizza joined in and said that the Minister's actions had put the tendering system in jeopardy.

PARA.TAB: What was Senator Bolkus's action? He involved himself in a tender for the purpose of ensuring that an Australian company would have an opportunity of tendering. For doing something as commendable as that he was dragged over the coals in here by the same canting, hypocritical, mewling, puking Opposition which is in here today taking me to task for, in fact, doing precisely the opposite. It is hypocrisy of the worst kind. I will state now what my involvement was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I take exception to being referred to collectively as `mewling, puking Opposition', and I ask the Minister to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—I am sorry, Senator Calvert, I did not hear it. Would you repeat your assertion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I called them `mewling, puking Opposition'.
—It verges on disorderly, Senator Collins.
—I withdraw.
—You said Baldwin was professional.

—Let us have a look at my involvement in the process. I had one direct and aggressive involvement in this tender process. Not only do I not apologise for it, but also I properly advised the Parliament of it.
—Protecting Baldwin.

—I wonder whether Senator Macdonald could stop his non-stop interjections. My involvement was to ensure that there was Australian involvement in this project. That was one of the issues which led me to begin the process of establishing what became the Macphee inquiry. I acted responsibly and that is where this censure motion falls absolutely to the ground. It falls down not just on the hypocrisy of attacking me for not involving myself in a tender when those opposite were in here attacking Minister Bolkus for doing exactly that, but also it falls down on what my involvement was. I will explain it to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I had a great concern that Australian industry got the maximum benefit out of this and I explained it directly to the board and to the Senate in this way. I said that my primary concern was that the board got for the CAA and for Australia—and Senator MacGibbon knows better than most people in this chamber how urgently it is needed—the best state-of-the-art air traffic control system that we could get on price, budget and so on. Secondary to that—and not by a long margin, but by a short margin—was that Australian industry should have the maximum involvement in that project. I addressed the board twice on that issue in very formal terms and told the board that, whichever tenderer was successful, so far as the Government was concerned, the tenderer had to be mindful of the maximum involvement of Australian industry in that tender.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're hopeless.
—Senator MacGibbon may be interested in this, even if Senator Macdonald is not.
—Say that again.
—I do wish that Senator Macdonald would stop ceaselessly interjecting; it is very disorderly.
—What did you say?
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you are distracting the Minister.

—I have to say—and I said this to the board—that I would have been delighted if IBM had won the contract on those grounds of Australian involvement. I was not suggesting for a minute that it should get it but, as the Minister, I would have been delighted if the board had taken that decision, because IBM employs 4,600 Australians, it has been established in this country for 60 years and it already exports hundreds of millions of dollars worth of product from this country. I had no dispute—as the Macphee report had no dispute—with the technical evaluation process rejecting IBM. As Senator MacGibbon knows, IBM operates on technology from the sixties which is currently being phased out in the home of IBM, in the United States. It was on those grounds that IBM was taken out of the process—a matter that Mr Macphee found perfectly appropriate and correct.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the process we had two front runners. Clearly, these critics have not read the report. Certainly Senator O'Chee has not read it, and I will get on to the outrageous press release that he issued yesterday. Hughes and Thomson were the front runners and Mr Macphee said that was also correct and proper. That is the correct decision that the board should have made; they were the front runners. It is a fact that they were neck and neck. An examination of the technical evaluation process shows that, because on every single criteria on scores out of 100, they were literally points in front or behind. As Senator MacGibbon knows, it came down to that very important issue—as it turned out to be in the minds of the board members—of the actual number of lines of computer code that were contained in the flight data processing components of the system itself. That was an extremely important consideration in the minds of those members. That is how close and how tight it was.

Mr Macphee finds, again correctly, that both companies produce a high quality product which works well. Again, to put into context a lot of those quotes from me, as well as making outrageous accusations of corruption—which Mr Macphee has laid absolutely to rest in this report—outrageous statements were being made about the operation of Thomson Radar. It would have been irresponsible of me as the Minister for aviation to have not strongly rebutted those claims, because Thomson Radar, as well as operating the air traffic control systems in 46 per cent of the world outside the United States and in the whole of New Zealand, also operates air traffic control system in Cairns, Coolangatta, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth where the people flying into those ports are also interested in a bit of safe flying.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many software programs have been changed?

—Senator Calvert should read the report; it is contained in there. The non-stop public statements of Senator O'Chee, in particular, about unsafe flying conditions at Cairns, in particular, and his predictions that aircraft were going to collide in the air over Cairns were outrageous and had to be strongly rebutted. I am pleased again to see that the Macphee report has absolutely and categorically laid those to rest. I will refer to the section of the Macphee report which deals with the constant accusations by Senator O'Chee that the Thomson system was unsafe. That was a very brave statement to make publicly. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: The controllers have many year's experience in procedural control. In the Review's opinion, the political and media attention given to the difficulties at Cairns and Coolangatta exaggerated the seriousness of the problems being experienced.
The conclusion, in emphasised type, says:
The Review is satisfied that the software problems, although serious, did not create a threat to air safety.

Another section of the report indicates that the Thomson systems in all of these places are operating satisfactorily as I—having visited the towers and spoken not just to the controllers but also to the technicians, and having viewed as a responsible Minister the problems in those places after they were reported—was satisfied they were. I was not simply acting on the appalling statements of Senator O'Chee. I personally investigated the matter and was assured by the controllers and the technicians on the site that the radars were operating as safely as Mr Macphee said they were. The person who should be censored in here is Senator O'Chee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—Senator O'Chee should listen. Senator O'Chee issued a press statement yesterday in response to the Macphee report. Unbelievably, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: There have been many doubts expressed about the Thomson radar system. The Australian travelling public can now have very little confidence left about the system.
