SPEECH.PARA: I want to briefly address the annual report of the Tobacco Research and Development Council in order to say something that I have said many times in the past; that is, that this Government has been prepared to ban tobacco advertising in Australia, except in respect of certain favoured events which will bring in the major tobacco sponsorship to Australia. I refer, of course, to the Adelaide Grand Prix, Eastern Creek, Mt Panorama and those sorts of things. What sticks in my throat is the fact that this Government puts $413,000 from this year's Budget into tobacco research. While it may be a legal crop to grow and a legal product to sell, this Government has banned the advertising of it. We have supported that. My colleague Senator Herron knows far better than I do the effects of tobacco advertising. But I believe that if we are to ban tobacco advertising we should ban it completely; we should not ban it very selectively.

PARA.TAB: I stood up to point out the Government's double standards not only on advertising but also in respect of the tobacco industry in that the Government gave it $413,000 out of Consolidated Revenue. It is not a matter of giving back to the industry funds that it had contributed through being levied at the rate of .05 per cent of its gross production. As far as I am concerned, these are the industry's own funds and the Government is merely giving back that money in order for it to be used. But in this year's Budget $413,000 is provided for tobacco research. If the use of tobacco is so bad—and I believe that it is; Senator Herron, an eminent surgeon from Brisbane—

TALK.START.PARA: —Very eminent.

—Senator Herron, a very eminent surgeon, has told us about that, and I go along with him. I have had the experience of seeing some of my relations die from tobacco smoking. Indeed, my mother-in-law died of passive smoking, I believe. But here we have a double standard in that the Government puts $413,000 into tobacco research at the same time as running around banning tobacco advertising. This Government—and any future government—has to address that. The Government should stay with one standard rather than run with the two. The Government has to make up its mind whether the tobacco industry is needed in Australia and whether it should be encouraged in Australia.

PARA.TAB: At an Estimates Committee hearing when I asked a question on this matter of Senator Cook he said that tobacco was a valuable export crop for Australia. If it is, the Government should be doing something different in regard to tobacco advertising. The Government is doing the right thing on tobacco advertising as long as it is doing the same thing right across the board—but if smoking is so unhealthy it should not be subsidising or paying money for research for the continuation of growing tobacco. I thought that I should again bring that matter to the attention of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report for 1991-92 of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, I commence by congratulating the Agency on an excellent report. It is not without significance that the report observes that the Secretary of the Senate Committee that deals with annual reports informed the Agency that its annual report for 1990-91 was used as a model for other authorities.

PARA.TAB: This is a very comprehensive report and I will refer to just one or two matters in it. First of all, I take this opportunity to congratulate the Chief Executive of ASDA, Steve Haynes, on his award of best administrator at the recent Confederation of Australian Sports awards in Melbourne. I think that was a reflection not only of his excellent administrative capacity but also on the contribution that he is making to sport in Australia generally.

Having said that, I observe that the report draws to our attention that litigation is presently taking place between Martin Vinnicombe and the Agency. One of the difficulties confronting sporting associations and authorities is that, notwithstanding the fact that athletes may be detected for having ingested performance drugs of a bad nature for which they should be suspended from competition, they have on a number of occasions been able to resort to the courts and have their ban overturned on appeal. The difficulty in some cases is that a number of the sporting authorities simply do not have the funding available to them to properly and adequately defend the original administrative requirements and decision. I note that an American athlete named Reynolds, commonly known as Butch Reynolds, who was detected for cheating has now sued the International Amateur Athletic Association for several million dollars. That just shows the difficulty that sports officials and administrators have in ensuring that the provisions are correct in order to enable them to properly eliminate the cheats in sport, of which Mr Reynolds, of course, is one.

I refer also to appendix 12 of the report which draws to our attention the matter of clenbuterol. This is a drug which is used by asthmatics. It is in the beta category and it is also an anabolic agent. A number of athletes have used clenbuterol because they believed that it was not particularly proscribed on the IOC doping list. However, the IOC practice of including `and related substances' means that that possible loophole does not exist. However, it is not without significance that there is at least one Australian athlete who has been detected as positive for using clenbuterol for the purpose of enhancing his performance who is now appealing his suspension. I suspect that that will embroil Athletics Australia in very large costs. It is a pity that the IOC did not take up the matter of clenbuterol earlier so as to clarify the situation, because it was drawn to its attention by the Canadian drug agency. However, the IOC did absolutely nothing about it for something like 18 months. Now various sporting bodies around the world find themselves confronted with that difficulty.

I conclude by quickly drawing to the Senate's attention appendix 3, which refers to our memorandum of understanding with Canada and the United Kingdom concerning reciprocal development and enforcement of measures against doping in sport. I can only say that until such time as we have arrangements of that nature including China, America and all the European countries, we will not eliminate the cheating at the Olympic Games and our own Australian athletes will continue to be disadvantaged, given that we have the most rigid regime in the world. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to appendix 8 of this report on the Australian Sports Drug Agency, which outlines the difference between the States in the manner of applying penalties for the taking of anabolic steroids. It is quite remarkable that the Australian Capital Territory has a very low level of penalty and very moderate laws to discourage people from taking anabolic steroids. It really is quite striking that in the Territory in which the Federal Parliament exists, and where there is a determined bipartisan approach against the taking of steroids, we have an administration that appears to take a remarkably lenient view.For example, this question appears in appendix 8:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Is it an offence for unauthorised supply of anabolic steroids through pharmacies?

We see that in Tasmania and New South Wales, there is a $2,000 fine—or in New South Wales, two years gaol. In Queensland, the fine is $1,200. In Victoria it is $5,000. In Western Australia it is $100,000 or 25 years gaol. In the ACT it is $200. That is disgraceful.

PARA.TAB: A further question is stated in appendix 8:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.A) Is it a requirement that a pharmacist is required to keep a record of all prescrip. dispensed?
In the ACT the fine for not doing so is $40. In Victoria, it is $5,000 or 12 months in gaol. In New South Wales it is $800 or six months in gaol.
3. Are all wholesalers of veterinary and human scheduled products licensed? B) Veterinary products?

I mention veterinary products because many drug takers appear to be taking them. In all States, it is required that they be licensed. In the ACT, the fine for not being so is $200. In Western Australia it is $100,000 or 25 years gaol. In Queensland it is $1,200. In Victoria it is $2,000. Question No. 4 of appendix 8 states:
4. Is it a requirement of the wholesale licence that supply of scheduled products can only be to a licence or permit holder?

Breaching that brings about a fine of $1,200 in Queensland, $2,000 in Victoria, $100,000 or 25 years gaol in Western Australia—and in the ACT, $200. It seems to me that this sort of thing is totally unacceptable, particularly when we come to question No. 7:
7. Is possession of S4 substances such as anabolic steroids an offence?

In every State and Territory of this nation except the ACT, it is an offence. Something has to be done about this. It is regarded so seriously that all of the other States have very high penalties. PARA.TAB: There is a lot more in this schedule. All I do is plead with the ACT Administration to fix this mess up.

PARA.TAB: Those figures will not show up in this report on the operations of the registered health benefits organisations. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired for consideration of Government documents.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 17 of 1992-93—Health Insurance Commission—Medifraud and Excessive Servicing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's Report No. 17 of 1992-93 on medifraud and excessive servicing is a particularly significant report, one that we have been waiting on for a very long time. The first I heard about the investigation into medifraud was some three or four months ago and it has taken a considerable length of time to actually drag, reef and haul out of the Government the information that is now contained in the Auditor-General's report.

PARA.TAB: It is a very sad state of affairs, because what we have really found is that the recommendations that were put to the Health Insurance Commission over 10 years ago have been almost totally and utterly ignored. We have actually seen in the past year, 1991-92, around $4.6 billion of Medicare fraud. One can only imagine what the unemployed could do in terms of job creation with $4.6 billion. Of course, the recoveries for fraud have been but $1m. Over seven years, 43 providers have been prosecuted. It would be very easy for any government to slip into a situation of doctor-bashing. I do not believe it is the doctors who are primarily at fault; it is the system that is clearly at fault.

One notable omission from the Auditor-General's report tabled tonight is the question of bulkbilling. When we are talking about such colossal amounts of money it is just amazing that the whole question of bulkbilling has not been raised. As my colleague and friend, Senator Herron, who of course is a notable surgeon, will probably mention later on, the ability for fraud under bulkbilling is just enormous. The key findings of this report are as follows:

There was a lack of prosecutions and disciplinary action . . . The performance of the Commission, with the exception of the last twelve months, shows little improvement over that of the then Department of Health in the early 1980s.
The Commission's legislative powers to combat fraud and excessive servicing are deficient in regard to the investigation and prosecution of unethical medical providers.
Medical Services Committees of Inquiry, the main disciplinary bodies, were not operating effectively. . . .

The growth in Pathology Benefits has slowed to the extent that there was a marginal decrease in expenditure in 1991-92 compared to 1990-91. However, Diagnostic Imaging expenditure is still escalating . . .

The ability to release information for investigation is important in preventing medifraud and the Commission has been reluctant to fully utilise its powers under the Health Insurance Act because of uncertainty about the effect of privacy legislation. A comprehensive policy is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's report recommends a number of changes, particularly in the legislative areas. Legislative weakness is cited as one of the greatest difficulties in enabling the Health Insurance Commission to pursue medifraud. Of course, there is also a need to have competent investigators.

PARA.TAB: We see in the Auditor-General's report, as we saw in the Harvey Bates report—the private consultant's report undertaken as a precursor to this report—that the Health Insurance Commission was particularly lax in pursuing and investigating within the guidelines that it had at the time. It was also lax in taking up the recommendations of the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which in the mid-1980s pursued a number of reports dealing with fraud and overservicing.
That Committee's reports reveal a number of factors which affected the Commonwealth health budget at that time. According to the Auditor-General, these factors included:
legislative weaknesses
prosecution difficulties—e.g. problems associated with collecting admissible evidence
Medical Benefits Schedule—e.g. lack of clarity
technological advances, especially in regards to pathology
oversupply of doctors, and
entrepreneurial fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: But one of the notable omissions, even from this collection of recommendations of the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts back in the 1980s, is the question of bulkbilling—and that question simply cannot be ignored.

PARA.TAB: It is a great pity that the Government has continued to try to hide what is going on in respect of medifraud. Recently I persisted and persisted in my efforts to get a copy of the consultant's report. I find it absolutely amazing that the Government is developing in this Parliament the practice of absolutely and utterly ignoring parliamentary requests. That has happened on this occasion just as it happened recently in respect of other documents. This Senate has requested the tabling of certain documents, yet the responsible Minister has said no.

There is absolutely no reason why Mr Howe should have said no to the request made a number of weeks ago for the Harvey Bates's report. It was alleged by him that it would teach people how to commit fraud. It certainly did nothing of the sort. What we are seeing today in the Auditor-General's report proves exactly that. If he was trying to conceal parliamentary inactivity by the Government, then that is one thing. If he was trying to conceal the inadequacies of the Health Insurance Commission, that is another thing. But simply to use the excuse of saying that it would teach people how to commit fraud is totally and utterly misleading.

What we are seeing in this Auditor-General's report is most disturbing, because money is being wasted and fritted away at a time when this country cannot afford it and a million people are unemployed. I certainly hope that we will see the Health Insurance Commission act swiftly on the recommendations in the Auditor-General's report. I also hope that the Commission will look very closely at the comprehensive report put together by the consultant, Mr Harvey Bates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not reiterate the points that Senator Knowles made in speaking to this report of the Auditor-General. I have seen today one of the most farcical press releases I have ever read since I have been in this place—a press release put out by Mr Howe who somehow has had some flash of light on the road to Damascus that something is not well with Medicare. Somehow light has dawned on him.

PARA.TAB: In the mid-1980s a report highlighted the problems that surrounded the Medicare system. Included in that report was concern about fraud. Also included was concern about lack of legislative powers under the Health Insurance Act to apprehend and deal with people for engaging in fraud and/or overservicing. Nothing was done about this until a year ago. We then began to see something being done. Why? Because the Auditor-General decided that he would do an audit. Suddenly the Health Insurance Commission decided that it would appoint a consultant. Things started to happen.
What does Mr Howe say in his press release? The press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Brian Howe, today signalled the Government would move quickly to draw up legislative proposals designed to enable the Health Insurance Commission to deal more effectively with fraud and overservicing of Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits.

He should have done that seven years ago when he was told that there were problems. But somehow it has taken the Auditor-General to go in there, and then Harvey Bates to be appointed as a consultant, for the Minister to do anything about it.

PARA.TAB: How much of the Australian taxpayers' money has been lost? How much money that has been lost because of fraud could have been used to reduce those dreadful hospital waiting lists? Millions and millions of dollars have been wasted in fraud. Hip operations have not been done; cataract operations have not been done; people are living in pain and anguish because this Minister and obviously previous health Ministers have sat on their hands and done nothing about what they knew existed. They had been told.

Mr Howe said—and this will make Senator Knowles laugh if she has not read it—that he was going to have wide and open consultations with the medical and pharmacy professions. I am sure that they will find that most entertaining. What are we told over and over again by the health professions? Every time we have the optometrists in, we are told, `We were never consulted. We do not get consulted'. The pathologists come in and say, `We were not consulted'; the pharmacists say, `We were not consulted'; the medicos say, `We were not consulted'; people in disability fields say, `We were not consulted'. Every time under this Minister we hear the words, `We have not been consulted'.

I do not think I get the same complaints from peak bodies of constituents in respect of any other Minister that they were never consulted. Mr Howe, on the road to Damascus, has suddenly discovered that the way forward is through open and wide consultations. I could have told Mr Howe before I even came into this place that the way to move forward is to consult, to find out, and to say to people, `We have got a limited amount of money. How are we going to achieve this together?'.

That is not what is done. The message comes from on high. We get some bureaucratic idea which is totally incomprehensible, such the idiotic suggestion that was made some years ago of merging all small rural nursing homes that were less than 250 kilometres apart. There is no concern for the humans at the end of the line—the real people. Notwithstanding that, we are told that there will be open and wide consultations.

Mr Howe says that he will get an adviser. He is going to appoint an adviser who will play a key role in consultations and in making sure we get it right. He said that he will be appointing an eminent medical practitioner. I can tell Mr Howe that it is too late. He should have got it right when he first got in and when other Ministers held the health portfolio. He has got it so wrong that he will not have the chance to get it right. It will be the coalition that gets it right, not Mr Howe with his fancy consultant. He should have had someone in there years ago.

The fraud has been extensive. We do not know how much it is and Senator Herron will deal with that in more detail. The Government has no idea. Seven per cent? Ten per cent? It is anybody's guess. Mr Howe also says that the Government is going to review diagnostic imaging services. Good for him, but when one sees the figures one will see that they have been going out for a long time too. Something should have been done about that before this. It took the Auditor-General going in for Mr Howe to be shaken and jolted into doing something about our Medicare system which is in disarray and which is not delivering services to people who genuinely need them.

I have said this before and I will say it again: I had a local newsagent ring me up in desperation. He told me that he cannot bear to see an old lady who comes into his newsagency week in and week out, deteriorating because she has waited two years or 14 months—I cannot remember what it is; it most probably seems like 10 years to her—to get a hip replacement. He has nothing to do with this lady; she is a customer of his. There are women and men like that throughout Australia. They have been waiting while the Minister sat on his hands while the fraud has gone on. He knew in the early 1980s that we needed legislative changes, that there were difficulties in having prosecutions, that there were problems with the medical benefits schedule, that there were technological advances in medicine that needed to be addressed and that there was fraud. Nothing has been done by this Government. The Government will stand condemned because, for the public, health is one of the major issues, next to unemployment, which are so drastic in this country.

This is the worst recession in 60 years and now we have a health system in total disarray. We have the Minister distributing in the press gallery an absolutely farcical story about how he has now seen the light and he is going to do something about it. Let me tell Mr Howe that it is too late. He will not have the chance because it will be Bob Woods the Minister for health who will address the problems and make sure that the health dollar is delivered in the right place to those people in need. We will reduce those hospital waiting lists, we will get a proper balance between private and public health and we will restore the best health system in the world. We had that and we will restore that. Mr Howe is so late that it does not matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General's report on medifraud and excessive servicing is an absolute indictment of the Health Insurance Commission and of Medicare itself. I particularly wish to draw the Senate's attention to the overview on the first page. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: At that time, the extent of fraud and overservicing was estimated by the then Department of Health to be `. . . at least 7% of the total medical benefits expenditure by the Commonwealth and health funds'. This 7% represented $100m in the 1981/82 financial year when Commonwealth medical benefits expenditure `. . . amounted to $1497m'. The Australian Medical Association agreed with this figure.

In 1982, the Australian Medical Association cooperated with the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett. When Dr Blewett came out with an announcement that Medicare fraud amounted to 7 per cent of the total medical benefits the AMA agreed with him and said that they should cooperate in doing something about this. When those figures were analysed, eventually Dr Blewett had to concede that there was no veracity at all in that statement. The President of the Australian Medical Association apologised to his members and was not re-elected on the next occasion. In fact, he stood down because he had misled both his membership and the Australian public. Yet this document, based on that figure, says that the base line is 7 per cent and it has been extrapolated from that that it must be more.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the figures in the report. In seven years the recoveries from excess servicing was $ 1/2m. It is estimated that Medicare expenditure over that period of time would be in the vicinity of seven times $3,000m to $4,000m, and out of that it got back $500,000—an average of $71,420 a year. I did a quick calculation on my calculator and that is 0.0000155 per cent. It is an infinitesimal amount, and 51 medical practitioners were disciplined in the recovery of that amount of money. In 1991-92 $55,000 was recovered from four providers. Senator McKiernan should note that of the 36,000 doctors in Australia, four were prosecuted and $55,000 was recovered. It is absolutely unbelievable on two counts.

It is unbelievable that the current mechanisms—I support the report in that regard—are such that with that enormous expenditure of money, $4,600m, we were able to recover $55,000. It is absurd. That was on what is called excessive servicing but let us look at fraud, deliberate attempts to steal. In seven years I estimate that about $28,000m was paid out by Medicare and $5.6m was recovered. If one goes to one's calculator and calculates $5.6m as a percentage of $28,000m, one again gets a figure of 0.000-something per cent—an infinitesimal amount of money. In that period of time, 12,000 investigations occurred and 43 of the 36,000 medical practitioners in Australia were prosecuted. It is absolutely absurd.

I am not saying that people are not committing fraud or overservicing, but that excessive servicing can be explained in some cases. A simple example is a friend of mine, an anaesthetist, who was investigated by a medical services committee of inquiry because he was putting three times the average number of intravenous drips into patients. He was investigated. The committee discovered that he was the chief anaesthetist at the Prince Charles cardiac hospital in Brisbane which required at least four drips to be put into any one patient having either a coronary bypass operation or a heart transplant. That example explains why some of those 12,000 investigations did not proceed.

The mind boggles at how much money may have been spent—this report does not allude to it—on investigating those 43 doctors over seven years who committed medifraud. In 1991-92, as I mentioned, $4,600m was paid out in Medicare and the recovery was $1m. That is 0.00002 per cent of the total expenditure.

Four providers out of the 36,000 doctors in Australia were actually prosecuted. It is not mentioned in the report that at least one of the four, a pathologist, for a significant sum of money, appealed to the High Court and had the judgment overturned. He was paid out over $1m. I bring these figures to the Senate's attention because they obviously demonstrate—and I support the Audit Office to this degree—that there is very little in the way of legislation or resources to deal with this problem.

What is the basic problem? How can this occur? Both Senator Knowles and Senator Patterson referred to it. The basis of it is that, under Medicare, there is a blank cheque. People are given a card, they can go to any doctor, the card is zipped through a machine and they sign it. There is no check on it, and no co-payment by the doctor.

If Senator Robert Ray had to put his hand in his pocket and pay out some money for a service, he would say, `What am I getting for this service? Why am I spending this money?'. He would then say, `I want to get my money's worth out of this'. But under Medicare he can sign a blank cheque—he need not even know what is put on the blank cheque—and it costs him nothing. So Senator Ray says to himself, `This is magic. It's costing me zilch. I have got the service, I have had the pathology test done—isn't that great', not appreciating that the taxpayer is picking up the cost at the other end and that it has the potential for fraud.

There are four case studies in this report, one of which involves tattoo removal by laser. The doctor involved advertised the removal of tattoos at no cost to the patient through direct billing to Medicare. He did multiple removals over a long period of time, bulk-billed Medicare and made a fortune out of it.

The second case study involves a public health CT scan. I will not bore people with the details because they are in the report. In this case a man decided to make money by having CT scans. He went to different doctors and gave false names and complaints because he thought that this was an absolute bonanza. He got $284 every time he had a CT scan.

The third case study involved double dipping. In Adelaide the Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science, a State operated pathology laboratory, provides pathology to doctors and providers. The Commonwealth assists with the funding of the institute. For the unethical pathologist, it is possible to have work undertaken by the Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science and then bill the patient under Medicare. That is what happened in the third case.

The fourth case involved a grandmother nicknamed `Granny Robin', who recently obtained nine Medicare cards. She went around making claims with the aid of dead women's birth certificates. Certainly bulkbilling is capable of exploitation.

The four examples in the report are an indictment of the Medicare system. The Department recognised that last year and wanted to bring in co-payment so that patients would be the ones who would put a brake on the possibility of fraud. All the organised medical profession wants to prevent the very thing that is referred to in the report.

Like Senator Patterson, I almost laughed when I saw in a press release that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) is to appoint an eminent medical person to advise him. When the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs investigated radiology, the Minister sent his adviser in this area to brief us on our report, which we believe was also an indictment on the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The adviser did not have any idea about radiology, he was unable to tell us anything, and the Minister was not prepared to come along and brief us. So if his press report is any indication of the position, I wish him well because he has never done that before.

The Minister should involve the organised professions in advising him, because I am sure they will. All of us on both sides of the Parliament want to stamp out fraud. It has to be done. The mechanisms have to be given to the Health Insurance Commission, and particularly the neural networking system of computerisation. It applied for funding of $500,000 but was granted $237,000 out of a budget of $4,600m. The profession must be given the resources to stamp out fraud. The basic cause of it is bulkbilling. Until bulkbilling is removed, there will be medifraud and overservicing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President, I present the following report of the Auditor-General—Report no. 18 of 1992-93—Efficiency audit—Department of Social Security—Administration of Special Benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure honourable senators will recall that the provision of special benefits under the Social Security Act is intended to provide adequate income for people in hardship who, although unable to support themselves or their independents, are not otherwise entitled to a pension or allowance. A basic condition of the payment is that the claimant is in severe financial hardship. Consideration is given to both the long term and short term needs of the applicant when he or she applies for the benefit. The rate of special benefit payable is discretionary, although it cannot exceed the rate of the Jobsearch allowance.

PARA.TAB: In short, special benefits are intended as payments of last resort to those in dire financial circumstances. During the financial year 1991-92, special beneficiary numbers increased from 29,800 to 34,800, or by 17 per cent. Payment outlays rose from $261.7m in 1990-91 to $304.1m in 1991-92.

The release of the Auditor-General's report today by the Australian National Audit Office confirms that tighter administration of special benefit by the Department of Social Security and a more rigorous application of DSS guidelines could save up to $7m in annual benefit payments. When he was Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson said in this chamber over and over again, especially when Fightback first came out, that no more savings could be made in social security and that everything was as tight as possible. We used the term `taut and terrific' because we were told that nothing could be done in social security to make savings.

Here we have in one small program an estimated saving by the Auditor-General of $7m. The ANAO estimates that further savings may be achieved by revising DSS guidelines to make them more consistent with the underlying purposes of special benefits—namely, to support only those individuals who are in immediate hardship and without any other available means of support for reasons beyond their control. The report also outlines that there were some inconsistencies in the internal guidelines for this program.

We are all aware of the parlous state of the economy, the record 11.4 per cent unemployment and the hardship that many in our community are suffering. It is absolutely essential that the financial relief the Government provides is well targeted and reaches those most in need. It is very much like the last report we debated dealing with the Health Insurance Commission. The money is limited and ought to be targeted. We ought to ensure that the money reaches the right people rather than its being lost to fraud, or in this case lost because the program has not really been directed at those to whom it is targeted.

It is apparent from today's report that the targeting has not been achieved. I refer particularly to the fact that it is found that special benefit has been used to accommodate difficult or sensitive cases from mainstream social security programs. Some would be assisted more appropriately under such programs as the Jobsearch allowance and disability support. The Auditor-General has said that there are people who would fit much better into those programs. Perhaps they have been slotted into that category because it is too hard or it is easier to put them under special benefits.

One of the key ANAO recommendations is that the Social Security Act and supporting guidelines be reviewed and strengthened to make them more consistent with the underlying purposes of the special benefit, but not to disadvantage the truly needy. Another recommendation is that more guidelines and support should be given to regional office staff in the exercise of their discretionary powers under this legislation.

While the DSS has recognised problems in the administration of the special benefit for some time and has in the 1992-93 Budget introduced measures that are expected to tighten the administration of the special benefit, which is expected to save $3.7m in a full year, I am disappointed in its response to this report.

The Department has only agreed to or partly agreed with 12 of the 22 ANAO recommendations. In addition, the DSS has not agreed with the ANAO's savings estimate and has further indicated that it believes that the guidelines are matters for government consideration only.

I believe that this is a shallow response and I put on the record my extreme disappointment at the blinkered view of the Department in refusing to take on board many of the recommendations made by the Australian National Audit Office.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
