TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 22 of 1992-93—Efficiency Audit—Department of Defence—New submarine project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report by the Auditor-General on the Department of Defence new submarine project concerns the project to build new Collins class submarines in Australia. This is of significance to the defence of Australia, according to the Auditor-General, because it represents an important commitment of expenditure of $5 billion in April 1992 prices. The Auditor-General states:

The contract for the submarines includes necessary performance standards and the Project Office is in the process of ensuring proper testing against these standards. The Project Office is also taking reasonable steps to ensure that the submarines will meet quality requirements. The ANAO is concerned, however, about the financial management of the project and the achievement of the contracted delivery schedule.

PARA.TAB: As the Senate will be aware, senators from New South Wales have expressed concern initially about the failure of appropriate volumes of this contract coming to New South Wales. Therefore, it is quite disappointing to find that the main findings of this audit are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: .the contract does not adequately protect the Commonwealth against loss
.the Commonwealth has advanced funds (initially $120m) to the Contractor without adequate information about the need for those funds

.in its dealings with the Contractor, the Project Office has frequently taken a position which would be more appropriate if it were dealing with a fellow Government entity rather than a commercial organisation with a primary responsibility to its shareholders
.the Project Office has not given sufficient weight to the importance of the timing of the payments

.the Project Office's assertion that the project is on schedule is not supported by the data that can be obtained from the Contract Monitoring and Control System and the ANAO believes the slippage which is evident within the schedule will be difficult to recover prior to the launch and commissioning dates for the first submarine
.contract amendment procedures may have resulted in excessive prices being charged by the Contractor.
The report indicates:
The ANAO makes a number of recommendations primarily intended to ensure that future contracts overcome the problems identified.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Defence contests a number of the ANAO findings but agrees or agrees in principle with 15 of the 30 recommendations in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would briefly like to mention a couple of other points made by the Auditor-General. The report contains one particular conclusion about the risk of loss of funds and states:
The protection provided by the Contract is insufficient relative to the losses that may be sustained by the Commonwealth in the event of failure or default by the Contractor.
The report makes the point that:
The Contract does not prevent the repatriation of dividends to shareholders prior to the major risks of the Contract being overcome.

PARA.TAB: Significant dividends and management salaries paid since the commencement of the Contract mean that in the event of Contractor default the total value of assets that can be obtained from the Contractor are less than the value paid by the Commonwealth to that time.
The Contract specifically prevents recourse by the Commonwealth to the Contractor's shareholders in relation to any deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also makes the point about financial risk without an appropriate return. The Auditor-General says:
Substantial funds have been advanced to the Contractor without sufficient certainty that this action is in the Commonwealth's interest.
I will not read too much more of the report because no doubt the Minister will want to respond.

PARA.TAB: In this case the advance of funds was based only on what the Auditor-General describes as `belief'. The Auditor-General goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Contractor did not provide budgeted cash flow statements or profit and loss statements to allow the Commonwealth or its consultants to verify the amount required.
This relates to considerable amounts of money, because the contract provides for the Commonwealth to pay ASC claims on a 30-day basis related to actual progress. The report states:
The average monthly claim made by ASC to 30 June 1991 was $37 million. The ASC earned $9m in interest in 1987/88 which would indicate an average investment of around $80m.

Providing up-front funding which was obviously not needed by ASC because it was put in the bank to earn interest, irrespective of the reasons for such funding, has provided the company with a means of making significant returns to shareholders before any major risk area has been overcome. The Auditor-General concludes:
The Contractor earned $9m in interest in its first year of operation and $77m in interest in its first four years of operation. This is not indicative of a `slightly positive' cash flow.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Auditor-General's report. I have not dealt with it at great length because we have pressures of legislation, but I ask that the Department of Defence may consider that more than just 15 of the 30 recommendations merit serious attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on the Auditor-General's report—an efficiency audit into the Department of Defence's new submarine project. It is terribly important for public life in Australia that there is an independent auditor. The Parliament raises taxes, which is never a pleasant obligation on the members of this Parliament. The payment of taxes, despite the legislative backing for it, is largely voluntary. It depends on the goodwill of the community to pay them. There is a contrary side to that. It puts an obligation on the Parliament to account very clearly for the way it spends that money. One of the ways of reassuring the public that the money has been spent properly and honestly is by having an independent auditor. In the last 48 hours we have seen the great problems that the Civil Aviation Authority got into because it did not recognise—
—Where was the Auditor for that?

—That is a very good point. I am glad Senator Schacht raised that because, instead of messing around with this sort of nonsensical efficiency audit, if the Auditor-General had inquired into the expenditure of the Civil Aviation Authority and the loss of several hundreds of millions of dollars through maladministration cumulatively over the years, we would all be better off.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we have an independent auditor and it is important that that auditor is not an instrument of the Executive Government; it is important that the auditor is answerable to the Parliament. His purpose ought to be to prevent fraud, theft and other malpractices in a financial arena in relation to the expenditure of public funds.

In recent times the Auditor-General, for reasons that I do not follow, has gone into this concept of efficiency audits. It may well be possible to run an efficiency audit if one has a chain of fish shops, hardware stores or something like that where there are volume sales and some pattern by which one can assess efficiency. But when it is applied to the Department of Defence—which by any standards is a notoriously uncommercial body where we have to have reserve capacity, where we have to provide for unforeseen contingencies and where it becomes increasingly difficult to buy missiles and equipment other than being part of a block purchase that we hold for years—the efficiency audit is really quite nonsensical.

I have said on many occasions when these efficiency audits have come up that the Auditor-General ought to back off from the efficiency audit. By all means, he should go into Defence and assure everyone that the money has been properly spent. But let us keep away from the efficiency side of it where the Auditor-General simply has no methodology that is competent to assess the situation.

In recent years we have seen glaring examples of the inadequacy of an efficiency audit. We had the recent audit on training areas. The Department of Defence, 10 or 12 years ago, bought a very large area of land for a very low price at Yampi Sound as a training area. That was bought for the next 100 years. The Auditor-General got very indignant about the fact that the land, for which $600,000 or $1.2m million was spent—I forget the figure, it is irrelevant, but it was a relatively low sum—has never been used. No-one has ever been on the land. The Auditor-General is totally incapable of understanding that it is for the future.

The Auditor-General's report on the ADF reserves was absolutely legendary for its misdirection and the false conclusions that resulted. I come back to the important point: that the Auditor has to be seen to be independent and objective. My great fear is that the Auditor is debasing his reputation by getting into nonsensical areas.

Most of the report that is before us deals with the contract that was set up between the Government and the Australian Submarine Corporation. I have very great difficulty in agreeing with anything the Auditor says about that. It is a matter of public record that the Australian Submarine Corporation, based in Adelaide, was set up as a pork-barrelling political exercise by Mr Beazley—not Senator Ray. I will put that to one side because I do not wish to embarrass Senator Schacht. The fact remains that a legally binding contract was drawn up between the Commonwealth and the Australian Submarine Corporation.

While it might be of interest for the Auditor-General or any other element of the Department of Finance to look at the terms of the contract with the benefit of hindsight and see how it could be improved in the future, the fact is that it was a contract that was freely entered into between the ASC and the Commonwealth. If the Commonwealth is now being taken down in the eyes of the Auditor-General because he thinks the payments are extravagant, I am afraid that is just too bad. Let the Commonwealth Government, the present government in power, wear the blame for writing an ill-advised contract. It is not fair, as the Auditor-General has tried to do, to hang the blame for the contract on the Australian Submarine Corporation.

In conclusion, I come back to the point that I started on. The Auditor-General ought to back off from efficiency audits. If he persists with this path, he will debase the high prestige that his organisation has because he is applying methodology which is totally inappropriate to a department such as the Department of Defence and its contractors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time I have ever bothered to come into the chamber to discuss an Auditor-General's report. I normally follow due process and draw up a response, as I must, send it to the Minister for Finance and implement the necessary adjustments recommended by the Auditor. I was somewhat disappointed to know that this report had been leaked to at least one member of the Opposition some weeks ago. That is disappointing from my point of view because it leaves me in a poor position.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators can imagine how much more seriously I viewed the fact that the Auditor-General's press release on this matter was issued yesterday before it was tabled in this chamber or in the other chamber. Inquiries were then instituted as to why this occurred and the claim was made that, unfortunately, the press release was accidentally issued. This is a sign to me that the Auditor-General either does not respect his responsibility to report to this Parliament before he reports to the press or that we have a fairly unprofessional organisation in some aspects. Either way, I think it raises serious questions about the management of the Australian National Audit Office. I was contacted today to be told that the Auditor-General plans to have a background briefing on this report for the press tomorrow. I do not know the ethics of that, but I do know that I do not like public servants having background briefings.

I also had some doubts when the Department was contacted for an efficiency audit on the purchase of the additional—up to 18—F111s before it even sent the negotiating team to Washington. Tonight I wish to acknowledge some of the criticisms of the Auditor-General but also contest some of these claims to give the Senate a more balanced view.

I want to look at the audit methodology. In looking at the report, I appreciate the difficulties that the Audit Office has in conducting a review of such a very large and complex project. The Audit Office's timetable in issuing this report today was self-imposed. My Department has strongly advised the Audit Office that more time should be given to discuss all the issues involved in this report. Brief discussion in recent weeks has led to a substantial modification of the Auditor's original stance. No doubt, further careful examination would lead to a significant shift in his position.

I want to give one indication of that. Honourable senators will notice that in a range of issues—I think Senator Baume touched on it—mention was made that there was a $5 billion contract, with $10m private investment, and that this particular matter was serious. In discussions with my Department, it was agreed to take that matter out of the executive summary because it was uncertain and simply leave it in the body of the report. That was agreed; that is the way it is in the report. What is the first major issue in the Auditor-General's press release? It touches on that very point to be highlighted. The matter agreed between my Department and the Auditor-General as uncertain was taken out of the executive summary but put up-front in that press release that was issued yesterday. I am most unhappy about that.

Frankly, the Audit Office lacks the technical expertise to address the biggest risks in this project—that is, the engineering and software aspects. It lacks the commercial experience to fully appreciate the practical realities of a fixed price contract won under fierce competition.

In the rush to get this report tabled, the Audit Office did not accept my Department's request for its response to be fully self-contained. In other words, there are the Auditor's views, and we put our views and what happens? Our views are not put up front, back or anywhere. They are cut and pasted and distributed, with full editorial rights, to the Auditor-General. Tonight I will table the response of the Defence Department in its comprehensive completeness so at least senators can read it and see what our overall response is, argued in a logical way, rather than cut and paste through the report. I table that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to incorporate it?
—I have not been able to clear that with those opposite, but I assure them that there is no defamation in it. I seek leave to incorporate our full response.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO Report is critical of aspects of the financial arrangements entered into by the Commonwealth with the Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC), and of aspects of the way the Contract with ASC has been managed particularly in respect of changes subsequently embodied into the Contract.

Defence notes that the original decisions taken by Cabinet were based on long—term strategies for the national interest. The Project was seen as an opportunity to enhance Australian industry capability and competitiveness, as well as to ensure indigenous support for the submarines throughout their operational lives of about 30 years. The greater part of the investment was to benefit Australia, not only through job creation but also through technology transfer, creation of new skills, improved quality practices, development of modern management techniques and the introduction of new and more progressive industrial relations practices.

The processes and procedures that led to the selection of ASC to construct in Australia six new submarines for the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) were thorough and exhaustive. The risks involved were substantial.

The determinants of risk were the unique platform and combat system (both of a new design), Australia's lack of previous experience, new consortium (ASC), separation of design centres from production centres, fast track design and production, the long construction phase (about 12 years), innovation (steel, ship control system, towed array, ADA software, anechoics, ILS elements, etc) and the Australian industrial environment.

The key judgment was where to share this risk with an Australian company which had no previous experience. In the view of the Government the majority of the risk should lie with ASC though it was inevitable that the Commonwealth would effectively provide much of the capital involved, and would share some of the risk. ASC's risk was in turn shared by its major subcontractors through the performance guarantee requirements of the Contract.
Before responding to ANAO criticisms, the Department would draw attention to the following:
a.the current status of the project which is on schedule, within budget and ahead on performance, a considerable achievement for a $5 billion project five years on;

b.the dominance in the original and current risk assessment of technical and performance risks (which are also the major source of cost and schedule risks), neither of which is raised as a matter of concern by ANAO;

c.the competitive circumstances surrounding the contract, which maximises value for money but simultaneously limits the Commonwealth's leverage to extract additional concessions from a winning tenderer without offering commensurate additional payments or other offsetting conditions;

d.the considerable advance made by Defence, and the Commonwealth as a whole, in its contractual practices with the Submarine Project, which have been further refined in subsequent projects (including in areas mentioned by ANAO);
e.the importance in such a large, long-term, high risk contract of close cooperation between the Department and its contractors including acceptance of their need to make a reasonable profit.

Generally, the ANAO findings reflect little appreciation either of these broader Government considerations or of the technical aspects of "development risk". Naval shipbuilding, including the relatively short history of submarine construction, has many examples where countries embarked in embryonic design/construction programs and suffered initial, disastrous losses. The Australian Government recognised these risks and took them into account.

After more than five years since contract award, the project is on time, within budget and the predicted performance of the new submarines (the Collins Class) generally exceeds the contract performance specification requirements. Importantly, through careful management by all parties involved in the project, the remaining risk is significantly less in many areas than perceived at the time of contract award. Nonetheless, some areas of technical (and hence schedule) risk remain substantial. It would be inappropriate to downgrade these risks until nearer to delivery of Submarine 01.
Progress to date includes:

the continuing successful implementation of the Government's defence self reliance policy, particularly the capacity to support, maintain and adapt the new submarines and their various systems throughout their operational lives;
the successful implementation of a number of major initiatives associated with the Australian Industry Involvement program:

PARA.TAB: -expenditure in Australia of 70 cents in the dollar of total project funds has been a major contribution to the overall increase in Defence major equipment spending in Australia from 30% to 65% over the last decade;

SPEECH.PARA: the creation of new industry capabilities (eg submarine fabrication and assembly, modular construction, management information systems, development of niche products);
the transfer of new skills and technology into Australia (eg system integration, ADA software, inspection test and trials);
the development of modern management practices and information systems (eg Cost Schedule Control System);
significant extension of quality management and accreditation in Australian industry;
the fostering of research and development;
a markedly improved industrial environment; and
the development of Australian products with export potential, including the prospect of export sales of submarine systems and equipments.

The contribution of the Project towards greater international recognition of Australian Defence Force and industry capabilities, and towards increased credibility and standing of Australia in the SE Asia and SW Pacific regions, should also not be ignored.

Defence appreciates the difficulties ANAO had in conducting a review of such a large and complex project, but questions the technical experience and understanding of the audit team to make the overall judgements implied in the report. It is also unfortunate that more time was not given to consultation with higher executives in the Project Office and the Department, and with related agencies such as the Attorney-General's Department.

The Project Office management focus has at all times been directed to ensuring that the six submarines would meet the required performance and be `fit for purpose'. Dominant project activities centred on engineering, safety and risk management.

With design and production centres spread across ten countries (Europe, North America and Australia), engineering management has been a formidable challenge. This would have been a difficult task in a mature industry environment. The Project Office had therefore the additional task of nurturing the creation of a new industry including the development of ASC. Difficulties with ASC were certainly encountered in the initial years of the contract. This was due to the consortium arrangements at that time, a situation which was subsequently rectified to the benefit of all parties.

To support its findings and conclusions, the ANAO cites, by way of examples, a number of Contract Amendments (CAPs). The factors involved in each of the Contract Amendments were more extensive than described by ANAO.

In the case of Electric Cables (CAP No. 321) for example, the negotiations also embraced the redesign, production and installation of a single bilge pump to replace the two units operating in series as designed by Kockums. While that design met the RAN performance requirements, it imposed operating procedures unsuited to the deep diving depth capability of the submarines.

While ANAO asserts that "ASC had planned on using cables which did not meet the contractual standard" the actual position was far more complex and was certainly not clear cut even taking into account advice from the Australian Government Solicitor. Kockums offered in good faith a cable to a Swedish specification during the Project Definition Study in the belief that it satisfied the RAN specification requirement based on UK standards (NES 518 and NES 525). The comparison of specifications and standards of one country with those of another is a difficult and sometimes impossible task because of the different philosophies and tests involved. In addition, standards (including those of the UK) are reissued from time to time to incorporate improvements based on experience (eg Falkland's war).

The RAN accepted the Swedish cable specification offered by Kockums because it was current, it met the requirements of the Royal Swedish Navy and it appeared to conform generally with NES 518 and NES 525. Some year or so after Contract award, however, Kockums advised that under certain laboratory tests, the Swedish electric cable discharged toxic gases with levels in excess of NES 518 criteria relating to sheathing materials.

While there were clear benefits in acquiring new electric cables manufactured to the latest UK standards, there were also a number of major difficulties. These included increased cost, a long manufacturing lead time, redesign by Kockums and other ASC subcontractors of electric cabling and, finally but not least, installation and handling (ie increased production costs by ASC). A major difficulty involved in the Electric Cable negotiations related to schedule. ASC initially advised that the changes in cable could involve a 14 month slippage to the program. Under the contract terms and conditions, the cost associated with such a delay could have been borne by the Commonwealth.

Resolution of the electric cable and bilge pump problems with their attendant cost, schedule, safety and performance implications was a major challenge that called for understanding and compromise on the part of all parties involved. The outcome, negotiated and agreed over many months, was fair and reasonable. ASC agreed to accept responsibility for the design and procurement of a new bilge pump, the Commonwealth agreed to fund the cost of the new cables including small premiums for a shortened manufacturing lead time and their installation. ASC agreed to fund the redesign work required by Kockums and other subcontractors and to maintain the original delivery schedule as contracted, and the Commonwealth agreed to waive Liquidated Damages only for late delivery of the first submarine for up to three months.

The circumstances and factors relating to each of the other examples of Contract Amendments cited by ANAO also need to be fully understood in order to gain an appreciation of the circumstances affecting the negotiations with ASC and the subsequent decision to accept each of the changes in their final form. The following synopsis of the more significant examples of Contract Amendments is relevant.
ILS Documentation Building CAP 149.

ANAO compared the cost of a purpose designed facility with that of a general purpose accommodation building. ANAO also relied on preliminary data relating to the timing of payments. The price of the ILS Documentation Building included elements for security, siteworks, external services, office fitout and

furniture, and construction management. When comparing the price of this building with the RAN Accommodation Building (part of the ACF), ANAO failed to recognise that these elements were priced in separate packages for the ACF. On a comparative basis, the price of the ILS Documentation Building was about $1 350/m(2).
The Electric Control Room and Control Room/Lower Accommodation Platforms Fabrication and Outfitting CAP Nos. 1538/1874.

The CAPs were priced on the basis of competitive quotations obtained by ASC for the fabrication work. The outfitting work was estimated by ASC based on Kockums limited progress of outfitting, setting to work and testing of the platforms for submarine 01. The final prices for platforms for submarines 02-06 were substantially less than the Project Office's own estimates derived from Kockums fixed prices for the platforms for submarine 01, the learning curves both in Sweden and Australia, and knowledge that ASC itself was not entitled to a profit margin for this particular work.

Combat System Support and Test Equipment (CSSTE) CAP No.1418. This complex CAP brought together all the remaining ILS work for the Combat System including documentation, training, training equipment, etc. The CAP was fully investigated by the Financial Cost Investigation Group in NSW. The total price of the ILS CAPs (including those for the platform) was some $90m less than the initial Contract indicative price for the same scope of work.

System Test and Software Support Facility (STSSF) CAP No.1327. The Contract was based on the premise that ASC would set to work the Integrated Ship Control Management and Monitoring System (ISCMMS) in the submarines. This activity included software integration and test. More than two years after Contract award it became clear to the Project Office that ASC's intent was a risky approach and that also a dedicated Land Based Test Site or STSSF would be required to support ISCMMS in service. Such a facility was not foreshadowed in the Contract. The negotiations with ASC were extended in order to have the company contribute to the cost of the facility on the basis that it would reduce its risk of delay in setting to work submarine 01. The 75/25 cost split was finally agreed on the basis that the Commonwealth will own the facility and it will be delivered in the late 1990s to HMAS STIRLING in WA on completion of delivery of submarine 06. The new approach also greatly enhanced safety.
Logistic Management Data System (LMDS) Cap No. 360.

The issue was not so much one of price and visibility but rather the relationship of LMDS to the Ships Information Management System and Ships Information System (SIMS/SIS). The negotiations, which continued over more than one year, were difficult because the RAN had not finalised its requirements for SIMS/SIS. LMDS was not a deliverable to the RAN and was in effect a proprietary item. A `cost reimbursement' approach would not have resolved this difficulty.

The ANAO findings convey the view that ASC benefited financially to a disproportionate extent through some Contract Amendments incorporated into the Contract. Given the complexities involved in each case, and the protracted negotiations, undoubtedly there is room for different judgements of what an appropriate outcome should have been. Consistent with sensible risk management, the Project Office also exercised a degree of `give and take' in its negotiations concentrating its efforts on key matters. Defence is satisfied that overall the Commonwealth position has been well protected.

The contract comprised fixed price elements of work (95% of the contract price), provisionally priced elements (5% of the contract price) and indicative priced elements for ILS and other work to be included into the contract at a later time. Most of these elements have now been incorporated into the contract at fixed prices. The provisionally priced elements increased in price by about $70m. The indicative priced elements (largely ILS) decreased by about $90m against the initial budget of about $530m. In addition, the total cost to date of engineering changes for all six submarines has been about $80m. The number and value of engineering change proposals has been extremely low by comparison with overseas shipbuilding programs of similar size and complexity. The net increase in the value of the contract price as initially identified has therefore been minor.

It is not for the Department to defend ASC, but Defence does question the ANAO view that ASC has intentionally exploited the Commonwealth for short term gain. Defence notes ASC's longer term commercial interest in quality, the development of its national and international reputation, and its long term corporate aspirations.
Risk of inadequate performance
The Department is confident that the performance of the new submarines will meet, and in some cases exceed, the specified requirements.
Risk of inadequate construction quality
Response to recommendation

The number of Australian companies with accredited quality management systems to an international standard has increased significantly since the mid-1980s. In future contracts, where companies do not possess accreditation, the Department will include some motivational measures to ensure the accreditation is given a high priority by the Contractor.
Financial risk—Loss of funds
Response to findings

The Department and Cabinet were fully informed of the risk position and the measures taken to minimise the risk to the Commonwealth. These measures included: financial guarantees initially worth $177m; mortgages over the assets of ASC; progressive vesting of title in the supplies; and, performance guarantees from the parents of the companies undertaking the major part of the work as subcontractors to ASC.

The $200m in ASC's annual accounts referred to by ANAO as advance payments by the Commonwealth, comprise that part of the contract price for materials and equipments which represents ASC's general contingency for future risks. This liability is not a measure of payment for materials and equipments which have not been vested by the Commonwealth, as ANAO implies.
The Department's assessment is that the financial risks to the Commonwealth today is low, given achievements to date, ASC's own risk studies, and remaining financial guarantees.

The Department is satisfied that under the most unlikely and extreme situation of default by ASC, sufficient assets will exist to enable the Commonwealth to arrange for completion of work. Under the contract the Commonwealth is entitled to recovery of guarantees, possession of the construction facility, control of all work in progress, completed design and due performance of subcontractors.

The Department is of the view that for a very long term contract it is unreasonable to expect major companies involved to delay repatriation of dividends to shareholders prior to the major risks of the Contract being overcome. Dividends should be assessed against reserves, contingency and residual risk, and the Department understands that ASC considers it has adequate reserves and contingency to meet its future commitments even under the `worst case' risk scenarios. ASC's dividends to date equate to about 2.5% of the Contract price.

While a case may be made to allow the Commonwealth recourse to a contractor's shareholders, such a contractual provision would almost certainly involve some cost premium. The need for such a provision also depends on the adequacy of other financial guarantees. The Department considers those other measures to be sufficient.
Response to recommendations

A formal mechanism for collating and reviewing all comments made in the tender evaluation process is already in place for major Defence projects. Contract signature does not occur until due Government processes, particularly consideration by the Attorney-General's Department, are complete.
Repatriation of dividends will be identified as a specific topic for negotiation in future major projects.
Financial risk—Risk without appropriate return
Response to findings

The advance of funds to ASC was determined in a fully competitive environment during the parallel negotiations with ASC and AMS. The start up costs and payment profiles were broadly similar for both contenders.

It is normal practice for companies to carefully calculate cash flow requirements and projections. The cash flow projections for ASC and AMS were similar across the life of the contract. A comprehensive analysis of the benefits and risks associated with the payment of Commonwealth monies to ASC was carried out as far as it was practicable to do so given the large level of risk inherent in the project. In any long term fixed price contract, there are inevitably swings and balances. The long term financial viability of ASC is paramount for project success.
Response to recommendations
For future contracts the Department will review its requirements for information governing payments to contractors.

Fixed price contracts have inherent benefits. They are fair to both parties and are relatively easy to administer. The Department does not intend to undermine their viability by including terms and conditions that apply to `cost reimbursement' contracts because of their potential to transfer risk back to the Commonwealth.

Defence will explore the position to provide up-front funding on a trust basis but up-front funding should be assessed against overall risk and the period of the contract. Benefits to the Commonwealth must be balanced by benefits to the contractor.
Risk of paying more than necessary
Response to findings

Contract amendments increase the scope of the contract. ASC is entitled to profit on additional work commensurate with the risks involved, which are more than just the shareholders' equity in ASC. It is quite unrealistic—and unreasonable—to expect the Commonwealth to negotiate Contract Amendments providing virtually no profit.
The assertion that there are examples of significant under-pricing errors by the ASC being corrected through the use of Contract Amendments to increase the amount it is paid is disputed.
Similarly, Defence does not accept ANAO's assertion that the Project Office has paid twice for the same work. ANAO failed to consider engineering and other factors involved.
Response to recommendations
Defence will continue to ensure that Contract Amendments provide due benefit proportional to cost.

Current departmental and government processes underlying management of the project require the project director to gain independent advice on significant contract amendments. The Department will consider further the financial delegations, but notes the considerable benefits of ensuring that the project director has direct control and responsibility for a project.

The terms and conditions of the contract, including the product specification, determine the Commonwealth's position in relation to any dispute. In the case of the Project, the terms and conditions are complex and often interdependent.
Risk of failure to minimise opportunity cost
Response to findings

The Project Office has always been satisfied that claimed progress was achieved prior to payment. This is the basis of CMACS and the accompanying verification procedures. For example, during the past 12 months, the Project Office verified 2342 activities out of a total of 13762 resulting in 63 minor discrepancies which were corrected. For the balance of activities, the Project Office relied on ASC's certification procedures.

The contract with ASC is a lump sum for all six submarines delivered at about yearly intervals. It is based on ASC and its subcontractors progressing work and ordering quantities by the most economic means. This promotes efficiencies in production.

Payments are made to ASC on the basis of certified physical progress. Physical progress, and payments to date, match the overall schedule and payment profile established at the time of contract award.

Analysis shows that, as a result of re-scheduling of packages, 498 were started later than the initial schedule baseline incorporated into the Contract, 294 were advanced. In addition, the first progress claim against the majority of packages (70 percent) has been made two months or more after the package start date. The analysis shows that the Contractor has successfully introduced workarounds to offset delays and maintain the overall schedule. The weight of delays to packages in opportunity cost terms exceeds that which applies to those packages advanced by ASC for risk mitigation. The Department therefore questions the ANAO's conclusion that the opportunity cost of funds provided to the Project is significantly higher than it needed to have been.
Response to recommendations

The Project Office will continue to place emphasis on risk management and mitigation, product quality, schedule and cost. Consideration of opportunity cost, while often important at the development stage of a project, generally has less relevance in relation to these other factors during project implementation. Nonetheless the Department will look more closely in future at its processes for considering opportunity costs.
The Project Office will continue to provide flexibility to ASC to vary the schedule of individual packages in order that the primary risk remains with the Contractor.
Risk of slippage in the delivery schedule
Response to findings
The primary purpose of CMACS is to measure progress. CMACS and ASC's Cost Schedule Control System (CSCS) are not the primary tools for schedule control.

Liquidated Damages are not the principal drivers to encourage ASC to perform to schedule and achieve the delivery of the submarines on time. Liquidated Damages are a means of offsetting costs incurred by the Commonwealth as a result of shortfalls in performance or delays. They do not offset or replace other terms and conditions in the contract which require ASC to deliver the submarines to quality, cost and schedule, the risk for which lies substantially with ASC. It is clearly in ASC's interest to achieve success.
Response to recommendations

The purpose of Liquidated Damages should remain extant and separate from other more significant terms and conditions. The Department agrees nonetheless that it is desirable for damages to reflect the cost of slippage to the Commonwealth without time limit, noting this needs to be negotiated for each contract.

The Department agrees that assessment of schedule should ignore advance progress of activities not on the critical path, but cautions against overly simplistic critical path analysis. The Project Office produces aggregate reports for the Project and Submarine 01, but these have limited value for determining schedule. Reports showing progress of elements and activities have much greater value and are used for assessing progress and initiating corrective actions.

The NSP employs a comprehensive range of information systems which are generally more advanced than those found in other major projects. The evolution of Management Information Systems for projects is ongoing and is given a very high priority. Requirements are generally tailored to meet the individual needs of projects.
The Project Office analyses Production Baseline Revisions in accordance with contract requirements and management needs.

The Commonwealth's position in relation to agreement to schedule revision and the effect of this agreement on any future delay-related damages claims is determined by numerous factors including consideration of its legal position. Advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department indicates that the position is complex and that any claim would need to be considered on its merits.
Risk of increased costs through contract amendments
Response to findings
As described previously, the majority of the risk lies with ASC and there is no evidence that the Commonwealth has been substantially disadvantaged in its negotiations with ASC.
In overall project cost terms, changes have accounted for a small portion of the work under the Contract, some 15% which includes ILS work.

For all CAPs, the Commonwealth has been provided with adequate visibility of data and information and has been satisfied that overall the agreements reached have been fair and reasonable. It is acknowledged that time is often of the essence to avoid consequential penalties.

All CAPs covering engineering changes are complex and require professional judgements regarding the estimation of cost vis a vis the performance, schedule, quality and safety aspects. ASC is largely a project management organisation with more than 80% of its work subcontracted to more than 170 equipment suppliers. Many of these companies in turn rely on hundreds of other lower tier subcontractors.

It is inevitable that ASC has relied on quotations from Kockums, both the designer of the submarines and shareholder in ASC. The matter of consortium arrangements and the potential for conflict of interest was addressed by the Defence Source Definition Committee during source selection.

A cost reimbursement approach to pricing for changes is not supported. Theoretically, contract amendments priced on a cost reimbursement basis would allow visibility of supporting information for ASC costs. In practice it would be impossible to separately measure the costs of implementing such changes during the construction of the submarines. Such changes would also undermine the fixed price basis of the contract with the consequence of risk being transferred to the Commonwealth.
Response to recommendations

Under a fixed priced contract, all work is required to be included under the general scope of the contract. It is simply not practicable to negotiate changes as a separate issue or in isolation, as such negotiations do not occur in a competitive environment and the changes themselves are intrinsically linked to the product specifications and overall contract schedule. In all negotiations involving changes, there is always some common ground and leverage on both sides.

The contract requires the Contractor to provide additional supplies on similar terms and conditions; requires pricing for Contract Amendment Proposals to be supported by evidence; permits Commonwealth investigation to establish reasonableness; and, requires the Contractor to warrant that the CAP presents the total impact on the Contract. The Project Office will pursue with ASC the additional certification requirements recommended by ANAO.

In the view of the Department, contractors involved in fixed price contracts are unlikely to agree to ANAO access to their accounting records. The Department is nonetheless reviewing its own need to have access to cost data in major, high risk contracts, noting there are strong arguments against such access for fixed price contracts won in strong competition.
The Department is satisfied with the ability of the Project Office to negotiate Contract Amendments with ASC.
Consideration of opportunity costs will be taken into account for future Contract Amendments where appropriate.
The Department considers it is not practicable for many contract amendments to be costed separately by a contractor during implementation particularly where the contract is a fixed price.
Risk of contract amendments causing slippage
With the cooperation of ASC, contract amendments have been negotiated and agreed without impact on delivery schedule.
Risk that contract amendments will reduce construction or performance quality
The quality of the product has been the dominant consideration for all contract amendments.
Risk of non-achievement of Australian Industry Involvement (AII) objectives
Response to findings
Currently ASC's AII commitment exceeds its obligation under the contract. There has been no evidence to suggest work has flowed offshore.
The definitions for Local Content are considered adequate.
Response to recommendations
Work done offshore by an Australian company is not regarded as Local Content nor has any such work been claimed by ASC.
Attention will continue to be given to the wording of AII provisions in future contracts.
General issues noted
Response to recommendations

The Commonwealth normally establishes certain minimum commercial terms and conditions as a baseline to assist Contractors in framing their offers. It is not practicable to expect Contractors to agree all such terms and conditions in advance of their offers. The development of terms and conditions should be progressed in a strong and sustained competitive environment as was achieved for the Project.
The Department notes the recommendation that it take into account the implied profit provided by the transfer of title in the Construction Facility in analysing the performance and position of ASC.

The Department considers that, overall, the Project Office has maintained a balanced perspective throughout the period of the contract. The JSPCA recommendations of 1986 advised against tangential management initiatives such as reliance on a semi-autonomous business management function. The Department will nonetheless review the financial delegations for more significant contract amendments, within the Acquisition and Logistics organisation's chain of responsibility.
Training programs are continuously refined to meet project needs. The concept of opportunity cost will be further developed to meet possible future requirements.

Project management systems are continuously refined and developed to meet specific needs. Consultants are engaged where necessary. The Department will review the criteria for such systems for future projects.

The Department normally develops transition and in-service support arrangements for all new equipments in procurement. It is anticipated that acquisition of long-term maintenance services for the submarines will be arranged through the Naval Support Command consistent with industry and contract policy guidelines.

The Government's policy of greater self-reliance depends on Australia being able to compete internationally in selected areas of high value added industrial production. The Submarine Project was seen to provide Australian industry with an excellent opportunity to demonstrate its capability to support high technology defence platforms and systems, and to break into related international markets such as the potentially large market in the South-East Asian region for electronics and defence systems. It should also provide Australian companies, with demonstrated capabilities of quality and reliability in defence production, opportunities in other commercial work. These opportunities are gradually being realised by Australian companies involved in the Submarine Project.

The ANAO Report contains no suggestion of any wrong doing, corruption or fraud. The majority of findings reflect differences in opinion between ANAO and the Department. Given the complexity, magnitude, cost and inherent risk of the Project, this is not unexpected nor is it cause for misgivings about the development or management of the Project.

The key issue for Defence, ANAO and ASC in this project is whether the submarines will be completed on time, within the approved estimated project cost and to the performance requirements specified for them. Both the Department and ASC, with the benefit of their fulltime involvement in the Project for the past five years, are confident in their ability to tackle the remaining risks in the Project and meet all three objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am most grateful to the Senate and to the honourable senators who have allowed me to incorporate that document. I will not repeat what is contained in it, but I do think it addresses some of the issues here.

PARA.TAB: The Audit Office has also raised many new points and comments on the Department's response which have not been discussed at all with the Department. Again, I think that is poor methodology. I am pleased to see that the report is at least in printed form, because the original intention was simply to table a photocopy.

The submarine project is a complex project, both in technical and commercial terms. I appreciate that auditors who have never seen a submarine or been associated with a project management would have some difficulty in coming to grips with the issues. The Audit Office has done a good job, considering its lack of experience of, and expertise in, these projects but it would have been better for the Audit Office to have taken more time to be educated on these matters.

I move to the question of the overall judgment of the project. The report concentrates on certain financial aspects and strikingly avoids any overall balanced judgment of the project. The project was always a high risk one and openly entered into by the Government with that knowledge. The biggest risk was always known to be in the technical engineering areas. Indeed, it is the technical risk which generates most of the schedule and cost risks.

Lost in the Audit Office reports is the significance of its implicit finding that the technical aspects of the project have been well managed by the project office. It is extraordinary that, in an audit of a $5 billion project, whose risks are primarily technology driven, the Audit Office should be so superficial about this issue. It is not just that this side of the project has been handled well—and credit should be given where credit is due. This still remains, and always would remain, the biggest area of risk. The failure of the audit team to consider how much risk remains and whether it has been rigorously and sensibly pursued is a culpable offence, in my view.

The Department's review, backing the project office and the Australian Submarine Corporation—and this is the key part of what I have to say tonight—is that the submarine is on time, and it is on budget with an enhanced performance. That is the essence of what a fixed price contract is about. It seems to me that what the Auditor is yearning for is a cost plus contract and they have proved to be disastrous in the past. The Auditor and the audit do not directly dispute the contention I have just put down that it is on price, and on cost with enhanced quality. The report sort of says, `Look, we're a bit unsure about whether it is on schedule'. It cannot really argue one way or the other. It does not suggest the project is at serious risk of going beyond its budget, but suggests a new performance measure because commercial project management would not be satisfied with completing a major project within a fairly generous budget; noting, of course, that the budget reflects that the Australian Submarine Corporation's fixed price was developed in a strong competition. I do not believe that is a balanced judgment.

No-one in Defence is saying the project has no risk, nor is anyone suggesting Defence should not pursue the best possible financial and performance result. But surely we can expect a major audit to give us a serious judgment on how the project is going on schedule, cost and performance and whether it is in line with the original budget estimate and performance requirements. If that is the case, the report should have said so.

Let us move to some of the key criticisms. Many of the Auditor-General's comments are made with the benefit of twenty-twenty hindsight. There is no recognition that the contract was won after fierce competition. The alternative tenderer sought nearly double the up-front funding to ASC. The up-front funding to ASC was negotiated downwards from its winning bid before the contract was signed. The Government, through the contract, was establishing a new consortium and a new industry.

The contract was signed only after the most exhaustive process which included Defence committees, the Department of Finance and the Attorney-General's Department. The Audit Office suggests that, somehow, in a fixed price contract, the Government should monitor in detail a contractor's cash flow and should claim back up-front funds not directly required. We can certainly look at that in future, but let us not pretend that such an arrangement will not affect the contract price or the sharing of risks between the Commonwealth and the contractor. The issues are not simple and I am concerned that the Audit Office comments do not reflect commercial experience.

The Audit Office also expresses concern about the Australian Submarine Corporation's dividend payments. A graph on page 10 of the report highlights the company's profits and dividends compared with the shareholders' assets. I stress that this is a $5 billion project in an industry effectively created by the Commonwealth. To suggest that the contractor's risk is merely the shareholders' capital of $10m and that the profits ought only to relate to that is plain silly. The more important question is whether the dividend payments increase the Commonwealth's risk to any significant degree.

The fact is, with the advice of the Department of Finance and the Attorney-General's Department, the Department has a substantial financial guarantee. If the contract circumscribed dividend payments, presumably there would have to be some contract cost involved. The real issue is whether the overall array of financial guarantees—mortgaging and vesting—provide sufficient insurance for the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, that issue was not adequately discussed because of the Audit Office's self-imposed deadline. The Audit Office's comments on the Department's response has not been seen before but the Department's position has the support of the Attorney-General's Department.

The other major criticism concerns contract amendments and the claim that the Commonwealth has paid more than it should. I do not intend to go into all the details here; that is a matter for the Department to handle in due course. It is clear that the rights and wrongs in this area are heavily dependent on technical considerations which the Audit Office does not appear to be in a strong position to judge. I am also concerned that the Audit Office does not appear to appreciate some of the commercial aspects of this area. There is a suggestion that, somehow, contract amendments can be negotiated by the Commonwealth from a position of strength and that greater use should be made of cost based funding arrangements.

The issues here are complex but I am concerned that the Audit Office's proposals could, in fact, add to the Commonwealth's costs and risks and remove the benefits of a fixed price contract. Again, time has not allowed the Audit Office and the Department to sensibly discuss these issues. The Audit Office also raises concerns over opportunity costs. There is no evidence here that the problem is a significant one for the submarine project. There is no appreciation of the consequences of pursuing opportunity costs in a fixed price contract such as might arise from the Commonwealth telling a contractor how to schedule and manage detailed work packages.

Having said all that, I am not trying to cover up the fact that some mistakes have been made with the project. It would be unrealistic to expect nothing to go wrong in a $5 billion project. My firm view is that the Department has come a long way in its project management capacity in the last decade. The submarine project is a considerable advance on the past and, might I say, a considerable advance in any comparable project being built overseas. This report has made a number of very worthy recommendations which I have asked my Department to look at closely and which will improve the management of the project.

There is another area involved, and that is the Australian Submarine Corporation itself, which the Auditor did not talk to, yet which has taken some big hits in his report—so much so that it may well dent its credibility in trying to market the submarine overseas. I will briefly put on the record some of the views from the Australian Submarine Corporation and seek, in due course, permission to incorporate its press release. Don Williams, the Managing Director of the Australian Submarine Corporation, has expressed his concern about the report, particularly its suggestion that his company is intent only on short term gain at the expense of the Commonwealth.

Dr Williams has stated publicly that the Australian Submarine Corporation's first objectives are to deliver a quality product and to achieve budget profit margins and that the ASC does not see itself as a single contract company. I can certainly believe him in this because I have seen him make investments in South Australia, and in Newcastle, and explore possibilities at the moment in Western Australia. Dr Williams has also stated that the Audit Office fails to appreciate the commercial reality of staying in business based on quality and integrity. In other words, Dr Williams is saying that the corporation will not have its reputation besmirched by poor quality work, cost overruns et cetera when it intends to stay in the shipbuilding and associated industries into the long and distant future. I also know that his view is that the overall management of this project by the Department and the Navy has been a remarkable achievement in the face of substantial risk and a wide range of knockers.

As I said at the opening of my remarks, I felt, because of the nature of this particular report, that I needed to put some of the counter-claims on the record. I am deeply appreciative of the fact that the Senate has seen fit to allow the incorporation in Hansard of the Defence Department's response. I also seek leave—and I think I cleared this with Senator Baume—to have the press release issued by the Australian Submarine Corporation incorporated in Hansard so that its views may be recorded.
Leave granted.
The press release read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN SUBMARINE CORPORATION PTY LIMITED
PRESS STATEMENT
December 17, 1992
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AUDIT OFFICE (ANAO) REPORTS ON THE NEW SUBMARINE PROJECT
Following the tabling of the above report in Federal Parliament on 17 December 1992, the Australian Submarine Corporation Pty Ltd (ASC) would like to point out two important facts.
1. ASC has signed a lump-sum contract (subject to escalation based on CPI and currency movements) for the design and manufacture of six new submarines for the Royal Australian Navy.
This means that, irrespective of the work involved in designing and building the six submarines, ASC is required to deliver them at the agreed price, on an agreed schedule.

The contract was awarded to ASC following a competitive bidding process between ASC and Australian Marine Systems (AMS); ASC and AMS having been selected from seven proposals based on designs from UK, France, Germany, Italy, Sweden and the Netherlands. The contract was negotiated in a climate of intense competition; with all aspects being finalised with both ASC and AMS, before final source selection was made by the Commonwealth.
Five years after commencement of the contract:
.the project remains on schedule—SM#01 will be launched on 28 August 1993
.the project remains within the original Commonwealth Government budget
.the submarines will meet, and in some cases exceed, the performance requirements laid down in the contract
.the Australian Industry Involvement program specified under the contract is being exceeded.
2. ASC is a private company—not a government organisation.
Like any other company contracted to provide services to the Government, it remains independent of the Government.

Accounting and tax standards require ASC to declare a profit on an ongoing basis and pay tax annually. It logically follows that when a private company has declared its profit and paid tax, it finally pays dividends.
ASC is proceeding with its foreshadowed plans for diversification and acquisition, so that the company can consolidate as a new major manufacturer of complex equipment.

It is very important to note that the Australian Submarine Corporation is rapidly building up to become a major Australian shipbuilding and heavy engineering company. This is being achieved through acquisitions which include the former Carrington Slipways in Newcastle and T. O'Connor & Sons Pty Ltd in Adelaide. Negotiations also are progressing in regard to the establishment of a presence for ASC in Western Australia.

Business plans are being developed which identify work for these facilities, and for the submarine facility at Osborne. This is entirely based upon the reputation ASC has established for project management, quality engineering, systems integration, on time schedule performance and as a leader in the application of integrated logistic support techniques which ensure maximum availability of high technology equipment.

As a final comment, ASC is disappointed that the ANAO report contains direct comment on its activities, particularly when at no stage did ANAO audit staff contact ASC with questions or requests for comment.

I understand that some members of the Opposition have an interest in going to a meeting that might be conducted in the not too distant future and that they would like to organise the business to facilitate that. It is very much in the Government's interest as well to proceed in this way because we are proposing to move more expeditiously to Government Business and legislation. The downside is that I accept that it is possible that it will reduce some of the time pressure on people speaking on reports because there is not the pressure of subsequent business, but it may be that the pressure of the hour and their colleagues' ire will compensate. In any case, I think it is in everyone's interest. So I will outline what it is we are proposing to do, and I understand we have the concurrence of all honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: We are not proposing to table at this stage any of those committee reports. They will still be on the Notice Paper; they will still be tabled later this evening, but not now. We will proceed directly to Government Business, subject to two matters. One is a Privileges Committee report to be presented by Senator Teague—he assures me he will be very brief—and there are some messages to come in from the House of Representatives. I just assure those concerned that those messages will not include at this stage the migration Bill, which we will do a few minutes subsequently. Also, in order to clarify things for people who are trying to time their arrival here, the first item of Government Business will be finalising the seafarers legislation, and we will then proceed to deal with the migration package following the presentation of the message from the House. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I present the fortieth report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Persons Referred to in the Senate (Ms Margaret Piper, Ms Eve Lester and Mr Seth Richardson).

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the seventeenth report of the Committee concerning a matter raised by persons under Privilege Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 14 December 1992, the President, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, referred to the Committee a letter from Ms Margaret Piper of the Refugee Council of Australia, on her own behalf and on behalf of Ms Eve Lester and Mr Seth Richardson, relating to remarks made by Senator McKiernan to the Senate on 7 December 1992. Ms Piper wrote to the President on 9 December 1992, and the matter was referred to the Committee as a submission under Privilege Resolution 5. The Committee has considered the submission and recommends that a response agreed to by Ms Piper, Ms Lester and Mr Richardson and the Committee be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: As previously indicated to the Senate, in matters of this nature the Committee does not judge the truth or otherwise of statements made by honourable senators or persons but, rather, it ensures that a person's submission, and ultimately the response recommended by the Committee, accords with the criteria set out in Privilege Resolution 5.
I would also like to point out to the Senate that this is the first time on which a statement has been made on behalf of more than one person.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The response read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSE BY MS MARGARET PIPER, MS EVE LESTER AND MR SETH RICHARDSON AGREED TO BY MS PIPER AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988

I wish to avail myself and my colleagues of the provision that exists for the Senate Committee of Privileges to examine remarks made by Senator Jim McKiernan in the Senate on 7 December 1992 relating to:
.Ms Margaret Piper, Executive Director of the Refugee Council of Australia (RCOA);
.Ms Eve Lester, Co-ordinator of the Refugee Advice and Casework Service (RACS) Victoria;
.Mr Seth Richardson, Co-ordinator, RCOA Port Hedland Project.
It is our belief that many of the remarks made by Senator McKiernan were inaccurate and that they impugn our reputation and that of the organisations we represent. To answer specific points raised:
1.". . . the Refugee Advice and Casework Service, which includes the Refugee Council of Australia" (Hansard p4307)

Mr Richardson and Ms Piper are members of RCOA; Ms Lester is Co-ordinator of RACS. It is inaccurate to say that the Refugee Advice and Casework Service includes the Refugee Council. RCOA is an umbrella organisation; RACS is one of the services operated by RCOA.

2."Eve Lester, Ms Margaret Piper and Mr Seth Richardson earned the accolade of being perhaps the worst set of witnesses that have ever appeared before a parliamentary inquiry. They did not want to answer any questions. . . we did not get direct answers to our questions." (Hansard p4307).

These comments imply that in our evidence to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations we were being purposely evasive and trying to disguise the truth. We attempted to answer as accurately as possible, and to the best of our knowledge, the questions that were put to us. There were times, however, that their questions appear to us to be vague or misdirected.
3.". . . they purported to be experts in the area." (Hansard p4307)

In response to the question from the Acting Chairman about the capacity in which we were appearing, Ms Lester advised that she was present in her capacity as Co-ordinator of the Refugee Advice and Casework Service. Neither Mr Richardson nor I was given the opportunity to answer this question because the Acting Chairman asked an unrelated question; the original question was not returned to.
4."We were insulted on a number of occasions. . . " (Hansard p4307)

We believe that we did not insult the members of the committee and we cannot find what could be described as an insult in the Hansard record. On the contrary, we found that the method of questioning was at times aggressive and with frequent interruptions.

There was also an occasion when Senator McKiernan made a direct attack on Ms Piper's integrity and that of RCOA on the basis of a misinterpretation of a previous remark. Ms Piper's efforts to correct Senator McKiernan's perception of what she said were interrupted.

5."Ms Margaret Piper is doing herself and her organisation a great disservice in making such statements (referring to a quotation from evidence to the inquiry) on the record. . . . The conditions in Port Hedland are nowhere near what they are in Hong Kong or in many of the other refugee camps around the world." (Hansard pp2307-2308).

Senator McKiernan has failed to recognise that Ms Piper's remarks related not to the nature of the buildings but to what happens there. A facility that is appropriate for short term accommodation for workers is not necessarily appropriate for long term detention of men, women and children, especially when one considers the fact that they are locked in behind barbed wire fences and under 24 hour a day guard.

6.". . . We asked direct questions of Mr Richardson and Ms Piper in this Committee to ascertain how much they were getting out of the public purse. Organisations such as theirs do have a vested interest because they exist on government funding. The initial answer to our questions on the matter of funding was that it was $55,000. Through persistent further questioning we got agreement that the funding was in the region of half a million dollars." (Hansard p4308)

The answer $55,000 (plus $30,000) was the correct answer to the question asked ie the amount of money received by RACS. Our attempts to explain the difference between the funding allocations to RACS and RCOA were interrupted by further questions. It was never our intention to disguise the figures and in fact we had brought the figures to the inquiry (as evidenced by their presentation) in case we were asked for them.
7.". . . what a difficult task the Standing Committee had in trying to elicit accurate and factual information from this body." (Hansard p4309)

If Senator McKiernan was concerned about the accuracy of the evidence we presented to the inquiry, he could have approached us directly or taken more formal measures. Instead he has made these very serious accusations under the privilege of parliament.
8."I also doubt very much whether they are getting the proper legal service that they should be getting." (Hansard p4309)

This is a particularly serious accusation impugning the competence and professional ethics of the lawyers involved in the projects, including Ms Lester and Mr Richardson. Senator McKiernan presented no evidence to substantiate these comments.
It is relevant to note that:
.there have been no complaints made by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (DILGEA) about the quality of the legal advice offered to the asylum seekers;
.the asylum seekers have made no complaints about their legal advice from RCOA and RACS;
.The lawyers' actions with respect to their client have been vindicated by the results of judicial action thus far, in particular the High Court decision of 8 December 1992;

.DILGEA has recently awarded a contract following the first tendering process to RCOA for the provision of legal advice to the Romanian asylum seekers in Port Hedland. If there were concerns about the quality of the advice we were offering, it is reasonable to assume that they would not have awarded us this contract.
If Senator McKiernan has grounds for these remarks, he may take his complaints to the appropriate bodies, namely the Law Institute and the Law Society. To our knowledge, he has not done so.
Conclusion

We are submitting this document in an effort to put on the public record the facts as we see them in the hope that the issue can be addressed constructively and we can proceed towards finding a resolution to the very serious problems that exist in the area of refugee determination.
Margaret Piper
Executive Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill makes changes to provisions of Division 4B of the Migration Act, which deals with the custody of people who come to Australia by boat without prior authorisation. The changes proposed are interim measures until the commencement of the relevant provisions of the proposed Migration Reform Act 1992 in November 1993, which establishes a new and simplified regime for dealing with all unlawful persons, irrespective of their mode of entry to Australia.

Honourable Senators may recall that in May this year the Minister presented a Bill to the House designed to ensure that people who arrive by boat in Australia without prior authorisation remain in custody until they leave Australia or are granted an entry permit. The Minister believed then, and continues to believe, that only those granted authority to enter should be permitted to move into the general community, and that a clear signal be sent that entry into the Australian community cannot be achieved simply by arriving here.

Aspects of Division 4B were challenged in the High Court, which recently handed down its judgement validating the custody regime it sets out. The Minister applauds this very valuable decision, which clearly affirms the Government's right to maintain control over Australia's borders for the protection of the community as a whole.

The High Court decision did, however, uncover doubts as to the validity of custody under Section 88 of the Migration Act, in which most boat people were held before the commencement of the amended legislation on 6 May 1992. Section 88, which formed part of the major 1989 amendments to the Migration Act, replicates a long-standing provision in the earlier legislation. A majority of the judges held that detention ceased to be lawful under Section 88 after the destruction of the boat on which the person arrived or in other circumstances making the boat unavailable for the person's departure. While most of the boats on which the people in Section 88 custody arrived remain in existence, including the two boats on which the 37 plaintiffs before the High Court travelled to Australia, there is nonetheless considerable uncertainty now surrounding the lawfulness of Section 88 custody.

This uncertainty turns not on the central issue of unauthorised arrival, but on the haphazard fate of the boat on which the people travelled. Should custody have become unlawful, it is as a result of a technical breach. This has created an artificial situation when the fact of the matter is that the boat people arrived in Australia unlawfully and their detention was based on our understanding of the provisions of Section 88 at the time.

Lawyers for the boat people are now publicly discussing compensation for unlawful detention, and already applications have been lodged in the High Court on behalf of some of the detainees. While our assumptions about the operation of Section 88 may have been misplaced, and the High Court has offered important guidance on this, the issue still remains to be tested in numerous cases. In the case of one boat, for example, the people were rescued at sea by the Royal Australian Navy as their boat foundered, and they were brought into Darwin on HMAS Townsville. One of the passengers rescued described their relief at being rescued in last Saturday's Weekend Australian. There must now be serious doubt about the custody of this group. It would be ironic if those rescued could now sue the Commonwealth for the privilege. Some 300 boat people in all are potentially affected. It is possible that, were a Court to find for these people, the Commonwealth could be ordered to pay a very considerable sum by way of compensation.

The Minister believes that it is essential to counter the possibility of significant damages claims. It would be absurd for the Australian taxpayer to be expected to underwrite compensation payments to people who had arrived here without authority and who had been detained on reasonable grounds while their claims to remain were exhaustively examined.

This Bill therefore introduces a provision which limits any compensation payable to an amount of $1 per day for any period of detention which a Court of competent jurisdiction finds to have been unlawful. This will apply to all designated persons under Division 4B of the Migration Act, including those who have already commenced proceedings against the Commonwealth for damages in relation to claimed unlawful custody.

In addition, this Bill seeks to put beyond doubt certain aspects of the custody scheme embodied in Division 4B of the Migration Act, in line with the guiding philosophy of that scheme: namely that designated persons remain in custody until granted an entry permit or removed, subject only the proviso that the processing of entry applications must be completed within the time frame set down in the legislation.

Specifically, the Bill introduces a provision to put it beyond doubt that custody is to continue between the negative determination of an entry application and the removal of the applicant. While removal must be effected as soon as practicable after the entry application is refused and all appeals against, or reviews of, the refusal have been finalised, there are inevitable lead times in procuring travel documents and making associated arrangements. It is essential that there be legislative authority for continued custody through this period.

The Bill also introduces a provision to extend the permissible period of custody where an entry application decision is reopened by an unfavourable ruling of the courts. This Bill provides that the period known as "application custody", which is limited to 273 days and which is intended to ensure that a decision is taken by the Department within that period, excludes any period of reconsideration following an adverse court ruling. The Bill provides an additional 90 days for each such reconsideration.
