The Bill also provides that the institution of proceedings in relation to unlawful custody does not prevent the Government from detaining or removing designated persons during the course of such proceedings. This Bill makes it plain that a stay order against removal may not be issued to allow an applicant to remain in Australia during the course of such proceedings.

Finally, this Bill extends the coverage of the existing provisions under Division 4B to include people arriving by boat on or after 1 December 1992, up until the commencement of the new measures contained in the proposed Migration Reform Act 1992, which was passed recently by this Parliament. When Division 4B was enacted in May of this year, it was envisaged that the planned Migration Reform Act would commence on 1 December 1992 and therefore the amendments related only to boat people arriving before that date. As the relevant provisions of the proposed Migration Reform Act will not now commence until 1 November 1993, it is essential to extend the existing custody provisions to cover people arriving on or after 1 December 1992, but before 1 November 1993.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992 and notes the need, as proposed by the Government in full consultation with the Opposition, for there to be certainty in the matter of the intention that we in this Parliament had when we adopted the Migration Act and its provisions as they now stand.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, after we debated and passed this legislation in May this year and as a result of a High Court ruling with regard to a recent immigration case that came before it, there were some comments made by members of the Bench. From these comments, it appears that a number of the asylum seekers, people arriving by boat illegally on Australia's shore, may—and I stress the word `may'—have been unlawfully in custody under section 88 of the Act from the time they first entered Australia until the amendment was enacted. It is also possible—and I stress the word `possible'—that if they were unlawfully held a claim for damages could arise.

The defect in section 88 which has given rise to this possibility was discussed by Justices Brennan, Deane and Dawson. It was suggested that detention is only authorised until the departure of a vessel carrying the alien from Australia or until such earlier time as an authorised officer directs. It is on the rub of when a boat bringing an illegal entrant arrives to the point when that boat departs that we have provisions in section 88 of the Act.

A situation has arisen which was not fully foreseen and which may—and I stress the word `may'—lead to a problem. That problem is this: in the particular case considered by the court, it was informed that the vessel had been burned by quarantine officials. The view of the court was that once a vessel no longer exists, or for that matter could never depart, the authority to detain a person lawfully might cease to have effect.

The High Court has a duty to adjudicate independently on the law as adopted by the Parliament. With all due respect to the High Court and courts at every level in this land, what we have is what I would see as a litigious game of hide and seek. Over the last 10 years we have had this litigious game of hide and seek not only in Australia but also in the United States and Canada, and a wide range of other countries which receive immigrants and which are subject to the phenomenon of illegal migration.

I would even say that well-intentioned lawyers seek to uphold what they see as the rights of illegal immigrants. They seek to find every loophole they can in immigration law in order to help their clients achieve the goal of gaining permanency in the country that they have chosen to come to illegally, without papers, without entry permits, without visas, and often without even passports. What is at issue in this game of hide and seek is in fact the national interest of Australia and the integrity of our immigration law. We must have a law that genuinely fulfils the intentions of the elected representatives in the Parliament.

Without seeking to provoke some honourable senators who might speak after me—and I see that Senator Harradine and Senator Chamarette are in the chamber—I wish to quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). This is the same second reading speech as the one that has been incorporated in this place. I quote from page 3946 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 16 December 1992:
This uncertainty turns not on the central issue of unauthorised arrival, but on the haphazard fate of the boat on which the people travelled.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to understand this central fact. If the boat was burnt, put in a museum, as one boat was recently, or disposed of in some way, there is a possible interpretation that section 88 of the Migration Act no longer provides that the person who came on that boat can be lawfully detained.

PARA.TAB: I am a plain man. I am not into litigious hide and seek, except insofar as to try to win a battle on behalf of the people of Australia and on behalf of the intentions of the Parliament. I would say that there was never any intention by the Parliament to allow an escape from section 88 of the Act on such grounds. Let me mention just a few examples. One vessel that arrived in recent years was called the Collie. The 79 people on board were all illegal immigrants. This vessel could not depart from Australia because it was sunk. The Echo, which had 10 illegal immigrants on board, was committed to a museum. It cannot leave Australia.

Another boat, called the George, carried 77 illegal immigrants. It was burnt. Another boat, the Harry, with 10 illegal immigrants, was sold and beached. The fate of the Dalmatian, with 33 illegal immigrants, is unknown. Because of the haphazard outcome of what happens to such boats, are we trying to maintain that we will allow some lawyers to drive their coach and horses through a loophole in the law and break down the intentions of this Parliament and, indeed, the integrity of our immigration laws?

Because of the doubt, it is necessary that there be certainty as to what the intention of this Parliament has been all along. This legislation applies to the period from 19 November 1989 to 1 November next year. After 1 November next year the provisions of the Migration Reform Bill, which we adopted recently, will make for certainty.

I do not believe that appeals to so-called human rights, appeals to the covenants on civil and human rights, or consideration of the rights of persons to be imprisoned or detained and the conditions under which they are detained, bear upon this matter as much as the haphazard nature of the outcome of the vessels on which they arrive in relation to the words that happen to exist in section 88 of the Migration Act.

I have read carefully the House of Representatives speeches of the Minister, Mr Hand, and my close colleague, Mr Phillip Ruddock who is the honourable member for Dundas and the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs. I want to quote two sections of Mr Ruddock's speech. He calls this Bill `an important piece of legislation, designed to ensure that the provisions of the Migration Act, which were enacted last May, are valid'.

I have spoken on behalf of the Opposition in the last four or five debates on immigration law. A few years ago we were involved in the reformulation of the whole Act. We have sought to make the Parliament's intention clear in legislation, despite this litigious game of hide and seek. We do not in any way wish to see in the immigration law of Australia any breakdown of human rights, any discrimination, or any action that is inhumane or lacking in compassion. We want to see fairness, justice, truth and certainly integrity in the intended immigration law of Australia. Mr Ruddock is reported on page 3951 of Hansard as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it has always been clear that our principal problem has been the unduly legalistic approach that has had to be adopted because of the Government's view that we ought to provide ready access to judicial review of administrative decisions . . .
He went on to talk about the creative way in which the High Court of Australia and other courts have got into the business of determining refugee claims and so on.

PARA.TAB: It is for the reasons that have already been set out in the House of Representatives—and which I have repeated—that we wish to see the original intention of the Parliament in the amending Bill of May this year maintained, despite this litigious game of hide and seek. We therefore support this Bill and we wish it speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992. The Government has initiated this Bill because it wishes to respond to the consequences of the High Court's decision that 37 boat people were unlawfully detained because their vessel was no longer in existence or in an Australian port—in other words, it could never depart.

PARA.TAB: The relevant section on which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) sought to support his decisions in this area is section 88 of the Migration Act which sets out the provisions relating to stowaways where the presence or departure of their boat is obviously a significant factor. The Government sought to use that section to justify the continuing detention of the 37 boat people whose boat had been burned.

The Government realised that it could not amend section 88 retrospectively. Rather than make an attempt to do that, it has brought in a provision in the current Bill which states: The compensation that may be awarded to a designated person in an action under subsection (2) is to be $1 for each day of the person's unlawful custody.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister claims that the provision is not contrary to article 9.5 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which states that anyone who has been the victim of unlawful arrest or detention shall have an enforceable right to compensation. However, it is clear that this is mere subterfuge and that, in substance, this provision is contrary to the principles of international human rights guaranteeing the rule of law.

PARA.TAB: It raises again the issue on which the Democrats have opposed the Government's recent amendment to the Migration Laws Amendment Bill; namely, that people who are before Australian courts should be accorded equality in our legal system, even if they are not citizens or residents at the time. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats will be opposing this Bill. However, it must be acknowledged that there are competing principles at work and that different views on this issue are possible. It is my understanding that some of my colleagues, in particular Senator Coulter, who will be expressing his views shortly, may take a different view on this issue which in many ways is a conscience issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hard to avoid being cynical as the Government yet again rushes into the Parliament to amend the legislation dealing with people seeking asylum in Australia by the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992. If it were not so tragic to the people concerned, this could be categorised as the `Oops!' legislation. The Government has tried and tried again to make sure that gaining refugee status in Australia is well nigh impossible unless people come through proper channels and wait in the queue. But each time it has discovered that it has left a tiny window through which the light of justice and fairness can shine.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this legislation has come about because the High Court has ruled on the Government's policy of detention without recourse to court jurisdiction. In May of this year, we saw legislation rushed in here to head off a court challenge and now the Government again wants to make sure that the courts are not able to evaluate the legal validity of its policies. So it is time to try to close the window once more.

In May of this year, we had the extraordinary situation of the Government insisting that even a court did not have the power to release someone held in custody by the Department. Why is this Government so hell-bent on this process which relies on detaining people against their will without recourse to the power of the courts to adjudicate on the merits of their detention? Whose interests are being served by this regime of detention without relief?

It costs the Australian community thousands of dollars per person held. Just for interest, at a very conservative estimate, the cost is $11,000 per person per year in Port Hedland and $27,000 per person per year at Villawood or elsewhere. This imprisonment reinforces antagonism towards these people in the community by making them seem different, not to say criminal, and denies people opportunities for overcoming the fears which they have sought to escape by coming here.

Studies overseas have shown that, in countries where refugee applicants are not detained during their processing, only 3 per cent fail to appear for the various steps required for their application. But even putting aside the remote possibility that the Australian Government could come at that, we have groups in our community which are willing and ready to provide accommodation and support for these people and to see them through the application process.

The Bill seeks to clarify some other matters which managed to slip through the net last time. So the 273 day detention period during which the processing must be completed is now to be able to be extended by a further 90 days for each extra step of an appeal process. A person's detention may so become nine, 12 or 15 months. Where will it end? The Government says that it is committed to ensuring that people will not be held in custody for three years or longer, as has happened to a number of people, but it seems to want to have the right to punish people with extra detention if they choose to appeal a negative decision.

We now also have the infamy of the Government setting people's right to compensation for illegal detention over the past few years at a paltry $1 per day. To add to the infamy, it recognises that a compensation claim can only proceed for the 104 people who fall within the High Court determination. But, nonetheless, it wants to limit the court's decision making powers by setting the level of compensation.

One dollar per day is an insult to those who have been illegally detained. In fact, the notion of someone bringing such an action, making use of legal representation possibly costing thousands of dollars, is an obscenity. Is this the hallmark of a civilised and caring society? Australia has limited by this legislation its liability to a total of some $23,000 shared between 104 people potentially, yet may still spend 10 times that defending their obligation to pay it. Such is the stupidity of this Government's attitude towards this tiny number of unfortunate people.

Just to make it concrete, the Department of Immigration does not intend to contest the claim of 71 of these people whose boat is no longer in existence. This would amount to $300 compensation for each person for their 10 months unlawful detention. However, the Department of Immigration would be prepared to contest the claims of the 33 people whose case for unlawful custody was upheld in the Federal Court and who, through this legislation, would potentially receive $60 per person.

The total number of refugee applications from people currently in Australia exceeds 21,000. But this Government has singled out a small handful of less than 500 for all the harsh treatment, manipulation of our standard legal processes and, indeed, the skewing of our entire immigration agenda to boot. Why is the Australian Government so deeply committed to allowing only 5 per cent of refugee applications to succeed? When compared with other countries—Canada is an obvious example—why are we so miserly with onshore applications? Even if we were to accept all of those who are at present in detention centres, especially those who have been in custody for three years or more, would it make any significant difference to our immigration program? Of course not.

Clause 6 of the Bill also provides a catch-all clause to negate any further possibility of redress to the courts at a State or Federal level for unlawful custody apart from the compensation I have outlined above. One of the pillars of a free country is recourse to the courts, yet through the insertion of proposed new section 54RA(1) in the Act there can be no further opportunities for these 104 or any other refugees who arrived in Australia after 19 November 1989 to find any sort of remedy through court proceedings.

This legislation is another disgraceful episode in this Government's refugee policy blundering. It seeks to snuff out the light of hope for a just and fair hearing for those who leave their homelands in terror and despair.

What is happening to this country? What is happening in this Government and in this Parliament? It has become heartless and inhuman. This legislation and the decision making and motivation underlying it expose a serious value vacuum in our society. The stories that we hear from Germany regarding the resurgence of the neo-Nazi movement promoting jingoism and racism are not so far afield. In Australia, it is emanating from our government policies rather than from subversive minorities. Australia's international reputation is at risk. Our approach to refugees exposes totally our hypocrisy in decrying the human rights violations of other countries.

As I have mentioned once before in a different context, the problem with racism is that people who have racist values and attitudes have great difficulty acknowledging that they are racist. They believe firmly that they are right and that everyone else is wrong. They live in an encapsulated world of black and white values and concrete thinking.

The reasons underlying this Government's preoccupation with migration legislation from the point of view of its supporters is simple: this land is ours; only if people apply through the correct bureaucratic processes will they be given consideration of their civil rights and access to the due process of law; and if we are not strict in enforcing our borders, we will be inundated by hordes trying to take advantage of our lenience and steal from us the benefits of this land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Supporters of this legislation. It is not my view. I assure those who have no difficulty with the view I have just expounded that there is another view. I believe that many people share it with me, and with Senator Harradine and some of the Australian Democrats. Unfortunately, very few of these people are in Parliament today. They are ordinary Australians who are not seized by fear or self-interest but who remember how fortunate we are to be in this country, and remember that we have done nothing to deserve being in this part of the world rather than elsewhere. The spirit of this is blatant in the second verse of our national anthem:

SPEECH.PARA: Beneath our radiant Southern Cross,
We'll toil with hearts and hands,
To make this Commonwealth of ours
Renowned of all the lands;
For those who've come across the seas
We've boundless plains to share
With courage let us all combine
To Advance Australia Fair.

I believe strongly that the spirit reflected in that anthem still remains the dominant community view. The narrow view that is reflected in this legislation is pathology, a disease which, as yet, has not pervaded or overwhelmed us. However, the disease emanates from the history of this country and is badly in need of treatment.

PARA.TAB: White Australia has a black history. This paranoia that people will rush in and steal our land may well be related to the fact that European Australia stole this land from its Aboriginal occupants only 200 years ago. I remember distinctly a brilliant cartoon—unfortunately, I cannot recall as distinctly its creator—in which the traditional Captain Cook arrival scene has one Aboriginal person onshore saying to another, `Mark my words, if we let in any more boat people, they'll be taking over.' Australia's lack of justice to Aboriginal people is now matched by its lack of justice to the unfortunate 450 boat people or `designated persons' who have tried to gain refuge on our shores.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to be brief in my contribution to this very important piece of legislation, the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992. During my speech, I will refrain from referring to an earlier matter of debate that was raised, but I will address in the future the fact that a committee of this Parliament can bring down reports and incorporate material into it without first giving the individuals concerned an opportunity of responding to distortions in a brief examination. I could prove the distortions, but will refrain from doing so at this juncture because of the pressure of other business. But I will address the matter when this Parliament resumes or when a new Parliament is elected next year.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and other government departments for their very speedy action in moving to protect the taxpayers of Australia. That is who we are talking about here—the taxpayers of Australia. Unfortunately, they should have moved on this matter some time ago and saved the taxpayers of Australia many millions of dollars, some of which has been poured into some sections of the legal fraternity to provide services which were not adequate for the task. I do not say that of every instance of government funds being given to sections of the legal profession to protect the interests of individuals involved in refugee applications.

I commend the Minister. On behalf of the taxpayers of Australia I record their thanks for the cooperation that the Opposition parties have shown in getting the legislation through the House of Representatives last night or early this morning and, hopefully, getting it through this place some time tonight or early tomorrow morning. Our obligations must lie with the taxpayers; they are the people who elected us to this place to govern and to spend money on their behalf. We would be abrogating our responsibility if we did not very quickly take action and enact legislation to protect the taxpayers' funds.

Some asylum seekers are seeking damages against the Government in the High Court. The Government has no money; the Government is in charge of taxpayers' funds. We have to protect those funds. I again commend the Minister and all concerned for moving so speedily in order to do so.
In her contribution, Senator Chamarette asked why the Government is singling out some 500 people.

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred and four.

—I understood her to say 500, but I accept her interjection. The record will show whether it is 500 or 104. The Government is not singling them out. The individuals who came here unauthorised and unasked and who did not apply singled themselves out. In many cases, they got together enough money to bribe boat owners in order to illegally enter this country. We did not bring them in. In some cases, they could have applied through the normal refugee stream and sought refugee status, but they did not do that. Perhaps they came here misguidedly; we are not getting the truth on all applications, possibly because of the legal assistance they are receiving. Maybe the truth will out at some time. I certainly hope that it does.

PARA.TAB: The Government and the Parliament has a commendable record on refugees in this country. It is a record that goes back to the early part of this century, and it is a record that all Australians have to be proud of. This Government, the fourth Labor Government, is sticking with that record.

In the recently announced immigration program for 1992-93, there was considerable debate and consultation with the Australian community—taxpayers, ethnic groups, government departments and State governments—on what the intake for immigration ought to be in this current financial year, 1992-93. It was determined by government that it be 80,000 in total. Twelve and a half per cent of that would be made up of refugees, which is an increase in percentage terms from last year accounted for by the fact that, in the last financial year, the figure was 12,000. It has gone down to 10,000, but the overall program has been reduced from 110,000 to 80,000. The Government has stuck with its principle of looking after refugees.

Where do we get the refugees from? We get them from all parts of this very troubled earth of ours. I refer honourable senators to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations tabled in this place about two months ago to give an indication of where refugees are coming from. A number of those people in the intake for last year actually came from refugee camps. They are true refugees; people who for a whole number of reasons have been displaced in their own country.

I advocated on a number of occasions in this place that that is where the priority should lie. The people who do not have homes and are living in appalling, subhuman conditions in many parts of world, including our very near neighbours in Asia, are the people we should be looking after first. We should not allow people, simply because they have money and are able to bribe their way into Australia, to take up the places that are allocated in our refugee program.

As the Minister said last night, it is disgraceful that some of those people are now seeking to sue the taxpayers of Australia. The taxpayers are the people who have kept them here for far too long, in some cases up to three years, and everybody agrees that it is too long. Now they have the gall to sue the taxpayers of Australia. Taxpayers have had enough.

Some of the interjections I have been getting from my right have talked about the white Australia policy. This is the danger. There are dangers in this argument. The taxpayers—the general public—are getting fed up of the apparent preferential treatment that seems to be given to some people. That is where the racism is coming from. In some cases it is very difficult to argue a contrary point of view, but it can be done if we persist. We have to do it with equity. We cannot just bend over and give it to some of the people who merely have some money in order to bribe their way into Australia.

It is a very troubled earth. The greatest proportion of my constituency work concerns immigration. I spend a great deal of time explaining to my constituents why their near relatives cannot get into Australia under the normal family reunion programs because of placings and their having to meet the points test. We have to argue that point through because of the limited positions available in our immigration program as determined by the elected government of the day.

One of the most soul-destroying things I have to do concerns people with relatives who are living in places like Bosnia-Herzegovina where nightly on television we see people getting killed, maimed and mutilated by people who were their former nationals. We cannot fit those people into the refugee program.

I am pleased to say that we have had some success and have been able to move very speedily. I commend the Embassy in Geneva for handling most of the claims under very trying circumstances. We are able to relieve the suffering for those people there and get them reunited with their relatives in Australia.

That is the job Australia should be doing. We should maintain control over it, and indeed we have to do so. The public demands that we maintain control, and by putting through this legislation tonight we are showing yet again that the democratically elected Parliament of Australia is determined to maintain that control and protect taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of legislation is a further chapter in the Government's shameful record in its treatment of refugees and applicants for refugee status to Australia.

PARA.TAB: I stand in this chamber in total agreement with what Mr Justice Einfeld said about Australia's treatment of boat people. He said that Australia's treatment of boat people seeking asylum had been a shameful blot on its compassion and humanity. Others have condemned Australia's treatment of applicants for refugee status, and among them is Brian Burdekin, the Federal Human Rights Commissioner.

This legislation is intended dramatically and drastically to limit compensation made to applicants for refugee status who have been illegally detained. It is another indication of the callous treatment of refugees by the Government and its absolute contempt for the judicial processes, including for the High Court.

The High Court ruled last week that the Government had detained 37 boat people unlawfully and that these boat people were entitled to compensation. It also declared invalid a law prohibiting a court from releasing a boat person from custody. Honourable senators will recall that that law was passed by this Parliament in May of this year and that a number of us—the Democrats, Senator Chamarette and myself—were vigorously opposed to that provision and the High Court struck it down.

Under this legislation, compensation will be limited to one dollar a day for any period of detention found unlawful by a court. Clearly, this legislation is designed intentionally to circumvent that decision of the High Court. What a preposterous situation it is. I will tell the Senate what the essence of this legislation is. In essence, if a boat person has been found by a court to have been illegally detained in a detention centre and that boat person is entitled to compensation, the Government will determine that compensation. Just think of the precedent that sets.

The Federal Government was the perpetrator of the illegal detention and the suffering for which the boat persons are entitled to compensation. Under this legislation the Federal Government sets itself up as the judge of the compensation to be made to the victims of its illegal act. That is a disgraceful situation. I have never known that to occur in any other legislation at all.

I challenge the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to tell the Senate what other legislation exists which contains such a preposterous provision. The implications in general areas of law are mind-boggling. If the perpetrator of a crime is the judge of what compensation will be paid to the victims of crime, then we are on the downward slide. That is precisely what this Bill does.

The Government should have heard what the High Court said. It should have gracefully accepted the decision of the High Court and agreed to relieve the torment and suffering which have been imposed on the boat people—in both Cambodia and Australia—by releasing them from detention and allowing their stay on humanitarian grounds. That appeal was recently made by the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference in Sydney, and the Government already has the power to do just that in respect of these 37 people.

The Minister says that he does not have the power in certain circumstances—I will come to that in the committee stage—to grant permanent entry on humanitarian grounds. I have an amendment being circulated which will put that beyond doubt. There will be no excuse for the Government or the Minister to say that they are bound hand and foot and have no power to consider matters on humanitarian grounds. Instead of gracefully accepting the High Court decision and taking that action, the Government has used devious and outrageous means to circumvent the High Court's decision, which was to uphold the individual human rights of these people.

The Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Tate, is also the Minister for Justice. How he can sit here and see this Bill do what it is doing is beyond me. Constitutionally, this legislation represents an unwarranted interference with the judicial power.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the Parliament's original intention?

—I will come to the Parliament's original decision. The High Court and any other courts look at the intentions of Parliament, and they obviously have looked at the intentions of Parliament. They have come down with a decision which struck out part of the previous legislation. I will come to that in a minute. The Government has set a totally unacceptable precedent in any democratic and civilised society committed to the rule of law. I look at the Minister and I wonder how he, as Minister for Justice, can countenance that.

PARA.TAB: As has been indicated by Senator Spindler, the legislation is contrary to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and our obligations thereunder. The covenant provides in article 9.5 that anyone who has been the victim of unlawful detention shall have an enforceable right to compensation. Article 26 provides that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled, without discrimination, to the equal protection of the law. Discrimination on the basis of status is prohibited, yet this legislation discriminates against applicants for refugee status whom the Government has described as designated persons.

The response of the Minister and Senator McKiernan to all of that is to blackguard the boat people. We should bear in mind that only about 400 boat people have landed in Australia. People are being told that there are thousands; there are 400. The Minister blackguards these people who have suffered torment in their place of origin, enormous difficulties in coming to Australia and then torment in detention in Australia for up to three years or more.

The Minister described these people as queue jumpers. Senator McKiernan accused them of bribing their way into Australia. There is no proof of that. It was a dreadful accusation and an assertion which should be condemned. These people have rights. They may be yellow, they may be coloured, but they have rights, the same as we have. The Opposition spokesperson, Senator Teague, said that these people have come here without papers, without visas and without passports.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have come here illegally.

—They came from a country—Cambodia—where there was no Australian embassy, at a time when the government of that country was not even recognised by Australia. How can they be queue jumpers? The words `queue jumping' suggest that people have not gone through the appropriate process. There was no process to go through. Many of them suffered under Pol Pot. Many of them suffered further under the Hun Sen regime, the Vietnamese-backed government. They came out here at a time when we did not recognise that government of Cambodia. It is morally and factually shameful to call them queue jumpers.

PARA.TAB: I heard what Senator Teague said: they are playing a legal game of hide-and-seek. If they are playing a legal game of hide-and-seek, let me ask Senator Teague this: is it a game to depart from the country of your origins to come to this country? Is it a game to suffer detention for over three years in this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it's the lawyers.

—It was not the lawyers at all. A number of church groups and community organisations asked the Department to allow these people to be released from detention into various communities on the cognisance of those church groups and community organisations. The Department deliberately, and with intent, refused that offer and kept these people in detention, unlawfully, as we have seen. Their lawyers did the right thing in attempting to get them released from the custody in which they were unlawfully kept. Two days before that case came before the Federal Court this Government rushed legislation through this Parliament to prevent a court considering the release of those people. I opposed it and it was subsequently struck down by the High Court.

PARA.TAB: I will move an amendment to the second reading motion that this matter be referred to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and I will come to that now as it is a germane point. When the Bill was presented to us in May it was rushed through the House of Representatives. I move:
Leave out all words after "That", substitute "consideration of the bill be postponed until the bill has been considered and reported on by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This measure to deny these people their day in court was rushed through the House of Representatives and rushed through this place two days before the court case, without the Bill going to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. However, after the Bill was passed in October this year, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did look at the Bill. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said a number of things about the measure. As to the provision that a court is not to order the release from custody of a designated person, the Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee suggested that the combined effect of new paragraph 54R(3)(e) and section 54S is that a `designated person' effectively would be denied access to the courts for the purposes of determining whether or not they should continue to be detained. The Committee suggested that this may be considered to be contrary to Article 9, paragraph 4 of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights. . .

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was drawing that to our attention, given its terms of reference. The terms of reference of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee include one which says that it must report in regard to Acts or Bills which trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The High Court found that it did trespass on these rights. I am suggesting to the Senate tonight that the courts will find parts of this legislation to be so trampling on the individual human rights of persons.

PARA.TAB: I am asking—unlike what the Parliament did last May—that this measure be allowed to go to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. As I said in the Senate on 7 December, the Government's treatment of refugees has been disgraceful, callous, uncivilised and bordering on the barbaric. Its handling of legislation in this area has been secretive and surreptitious as indicated by its latest actions in ramming this legislation through the House of Representatives in the early hours of this morning and expecting the Senate to kowtow to its wishes on this, the last day of the Parliament's sittings. If the Senate succumbs to these outrageous tactics with disregard for the rule of law and the rights of individuals and proper parliamentary procedures, it will be a day of shame.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) which is before us tonight is, indeed, an extremely difficult piece of legislation from the point of view of conscience and from the point of view of balancing the appropriate demands of various sections of the community for justice and fairness. I have had a great deal of difficulty with this piece of legislation, but I have come down on the side different from that of my colleague Senator Spindler, whose position I very much respect. I can fully understand and fully sympathise with his position but, on balance, I have come down on the other side. I would like a few moments to explain why I have taken that position. I do not know what the position of my other colleagues will be, because I think this is very much a matter of conscience.

PARA.TAB: I am also repeatedly on record as saying that Australia should substantially increase its intake of refugees. The position of the Democrats has, for a long time, been one in which those who come here for economic reasons—either their own or the perceived economic advantage of Australia—should be pushed aside in favour of those who come here for humanitarian reasons. For those reasons we have argued against the business migration and skills migration program and have argued for a substantial increase in migration of refugees.

I support a point made by Senator Harradine. Section 88 of the primary legislation is one that should have been reviewed a long time ago. There is no doubt in my mind that the Department has been lax in not attending to this matter before, and to do it at this late hour is a long way from ideal.

This situation has arisen because the High Court has ruled, as several other senators have said, that the part of the legislation recently passed through this Parliament in relation to the ability of the courts to order release from detention was invalid. In the course of that judgment, the Hight Court also passed some remarks about the availability of the means of egress from Australia being the means by which people came in here. It would seem that that part of the High Court decision does involve, as Senator Baden Teague pointed out, a considerable degree of arbitrariness in that, if the success of a case for compensation turns on whether the boats have been destroyed—and they may have been destroyed for very good reasons, say, of quarantine—then it seems a bad law that compensation should simply turn on that.

One example given to us in the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) was that people were actually rescued and brought into Australia on a naval vessel and, because that naval vessel has gone back into international waters, their means of entry into Australia is no longer available to them. Therefore, having been rescued, through this arbitrary mechanism, they may be eligible for compensation. That seems unusual and unfair. It certainly is discriminatory.

However, I spoke to Father Frank Brennan this afternoon, a person whom I very much admire and respect in this area. He points out that even if that leg of a claim were not to stand up, the claim might still stand in relation to the fact that section 88 was being used in an inappropriate way. He pointed out to me that that section was originally used in relation to people who had stowed away. They were, therefore, only likely to be detained for a very short time and then returned to the boat on which they had come in, and off they would go. He argues that it may well be that these people would be able to still sustain a case for compensation on the grounds that section 88 was being used in a way which was not intended originally.

So we are then left with a situation in which the number of people who may be eligible for compensation could be quite large. I understand the number is some 267 people. In my mind, that raises another issue of fairness and equity. If the amount of compensation is going to be very large, one must balance the demands on that amount of money for other perfectly good humanitarian needs in the community.

Senator Chamarette in her contribution mentioned the Aboriginal people from whom we, the white people or Europeans, took this continent 200 years ago. One is aware of medical programs, health programs, education programs and a whole lot of other things that are underfunded in terms of the indigenous people of this country. Yet money might well be expended on people who are not Australian citizens but who have come here for their own reasons and who have not yet entered Australia.

That brings me to the next point I want to raise. The word `detention' is used quite a lot in respect of these people. In a sense these people are not in detention. These people have not yet entered Australia. They are, as it were, in the same position as people in quarantine. They do not have visas or passports and they would enter Australia when they pass out of that place of detention through the gates with the appropriate paperwork.

So the argument in relation to fairness and the extension of Australian law to those people who are not yet in Australia but who are claiming refugee status and whose status has not yet been determined, in my view, is no different from that of a refugee who may be living under equally horrible or even worse conditions who is also outside Australia and still in the country of origin or some third country. I have been to some fairly horrific refugee camps in such places as Jordan where Palestinian refugees are living. If we are to extend the rights of Australian law to potential refugees who have not yet entered Australia but who are in detention camps on Australian soil, it seems to me that we should logically extend Australian law to those refugees who are in detention camps who apply for refugee status while on Jordanian soil or some other soil. The issue of how far one extends this particular prerogative seems to me to have become extremely blurred.

Let us consider the situation of people who have, to use Senator McKiernan's term, `bought their way in'. These people have presumably had enough money to buy a boat to get to our shores. In respect of fairness and equity, I think it is fair to compare the rights of those people with the rights of those who do not have that facility and who are in refugee camps, say, in Jordan and who are going through the processes of applying to enter Australia as refugees. I think there is a real equation here that has to be weighed up very carefully. I have great difficulty in accepting the argument that, simply because people have been able to buy a boat and land on our shores unannounced, their rights should supersede the rights of those who are somewhere else and applying for entry. It seems to me that those people should be treated equally, and then either Australian law has to be extended to those people in terms of compensation if they are in detention or, if not, if they are of some other status, the appropriate course is to treat them as people who are applying for entry but who have not yet entered.

Another aspect in relation to detention is that these people are not like prisoners who are kept in gaol. They are perfectly free to go back to their country of origin in that I understand at every stage the offer is there for them to be flown back to their country of origin. They are therefore not quite in the same situation as somebody who is in gaol. They are being detained in terms of not being allowed across that border from the detention camp into Australia.

It is for those reasons that, on balance—and it is very much on balance—I am concerned that this legislation should be passed. I want to reflect again on the inadequate way that the Government, apparently over a quite long period, has dealt with this legislation so that continually we find these loopholes that need to be plugged at the last minute. That is a very unsatisfactory situation and one that I hope the Government will now give some attention to and review very quickly so that these things do not occur again.

In relation to the reference to a committee—and this is the last item I want to pick up—it seems to me that if we refer this matter to a committee at this stage there will be in the interim a large number of applications before the courts and we will be very much in the situation that we were in last time, with the argument being put that we cannot change the situation once the matters are before the courts. So, if one perceives that this is a loophole, however unsatisfactory it is to close it in this arbitrary and peremptory way, I think it is better that it be done. I have great difficulty with this matter. I have spent many hours this afternoon worrying about this legislation. I fully sympathise with the position that has been taken by Senator Harradine, Senator Chamarette, Senator Spindler and probably some of my other colleagues, but, on balance, I have to say that on this one I come down on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the Minister sums up the whole debate, I thought it would be useful to speak on the amendment moved by Senator Harradine to refer the Bill to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills rather than have it proceed tonight. This is tantamount to the Bill not being passed. In my earlier remarks on behalf of the Opposition I noted the urgency of this legislation, and we must come down on the side of the urgency of this Bill being passed tonight.

—May I also briefly address the amendment moved by Senator Harradine. I will support the amendment. I believe the due parliamentary process needs to be observed at all times, even if a Bill is rushed through at the last minute—and perhaps even more so in that case. This is particularly the case with a Bill that proposes to vary the legal rights for a particular class of persons on Australian soil going before Australian courts—people who are to be denied their rights to challenge in court the amount of damages if they are found to have been unlawfully detained, and only in that case. I believe that that is a principle that needs examination before this chamber votes on it. It should not be determined in the hurry in which we are asked to do so tonight. Hence we will be supporting Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate, probably not surprisingly, my support for Senator Harradine's amendment. I would like purely and simply to defend the additional openness to compassion that this amendment allows us to have by referring to the Canadian policy on requests for refugee status. It is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Requests for refugee status can be made at Canadian ports of entry, at any Canadian Immigration Centre for those already in Canada, or, for those contravening immigration law, at the beginning of an immigration inquiry.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Chamarette, is that relevant to this particular amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe so.
—The Minister says it is not. You must be relevant to the amendment that is being proposed by Senator Harradine.

—Then I just say that I support Senator Harradine's amendment because it allows the Minister additional discretion, it escapes from the tight legality of the legislation currently before us and it allows us, as a nation, to have true consideration for strong humanitarian grounds, as he said, in 47A(1):

SPEECH.PARA: (b) there are strong humanitarian grounds for the grant of a permanent entry permit to the person.
Why I was referring—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chamarette, as I understand it, that is the amendment that Senator Harradine will move in committee. I think it is different from the amendment that he has moved to the second reading motion. You will be able to speak it to in the committee stage.
—I will seek leave later.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —In setting the context for this debate, may I first absolutely reject the extravagant language of both Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine. Senator Chamarette, for example, claimed that we were involved here in yet another expression of government sponsored resurgence of Nazism—that is what she said. She is speaking of a Government which, in the most difficult and trying times in the Australian community, still finds enough compassion—to use Senator Chamarette's terms—to permit entry and welcome to this country 10,000 refugees, who satisfy the humanitarian criteria.

PARA.TAB: That is what Australia does: we take 10,000 people into this country on humanitarian and refugee grounds every year, including during the last several years this Government has been in office. We do that with the support of the Opposition, and, I think, of the Australian community, despite hard times. We recognise the plight of tens of thousands of Cambodian refugees; we go to the border camps to assist them in coming to this country to find a future for themselves and their families.

To speak of the record of this Government and the Australian community in those terms has to be utterly rejected as flying in the face of the facts. Also, Senator Harradine said that the Government was tonight inviting the Parliament to act in a racist way because these people were brown or yellow—that was what he said. But what about the Polish people who arrived unannounced in a vessel back in October? They were also assessed against the international criteria in a process which allowed, of course, for natural justice. They were found not to have satisfied the internationally accepted criteria relating to refugee status, their claim was not accepted and they were deported; they were returned to some other country. The fact is that that was done in an even-handed way. Those people were not brown or yellow. Senator Harradine's claim that this is racially motivated legislation must be utterly rejected.

He also suggested that we should find some solace in the words of Mr Justice Einfeld. Why Senator Harradine called him Mr Justice Einfeld, I do not know. I do not think he was acting in a judicial capacity or exercising judicial power when he made the remarks to which Senator Harradine referred. Apparently he said that the way in which we treated those seeking recognition for a claim for refugee status was `a shameful blot on our compassion and humanity' when, in fact, there is a most exhaustive process of assessment of such claims according to the principles of natural justice. Perhaps it is that exhaustive process which may be subject to criticism rather than the claim that we demonstrate a lack of compassion and humanity.

I believe that the main argument of Senator Harradine, and perhaps other senators, is really directed against any detention at all while the claims of these people who arrive unannounced are being assessed. Whether the detention is lawful or unlawful is, in a sense, a secondary matter to the major objection to the process of holding people in detention for a period—which has in some instances been lengthy—whilst the claims are being dealt with. As I say, I reject the general claims that have been put in a such way as to colour the argument and try to move people to oppose this legislation.

I admire Senator Coulter for exposing the way in which he wrestled with and tackled the various arguments that can be put in relation to this legislation. It is not straightforward to give unambiguous adherence to what is put forward tonight by the Government to the Parliament as a way of dealing with a very difficult situation. But the fact is that we were faced with the High Court decision, which expressed a view as to the lawfulness or unlawfulness of the custody of certain persons who were held, it was intended, under section 88 of the Migration Act. The majority of the judges indicated their view that that detention or custody ought to be characterised as unlawful if the vessel on which the people arrived was no longer available to take them back into international waters; basically, that is what it amounted to.

I think Senator Coulter was the one who made a very telling comment when he said that, for example, if two boat loads of people came into the same inlet in north-west Western Australia, one vessel riddled with some disease-bearing organism which justified destruction by the quarantine authorities in order to preserve the Australian community from the encroachment of some exotic disease which could do great damage to our pastoral industries or to our human health, and the other vessel not so riddled and therefore able to be tied up at a wharf when seized by the various authorities concerned, those people who were on the boat that was destroyed in order to protect the Australian community would now have a claim for damages, for compensation from the Australian community in relation to their detention—

TALK.START.PARA: —The others wouldn't.

—whereas the others would not. This is really an absurd situation. I do not see anything untoward in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia saying—and I emphasise this—not that there is an interference with the judicial power, with the right of the court to determine whether the detention was unlawful—that is still a very proper, central, primary task of the bench of judges who will be approached in relation to these matters—but that the bench of judges will decide whether the detention was lawful or unlawful in accordance with the criteria which has been pointed to by the High Court in relation to section 88; that is their primary function. It is not being stripped away.

PARA.TAB: All that the Parliament is being asked to do this evening in relation to a decision made by a court that the detention was unlawful is to limit and restrict the quantum of the compensation. In that way, the interests of the Australian community will be properly protected by decision of the Parliament. That would be a justifiable approach which would be well understood within the Australian community which we represent; not in a racist, xenophobic way and not in a neo-Nazi way, but in a simple way to recognise the needs of the Australian community and the capacity of the Australian community to deal with the consequences of the High Court decision in this regard.

Senator Coulter again gave the example of persons being rescued at sea. Consider this for a moment. HMAS Townsville rescued persons at sea from a boat that would otherwise have sunk and they would have perished in the waters close to Australia. They were brought into Darwin. But, because the Townsville had to then go on other duties and was therefore not available to take these people back into international waters or back to their country of origin, their transit country or whatever, should a large compensation package be offered to them for the period that they were detained unlawfully if that is what a court determined their detention to be? Does anyone seriously suggest that the Australian community should now offer a large compensation package in respect of those persons who were saved from perishing by an Australian naval vessel? It is just absolutely absurd. It is just absolutely absurd when those whose boat did not founder and who came into the Port of Darwin and tied their boat up to the wharf would not have such a claim against the Australian people for compensation.

The Bill is saying that, in the situation where we have that consequence, there is a limit to the compensation to be determined by the Parliament. That limit is justifiable and, I believe, can be supported in good conscience by senators.

Finally, Senator Harradine says, `Well, perhaps the matter should be sent to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee'. As one of the founders and, if not the inaugural chairman, certainly an early chairman, of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, I think I understand its role reasonably well. Its role was to alert the Parliament—the Senate chamber in particular—to those instances where legislation might otherwise escape scrutiny, and a provision or some effect or impact on the rights of those who would be subject to the Bill might not be noted in a way which would allow proper debate in the chamber before a decision was made on whether to give support to the Bill concerned.

That is not the case tonight. Senators know the situation. We are having a very vigorous debate, which I think just exemplifies my point. There is no need for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to alert us to the various controversial elements in the Bill. I believe we are well able tonight to make a decision and I believe we ought to do so. Therefore, I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst some Opposition senators are in the chamber, I would like to ask Senator Tate whether clause 3 has a retrospective effect such that it could deny rights to certain people that they already had.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that I completely grasp the question. This Bill is designed to include those persons who arrive in the territorial sea of Australia between 1 December 1992 and 1 November 1993. My understanding is that it deals with a group of people who might arrive in the future and therefore does not strip away the rights of those who have arrived in the past.
—The date today is 17 December. This clearly is retrospective. It operates from 1 December.
—Nobody has arrived, Senator.

—If nobody has arrived, why does not the Government make it from today? Thus we would not be voting for retrospective legislation. As it is at the present moment, it is retrospective legislation. To Senator Tate's knowledge, nobody has arrived thus far. But who knows? There may indeed have been some people arrive. I am asking the Minister: on the face of it, is it not retrospective legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —The object of the Bill is to make sure that there is no gap in the coverage of the legislation. We therefore marked down 1 December as the operative time from which to have the extension to 1 November 1993. Those dates mark the beginning and the finishing limits of this provision. I suppose it is possible that somebody may have sneaked in in the interim, over the last couple of weeks. I cannot deny that is a possibility. It is intended that the legislation, to that extent, deal with such a situation.

—I would like to ask the Minister to respond to a question that was put by Senator Harradine in his speech. Senator Harradine spoke of the incongruity of the determination of compensation being made by the perpetrators of the particular unlawful offence. I would also like the Minister to comment on proposed new section 54RA, which refers to compensation. How will this place Australia in relation to article 9.5 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which states that where a person has been detained unlawfully they shall have an enforceable right to compensation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette will not find a provision in this Bill saying that the Executive will determine the limit of compensation. The whole point of the exercise is that we are asking the Parliament to determine the limit and the amount or quantum of compensation. So the rhetoric of Senator Harradine is really ill founded. It is not simply the Executive making a decision as to the quantum. We come into the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia asking it to pass that particular provision, which Senator Chamarette will find on page 3 of the Bill. Clause 6, 54RA(3) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The compensation that may be awarded to a designated person in an action under subsection (2) is to be $1 for each day of the person's unlawful custody.

That is a provision which is to be given statutory status if it is passed by the Parliament; it is not an executive matter. As to the question of the international covenant, the Government is not stripping away the right to compensation. It is, as I said, setting a level of compensation, a quantum, but it is not denying the process, most importantly, of allowing a judicial tribunal to determine whether the detention was unlawful or not. That is a basic judicial function. As to the quantum, that is being dealt with in the way suggested in the Bill and the Government does not believe that that is at variance with the international covenant which the honourable senator mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the Minister. Senator Chamarette appears to be quoting from Senator Harradine's press release of today which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government was the perpetrator of the illegal detention—now it sets itself up as the judge of what compensation is to be made.

When I read that I had the same response—that it is the Parliament that is determining the law. It is the Parliament that is setting the limit on compensation. I can only say in concert with the Minister, Senator Tate, to Senator Harradine and Senator Chamarette that they seem not to have grasped the burden, the central element, of this legislation which I tried to explain as clearly as I could and, of course, as Senator Tate did in summing up this second reading debate. I think Senator Coulter got to the kernel of the legislation. It is the arbitrariness of seeing an avenue to compensation never intended by this Parliament and the arbitrariness of that avenue opening up as a loophole on the grounds that the boat on which they arrived may not any longer exist.

PARA.TAB: I think we could have all sorts of semantics for another half an hour. I do not wish to rise again, but I just want to say that there is no point of difference with regard to this legislation between the Government and the Opposition. The Government and the Opposition have an approach to the integrity of Australia's immigration law which seems to have been lost by my good friends Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine. I can only appeal to them not to create straw men by the questions they ask of this legislation.

As I am on my feet, I will refer to the amendment that has been circulated by Senator Harradine. The amendment would require the Minister to respond within 28 days to any application for refugee status and the granting of a permanent entry permit on the basis of strong humanitarian grounds. The Opposition believes that the legislation is adequate and we will not support that proposed amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that extraordinary and indicative of a closed mind approach towards this matter. Senator Teague has just stated that he would vote against an amendment that has been circulated but not moved. He has not given me the courtesy of hearing any arguments that I might advance in favour of that measure. I will come back to that in a minute.

PARA.TAB: I also take note of Senator Teague's statement that the Opposition and the Government are at one in this matter. I wonder whether, in their hearts, all of the Opposition and all of the Government are at one in this matter, particularly in its legal consequences.

The final point I want to briefly mention without arguing about it is the statement by Senator Teague that we should not carry on with semantics and we should not raise straw men. I have heard a few semantics around this chamber tonight—one being the suggestion that certain boat people would be discriminated against in that they would not be able to claim that they were illegally detained because they had been brought into Australia by a ship of the Australian Navy which rescued them. That is arguable anyhow because that ship, as I understand it, has left Australian shores. I will not get into that argument. That is semantic argument for the purposes of this chamber.

The faults in the legislation are not the fault of the refugees. They are not straw men; they are real people who have suffered in their own country and suffered at the hands of this Government in Australia. I remind the chamber that church groups and community groups appealed to the Government to allow these people to be released into their custody and on their cognisance and the Government deliberately and callously refused that request. We cannot blame the refugees for seeking to go to the courts to be released from detention. I am not talking about semantics. Does proposed new section 54RA(1) remove a person's common law right to claim damages for false imprisonment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—As I understand it, the Minister said yes. I appeal to the chamber to listen to that statement. The Minister said that proposed new section 54RA(1) removes a person's common law right to take a damages action for false imprisonment. If it can be done for these people, it can be done again for others. If we regard these people as being somehow different or not equal to others, we are surely contravening the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and undermining the rule of law.

PARA.TAB: I have another question with regard to proposed new section 54RA(3), which fixes the compensation that may be awarded under subsection (2) at $1 for each day of a person's unlawful detention. I remind the chamber that proposed new section 54RA(2) substitutes for a person's common law right a right to paltry compensation that is technically determined by this Parliament but which we all know is determined by the Government. I restate what I said because it is accurate: the perpetrator of the actions which kept these people in unlawful detention has set itself up as the judge of the amount of compensation that will be paid to its victims.

My question regarding 54RA(3) is this: can the Minister advise the chamber of legislation which limits compensation for persons who have suffered false imprisonment? What is the situation of the Australian Federal Police? If the Federal Police has detained persons unlawfully, is there legislation which limits the compensation that is meted out to those persons or is that not a matter for the courts to determine, having regard to all the relevant circumstances?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has raised various matters. I will return to the question of proposed new section 54RA(1) and the question of the retrospective effect of unlawful imprisonment, as it was put, that would take away the right to sue for damages in relation to unlawful detention. I re-emphasise what I said before: the question of the unlawful detention, the false imprisonment, is still proper for a court to determine. Nothing in this Bill affects that. I simply want to emphasise that what is negated is the usual method of receiving an award of damages from the court should the detention be found to be unlawful. Senator Harradine then moved to proposed new section 54RA(3) to talk about the provision for compensation. He reiterated what is patently untrue. Perhaps I cannot put it that way; I beg his pardon.
—I don't mind.

—It is patently not the case that the Government controls the Senate. Government senators are a minority in this chamber. The Senate will determine this matter, not the Government. The Government is not imposing this matter. This will be a matter for the vote of the Senate as a chamber of the Commonwealth Parliament.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of whether I know of any statutory provision which is analogous to or a precedent for this, I do not know of any such provision. This is a case where—to once again return to the second reading debate but not to linger on it—the unlawfulness of the detention or custody depends on a set of circumstances which, I submit, are quite different to the sort of unlawful detention that might occur if a Federal police officer, without any cause whatsoever, simply took somebody off the street and held that person against his or her will.

An example put by some—no doubt it would be tested in a court—is that of a Royal Australian Navy vessel rescuing a foundering boat, taking the bedraggled and forlorn survivors off the sinking vessel from almost certain death into a port and then sailing away on other duties and that the fact of sailing away makes the detention of the boat people unlawful. That is a very different circumstance to the one that Senator Harradine pointed to as an analogy. I believe it is in that peculiarity that the right of the Parliament to substitute its view as to appropriate compensation for that which would otherwise be awarded by a court is proper to the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. That is why I believe the provision can be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —At what stage did the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs suspect that the 37 people were being unlawfully detained?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I may have missed the first part of the question, but I have tried to be scrupulous in not making a judgment as to whether any particular group of persons was unlawfully detained or held in custody. I understand that the High Court has made some suggestions that certain persons could be said to have been so held if it were the fact that, for example, boats were burned or whatever. I have merely tried to give some examples of where that claim could be made so that the detention could be characterised as unlawful. But I certainly did not mean to assert and substitute my judgment for that of a court as to whether the 37, 14 or 103 people were unlawfully detained. That is a matter for the courts.

—That does not answer my question. The Minister is asking us to tighten loopholes by this legislation. He said it in his second reading speech. He also pushed through legislation here in May to tighten the loopholes to ensure that persons were no longer detained under section 88 but were detained under division 4B. When—some time last year or January or February this year—did the Department become concerned that holding any boat person or any applicant for refugee status under section 88 in detention may not be lawful?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to recall, with the aid of officials, some of the history of the matter but, as has been reiterated during the debate today, the May legislation was triggered by an approach by some people to a court with the suggestion that detention could be said to be unlawful. I would imagine it must have been some time in April or thereabouts when this matter was being discussed.

PARA.TAB: That is not a primary consideration in the Senate's deliberations on this Bill tonight. That may have been relevant to the discussions in May.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister a couple of questions concerning the quantum of damage that the Bill provides. Senator Harradine called it paltry; I call it a subterfuge. I put it to the Minister that essentially the whole provision fixing the damages at no more than one dollar was introduced to, technically at least, evade the international convention that people must have the right to compensation if they have been unlawfully detained.

PARA.TAB: If the Minister does not agree with that proposition, I would like him to tell the Senate how he has arrived at the figure of one dollar per day.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I do not think it is fair to characterise this provision of a limited quantum of damages or compensation that might be available to a person as a subterfuge or a way to avoid an implication under an international undertaking that Australia has entered into. It is a way in which the Parliament is setting a limit, given the peculiar character of the circumstances which may lead a court to hold that the detention or custody of persons during a particular period was unlawful.

PARA.TAB: It is a very unusual circumstance. There is unlikely to be a precedent or a similar situation arising in the future and I believe that the amount of compensation is not to be properly characterised as mere tokenism. It is proper recognition, but obviously I will have to agree that it is a limited one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do find it difficult to understand the Minister's feeling that a person's freedom for 24 hours is worth one dollar. I wonder if the Minister can give me any precedent in Australia or anywhere else where a person's freedom—perhaps in the comparative imposition of a monetary fine and imprisonment—was equated to one dollar. I really do not know of any instance and I am searching for the Government's logic for it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are trying to grapple with the `logic' of the High Court. That is the problem that this Parliament is confronting. One is confronting a situation which—and I repeat this; Senator Spindler may have been out of the chamber when I said it before—arises from an example given by Senator Coulter. Suppose that two vessels limped into port. One was riddled with some disease-bearing organism which threatened the integrity of human health in the Australian community or posed a real threat to the pastoral industry in north-west Western Australia, and therefore that boat was destroyed and burned at the order of the quarantine authorities. The other boat was not so infected and was allowed to tie up in port. If elements of the High Court's decision are correct, the persons who came in on the vessel that was burned would be entitled to have their detention subsequently characterised as unlawful and would be, if the Parliament did not act, entitled to compensation or damages determined by the court in some way which is unsupervised or uncontrolled by this Parliament, and the others would not.

PARA.TAB: I will not go through the Royal Australian Navy example yet again. It is just such a peculiar situation that the Government is inviting the Parliament to act in this way. The fact that we cannot point to precedent only illustrates that this is a totally singular situation which has been brought about by the `logic' of the High Court's decision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister two questions. It seems to me that there are two elements to this. One is whether detention is lawful and if it is not, flowing from that is the question of compensation.

PARA.TAB: The first question is: if the amount of compensation which is payable is increased, does that not increase the arbitrariness of the difference between those people whose boat is destroyed and those whose boat is not destroyed, so that it actually decreases the arbitrariness of the decision in reducing the amount of compensation?

Secondly, on the question of the lawfulness of the detention—and this is the more serious question—is it the intention of the Government in setting the compensation at a very low level that people might continue to be kept in custody unlawfully simply because the amount of compensation payable has been reduced, or, if the court judged that the detention was unlawful, that those people would be released? I think that is the more substantial issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first point, it is probably theoretically true or practically true that the compensation level will be such that the discriminatory aspect of it is minimised, rather than if it were a large quantum of compensation that were granted. If that is Senator Coulter's point, I suppose I can agree.

PARA.TAB: As to the second point, there has been so much legislation going through that perhaps I am not as alert as I ought to be and I have forgotten the actual thread of the argument.
