Those who are presently held in custody or detention have been held in custody or detention lawfully. The High Court has confirmed that since the passage of the legislation in May.

Our dealing with those who may be said to have been held unlawfully up to that point in the way that is suggested in this Bill, does not really have an impact on or any relation to the Government's decision or good or bad faith in continuing to detain people under the current provisions. I am not sure that I have completely understood Senator Coulter's point and if he wants to reiterate it, I am happy to try to respond.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point is fairly simple. If there is a case—and I understand there is—where people have been detained unlawfully, and if those people are still in detention and the cost of keeping them in detention is only one dollar a day, is it the intention of the Government, if the High Court rules that their detention is illegal, to continue to keep them in detention, because it is very cheap for the Government to do so? Or will the Government release them? Does cost become a factor in the thinking of the Government as to whether it will adhere to the decision of the High Court or not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —The confusion arises because Senator Coulter is using the present tense. The question of this dollar a day business only refers to that period of detention which could be characterised as unlawful up to 6 May when the present provisions came into effect. The continuing holding of people in detention cannot be characterised as unlawful in the way that the High Court spoke of in elements of that judgment. Senator Coulter's question does not really follow.

—Could the Minister tell me whether this provision is limited to cases where a boat either is or is not available for people to leave? If people were found, say in the next two or three weeks after this Bill comes into effect, on an entirely different ground to have been held unlawfully, would not this provision of $1 a day apply equally to them? We seem to be hung up on that one example.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —If a person were found by a court to have been held in custody unlawfully between 19 November 1989 and before this Bill commenced, the terms of the Bill would apply and the provisions relating to compensation would come into operation. The point is being made that the Parliament is being asked to respond to indications given in the High Court judgment that the detention that would be characterised as unlawful would, in the opinion of the High Court, be related to those situations such as we have been describing and illustrating during the debate. The terms of the legislation itself do not restrict it in that way. It is up to the court to determine what is unlawful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My questions relate to our international obligations, in particular, under the ICCPR. I refer to article 9.4 and article 9.5. Under section 54RA(1) of the Migration Act, the right of a designated person who is in custody between 19 November 1989 and May 1992 to access common law under State, Federal or Territory law is removed. In passing, I say to Senator Spindler it is this which would restrict the compensation to the boats because this legislation that we are being asked to pass tonight denies any access to any other people who may have been in slightly different circumstances and may have been considered as unlawfully detained. They can no longer be considered. I refer the Minister to article 9.4. Does not section 54RA(1) of the Act contravene article 9.4? It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who is deprived of his liberty by arrest or detention shall be entitled to take proceedings before a court, in order that that court may decide without delay on the lawfulness of his detention and order his release if the detention is not lawful.
My second question relates to article 9.5 which refers to the contemptuously small amount that is being determined for the limitation of compensation. Article 9.5 says:
Anyone who has been victim of unlawful arrest or detention shall have an enforceable right to compensation.

I ask the Minister for his definition of compensation. How is compensation normally determined under law? Can it possibly be identical for 104 or so people? Is it not the case that an understanding of compensation has to take into consideration the individual circumstances of each person who is asking for that compensation before a court of law?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to emphasise that the question of the lawfulness of the custody or detention is and always should remain a matter for the court to determine. Therefore, the first part of the International Covenant which Senator Chamarette adverted to is properly observed in this Bill.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of compensation, we are reiterating matters. Quite clearly, compensation in this case is awarded by a court, if it decides to award it, in the amount of $1 per day for each day of the person's unlawful custody. Compensation is a monetary response by society to the finding of the court that a detention or holding in custody has been unlawful. It is an amount which is properly described as a community response to that finding. The amount which the society is prepared to pay in a particular circumstance can be properly determined, quantified and limited by the society's elected representatives. That is what the Parliament is being invited to do tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we not pre-empting the court's determination of what is appropriate by making something uniform? I would also like to point out that it was Parliament which moved the legislation in May and, therefore, was in error in making what the Federal Court believed could be a case of unlawful detention. It is again Parliament which is being asked to set the penalty. We are being asked to set a penalty quite irrespective of the individual circumstances of the people who may be in the category of unlawful detention. To use Senator Coulter's term, it is an arbitrary provision that we are being asked to ratify.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can add a great deal more. I have indicated that it is a deliberate action of the Parliament to substitute its own judgment as to a fair response—monetary response in this case—by society to a finding of a court that detention or custody was unlawful. Therefore, what Senator Chamarette says about the different operation of the provision that would be the case if the court awarded compensation is undoubtedly true. But I still urge the Senate to accept that this is a proper role for the Parliament in this peculiar situation.

—I want to raise three very quick matters. How many persons does the Department estimate the rights of whom are likely to be affected by this legislation? Are those people only Cambodians or are they Chinese or Vietnamese?

PARA.TAB: In respect of the forcible return of PRC nationals who have sought refugee status in Australia, what is the situation in regard to Mr Conybeare's visit to the PRC? Can the Government give a guarantee that persons who have been forcibly sent back to the PRC have not and will not be punished? Finally, the Minister mentioned that I had used the word `racist'. I used the word, but I do not know that I used it in my statement. If I did, I probably did so because on 11 November 1992 on the SBS program Dateline Michael Phillips, the assistant director of determination of refugee status at DILGEA, described the attitude of some people in the Department in this area as having a rejection mentality, as being biased and extremely racist and having preconceived ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: —His statement does not justify this Bill being called racist. It is not racist.

—These people have been detained in custody. They have been illegally held in detention, and deliberately so. Michael Phillips, the assistant director of determination of refugee status has been saying this. I reiterate the fact that it is not the problem of these people who have been detained. They have been offered, at any stage, to go back to Cambodia or China. Although they have been held in detention, sometimes for three years, they have not chosen to do so. They could have had free flights to China or Cambodia with chicken and champagne breakfasts. They have decided to suffer the illegal detention. That is what we are talking about. Do not get me going on the situation. The points that have been made here are red herrings. As I have said before, church groups and community groups have asked for these people to be released into their custody and the Department has deliberately refused to do so. It is the Department which is holding them illegally in custody.

PARA.TAB: I will come back to my questions. I want to know how many are involved whose rights are affected by this Bill. What guarantees have been received and how have these been tested? I have asked this question again and again and I have not been given a satisfactory answer: are those seven refugees who were forcibly sent back from Port Hedland to China in custody? An affidavit has been presented to the Federal Court in Perth which states that they are in gaol and are undergoing re-education which involves forced labour.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to Senator Harradine's first question about those whose rights are likely to be affected, that would depend on the Government, the Department or me offering an opinion as to whether a certain number of people were unlawfully detained. Of course, that would be a question for the court. I am advised that in the order of 300 people have been detained. A court could find that a portion—greater or smaller—of that number had been unlawfully detained in the previous period, if the High Court's indications are followed through.

PARA.TAB: As to the visit to Bejing recently of Mr Conybeare, the Secretary of the Department, I understand that he was given assurances at a very high level within the foreign ministry of the Peoples' Republic of China to the effect that those who returned, or were returned, from Australia—both instances—would not be mistreated or persecuted simply because of their fleeing, if that is the word, from China. That assurance was given at an extremely high level and is understood by the Australian Government to have the full authority of the Chinese Government.

Senator Harradine referred to an affidavit presented to the Federal Court in some proceeding in Perth. I am not in a position to say whether that affidavit can be found to be justified or truly pointing to the facts it claims to present. All I can do is repeat the assurances that have been given at those high levels. I believe that was the proper task and responsibility of the Secretary of the Department and that is what he obtained.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let that go. I had the honour of having dinner with Professor Wang Ruowang, one of the most famous of Chinese dissidents. He was gaoled by the KMT, became a communist, went right through the system, was gaoled by the communists, and is a very well known author. I put that question to him. His clear response was that you do not believe what the PRC officials tell the outside world; you believe what they tell their own people. They told the outside world that nothing happened in Tiananmen Square; these are the same people who gave Mr Conybeare those assurances. Have Mr Conybeare or any of our officials been to the area where these people were returned? Have they actually seen for themselves whether what is stated in that affidavit—on the information provided by a Chinese PRC security officer—is correct? This is a very serious question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —No independent team has been sent to check the particulars of the allegations that are contained in the affidavit that has been put in to a Federal Court in Perth. As I say, the responsibility and the task of the Secretary of the Department was discharged in the way I have described, and that is the sum of that matter that I can relate to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "2A. After section 47 of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Circumstances in which permanent entry permits may be granted to persons whose application for refugee status has been rejected

PARA.TAB: 47A.(1) The Minister may grant a permanent entry permit to a person whose application for refugee status has been rejected if—

TAB.TAB: (a)a person applies to the Minister for a permanent entry permit within 14 days of being notified of the rejection of their application for refugee status;
(b)there are strong humanitarian grounds for the grant of a permanent entry permit to the person.

PARA.TAB: (2) The Minister must determine an application made in accordance with subsection (1) within 28 days of receiving the application.".

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Committee that this amendment proposes to insert after section 47 of the principal Act a provision whereby the Minister may grant a permanent entry permit to a person whose application for refugee status has been rejected. It then goes through the circumstances that apply. I will not take up the time of the Committee by reading it all out.

PARA.TAB: The reason I am putting this forward is that I believe that there are circumstances in which the exercise by the Minister of a power to grant a permanent entry permit on strong humanitarian grounds is warranted. That is recognised in any event by the provisions of section 115 of the legislation. I quote from a copy of a letter which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) provided to me after our last discussion here on 8 or 9 December:

SPEECH.PARA: The current mechanism for allowing some persons rejected for refugee status to stay in Australia on humanitarian grounds makes use of the Minister's powers under section 115. In essence, the Minister grants applicants a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit in spite of the fact that they have been found not to meet an essential criterion for the permit, namely that they have been determined to be a refugee. The key point is that to access the Minister's powers, an entry permit review application must have been rejected. A refugee status review rejection does not trigger the Minister's section 115 powers. This reflects the fact that at the time section 115 was drafted, refugee status decisions were not formally incorporated in the Act.
Rather than read the whole letter, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter read as follows—

PARA.TAB: MINISTER FOR IMMIGRATION, LOCAL
GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brian Harradine
Senator for Tasmania
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to the issue you raised in the course of debate on the Migration Reform Bill 1992 on 10 December 1992 on the subject of access of the Cambodian boat people to humanitarian consideration. I am writing to confirm the position outlined by Senator Tate in response to your questions on the issue, namely that under the present Act and Regulations persons who make unauthorised entry to Australia do not have such access.

The procedures currently in place for allowing refugee applicants access to humanitarian consideration are complex. They rely on a power of the Minister to grant individuals an entry permit, in this case a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit, in spite of the fact that criteria for that permit may not have been met, in certain exceptional circumstances.

The Migration Act provides that applicants are entitled to be granted an entry permit if they meet the criteria set out in regulations. Conversely, the Minister is specifically enjoined from granting an entry permit where the criteria are not met. There are only two circumstances where the Minister may grant an entry permit to an applicant who does not meet the regulatory criteria. This is when an application for a permit has been rejected either at internal review under section 115 of the Act or by the Immigration Review Tribunal under section 137 of the Act. In that case, the Minister may grant the permit if he or she considers it would be in the public interest to do so.

The current mechanism for allowing some persons rejected for refugee status to stay in Australia on humanitarian grounds makes use of the Minister's powers under section 115. In essence, the Minister grants applicants a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit in spite of the fact that they have been found not to meet an essential criterion for the permit, namely that they have been determined to be a refugee. The key point is that to access the Minister's powers, an entry permit review application must have been rejected. A refugee status review rejection does not trigger the Minister's section 115 powers. This reflects the fact that at the time section 115 was drafted, refugee status decisions were not formally incorporated in the Act.

The Cambodian boat people are designated persons held in custody under Division 4B of the Migration Act. Previously their status was that of prohibited entrants held under section 88 of the Act. No review rights attach to any entry permit or visa application made by a prohibited entrant or a designated person. As a result, the Minister's powers under section 115 or section 137 cannot be engaged in respect of any such application.

As applicants who have not entered Australia, in the strict legal sense in which the term entry is used in the Act, there are a limited number of visas and entry permits for which the Cambodians can be considered. It would seem that the only permit for which they might qualify is the domestic protection (temporary) entry permit. If the Cambodians are not found to be refugees it is likely that they will not meet the regulatory criteria for any entry permit or visa. If this proves to be the case, neither the Minister nor any officer of the Department will have the power to grant them an entry permit or visa under the law as it presently stands.

In your remarks to the Senate on this issue, you drew attention to the Report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System, particularly paragraphs 5.4 and following. In those paragraphs, the Committee outlines its understanding of the operation of the present mechanism for granting humanitarian consideration. Although I cannot, of course, speak for the Committee, I think it would be fair to assume that the paragraphs in question were not intended to be a full and complete description of that mechanism. As it happens, the Committee has quite correctly set out the procedures which apply for the normal case. The Committee apparently did not feel it necessary for the purposes of its report to note that these procedures do not apply in all cases. As noted above, in the case of a designated person or a prohibited entrant, the Minister has no power to accede to a recommendation to grant an entry permit on humanitarian grounds.
I hope that this letter helps to clarify the issues you have raised in relation to this complex and important issue.
Yours sincerely
Gerry Hand

TALK.START.PARA: —In short—and I will be very short—it seems to me that there could well be circumstances where the Minister may consider, pursuant to his letter, that he has no power; that his hands are tied. There may be circumstances where he would say, `Yes, clearly there are strong humanitarian grounds and we should consider those grounds; we should not close the option up'. Under the present circumstances, pursuant to the letter that he has written to me, he does not have such power. I read the penultimate sentence of that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: As noted above, in the case of a designated person or a prohibited entrant, the Minister has no power to accede to a recommendation to grant an entry permit on humanitarian grounds.

I believe that to be unduly restrictive, and I think any reasonable person would understand that. I am not necessarily talking about the people under current review, although I know that there have been appeals, including by the Australian Bishops Conference, for those people to be allowed entry on humanitarian grounds. But, in general terms, I believe that this measure deserves to be supported. It sets certain time limits. It is not a Kathleen Mavourneen. It is not putting the thing on the long finger and stretching things out because, in respect of a person whose application for refugee status has been rejected, I have included the provisions that:
(a)A person applies to the Minister for a permanent entry permit within 14 days. . .—
so he or she has to apply within 14 days—and:
(b)There are strong humanitarian grounds for the grant of a permanent entry permit to the person.

If those conditions are met, this enables—it is not a mandatory thing—the Minister to consider that and to grant a permanent entry permit, if the Minister so chooses. Also, the Minister must determine the application within 28 days of receiving it. I think it is perfectly reasonable and I appeal to the Committee to accede to this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in support of this amendment. I begin by saying that I do not consider this legislation to be racist. Policies may be determined as being racist. However, this legislation, in respect of which we are considering an amendment, is a logical extension of the 4B legislation which this Parliament passed in May of this year. As I said, I do not regard the legislation as racist, but it is, arguably, discriminatory.

PARA.TAB: To call arguments coloured or emotive may be a way of marginalising them. People are entitled to hold their different views. In my view, the policy underlying the legislation represents a discriminatory stance. Australia's migration intake is, in my view, biased against refugees. If people have money, connections and the ability to fill in forms, they are facilitated in access to this country. Senator Tate said earlier, as an example of our generosity, that we take 10,000 refugees. This legislation determines that we only take 10,000 refugees who are able to satisfy bureaucratic requirements. That makes it discriminatory because consideration is attached to a capacity to fill in forms and undergo entry requirements. The obvious example given by Senator Harradine was the ridiculous labelling of people from Cambodia as queue jumpers when there is no existing queue.

Determination of refugee status should be based not on capacity to fulfil procedures but on an examination of certain factors that have to do with the situation from which those people have come. It should not be based on their capacity to comply with correct bureaucratic process. I cite the Canadian practice and policy which is quoted in the August 1992 report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations entitled appropriately—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette, are you speaking to the amendment?

—I am. It may seem a bit convoluted but it will come back fairly shortly, Mr Chairman. That report is entitled Australia's refugee and humanitarian system—achieving a balance between refuge and control. I am using this to illustrate that Senator Harradine's amendment actually assists us to achieve a balance between refuge and control. In sections 2.47, 2.48 and 2.49 of this report, we are given an example of the procedures that are used in the Canadian ports of entry. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.47Requests for refugee status can be made at Canadian ports of entry, at any Canada Immigration Centre for those already in Canada, or, for those contravening immigration law, at the beginning of an immigration inquiry.

2.48At the preliminary stage, senior immigration officers carry out a pre-inquiry review of any humanitarian and compassionate factors on the case which may warrant special consideration. The factors considered are whether:

TAB.TAB: .it is a person upon whom their government likely will impose severe sanctions on their return home;
.it is a person upon whom others in Canada already are dependent; and
.an individual whose personal circumstances in relation to the laws and practices of their country are such that they will suffer unduly on returning home.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.49Individuals who meet these criteria can be granted permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds, and are not required to go through the refugee determination process.

I support Senator Harradine's amendment because it reduces the cold, technical, inhuman, watertight implacability of this Australian migration legislation. Without allowing the concern that people have expressed about judicial process, it actually opens up to the discretion of the Minister the humanitarian factors that we ought to be taking into consideration. I therefore urge other people in this chamber to also support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting this amendment. The Bill is designed to remedy a particular problem that has arisen. We do not believe that this is an opportune moment to be vesting the Minister with the sort of power that is envisaged in Senator Harradine's amendment. In fact, I think Senator Chamarette's remarks really led to a true description of what is intended, in a sense. Senator Chamarette spoke in glowing terms of the Canadian system, where I think she said that, in the end, a person does not have to go through the rigours of the refugee determination process. That is precisely what, in a sense, Senator Harradine's amendment would achieve: that one would formally go through a refugee determination process, but in the end the pressure would be on the Minister to grant entry anyway. I believe that that would not be an appropriate way to deal with certain matters, and certainly not in the context of this Bill tonight. For that reason, the Government will be opposing the amendment.

—The Democrats will be supporting this amendment. To summarise briefly all of our arguments: it would be a brave person indeed who in this particular area could foretell every circumstance and could draft legislation designed to meet every possible configuration of human circumstances in this situation. We believe that some discretion and responsibility must be left with the Minister to discharge in this situation.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not seeking to divide on these questions. We have made clear our position on the clauses of the Bill.

—Because we have concluded the debate at the committee stage, I rise only to say that when similar matters to this were before the chamber on 7 and 8 December, I asked the Minister and the officers—informally and formally—for a point by point answer to two articles that had appeared in the Australian making allegations about government practice in the detention of boat people. I still expect that response; I have not got it yet. The Parliament is finishing, but I would still like to get the response. I shall not speak for any longer than is necessary to mention that yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald, there was another article by Louise Williams citing a former officer at the Villawood Detention Centre, a Mr Biro, and he made other allegations. I am patient with the Government, but I would like to see the Government's responses to these matters as soon as it may be practical to receive them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —On that occasion, Senator Teague indicated that he was going to ask questions in relation to these matters point by point. I was briefed to respond. He did not ask the questions in the committee stage of that debate.
—There was a misunderstanding.

—There may have been a misunderstanding, but we were ready to respond fairly comprehensively to the various points. If we can deal with the matters together, we will, but I do not want to leave it on the record that we ignored Senator Teague's request. We understand that there has been a misunderstanding as to the timing of the response. We will respond—this side of Christmas, I hope.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
House of Representatives message:

PROCTEXT.PARA: SCHEDULE OF THE AMENDMENTS MADE BY THE SENATE TO WHICH THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES HAS DISAGREED
No. 1—After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "2A. The provisions of this Act do not apply to benefits provided to employees of scientific, religious, charitable or educational institutions.".

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to amendment No. 1 of the Senate

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senate amendment No. 1 is not acceptable because:

(1)Many of the benefits provided by the institutions mentioned in this amendment are exempt from fringe benefits tax. For example, benefits provided to religious practitioners in respect of their pastoral duties, benefits provided to employees of public benevolent institutions, live-in accommodation and food benefits of employees of government/religious/non-profit organisations who care for elderly and disadvantaged persons and live-in accommodation and food benefits of domestic workers employed by religious institutions or religious practitioners are exempt benefits.
(2)There is no reason in equity why those institutions mentioned in the amendment which are subject to fringe benefits tax should not pay fringe benefits tax on car parking benefits.
(3)The use of the term "educational institution" rather than "public educational institution" grants the exemption to profit making organisations who pay both income tax and fringe benefits tax.

(4)While the words "scientific, religious, charitable or educational" have a developed interpretation in the context of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a different meaning may be given to these words under the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Committee does not insist upon the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments have been rehearsed pretty well, and I will not extend them. Nevertheless, this matter is fairly important. I am aware that Senator Watson proposes to move an amendment to this motion, and I imagine Senator Kernot will want to speak on it as well.

PARA.TAB: I want to make a few points to make the Government's concern clear. Senator Watson's proposed amendment, which he has circulated and which, I accept, is a significant step forward from where we were with the first amendment that was sent back with which the House disagreed, solves two of the problems which I had. I recognise that; but it still causes two problems.

The first and most obvious problem is revenue. It is very hard to be specific, but my personal estimate—it is not an official estimate—is that it may cost Consolidated Revenue about $10m. That means either that we have $10m less with which to provide public services, or that we have to get $10m from other taxpayers or increase the deficit by $10m; one of those three things. Each time we propose an amendment, thinking we are being generous to one group, we have to reflect on the fact that we are punishing someone else.

The second problem is that it imposes an inequity. Let me give two examples. If the amendment proposed by Senator Watson is accepted, we get two absurdities. One is that the vice-chancellor of the University of Melbourne will be able to park tax free in the centre of Melbourne—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the tutors?

—I want to make a comment about the tutor at the university who gets paid about the same as a low to middle range clerk in any private sector institution, so I will come back to that. The vice-chancellor of the university will be able to park tax free, but the person who comes to paint the building will not be able to do so. A clerk in the Public Service or private sector on one-tenth of the salary of the vice-chancellor who has free car parking back at headquarters, will not be able to. I do not blame the vice-chancellor for being concerned about that; what I cannot work out is why the Senate is concerned about it.

PARA.TAB: Then there is the second ridiculous anomaly. Senator Kernot raised with me privately and then in her interjection the analogy of the university tutor. Let me put this to her: what she is proposing is that that university tutor will be able to drive into the university and park in the staff car park tax free; but the person who works in the bank on the university campus will not. People who work anywhere where they are not employees of the university will be doing exactly the same thing, but their tax situation will be different. I think Senator Kernot is creating absurd anomalies. We would very strongly suggest that it is not the most appropriate thing to do. We hope that the Senate will take this last opportunity to reconsider its position. I do not wish to take any more of the Senate's time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for his comments. The hour is late. I also thank him for advising the Senate of the cost to the revenue of $10m. We acknowledge that the cost to the revenue is a significant amount of money and could well be in that order. We do not dispute that amount. The Senate has to honour a commitment to the Budget in terms of this Bill of $90m. That $90m will be met and will be exceeded by quite a significant amount.

PARA.TAB: The Senate may recall that when we examined the Budget Papers the figure for car parking was $120m. That was based on the premise of a start-up date in April. By the Government's own action, the deferral is to 1 July. Further, by the Government's own action in terms of the amendments that it made, initiated through this chamber, to the Fringe Benefits Assessment Bill, the grossing-up impact reduced the second year's take quite significantly. So by the Government's own action it has significantly reduced the revenue from car parking on two counts.

The Parliamentary Secretary mentioned certain inequities. I put it to him that this car parking Bill is full of inequities. There is the one kilometre discrimination. You can have one part of your factory within the one kilometre and another part of the factory just across the road or down the road outside the one kilometre—it is full of discrimination. Does not the Parliamentary Secretary have any concern or compassion for those struggling demonstrators in the physics labs and the chemistry labs who are working part time struggling to get an undergraduate degree or working for a postgraduate degree? He should think of not only the demonstrators but also the part time tutors. Senator McMullan might have been one himself. He should think of all those people who came up the hard way, pulling themselves up by the bootstraps, coming onto campus in the old Volkswagen, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —Selective indignation.

—Senator McMullan has selected the vice-chancellors; I am selecting the struggling people. I put it to the Parliamentary Secretary that this whole Bill is not going to attract the tax from the sort of people he says it is. The real people he will catch are the poor workers who park at the back of the factory around Tullamarine. What is the boss going to say? `Out on the street because of the car parking legislation, because it's going to cost us too much money or cost you your jobs. Your job, or out on the street for your car'. It is full of discrimination. So the Parliamentary Secretary should not come to me with a sad story at the university.

PARA.TAB: Universities are short of money; TAFEs are short of money; and schools are short of money. The whole purpose of these amendments is to help those who have a lesser ability to pay. We have tremendous concerns about the impact on the business community because we do not like taxes on business. But we also have a far greater concern about those sections of the community who have a lesser ability to pay.

I must respond to the manner in which the Parliamentary Secretary in the other place had some concerns about our inclusion of religious institutions. He quite rightly said that ministers of religion in the pursuit of their pastoral duties are not subject to the same degree of fringe benefits tax as are others. But I ask the Parliamentary Secretary: what about the part time secretary who comes in five hours a day for one day a week who is going to get caught? The church will have to pay the fringe benefits car park tax. What about the church gardener who comes in and works six or seven hours mowing the lawns, and the cleaners who come in to do the cleaning up, who park behind the church and who are going to get caught by the fringe benefits? These are the people who the Parliamentary Secretary in the other place, in following his prescribed notes so closely, failed to acknowledge. We can always draw exceptions, but we are concerned about these particular categories.
I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this new amendment that I now move on behalf of the coalition. I move:
That the Committee does not insist on the amendment disagreed to by the House of Representatives, but proposes the following amendment in substitution:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 5, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) Section 58G of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following subsection:

SPEECH.PARA: `(2) If the employer of an employee is:
(a)a scientific institution (other than an institution carried on by a company, society or association for the purposes of profit or gain to its individual shareholders or members); or
(b)a religious institution; or
(c)a charitable institution; or
(d)a public educational institution;
the following benefits provided in respect of the employment of the employee are exempt benefits:
(e)an eligible car parking expense payment benefit;
(f)a car parking benefit.'.".

The difference between this amendment and the amendment that I originally sent to the House of Representatives is that my amendment was in terms of the Car Parking Bill; I have now included my amendment as part of the Fringe Benefits Assessment Bill. This procedure is a lot neater for people wanting to index and follow in proper sequence over time the effect of the exemption on these particular institutions. It is far easier to go to a fringe benefits Act, which is readily available, than a separate little Act called the Car Parking Act. Of course, the Car Parking Bill did get incorporated into the Fringe Benefits Bill. So it is a tidying up process, and I thank the Tax Office for the assistance which it has given us.

PARA.TAB: Since this amendment has been mentioned, there has been almost all-party support around the traps—put it that way—for it. I think it will be immensely popular amongst the public educational institutions and the charitable institutions. One might say that a couple of those terms are perhaps a little superfluous, but I think it indicates our intention to include them. I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his goodwill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson is particularly persuasive at this early hour of the morning. The Australian Democrats have given this a lot of consideration. We can all use selective examples; we have heard the example of the vice-chancellor, we have heard of the painter and the tutor.

PARA.TAB: The question is what impact this amendment will have on public educational institutions in particular, which will have the choice of absorbing the cost or passing it on. If it is passed on, this will be an impost on those who seek the services of these public educational institutions. In recent years these institutions have been starved of funds. A little while ago Senator Schacht interjected, `We just cannot raise the revenue to give these institutions more money'. There is no suggestion of this revenue being tied. All of this revenue money goes into the black hole. Revenue from HECS was going to find its way back into education all those years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does.

—It is just a revenue raising measure. The proposal in Senator Watson's amendment is said to be going to cost $10m. Senator Watson has asserted previously that although the Government has estimated that the whole measure will raise $90m in the first year, his assessment is that it is going to be double that at least. There is a windfall coming and the Government wants to quibble over $10m.
—You cannot deny it is still going to cost money.
—It is, but the Parliamentary Secretary should not lose sight of what the Government is going to make out of it either. To be brief, we are attracted to Senator Watson's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the bona fides of Senator Watson in raising this issue of protecting scientific institutions, schools and churches. It is basically supporting the motherhood groups in the community that all of us would naturally feel obliged to support. But I really think the issue at stake is one of equity.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson says there are inequities if one is on the wrong side of wherever one draws the line—whether it is one kilometre or 1 1/2 kilometres. It means that if one is inside the line, one has to pay no matter what one's income is and no matter who one is. What Senator Watson is doing with this amendment is adding another inequity in that if a person happens to be in a certain occupation he will get an advantage.

It is not just a matter of the chancellor or the vice-chancellor of a university. Many other people in these institutions on medium and upper medium level incomes and even low income earners may be affected. Other very low income earners in that kilometre range working in the private sector will also be affected and will have to pay. Once that boundary is defined, I think it is inequitable that a person who happens to be in the private sector has to pay but a person who is in the public sector or in a general charitable or religious area does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The boss pays.

—The employer pays. I am saying that if one happens to be a private sector employer, one has to pay. If one is in a certain public sector or in a charitable institution, et cetera, one does not have to pay. I am always intrigued that when lists are drawn up we always find somebody who goes out of his way with the help of a clever tax accountant to find a way to broaden that exemption into definitions.

PARA.TAB: I notice that proposed new subsection (2)(a) in Senator Watson's amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: a scientific institution (other than an institution carried on by a company, society or association for the purposes of profit or gain to its individual shareholders or members); or
Many of our universities, for example, are now setting up private subsidiary companies to commercialise their research to take advantage of the encouragement we have given them to make a profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because they want to take advantage of their research. So if one happens to be the head of a university research section that makes a profit as a commercial operation, under Senator Watson's amendment one will not have to pay a tax. However, a private enterprise research body down the road which, as a commercial undertaking, makes a profit, has to pay. This is where I think we run into the problem of creating an inequity in respect of low income earners and high income earners working within the same one kilometre. The argument about the one kilometre is a different matter. I argue that, in terms of real equity, once one is inside the line there should be no exemptions.

PARA.TAB: The final point I want to make is that, in a practical way, many people in these institutions will get a real advantage. They will be using their car park. Take my own case in South Australia. Adelaide University is on a prime site. It is almost in the centre of the central business district of Adelaide and has hundreds of car parking spots for staff. They will all be exempt. The university staff members will have the social advantage of being able to use that car park of a weekend and after hours for their social amenity of going shopping, going to entertainment and so on.

It is a real advantage to be able to park one's car in the Adelaide University grounds, close to the central business district and all the entertainment areas of Adelaide. Staff will pay nothing. But if one is in the private sector a hundred yards down the road, one will have to pay. I do not think an institution such as the Adelaide University should be exempt. I think it creates inequity that will cause some sense of upset and envy between two different groups of people.

I can understand in a simple way that the amendment seems good. But the amendment will create real inequity between groups of people within the one kilometre. Therefore, I would urge Senator Watson and Senator Kernot from the Australian Democrats to consider the issue of real equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to a number of points raised by Senator Schacht. I think it is very important that we clarify the point that the employers pay the fringe benefits tax on behalf of the employees. In effect, it is a poll tax, and the rate of the poll tax is determined by the price at the nearest commercial parking station. Admittedly, this will be the lowest price. That parking station does not discriminate between the rich fellows and the very poor fellows, and this is another bad feature of this tax.

PARA.TAB: Fancy putting a tax on the rich at the same level as the poor! This is effectively what we are doing. We are seeing a poll tax imposed by this Government that discriminates very strongly against the lower income sections of the community. I am quite appalled that a man of the humanity and humility of Senator Schacht should support a tax that will be imposed on universities. It is late in the night; perhaps we had better stop talking.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Resolution reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

PARA.TAB: That the report be adopted.

Next time honourable senators have a pet project which they would like funded, they should come and see me and I will tell them why we have not got the revenue to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The schedule does appear to meet the Liberal-National Party coalition's amendment which was passed by the Senate on 16 December 1992 and which was subsequently, I think, rejected today by the House of Representatives. Honourable senators will note that, in lieu of the date that was agreed to by the Senate, being 5 November 1992, the date agreed to in the House of Representatives is 18 August 1992—Budget night. Very long and considered thought was given to the fact that the Budget Papers were written in such a way that there was a doubt, so far as the ordinary, reasonable man was concerned, about whether operating leases came within the ambit of the definition of royalty. For that reason, we believed that it was incumbent on the Government to so frame its Budget documents to make sure not that the top 10 tax experts in Australia understood what the Government meant but that the ordinary, reasonable man in Australia understood.

PARA.TAB: As a result of our backtracking, there will be some harm and some hurt caused to at least one company that made a very passionate appeal to a number of senators and to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. In fact, I think that all those who were present at that meeting were very deeply moved by the comments that were made. Those comments led to the coalition framing its original amendment to ensure that there was no retrospectivity—that contracts validly made prior to Budget night would not get caught up retrospectively in the new legislation.

We on this side of the House have something of an abhorrence of retrospective legislation. It is retrospective legislation not of a kind which changes tax rates but which fundamentally alters the structure of the taxation that will apply to those particular payments. I remind the chamber that these particular payments, royalty withholding tax, were actually scrutinised quite openly by the Tax Office. Tax was paid on an assessment basis depending on where it went. In some cases there was an exemption, and assessments were made in relation to this withholding tax. Then along comes the Government on Budget night and changes the whole basis.

Effectively, where Australian companies are responsible for the tax, the rate is upped to 43 per cent gross—a very draconian rate. I understand why. It is trying to discourage certain payments that go off to places like Jersey or tax haven countries. But we have to be very wary in this country, in that in trying to eliminate tax avoidance many other genuine contracts go off to a lot of other countries around the world that are not necessarily tax haven countries—countries that have built up degrees of expertise. We require that expertise to be used and be developed here in Australia. It is generally the scientific area—the new technology—that we should be trying to promote and to encourage in Australia. I know there will always be people who will try to minimise tax arrangements. We believe it is right and proper to plug loopholes within the law which people are exploiting. But where contracts have been validly made we believe that they should expire before the new rules apply.

The Committee will note that the Opposition has been particularly concerned that in the definition of contract no extension arrangements have been allowed. We are fairly tight on it. So I think our bona fides in the tax avoidance debate are quite clear. We are concerned with the retrospective effect—the impact it will have on industry and employment. There will be an impact on one company, but because it is retrospective to Budget night it will not wipe the company out entirely. True, it will have some severe financial ramifications, but we have to consider that good law is not made by hard cases or, putting it another way, bad law often results from hard cases.

The legislation is to apply as from Budget night. With that warning given to the Government, if it continues to so frame its announcements in such ambiguous or unclear terms that the ordinary, reasonable man cannot understand, we may in future have to insist on a later date. I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan). I thank my colleagues for the support they have given to this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds as though Senator Watson has done one of those Opposition deals with the Government on this matter. I cannot believe that; I thought only the Democrats were allowed to do that! The deal has improved the original Bill to some extent.

PARA.TAB: When we last talked about this amendment, Senator McMullan talked about the Opposition and the Australian Democrats assisting tax avoidance, and we made the point about pursuing purity at the expense of jobs for Australians. I ask the chamber to imagine a boss going up to an employee and saying, `Look, the Government is doing a great thing. It has just decided to put a tax on non-residents who are rorting the non-tax system. That's a great idea. Unfortunately, the impact of it is that it will be a tax under contracts that we've just signed. This will have a huge financial impact on us. We're probably going to have to lay off the whole 175 of you'. Senator Watson said, `In the pursuit of tax purity, we are prepared to sacrifice people's jobs'. I just do not think that we can do that at this time. We are not mad about this as a matter of principle, but we will not pursue it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
