PROCTEXT.PARA: RURAL ADJUSTMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: RURAL ADJUSTMENT BILL 1992STATES GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT BILL 1992INCOME EQUALISATION DEPOSITS LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 6, page 3, paragraph 1(b), line 4, omit "7", substitute "11".
2.Clause 6, page 3, paragraph 3(d), lines 14 to 16, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(d)at least two are to be appointed because of their expertise in banking; and
(e)at least two are to be appointed from the rural counselling services of state rural adjustment schemes; and
(f)the others are to be appointed because of their expertise in economics, financial administration, sustainable agriculture, farm management or training.".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments will add an extra four people to the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council. Anyone who has read the Rural Adjustment Bill will realise how important the Council will be. It will be the body that will advise government, and it will have a major impact on the future of agriculture in this country. These amendments add four people to the Council to bring the total to 11. Two of those people are to be appointed because of their expertise in banking and two because of their expertise in rural counselling services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments increase the size of the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council from seven to 11 and make provision for four additional members from two areas—two from banking and two from rural counselling. The Rural Adjustment Bill already makes it quite clear that there will be diversity on the Council, with one representative from State government, one from the Commonwealth Government, one from primary industry, one from the NFF and the rest with experience in financial matters, including banking. The coalition is of the view that the Australian Democrats' concerns are already covered in the Bill and it will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a series of amendments by the Australian Democrats. I guess the one that I should start with is the one that I am most familiar with. The view of the Government is to not accept any of these amendments. The key points of the amendment moved by Senator Lees that deals with clause 6 and clause 6(3)(d), page 3, are that the administration of the rural adjustment scheme, RAS, is devolved to the State RAS authorities. The Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council is intended to provide oversighting at the strategic level by the Commonwealth and monitoring of the effectiveness of this scheme. It is therefore inappropriate to expand the size of the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, which could lead to the perception of increased Commonwealth direction and upset the balanced relationships with the States.

PARA.TAB: In our view, the expertise sought by the expanded membership is well covered by the expertise criteria for membership outlined under clause 6(3) of the Bill. The membership will include members who specifically have expertise in rural counselling and banking. In addition, a membership of eight is considered to be the maximum for an effective working size, given the role and functions proposed for the Council. In our view, 12, including a chairperson, as proposed in the amendment, would be far too unwieldy.

To some extent, the proposed amendment is factually incorrect. The rural counselling services are part of a joint Commonwealth-State program which is separate from the rural adjustment scheme. There are no State rural adjustment schemes in that sense. As I have said, the Government will not be supporting these amendments. I note that a number of other amendments have been circulated. We will not be supporting those either.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: STATES GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill. Senator LEES (South Australia—Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats) (1.08 a.m.)—I have several questions for the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Cook) on the Farm Household Bill 1992. Can the Minister give a commitment that accessing the new child support payment—formerly known as the family allowance and the family allowance supplement—is not ruled out by the farm household support provision that no other support payment is received?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no instructions on that at the moment. If there are some other questions, I suggest that they be put. I will obtain instructions on the first question in a moment.

—I am sure that the Minister can understand how concerned farm families are that they could lose their family allowance or family allowance supplement, or what is now known as the child support payment. That is why I am asking about it. I have been specifically requested to get a commitment on that point this morning.

PARA.TAB: My next question is about how the Department of Social Security will treat the re-establishment grants once farmers are off the land and presumably in the city looking for work. If they cannot find work, how will that amount of perhaps as much as $45,000 be counted? Do they have to spend most of it—in other words, get down to their liquid asset threshold level, which for independent and single people is about $5,000 and for a family is $10,000—or are they able to somehow have that treated differently by Social Security if they find themselves on unemployment benefits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I am now in a position to deal with the first question that Senator Lees put to me. The briefing I have in the summary of the Farm Household Support Bill says—and I think this does cover the point raised by Senator Lees—that the farm household support scheme outlined in the Bill is to commence on 20 March 1993. It replaces the household support provisions of part C of the old rural adjustment scheme.

PARA.TAB: The farm household support scheme is essentially a loan available for up to two years for farmers who are unable to obtain carry-on finance from commercial sources or RAS support. Its purpose is to assist farmers to meet the daily living requirements of the farm family. I think that answers Senator Lees's first question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand perfectly what the Minister has just said, but does that exclude them from child support payments? Every other family in the country—
—No, it does not exclude them from family support payments.

—I now ask for the second question to be answered as to how the grants will be treated by Social Security once farmers presumably find themselves in the city and probably, given the unemployment situation at the moment, on unemployment benefits. In other words, will they have to live on the grant for a month until they get it down below the liquid asset threshold, or will they have some special treatment so that they can keep that? Perhaps they will be looking at eventually buying a house or something. Will they still be able to tap immediately into unemployment benefits if necessary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that this is a loan which is applicable while they are on the farm. If they leave the farm, the loan then does not apply. If they transfer to the city and vacate the farm, the loan does not apply and they are a normal beneficiary as far as social welfare might be concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not speaking of the loan; I am speaking of the grant. Senator Tambling might know, but I think it is some $45,000 maximum, tapering out once the farmer actually gets more than that out of the farm and cutting out all together at $90,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a loan. That is the exit grant.
—Yes. How is that going to be treated?

—I am advised that it is inalienable. Once they leave the farm with that grant—and I will be careful about these words and look to my advisers to correct me if I am wrong—they will be entitled to then receive any welfare benefits, or whatever other benefits there might be, in the normal way that a person who was ordinarily resident in the city would be entitled to receive payment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I realise it is getting very late, but an ordinary resident in the city would have that $45,000, which presumably will be in cash, treated as an excessive amount of money in terms of Social Security. They would have to spend that liquid asset down to presumably $10,000 for a family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, they will have to do that. It will not be available so that they have special treatment. They will have to spend it down until they are eligible for other payments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My next question relates to clause 50. What interest rate will the farmers be paying if they do indeed end up with a loan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —My adviser is unable to advise me. My understanding of this Bill is that there is a lower interest rate than is normally commercially payable, but I will ask my adviser to check that and provide Senator Lees with exactly the answer in a few minutes.
—What terms will the loan be repaid on?
—The advice I have is this: of course, if they leave the farm and they have not repaid the loan, they then have to repay it in full. If they do not, debt recovery proceedings will be instituted.

PARA.TAB: While they remain on the farm, after two years they have to commence repayment of the loan and the terms of the repayment are negotiable. It depends on the circumstances that each individual landholder finds himself in. Obviously, some assessment procedure will be made as to what is a fair term for repayment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My next question relates to clause 41 on page 16 and I will take a moment to explain it. There are a series of very heavy penalties including imprisonment for six months and 12 months relating to a person who, without reasonable excuse, refuses to file or comply with a notice. Basically that is about actually notifying change of circumstances. Clause 42(7) says specifically:

SPEECH.PARA: This section extends to:

PARA.TAB: (a)acts, omissions, matters and things outside Australia whether or not in a foreign country;. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister: what sort of events outside Australia and likely to have an effect on one's income does one have to notify? Presumably it is matters such as a breakthrough in the GATT talks or floods in California. I am serious about this, because there is a very heavy penalty for not notifying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that these are the standard provisions for all social security payments. This is not something specific to this program. It is something that applies for all social security and it is applied in this program routinely. It therefore contains no specific clauses about rural life or farm life. It applies on the general social security level. Earthquakes in California or floods in some other place are not the criteria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 5, pages 4 and 5, line 2 (page 4) to line 7 (page 5), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "5. The grant period in relation to a person to whom farm household support is payable is the period of 9 months from the operative day, being—

TAB.TAB: (a)in relation to a former RAS (Part C) beneficiary—the day on which Part C assistance became, or last became, payable to the person under a RAS scheme; or
(b)in relation to any other person—the day on which farm household support became, or last became, payable to the person.".

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 26, page 13, line 3, omit "loan", substitute "grant".
10.Clause 49, page 20, lines 7 to 16, clause to be opposed.
11.Clause 50, pages 20 and 21, line 18 (page 20) to line 3 (page 21), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Agreement for repayment of RAS (Part C) assistance

PARA.TAB: "50(1) A person who is a former RAS (Part C) beneficiary is liable to repay to the Commonwealth an amount equal to the sum of the total amount of Part C assistance paid to the person under the RAS scheme applicable to him or her immediately before the commencement of this Act together with the amount of interest payable on the Part C assistance under the regulations.

(2) When a person who is receiving farm household support and who is a former RAS (Part C) beneficiary dies, the amount that would have been repayable to the Commonwealth by that person under subsection (1) if the person had not died, is to be repaid to the Commonwealth from the person's estate.".

SPEECH.PARA: 12.Clause 51, page 21, lines 5 to 21, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "51.(1) The Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy may enter into an agreement with a person liable to repay an amount to the Commonwealth under subsection 50(1) regarding the terms on which any repayment is to be made.

(2) The Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy may enter into an agreement with the personal representative of a deceased person regarding the terms on which any repayment is to be made under subsection 50(2) from the estate of the deceased person.

TAB.TAB: (a)there is no agreement under subsection (1) or (2); or
(b)any term of an agreement entered into under subsection (1) or (2) is not complied with;

SPEECH.PARA: the total amount payable under subsection 50(1) or (2), or so much of that amount as remains unpaid on the contravention of the agreement (as the case may be), may be recovered by the Commonwealth as a debt due to the Commonwealth.".
13.Clause 52, page 21, line 22 (page 21) to line 12 (page 22), clause to be opposed.

These amendments seek to change the nature of the scheme from a loan scheme to a normal welfare payment while retaining the financial incentive offered for families to leave farming. In conjunction with other amendments, the effect is to extend the time frames of decision making without such an onus on the first nine months.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats believe that the only strings which should be attached to basic household support are to make the farmer consult on a regular basis with rural diagnostic experts so that they can ascertain very clearly what their situation is, get some support, know what the options are and look at debt restructuring.

The Minister's office has told us that basically this is already allowed for in the legislation, so we do not have to move anything to try to write it in. I reiterate that the amendments retain the incentive offered that if a farmer decides to leave the farm within the first nine months, he or she gets the whole nine months farm support as a grant.

The Democrats believe that that provision, plus access re-establishment grants, provide adequate incentive to leave without the threat of another debt hanging over your head if you do not. The bottom line to us is that under the normal process of commercial loans, those farmers who are genuinely unviable will eventually be forced to leave the land anyway.

I am advised that, due to some drafting complexities, these amendments may not be 100 per cent accurate. However, we do have confirmation that in another hour or two we will be able to fix them up if it is the will of the Committee to pass these amendments. Rather than delay the initial consideration of these Bills, I propose to deal with them as they are, especially since both the Government and the Opposition have indicated that they will not support the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very indicative that we are dealing with this legislation at such a late hour on the last day of the sittings in the calendar year, and possibly the last day in the term of this Government. Unfortunately, as has become the practice, the Government seems to schedule primary industry and rural affairs matters, whether it is in the Appropriations debate or for Senate consideration, at a very late stage and late hour. It is now 1.20 in the morning and we are being forced to consider, as Senator Lees has said, very complex legislation and very complex amendments. Senator Lees gave us an indication a day or so ago of the area she wished to pursue but the amendments were not made available to us in their present form until just before Question Time this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: It would be the coalition's policy to move towards grants and we would certainly intend to do that following the next election, which will not be that far away. We are sick and tired of amending the Government's mistakes in legislation. That is made obvious by the fact that the Democrats have had so many problems in drafting the technical amendments to this legislation. The Minister has possibly indicated that there is no guarantee that the Government would accept any of these amendments at this time.

The National Farmers Federation was not consulted about these amendments. That is an important consideration. It certainly wants to see the legislation proceed. The fact that this consultation has not occurred, the fact of the complexity and the manner in which these amendments are being foisted on us at the very last minute, and the fact that our policies are clear—and it will be very much a matter of supporting the farmers—mean that in this instance we will certainly not support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the intention of the Government to support the amendments either. In summary, we would explain our position by saying that the nature of these amendments changes the character of the measures that we propose to put in place. It changes the character of a loan to the character of a grant. On the face of it, that may seem to be worth while, but it is not appropriate in these circumstances. It would confer a benefit on this group which other groups who do not have access to this sort of privilege would want as well. It is not appropriate to deal with these things in this manner. Rather than create this sort of unnecessary precedent, we believe the loan approach is a worthwhile way of encouraging good farm management and a worthwhile way of proceeding so that farmers can evaluate their risk and take some responsibility as well. We oppose the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 26, page 13, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2)Instalments paid to a person during the grant period defined in section 5 are not to be included as part of the loan.".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 50, page 20, subclause (1), line 23, after "part 5", insert ", excluding instalments paid to the person during the grant period defined in section 5,".
3.Clause 50, page 20, subclause (2), line 34, before "together", insert ", excluding instalments paid to the person during the grant period defined in section 5,".
4.Clause 52, page 21, subclause (2), line 40 (page 21) to line 7 (page 22), omit the subclause.

These are very tightly drafted amendments and their intention is very clear. The intention is to implement Liberal policy, as best I understand it. These amendments retain but delay the loan component of the scheme so that the farm household support becomes at first a nine-month income tested welfare grant equivalent to JSA, which is not conditional on whether the farmer finally leaves or not. After nine months it then becomes a loan. I understand from my reading of what I can find of Liberal policy that this is what the Liberal Party basically would do if in government. While it is far from ideal as far as what the Democrats want, it is certainly a lot better than what the Government is offering.

PARA.TAB: On listening to the Minister's comments, it would be fine if there was nothing other than a management problem on a farm, but we should look at what is happening on the west coast of South Australia at the moment. As of this morning the entire crop—some $70m worth—that was to have been the saviour for many of those farmers has been destroyed. We listened to Senator Boswell on the night that we made our speeches in the second reading debate talking about droughts in other parts of the country. There are so many things that are well and truly out of the hands of our farmers. The Government's legislation that we are finally dealing with tonight will probably see some 20 per cent of family farms now in existence close to the point where those people presumably will simply join the unemployment queues in the city. I commend these amendments to the committee.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—Senator Lees, could you give us some direction as to the manner in which you intend to proceed. We are now talking about amendments 1 to 4, marked as additional amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had to be moved if the previous amendments failed.
—Not all of the amendments numbered 1 to 15 in the previous package of amendments have been moved. Do you intend to move the remaining amendments in that package?
—Yes, in two additional packages after this group.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can accept the point that Senator Lees makes with regard to the plight of many farmers in Australia today. The other evening my colleague Senator Boswell very clearly outlined the situation in Queensland. His speech was very far-reaching and I would certainly commend it to anyone in the farm industry. Once again, we are seeing this typical Democrat rush to achieve things at the last minute—
—Rush!

—It is a rush. The amendments were made available at 2 o'clock today. Our position has been very clear. Our policy is well stated by the shadow Minister, Mr Bruce Lloyd. Certainly when in government we will amend this legislation to achieve all the objectives that we have put forward in our policy. We certainly will not be blackmailed by the Democrats on technical amendments that are rushed at the last minute, which have been proposed without the proper consultation with the NFF or, particularly, with the rural community, let alone parliamentary colleagues. We will not be supporting the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let a lot of that nonsense go unanswered. I certainly have consulted with rural groups, although not with the NFF. I do not believe that the NFF truly represents the farmers who will be hit hard by this legislation. Those in South Australia that I have consulted have plenty of evidence to bring forward to show why the Government legislation, as it exists, will probably change the face of farming in Australia for the worse forever. Basically, these amendments are what the Liberal Party proposes. I see absolutely no reason for members of the Liberal Party not to support them. They have had the thrust of these amendments for well over a fortnight. These amendments have not changed in any substantial sense and they have had these for over a week. It is a very weak excuse to try to say they have not had time to consider them when I know they have.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only point I wish to make in response to the comments just made by Senator Lees when she implied that this legislation and the amendments were made available a fortnight ago, is that the first occasion on which we saw the proposals for these amendments was on Tuesday of this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason we will not support these amendments has already been explained to the chamber by Senator Lees—that is, they are Liberal Party amendments meant to embarrass the Opposition into forcing it to a vote. That is an exercise that takes place in this place from time to time, but we will not be party to it. We will oppose the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 20, page 10, subclause (2), line 18, after "took effect", insert ", or the day on which the new determination is made, whichever day is chosen by the recipient.".
3.Clause 20, page 10, subclause (3), line 30, after "review", insert ", or the day on which the new determination is made, whichever day is chosen by the recipient.".
4.Clause 20, page 10, subclause (4), line 42, after "took effect", insert ", or the day on which the new determination is made, whichever day is chosen by the recipient.".

These amendments give the option to the recipient when he or she wants payment of farm household support to start after a successful review of a decision either on the day of the new decision or eligibility can be backdated. If they choose backdating, as in the legislation now, they would get a lump sum payment. If they choose from the new decision, they would effectively have their time extended. This is because of the delays which, we are told, are up to 12 months in the Department of Social Security applications and appeals processes. That is despite the promises that have been made recently about efficiencies. So this is an important option. Otherwise, the grant period could effectively be over before the farmer knows whether he or she has actually qualified for farm household support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition's position on these amendments is clear. Clause 20(2) on page 10 of the Bill states that if a person is knocked back and the person applies for a review within three months and the review is successful the determination takes effect on the day on which the previous decision took effect. The Democrats want the person to have a choice of starting back then or from the day the new determination is made. Why would a farmer want to knock back back pay in those circumstances? Clause 20(3) on page 10 simply says that if one takes more than 30 days to apply for a review the new determination dates from the date one applied. The Democrats want a choice of that date or the day on which the new determination is made. Again, why would farmers want to knock back back pay?

PARA.TAB: Clause 30, subclause (4), on page 10 of the Bill, simply says that a person who was not notified on being unsuccessful can apply for a review and, if successful, it will date from the day that the previous decision took effect. Again, the Democrats want to allow the person to scrap the back pay. Why would they want to do this? They probably have been borrowing money from friends to stay afloat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —For much the same reason as has been put, we do not support the amendments. There is no incentive to opt for anything other than the best return, and the best return is available now. One can appreciate that there is a choice, but the choice is not worth taking in any circumstances. Therefore it does not seem to us as important as it has been presented. We oppose the amendments.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

7.Clause 41, page 16, subclause (6), line 39, omit "Imprisonment for 12 months", substitute "$1,000".

9.Clause 42, page 17, subclause (6), line 29, omit "Imprisonment for 12 months", substitute "$1,000".

15.Clause 54, page 23, subclause (8), line 14, omit "Imprisonment for 12 months", substitute "$1,000".

I briefly explain that these amendments are related to penalties for not complying with directions to provide information; in other words, for things like not sending back forms on time. The penalties are draconian at six months imprisonment and 12 months imprisonment for not providing information or providing misleading information respectively. We believe that they are ridiculously harsh for the offences they represent and the amendments seek to reduce the penalties to $250 and $1,000 respectively.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The penalties under the Social Security Act include imprisonment for two years if the person is guilty of an offence. Therefore, the penalties under this legislation—that is, imprisonment of up to 12 months—are not unduly harsh. I understand that there is a move to have a consistency between this legislation, the social security legislation and the Crimes Act and I would certainly ask the Minister to confirm that it is the Government's intention to have the penalties across all three made consistent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

Debate resumed from 11 November 1992, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill 1992 brings within one piece of legislation the authority for the Commonwealth to develop integrated approaches to land, water and associated vegetation management issues with community groups, the States and Territories and other organisations. At the moment much of the Commonwealth finance for landcare is channelled through the States and in many cases the States have used it to finance their previously State funded soil conservation offices. While the administration for water, land and related vegetation programs is through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the different legislation means programs are confusing and lack coordination. The Government circulated a discussion paper in April this year to key groups and the Government claims the comments supported a more integrated approach to natural resource management.

PARA.TAB: Recently the Federal Government obtained agreement from State governments to combine the Ministerial Councils of Agriculture, Water Resources and Soil Conservation to ensure that a more comprehensive focus to Federal and State policy discussion occurred in these areas. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) on the Natural Resources (Financial Assistance) Bill there were some positive aims. On the basis of these positive aims, the coalition is prepared to support the Bill and to monitor the progress of the consolidated arrangement.

The first proposal in the Bill that the Minister refers to is his aim to combine the Ministerial Councils for Agriculture, Water Resources and Soil Conservation. The aim is to provide a more comprehensive or integrated approach to those related aspects of sustainable development in agriculture, which is certainly worth while. Part of the broad proposal is to merge the national soil conservation program and the Federal water resources assistance program into the one, and that is basically the content of this Bill.

The budget for this year is to be $77m. We are talking here generally about what is commonly known to the ordinary person as landcare. There are really separate programs. There is a separate Landcare Ltd, a private company that is in a very positive way getting in the private sector or company finance to further promote the total soil conservation and landcare ethics. There are also the water programs that are concerned with salinity, high water tables et cetera. They have their own community groups separate from the landcare groups.

Community groups all have the aim of raising community awareness of soil, water and vegetation problems. They concentrate on community programs more than they do on particular problems on actual farms. That is where the major action actually has to occur—on the farms themselves. If these changes, or this consolidation of legislation, simplify the application procedures and reduce the administrative delays and costs, the change will be positive because there has been confusion and there have been complaints about this in the past.

There has been a further problem in the past where the finance from those two programs has gone via the States or through the State system and where the States themselves have been the recipients of the programs. The aim expressed in the Minister's second reading speech of the third element of this proposal, the partnership agreements—which is where the Minister can make comment if he feels that this is not right—is to hopefully overcome or reduce this weakness of States that do not maintain in real terms their expenditure in these areas prior to the Federal Government's assistance arrangements commencing. The States will be required to maintain in real terms their own expenditure at the same time, and this is sometimes the opposite part of the problem—not establishing too much duplication at the Federal level with regard to checking how the money is spent, applications and so on.

Landcare, in broad terms, has been bipartisan, and continues to be bipartisan. But there have been times recently at particular functions when the original arrangement has not been maintained and there has not been recognition of the bipartisan approach. The shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray, Mr Bruce Lloyd, in his speech in the second reading debate in the House of Representatives, voiced his concern that the level of budgetary provision for landcare remains flat. In fact, it is declining in real terms.

With this comes another problem. If one looks at just the last three years of expenditure, at the expenditure estimated for a financial year as proposed in the Budget for that year, and the figures in the Budget documents for the following year which show what was actually spent, one sees that the figures are quite different. For example, in the year 1990-91 the Budget estimate was $88.5m; the actual spending, $73.5m. In 1991-92, the Budget estimate was $70.8m; the actual spending, $60.2m. In this year's Budget, for 1992-93, the Minister refers to $77m. I would hope that very close to $77m would be spent in this important area.

When one looks at the decade of Landcare and the figure for the national soil conservation section, of around $25m a year for each of those 10 years in real terms, one sees that the actual commitment is declining. We have to do better than that for the remaining years in the decade of Landcare. For a start, we have a number of Landcare groups—there are now many other types of groups as well as those referred to as Landcare groups. In fact, there are over 1,300 of them. They have increased dramatically. Presumably, there will be further increases. While the money they want may not be able to be provided, there is obviously a continuing and growing commitment in this area.

Separate to this, and additional to it, is the real problem of encouragement to farmers for on-farm remedial measures, which can be quite costly in some cases. This is where section 75D of the Income Tax Assessment Act has been quite important. In some locations in Australia, this Government has removed some of the tax incentives for on-farm works, for soil conservation, or for irrigation improvement. However, the write-off in the year of expenditure for lasering and related measures was never removed. This has been tremendously important.

There have been some anomalies that have been subsequently sorted out concerning tree planting and fencing and some things that have been clarified and improved again in recent years. In some areas of Australia, farmers have spent up to $25m in some difficult years, and now close to 50 per cent of the total irrigation area of areas such as northern Victoria will be covered by these improvements.

That is a tremendous achievement. That really is doing more to help in the slow but sure improvement in the quality of Murray River water from that part of the State, in the sense of drainage of irrigation water that goes into the Murray, than anything that has been done by communities through Landcare groups, SPAC groups, the salinity program action groups, or whatever we like to call them. They are tremendous groups; all of them. The real action is and always will have to be on the farms themselves. Any on-farm activities are very expensive. We are talking thousands of dollars for any worthwhile project. If there is a low cash flow, it is very difficult, even with section 75D tax deductibility, to write-off in the year of expenditure to provide any real incentive.

We have a challenge here to provide incentives and encouragement for those on-farm practices so they may proceed to a greater degree than they have so far. The future of sustainable agriculture in these areas and, for that matter, in dry-land areas or wherever it may be in Australia, has to be addressed. In addition to the Landcare programs, and so forth, which provide community awareness, which do very good things and have to be maintained in real terms, additional policies or programs need to be put in place to ensure that more farmers are encouraged to do what they themselves would naturally want to do: that is, to improve the state of their farms so that every farmer who would want to, could leave the farm to the next generation, or sell it to whoever they wish in a better sustainable position than when they started.

I deviate slightly from this legislation to a related matter that has been drawn to my attention today. That is a press release by the Environment Centre, Northern Territory, which has been released by the campaign's coordinator, Mr Jamie Pittock, in which he blatantly attacks an outstanding company operating in the Northern Territory, Zapopan. Zapopan NL is a respected company which, in all dealings with government and environmental groups with regard to the Mount Todd gold mine, has used the correct process of approval of this project. This disgraceful press release has only been released today, but it includes some of the following statements by Mr Pittock with regard to the draft environmental impact statement conducted for the Mount Todd gold mine:

SPEECH.PARA: The Supplement is a cynical exercise in deceiving the public into believing the endangered Gouldian finch will be adequately conserved. All Zapopan has proposed is to cut most of the finch monitoring program at Mount Todd (200 person day per year of 360) and give the money saved to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS), who are currently assessing the mine proposal, for a national recovery program.

The Commonwealth Government should be ashamed of entertaining Zapopan's latest proposal. The message it gives to developers who threaten endangered species is that they can buy their way out by giving money to the ANPWS. This is particularly disturbing since ANPWS as recently as May 1992 claimed the first step to conserving the bird involves `full protection to large breeding colonies'. Sacrificing the largest known colony of finches at Mount Todd is no way to conserve the species.
Mr Pittock goes on to say:

While we welcome ANPWS's establishment of a finch recovery plan it is only part of a solution that would conserve the finch and allow the mine to proceed. Zapopan's plan offers the finch next to nothing, no reserves for breeding areas and an inadequate monitoring program.
Further on in Mr Pittock's attack on this very respectable company, he says:

Zapopan have effectively and deceptively unloaded responsibility for protecting the finch. A new monitoring program is proposed that is so weak that timely detection of any significant impact is virtually impossible. While we criticised the previous monitoring proposal the issue was Zapopan's lack of will to properly implement the CSIRO monitoring plan by collecting sufficient pre-mining data and by defining a `significant impact', not the plan itself which is sound.

We note that Zapopan has not repeated many of its unsubstantiated and misleading statements, such as claims in the DEIS that only 1% of the breeding area and 0.2% of the nests of the endangered Gouldian finch would be destroyed. While this vindicates our previous criticism this is of little comfort if the Commonwealth Government fails to act in the interest of the finch.
Finally, he says:

Zapopan has not answered the serious scientific criticism levelled at the DEIS by the World Wide Fund for Nature, Royal Australasian Ornithologists Union, Australian Conservation Foundation and the Centre.

This press release is nothing less than appalling. Zapopan has designed the Mount Todd project to ensure that the Gouldian finch population in the Yinberrie Hills is protected to the maximum extent practicable. In fact, in a company profile of Zapopan, since 1986 approximately $1.5m has been spent by various organisations on research and investigation into the Gouldian finch; 33 per cent of this has come from Zapopan. I am pleased to note that the Northern Territory Government has been another major contributor with 64 per cent of the $1 1/2m going to research on the finch.

PARA.TAB: The project design features described in the draft environmental impact statement, October 1992, represent substantial modifications to initial planning and design concepts with the objective of pre-empting or mitigating effects on the Gouldian finch. They include three points. All but one component have been relocated to alternative sites outside the Yinberrie Hills. The exception is the main pit, which cannot be relocated. Features that will prevent or discourage access to solutions containing concentrations of cyanide that could be toxic to wildlife have been incorporated into the design. Specific measures and safeguards will be implemented to enhance and protect the breeding habitat in the Yinberrie.
The draft environmental impact statement concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that mining activity is unlikely to pose long-term threat to the viability of the Gouldian Finch in the Yinberrie Hills.
Further on, it states:

Of far greater concern are factors such as the habitat impact of land-use practises across the species' range and the prevalence of air-sac mites, either or both of which may have contributed to the decline in the wold of the Gouldian Finch.

I am afraid the scare campaign undertaken by the Environment Centre, Northern Territory, deserves everything it gets if Zapopan considers taking further action and prosecutes the Centre for such defamatory statements on this most sensitive issue, on which Zapopan should be commended for the way in which it has listened to all concerned interest groups on the mining proposal at Mount Todd in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: Whilst that issue is certainly parochial and a matter of concern to the Northern Territory, it is opportune and proper to state it. Some of the aspects of this Bill appear to be positive and, hopefully, will be positive with regard to the future of the program. The coalition will be supporting the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the thrust of the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill, which is to develop and implement an integrated approach to natural resource management based on ecologically sustainable development. We recognise that the aim of the Bill is to facilitate efficient, equitable and sustainable management of Australia's natural resources. We also recognise that the Bill has the support of such groups as Greening Australia, the Australian Conservation Council and the National Farmers Federation.

PARA.TAB: In brief, we agree with the description that has been given by Senator Tambling of the purposes of the Bill. We applaud the fact that it establishes arrangements for the financial assistance between the Commonwealth and the States specifically for natural resource management projects. The way it goes about this in terms of legislative replacements and making the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act and the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act redundant is recognised as well. The fact that about 1,400 Landcare groups will be funded through this mechanism provides a slightly more efficient and a less circuitous method of funding. That is also to be applauded.

I will refer later to the structure of the committee which is to be established through this Bill, the National Landcare Advisory Committee, to provide advice on the priorities and strategies for natural resource management programs. But the fact that a committee is being established is also recognised as important. To have that committee with a non-government majority is also important.

We think that the strengths of the Bill are that the integrated management of land, water and vegetation is encouraged and that there is an introduction—that is an important word in this context—of the principles of ecologically sustainable development as a context for the development and implementation of natural resources management in Australia. The value of a community oriented approach to natural resources management is recognised by this Bill. But, for all those strengths, it is particularly noticeable that this Bill does not provide for a definition of `ecological sustainable development'—and that is a significant weakness. The composition of the National Landcare Advisory Committee is also questioned by us. We congratulate the Government for the reforms that it is undertaking in this area of resource management and the integration of the financial arrangements. But we think it is important to support the whole systems approach to natural resources management and to recognise the conservation of a biodiversity.

The soil productivity and water quality of Australia are matters which have received considerable press recently. If this is a means by which we can maintain those ecological processes, then I hope that it has the capacity to deliver. Perhaps I will refer to that a little later. It is good to see that we have the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) working together, even if only in a tentative manner here, to develop a more integrated approach to natural resources management. This Bill can only be one part of the new approach but, as I have said, even if it is tentative, it is to be recognised.

What we need and what I understand is being developed is a whole new program framework which includes land, water and vegetation and the national landcare program. The discussion paper on the national landcare program, which was produced in April 1992, proposed that a single natural resources advisory committee be established to guide the Commonwealth on community attitudes to natural resource issues, issues of national significance and priorities for action. The paper stated that the membership of the committee would comprise parties affected by the outcomes of natural resource management policies and programs.

Comments were received on that paper from, amongst other groups, Greening Australia, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the National Farmers Federation. Amongst other things, those groups made three recommendations about the advisory committee. The Government has here accepted two of those: that the advisory committee should include a majority of community representatives and that it should be chaired by a person from the non-government sector. However, a third point was not accepted and that was that the community sector should be given the right to appoint community positions to the advisory committee.

I foreshadow a Democrat amendment, which I will be moving in the committee stage, which addresses that problem. The reason that amendment is necessary is that it is so important that the community itself be recognised for its capacity to understand what is involved here. That has been demonstrated, as has been mentioned by Senator Tambling, by those hard working, well informed and expert practitioners of landcare who are the community—not the bureaucrats, not the academics and not the people who are removed from the actual practice of landcare. We strongly believe that the community sector should have the right to choose who represents them. The community, rather than the bureaucracy and the Minister, is more in touch with those who can best represent them on such an advisory committee. The expertise, experience and the established networks that we see operating in such groups as Greening Australia should be recognised and strongly supported. The process which we have here I do not think pays sufficient regard to those qualities I have just mentioned.

The other problem we have with this Bill is that it lacks a definition of `ecologically sustainable development' which can be followed through. The problem with this is that we end up with a situation where, unless that concept is defined, we have further decisions made and subsequent actions taken either by the Commonwealth or by State governments which are able to choose their own definition and are able to provide qualifications to what is ecologically sustainable development. A recent decision by the newly formed Council of Australian Governments was to endorse ESD, without defining it, and greenhouse strategies subject to budgetary constraints and priorities. Such a qualification by the States and Territories makes the whole commitment a non-commitment, an absolute nonsense. The conduct of the business in the States and Territories can be business as usual.

The biophysical constraints of those States and Territories have been ignored; they are being exceeded in many cases. We cannot sustain such a practice of conducting our affairs. There will always be economic constraints operating in the economy. That is what it is about; that is what it is; that is what it means. To use that as a caveat of recognition for ESD is so faulty it is ridiculous. The constraints are not temporary. Action to implement the ESD recommendations needs to occur now. Action cannot be delayed any longer. We have to demonstrate fully and clearly the axiomatic statement. I am sure Senator O'Chee would be interested in this as he is terribly interested in axiomatic statements; here is one for him to stick away in his little book. The governments of Australia do not recognise that unless ecology is sustained there cannot be an economy.

I have foreshadowed amendments to be made in the committee stage. They are amendments which do not detract from the thrust of the Bill and support rather than militate against the Minister's reforms in the agricultural sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important at the outset to state that this Bill is integral to the overall approach to facilitating an ecologically sustainable agricultural industry in Australia. The Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill, whilst undoubtedly a move in the right direction, has some shortcomings which require attention. The very definition of ecological sustainability is crucial in this regard, as Senator Bell has already mentioned.

PARA.TAB: In the context of an agricultural system, the major determinants for ecological sustainability, according to Dr John Cameron and Jane Elix from the Australian Conservation Foundation, are dependent on the system generating its own nutrients; having a high degree of species diversity; having high comparative energy efficiency; not being dependent upon fossil fuel energy sources; having internal mechanisms for control of pests and weeds; and being resilient, meaning it can return to its original productivity after a major external shock or a period of stress. Whilst these criteria are not always able to be met they are, nonetheless, an ideal that we should work to achieve. Unfortunately, this approach is not accepted in some circles where a more short term, economically based approach is favoured.

It is this difference in approach to ecologically sustainable development that points to the shortcoming in the drafting of the legislation. The Bill states that one of its objects is to facilitate natural resources management in Australia `consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development'. The phrase `ecologically sustainable development' is, however, not defined in the Bill and this could lead to either misunderstanding or manipulation by vested interests.

In most other respects, the Natural Resources Management Bill appears to be a positive step towards better management of our natural resources. In particular, it is pleasing to see at last that a more integrated and holistic approach is being adopted in government policy. We cannot continue to follow the reductionist approach that has dominated government policy making to date, in which the interconnectedness of ecological systems has been neglected or ignored. This approach should be reflected in all government legislation that relates to the environment in which we live because, after all, the environment represents our own life support system.

There is however a long way to go before we can truly claim to be on the path to sustainability. As Professor William Rees from the University of British Columbia in Canada stated in an article entitled `The Ecology of Sustainable Development':

SPEECH.PARA: Most discussion of sustainable development in the socio-political mainstream emphasises the need to sustain economic growth and assumes that we can `account for' the environment through greater efficiency of resource use, improved technology, better pollution control and wider use of environmental assessment. Such incrementalism may constitute a necessary first step but by itself would result in little more than a somewhat better dressed version of the growth-bound status quo, requiring a minimum of adjustment to either industry or individuals.

The evidence suggests, however, that we may be fast approaching absolute limits to material economic growth. We no longer have the luxury of `trading off' ecological damage for economic benefits if we hope to have a sustainable future. The maintenance of global ecological integrity necessarily becomes our highest priority and must be taken into account in every local and regional development decision.

Finally, from a personal perspective, it was invaluable for me to attend the Winning back the West conference in Fitzroy Crossing earlier this year. The conference initially examined the history of the pastoral industry in the Kimberleys and the devastating impact that that free ranging cattle grazing often had on the ecology of the region. We were then informed about the many initiatives in the area to minimise the impact of cattle grazing on the rivers and land. In the context of this Bill, it is important to note that the role of the local Landcare groups has been crucial in these developments.

PARA.TAB: It was also interesting to note at this conference that the local Aboriginal population is also contributing to these efforts, and this collaboration is perhaps beginning to assist in developing some common sense of care for the land that we all share. The sentiments expressed by Pat Dodson, from the National Reconciliation Council, and local Aboriginal representatives, during a wonderful meeting on the banks of a dry river bed on Louisa Downs Station were both inspirational and consistent with this belief.

The potential for different groups working together and having Aboriginal representation on the advisory committee is also exciting. As I said at the outset, I believe that this Bill, in establishing the National Landcare Advisory Committee and providing arrangements for financial assistance to the States for natural resources management projects, is a step in a positive direction. The Democrats amendments are further helpful additions because of the spelling out of ecologically sustainable development principles and improving experienced community representation on the advisory committee. I indicate my support for the Democrat amendments and for this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important Bill. I thank all the senators who have contributed to this debate. Landcare is something about which I have considerable interest and in my former guise as Minister for the Resources I provided, I think, some assistance to the landcare movement in Australia, but I think that at this hour of the day—
—It is one of the things you did reasonably well.

—I thank Senator Brownhill. I just want to make sure Hansard has his remark that there is something I did reasonably well. However, I do not wish to labour the point now. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 4, page 3, subclause (1), after definition of `officer', insert the following definition:

PARA.TAB: `"principles of ecologically sustainable development" means:
(a) to enhance individual and community well-being and welfare by following a path of economic development that `Safeguards the interests of future generations;
(b)to provide for equity within and between generations;
(c)to maintain biological diversity and ecological processes and systems;
(d)to recognise the global dimension; and
(e)to give effect to the precautionary principle by adopting an anticipatory and cautious approach to policy development and decision-making.'

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 14, page 8, line 36, omit `12', substitute `14'.
3.Clause 14, page 9, subclause (4), lines 1 to 3, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause.:

PARA.TAB: `(4) Three members (other than a member mentioned in subsection (6)) are to be persons with experience in, or special knowledge of, natural resources management including conservation, vegetation management, environment protection and community organisation.'

SPEECH.PARA: I will not waste the time of the Committee by reading the details of the amendments. I will describe briefly their purpose. We have, over some considerable time, been informed about the Government's development of and interest in the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development. We have been presented with any number of opinions about this, and we have, during that process, heard a number of people attempting to define ESD. We have received, as a result of the considerable amount of time spent on it, the statement of Australia's goal, objectives and guiding principles for the ESD strategy.

PARA.TAB: Without listing the goal, the core objectives or the guiding principles in order, I would just like to remind the Senate of what the goal has been stated to be. It is: development that improves the total quality of life, both now and in the future, in a way that maintains the ecological processes on which life depends. To meet that goal, one of the changes to government institutions and machinery which has been recognised by this Government is a commitment. Quite blatantly, in black and white, that commitment states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government will:

PARA.TAB: incorporate ESD principles into the objectives of relevant
legislation as appropriate, particularly for legislation concerning
natural resources use and management.

SPEECH.PARA: Here it is—the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill 1992. The opportunity is here, so let us see it being incorporated. It is provided by the generosity of the Australian Democrats. It remains within the capacity of the Government to accept that and to recognise that here is the opportunity to deliver on that promise.

PARA.TAB: The other part of our amendments is quite simply a matter of recognising the need, as I indicated in my contribution to the second reading debate, to ensure that the advisory committee which is to be constituted under this legislation actually takes account of the experience which exists in the community and elects to that committee people with sufficient experience in or knowledge of natural resources management including conservation, vegetation management, environment protection and community organisations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —At 2.20 in the morning we are faced again with further latter day amendments from the Australian Democrats. My office first saw anything relating to amendments to these Bills from the Democrats in a draft form at about midday today and of course the final amendment was put on our table, I think, 10 or 15 minutes ago as it was distributed. In the package that we are looking at there are essentially two substantive amendments from the Democrats: one which talks about a definitional area, in the area of sustainable development; and the second relating to the size of an advisory committee.

PARA.TAB: Once again, the way in which Democrat policy is developed at the late stages and approaches are made on this could only be described as verbal diarrhoea. By the time one finished reading the definitions put forward in clause 4 for the principles of ecologically sustainable development that the Democrats are proposing, one would probably have died of old age and certainly nothing would have happened to any of the projects.

I highlighted in my speech during the second reading debate my concern at the process of review that had taken place with regard to Zapopan's development and the frustrations that are being caused there in that particular project. Similarly, I think the principles of ecologically sustainable development that have now been put forward as an amendment to clause 4 would give us cause for concern about the viability and the future of any significant and major projects. I am sure all senators will take particular interest in the proposals and the policies of the coalition with regard to the fast tracking procedures for appropriate developments in Australia which create jobs and create wealth and, at the same time, protect the special environment and Aboriginal interests that have to be preserved in Australia.

What we need to see in legislation is a recognition of those appropriate areas of environmental and Aboriginal interests as have recently been demonstrated by the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government in the fast tracking of the Mount Todd proposal in the Northern Territory, and also the development of the MacArthur River project by Mt Isa Mines. I would certainly commend the work that Mr Brereton and the Northern Territory Ministers have invested in ensuring that those projects get up and going. If we were to accept this type of amendment, we would certainly be bogged down and would not be able to get on with that sort of project.

We will not be supporting the Democrat amendment to clause 14 concerning the National Landcare Advisory Committee as we believe that a committee of 12 will already have wide representation. It is unnecessary for a committee of 12 to be restricted, as the Democrats are now proposing, to three of its members having experience or special knowledge of conservation, vegetation management, environment protection and community organisation. Talk about jobs for the boys! Very obviously, the Australian Democrats are looking to stack committees by ensuring that the membership of these committees is increased and after their particular and special interests. The coalition will not be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting the Democrat amendments either, but the office of the Minister has furnished me with these statements that I can make with respect to the two material amendments before the Chair. An authorised comment from the Minister, Mr Crean, states:

SPEECH.PARA: We are committed to incorporating into this and other relevant portfolio legislation a more specific reference to the core objectives and agreed principles of ecological sustainable development as agreed by the governments in a national strategy for ESD at the recent council of Australian governments meeting at the earliest opportunity.

With respect to the second amendment, the Government of course again does not support these proposed changes. But I can say that the legislation reflects the Government's balanced approach and therefore no particular interests will be given prominence in the membership of the National Landcare Advisory Committee. As Minister Crean stated in his second reading speech, non-government representatives, including the Chairperson, will form the majority of the Committee's membership. These will be well qualified individuals from a broad range of backgrounds. With those comments on the record, I indicate the Government's opposition to these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier, I will be supporting the Democrats' amendments if they choose to call a division on it. I must say that the comments I have just heard from the Opposition and the Government cause me some genuine alarm, because I would have thought that the Democrats' amendments were eminently sensible for inclusion in this Bill. I believe that it is shoddy and slapdash to leave out such important concepts as definitions of the ESD process and the specification that, within a committee which is addressing these concepts, there should be some relevant experience.

PARA.TAB: I think I was not necessarily expecting the Opposition to support the amendments, but I feel that refusal to accept the very reasonable amendments put forward by the Democrats actually calls into question the genuine motivation of both the Government and the Opposition with regard to this Bill. It makes me want to vote against the Bill, which would, I realise, be a token gesture. I will maintain my support of it, but I do condemn the Government strongly for failing to include these components within the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, given to us by the Minister representing him. I must address the typical criticism that has been delivered by Senator Tambling. The normal response we have received to anything that has not been given several weeks worth of consideration has been that it has all been a bit fast for the thinkers opposite. I must say that the principles of ecologically sustainable development which we have listed here are in concert with the principles contained in the Brundtland report. Senator Tambling should, if he were interested in these sorts of things, have had that particular document on his bookshelf for at least three years. If these principles are a revelation to him today, then I am only sorry that he has revealed that by showing that he has not had the time to appreciate and understand it.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that there has been plenty of notice for those who are interested in these principles to have absorbed and reached a conclusion about their appropriateness to be included in legislation. I was ready to accept the reasons for not going along with the second phase of our amendments—that which considered the numbers on the Committee. I thought that that was fair enough; there was a reason for that. I thought the sting in the tail of Senator Tambling's reasons was gratuitous and really not worthy of this place; I was happy to accept the reasons but I thought the insult was useless. Again, I welcome the statement by the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —One is never surprised when the members of the Opposition get up and speak on things like ESD; they reveal that they have very little knowledge and care less about things environmental. As my colleague Senator Bell has pointed out, since the Brundtland report the concepts of ESD have been well rehearsed. After much prodding, the Government itself set up nine committees which looked at ESD and made many hundreds of recommendations. That was some 13 months ago. The Government is yet to take up any of those recommendations so it has not shown any great willingness to process this. The Minister is now turning around and saying that the Government will insert these principles at the earliest opportunity; I say, `Here is the first and earliest opportunity', and yet it is not prepared to do it.

PARA.TAB: I find that quite remarkable. I think it indicates that still, at this stage, neither the Government nor the Opposition has any understanding or any serious commitment to ESD. They are really playing with it; they have taken up the words. Just today we have seen the Opposition release its concept of ESD. It is going to set up a department and, exactly as Senator Tambling said, it will be a department of fast track development. The idea of ecological has been dropped entirely from the concept; it is sustainable development. The Opposition does not yet know that development is not going to be sustainable if it does not look after the environment. So there is still a shock in store for it.

Many of us have already understood that; we are trying to teach that lesson to a few others but they are still to learn it—very unfortunately, and very unfortunately for this country. If Senator Tambling were to go back and review the history of EISs, for instance, he would find that, with those EISs that have been most thoroughly carried out, with those EISs where the public has been most thoroughly involved and the longest time has been involved, those projects that have then eventuated at the end of that process have done the least environmental damage, have gone forward to the greatest profitability and have been the most successful projects. Fast tracking, really, is a recipe for imminent disaster. If the Opposition is going to fast track everything it is really going to rip this country apart. That is a lesson that is already there in the record if its members choose to look at it, but it is a lesson that they are not choosing to learn, or even to look at at this time.

So we will divide on this, Mr Chairman; it is a very important principle. It is the first opportunity that the Government has had to incorporate this into legislation; it is choosing not to and that is a very sad reflection but it is not an unsurprising reflection. On Monday, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) releases his environment statement, I will be very surprised if there is any strong emphasis on ESD. If there is, I will be there pointing out to the Prime Minister how hollow his words are.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.
