TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Residue Survey Administration Bill 1992 and cognate Bills are to allow the Government to recover 100 per cent of the Government's cost of undertaking the national residue survey from July next year, instead of the current 60 per cent. This survey is conducted by the Government to determine the chemical status of Australian food. Until a few years ago, the Government paid the $6m annual cost as a public health measure. This changed to 50 : 50, and then to 40 : 60. Now complete cost recovery is required, all of it from primary industry.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the honourable member for Murray, and shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, pointed out in his speech during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives that he was unaware of any other country in the world where producers are required to pay in full, as this Bill requires, for a public health facility. In the industry there are 25 separate items on the schedule encompassing 17 levy Bills. This shows the spread of levy throughout agriculture. The survey analyses samples of Australian produced animal and plant food products, particularly meat, for residues of a wide range of contaminants.

Those in the agricultural industry are generally fed up with this Labor Government because of the number of charges that have been imposed on the industry. The industry is being pushed to promote the pure food status of Australian food products, which is worth promoting, but when it comes to any form of government assistance to the industry, another tax is slapped on them. The Government could not even assist the industry to the tune of half of the $6m per annum required for the public health facility—a mere $3m a year.

These Bills are to allow the Government to recover 100 per cent of the Government's cost of undertaking the national residue survey from July next year, instead of the current 60 per cent. The Cattle Council, which represents the major levy payers, has objected to this increase because it believes that, while it does benefit from survey in the marketplace, the major reason for the survey is public health. Other levy payers have also objected. To the rural industry this Bill is seen as being symbolic of the Labor Government's attitude of unfairly transferring public costs to farmers, imposing user pays with no accountability as to the efficiency of the program.

The National Residue Survey Administration Bill 1992 provides for a trust account to be established which will allow funds and obligations to be carried over beyond the end of the financial year. Provision is also made for other contributions to be received from industries. This will give industry more flexibility in the way its costs are paid if it does not want a levy. Industries will have the power to pull out of the survey, or alternatively, have more products included. The Minister cannot include products unless satisfied that the industry wants them included. By increasing its cost recovery from 60 to 100 per cent, the Commonwealth expects to save about $2.7m.

As these are Budget Bills, the coalition parties will not be opposing them. However, as Mr Lloyd has already said in his speech during the second reading debate, on being elected to government, the coalition will amend this legislation and return to 50 per cent cost recovery. The coalition believes that is a reasonable apportionment of the public health situation versus the industry. We would, of course, make the appropriate Budget adjustments that would be necessary to implement any such amendment and change in the future. There are 18 of these primary industry Bills in total and I would hope that it is possible to consolidate some of them in the future.

This will be an issue during the election campaign. The Opposition will be saying to industry that it recognises that government, as well as industry, has a responsibility; that when it comes to encouragement for promotion overseas, and reassurance at home, of the pure food status of our products, a coalition government is prepared to give some practical and pragmatic recognition and assistance. That will certainly be on the agenda for the forthcoming election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the National Residue Survey Administration Bill to the extent that it sets up a trust account from which to pay the costs of the national residue survey. The Democrats wholeheartedly support the residue survey run by the Bureau of Resource Sciences, but we agree with many of the criticisms that have been made of that survey.

PARA.TAB: Many argue that export produce is still predominant in the survey at the expense of domestic produce, particularly fruit and vegetables, although agricultural chemicals are widely used in their production. The Australian Science and Technology Council, for example, has said the survey should be expanded to provide a broad based monitoring program for all agricultural produce. Some argue that the range of chemicals tested is too narrow. The Science and Technology Council has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The areas of deficiency are in analyses for antibiotics, anti-helminthics and hormones in meat and for fruit and vegetable and minor crops in general, grains and imported food.

Another concern is the adequacy of procedures to enable the identification of the source of excessive chemical residues. The National Farmers Federation stated to the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia:

The effectiveness of the NRS as a monitor and a means of preventing excessive residues is dependent on the ability to trace the products tested back to their source. NFF urges the introduction of procedures which will permit residues detected in NRS to be traced back to source and for the NRS to be directed more towards locating residue levels in excess of NRLs.

Another criticism was that the survey did not include imported food but a recent Bill has corrected this. All of these concerns have been accepted by the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals.

PARA.TAB: The other criticism, and one shared by the Democrats, concerns funding arrangements. A widely shared view is that the survey should be funded by a levy on chemical sales instead of a levy on food producers. Both the Australian Science and Technology Council and the Senate Committee have suggested a monitoring levy on the chemical producing industry itself.

It goes without saying, I think, from the consistent stance that we have taken in this area, that the Democrats would much prefer that we did not need to monitor our produce for chemical residues at all, because we should reach the situation where no harmful chemicals are being used in their production. To be practical, though, we recognise that, although we do not stand alone in holding this view, it is widely believed that we must throw chemicals around all over the place in order to maintain our agricultural and horticultural industries. Using chemicals in agriculture has become a billion dollar industry with in-built incentives. The in-built incentives maintain vested interests and ensure that there is a continued drive towards expansion of this industry.

This Bill will do nothing to contain that expansion. It will fund the survey and it is flexible enough to expand as the need to monitor the chemicals in our food expands. That will not attack the fundamental problem, which is the attitude which encourages our growing dependence on chemicals.

The proposals here place a levy on producers, whether or not they use chemicals. If we are to have the principles of cost recovery and user pays, we should do it properly. The funds for this survey should come from the sale of chemicals. There is then an economic incentive to limit their use. That is our fundamental objection to the Bill, not just the principle of cost recovery.

I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage which, if passed, would enable the Minister to come back next year with a proposal that rightly places the cost burden on the chemical industry itself. I also foreshadow that that amendment would have the effect of inviting the coalition actually to vote for the policy enunciated by Senator Tambling. I have suggested in this case that the excuse that he has not seen it before cannot be applied. It is in fact the policy of the coalition. The shadow Minister's speech during the second reading debate in the other place made mention of the fact that in no other country in the world, to his knowledge, are producers required to pay 100 per cent of the cost of such a survey. That is a comment I would endorse and which I would agree is a situation which should be recognised by those who propose that our producers meet 100 per cent of the cost.

I would also agree with much of the rest of what was contained in Senator Tambling's speech about the necessity to recognise that such costs placed on our producers are not equitable and do not recognise that there is a community health benefit from surveying and understanding what is in our foods; and in fact the Government has an obligation to reduce the amount of tax imposition on our primary producers. I recognise those things and because I recognise them I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment to meet the concerns expressed on behalf of the coalition.

We do not share the view that because something is a Budget Bill it is sacrosanct and cannot be touched; there certainly can be a request made. Perhaps it should be realised that that particular excuse has, on occasions, been ignored by those in the coalition when it suits them. I will eagerly await the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their responses. I will be brief in responding to a couple of points that were made. One concerned which other countries might be on full cost recovery; my advice is that New Zealand and the United Kingdom both have full cost recovery in place for their national residue monitoring programs, and the move to full cost recovery for the national residue survey is consistent with current Government policy on user pays in Australia. It is, in that respect, part of the overall micro-economic reform package.

PARA.TAB: On the point that Senator Bell was making, that the chemical industry has not been asked to contribute to the cost of the national residue survey, that is because it already contributes substantially to the cost of establishing residue limits, and the occurrence of residues above those limits is, of course, frequently due to misuse of chemicals. The other reason is that large parts of the survey are for residual chemicals no longer produced by the industry, or from natural resources.

The other comment I should make concerns the survey itself, which is about adding value to Australian produce not covered by other surveys. It is a trade based survey; it is not about nutritional habits. The Australian market basket survey, which is conducted by the National Food Authority, is to estimate the dietary intakes of chemical contaminants by Australians. That survey is based on a small sample size of processed and raw food available in supermarkets. The food is prepared to table ready form before analysis and foods included in that survey are not necessarily of Australian origin. With those comments in relation to some of the points raised by the speakers in this debate, I commend the Bills to the Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY ADMINISTRATION BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to get some information concerning the table in the schedule to the Bill as mentioned in clause 4, on how the suggested operative rates have been put together. I refer particularly to potatoes. Information that I have received from the Department says:

SPEECH.PARA: The potatoes rate was calculated allowing a potato program costing $52,000 and a domestic production level for 1990-91 of 1 180 000 tonnes.

On a cost of that nature, I find it completely incongruous to have what is probably the most similar vegetable possible—the onion—listed at $1.56 a tonne. If that figure does not contain a misplaced decimal point, and a few other things as well—and I trust that it does—I would like the Minister to bear in mind that, at $1.56 a tonne, that is probably all the profit there is in exporting onions. There is no way in the world that we can have an industry that is being run just to fund a residue survey.

PARA.TAB: When honey is 0.12c a kilo and onions are $1.56 a tonne and potatoes are 4.5c a tonne, there is clearly a mistake of some sort. Because I sensed a week or so ago that this was the case, I contacted the Minister's office and I received a response which provides that information. I seek leave to include it in Hansard so that it is on the record.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: SUBJECT: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY BILLS
11 December 1992
A Free
Liaison Officer
Office of Minister for Resources
In response to your queries yesterday on the National Residue Survey Bills arising from the Opposition questions asked of the Minister's Office, I offer the following:

The Operative rate levy figures found in column 2 of the schedule of the National Residue Survey Administration Bill are estimated from current Survey program costs divided by the amount of production (or export) from statistics. Column 3 of the schedule sets a maximum levy rate based on a level generally 2 or 3 times the Operative rate.

The onions rate was calculated allowing an onion program costing $85 000 and an export tonnage of 54 578 tonnes in 1990-91 (the 1991-92 export figures now available indicate nearly 75 000 tonnes which would mean about $1 levy on the same cost base). The potatoes rate was calculated allowing a potato program costing $52 000 and a domestic production level for 1990-91 of 1 180 000 tonnes.

These figures in column 2 show the size of the levy but the actual levies to be imposed are intended to be set by regulation after industry consultation before they come into effect, as is the normal practice. Clause 9(2)(b) of the same Bill makes a levy set by regulation to be the one that prevails.

The levies to be set by regulation will mostly be lower than indicated in column 2. Those industries either not participating in the survey or funding it through other means will have the levy set at 0.00 cents. Other levies will be lower than indicated because of reductions in Survey costs. For example, the move of analytical testing to open competition and away from exclusive use of Aust. Govt. Analytical Laboratories is expected to significantly reduce survey costs. Likewise, so will a reduction in the annual number of samples analysed for some commodities.
Neil Williams
Executive Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like some information on that matter because, if the figure in the table is as the Minister believes it should be, we should certainly be moving an amendment to have it changed. It is ridiculous. If it is wrong, let us put it right now because at $1.56 a tonne it cannot stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The figure is accurate. The method of calculation for it is the same as the method of calculation for the other figures in the schedule; that is, there has been an estimate of the projected costs of the survey and that is one element of the calculation. The other element of the calculation is the production of the particular commodity. The objective of the calculation of the formula is to make sure there is no cross-subsidising between the various categories of commodity that are mentioned here so that we have a fair cost per commodity. I understand the point that Senator Archer is making but my advice is that, when it is calculated in that way, which I think people would regard as a fair way, the results come out as we see displayed in the schedule.

—We are talking about 75,000 tonnes of one product and 1,180,000 tonnes of another product. All we are looking for is a residue. Is it necessary to test every onion as against checking, say, one potato per 100 tonnes? The figures are ridiculous. I understand that the testing is not different. It can be done in the same laboratory, with the same plant, to come up with the result. Potatoes are grown in every State in Australia. Onions are grown in every State in Australia. The figures do not stand up. Before we can possibly agree to wreck an industry because of some crazy costing figure, we need to know what is the similarity or the difference between these two products that the departmental officers see as necessary and we need to know why this should be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should have said that we are not talking here about all the onions produced—
—Yes, we are. The letter says so.
—We are talking about the export production of onions.
—It doesn't mention that.

—I am advised that that is the correct situation. When we are talking about the way in which the survey is to be conducted, we are not applying a different type of sampling to one commodity as opposed to the other. The approach here is by random sampling with the necessary weighting to make sure there is a fair sample compared to the volume of production. It is not that someone is picking on the humble onion, it is that when those measures are applied it comes out this way.

—The Minister is still not on track. It does not matter whether it is one tonne of onions or a million tonnes of onions. We are talking about $1.56 per tonne of what is exported as against 4.5c per tonne of the potatoes that are exported. Is that understood? The rate for onions is nearly 40 times the rate for potatoes. I think that anyone here, even at this hour of the day, would be able to see that that is ridiculous. Is it a decimal point that has gone wrong or something, because it is obviously stupid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the honourable senator's point. Surely, in return, he understands the explanation. This is not a mistake in the schedule.
—We haven't had an explanation.
—With the greatest of respect, I have given the honourable senator an explanation.
—No, I have been given an excuse. What is the explanation as far as the cost of the survey is concerned? Why should an onion cost more? It is the same survey.

—The advice I have given the Committee is that these figures are calculated by projecting the costs of the survey and looking at the exportable tonnage—in this case of onions—and coming to a figure. No-one is saying that the way in which onions are sampled is different from the way in which potatoes or some other commodity are sampled.

PARA.TAB: I have a further breakdown of the estimates. The explanation I have given is consistent with the figures that I will now put on the record. For onions, the proposed total cost for the survey in dollar terms is $85,300, and the production against which this is calculated for 1990-91 in tonnes—export only—is 54,578. That comes to a unit cost per tonne of 156c. For potatoes, the proposed total cost of the survey is $52,500 and the production in tonnes for 1990-91 is 1,180,000, which brings a unit cost per tonne of 4.5c. It is clear how the figures come out. For potatoes, the total cost for the survey is $52,500; for onions it is $85,300. The production of onions is 54,500 tonnes; for potatoes it is 1,180,000 tonnes. If one applies those inputs, one gets these outputs on that cost ratio.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not sell 1,180,000 tonnes of potatoes overseas. Why select the export of onions and the domestic consumption of potatoes? Let us look at the two things together. Alternatively, why are 35 times as many onions out of the crop inspected and tested as potatoes? This is the sort of silly answer that we have got. It is just absolute nonsense.
—Irish logic.
—It is not even Irish logic, even at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Onions are, for the purposes of this levy, costed only in so far as the export of onions is concerned, not the domestic consumption of onions. But potatoes are costed for the total production. The explanation, I am advised, is that it is not possible to calculate the production—
—It doesn't make sense to you, does it?
—I want to be precise because I divine there is a bit of temperature rising in the chamber.
—I will give you a half-hour adjournment.
—I do not need a half-hour adjournment. I want to check each of my words with the advisers so that the record is correct. The advice I have is that it is not possible to levy domestic onions.
—Why not?
—Why potatoes and not onions?
—The advice is that there is no existing mechanism in place to do it.
—So onions are that huge amount extra. It is really ridiculous.
—My further advice is that onions are export sensitive. It is not the domestic end of the onion market that needs the survey, it is the export end.
—Can we adjourn for half an hour?
—No, we cannot. We must deal with the legislation now. I have provided the Committee with an explanation.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, if that is the best explanation that can be given, should we move an amendment? It is ridiculous to pass a measure which could absolutely wreck an industry. The amount of $1.56 a tonne is more than every onion exporter in Tasmania made for the whole of last year's export crop. They did not make $1.56 a tonne. Are we going to lumber them with something that will ensure that there is no export industry, or are we going to get this costing down to something like what is reasonable for others? We are talking about 25c a tonne for apples, pears and citrus fruits; we are talking about 4.5c for potatoes. Why are we talking about $1.56 a tonne for onions? It is nonsense.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to be a party to trying to wreck the industry because of some stupidity that is perpetrated in this legislation. It is just not good enough. It is said that one thing needs to be done because it is for the export market and the other thing needs to be done because it is for the domestic market. Let us be consistent about it and say, `Does it matter whether it is done for export, does it matter whether it is done domestically?'. Let us come up with something that is reasonable. At $1.56 a tonne one could test damned nearly every onion—it is just crazy. At best, one probably only needs an onion tested for every export truckload—every 20 tonne container or something. I have grown onions for export. If one has an onion crop of, say, 50 acres, one does not need to test every onion if one has treated them all the same way. If they are being grown in a district and they are all treated in the same manner, every onion does not need to be tested.

I know that onions are grown for export in Western Australia, South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and Queensland, but they are all grown on much the same basis. We are now winding up with a nonsense. I am prepared to let Senator Bell now have a chase of the rabbit, but I want to come back to it before we finish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

DEBATE.TITLE: AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Preparation for the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Bill 1992 and the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Amendment Bill 1992 commenced in 1967. In July 1991 the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments agreed to replace the existing eight State and Territory registration bodies with a single national scheme to register agricultural and veterinary chemicals. These Bills establish the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals. The Authority is another step towards the development of a national registration scheme for these chemicals.

PARA.TAB: The Authority will replace the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council as well as eight State and Territory statutory authorities. Its statutory power is considered necessary as it will be the national registration authority for these chemicals. The Bills do not change the arrangement for the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Another Bill to do that is expected next year. The Minister will have the power to direct the Authority in exceptional circumstance but, if he does, he must present the direction to both Houses of Parliament and it has to be reported in the Authority's annual report.

The Authority will have eight part time directors, appointed by the Minister for three years. They will come from industry, State government, the rural sector, the trade union movement and consumer organisations. The Authority must fully recover its costs from the ag-vet chemicals industry over the next four years. The Authority is to be given maximum flexibility to operate in a businesslike manner, free of government and Public Service restraints. It can set the terms and conditions of employment for its staff. It is being established before the main legislation relating to the national registration scheme to allow it to contribute to the development of the legislation which it will administer and to consult with interested groups.

The Australian agricultural industry is one of the least intensive users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in the world. Australian agriculture has also been one of the most careful users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. That is a positive image and a situation that we should continue to exploit with our exports to other countries. Australian agriculture is not a heavy user of chemicals compared with many other countries, due to the fact that our agriculture is extensive rather than intensive. This means that it has a low input cost system because it gets only a low return in export markets. Much of our agricultural area has low rainfall, and this creates certain restraints on the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals from a cost-effectiveness point of view. Also, much of our agriculture is grazing and livestock production rather than cropping. Cropping forms of agriculture are heavier users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals than the grazing industry.

At present we have the situation in the sheep industry where the industry would be better off if it could afford to use more veterinary chemicals than is presently the case, a situation brought about by the low returns to many of those sheep farmers. On the other hand, horticulture is a more intensive user, but it has adopted a positive policy to reduce the use of agricultural chemicals. I have noted the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Murray, the shadow Minister for primary industries, Mr Bruce Lloyd, regarding the horticultural industry's policy towards reducing the use of agricultural chemicals to biological control.

The growers have a legitimate complaint because, while in Australia there are restrictions on the use of chemicals and on residue with regard to fruit, vegetables, meat, et cetera, at this stage there are not the same requirements on the products coming into Australia with which they have to compete. That is an unfair situation as well as one that is not in the best interests of the consumer. I know that progress is being made in this area. I just hope that it accelerates so that we have a situation where the standards required for people producing food in Australia are applied equally to food, or whatever it may be, that is being imported. These Bills are supported by the industry and by the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the general direction of these Bills but they fall far short of what is required. Honourable senators may recall some of the issues I have raised, during adjournment debates in particular, relating to the use of chemicals in the environment. I have spoken of the poisoning of fish in the Barwon River, near the border between Queensland and New South Wales, caused by run-off from a nearby cotton farm. Samples taken from the area were positive for endosulphan, an insecticide withdrawn from the home garden market in March this year. I have spoken of the problems caused by aerial spraying in Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, and told the story of the results of spraying insecticides at a Hobart kindergarten for children having a variety of physical disabilities. As a result of the problems associated with that, the school was eventually closed.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that the issue of the use of chemicals in our environment and their effect on people's health is a subject with which almost everyone has some first hand knowledge. There are groups of concerned people all over the country and they are trying to bring some sanity and control into our propensity to throw chemicals around.
I quote from a letter from Mr Peter Harding, president of the Australian Chemical Trauma Alliance. He wrote to me in the following terms:

I am writing to you to bring to your attention the number of our members who have been injured and made ill through exposure to toxic chemicals, many of them having been affected by pesticides and herbicides which have been their downfall.

It is bad enough that disabling illnesses frequently result from exposure to various toxins, but this is usually followed by hardship and upheaval which are indescribable to those who have not been similarly affected.

This stems from the fact that either insufficient is known about the ill effects of certain chemicals on the human system, or indeed because such knowledge is deliberately suppressed to make life as difficult as possible for people who are seeking redress for their injuries.
Chemical victims encounter what seems to be a conspiracy to deny them justice when they seek redress. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I do not need to read all of Mr Harding's letter, but honourable senators will get the general thrust. The central problem is that we have created a chemical industry, the end result of which is the sale of chemicals, and it is a profitable result. But it has become far too powerful. We talk about—and we hear other people talk about—clean agriculture. It is a nonsense; it is mere words and public relations. We do not yet demonstrate a commitment to chemical free agriculture. We cannot honestly promote clean food until we have chemically free food.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, set up on the initiative of the Australian Democrats, proved to be an important catalyst in focusing our collective attention on some of these problems. The Committee reported in August 1990 and, nearly two years later, the Government has responded. It indicates an appalling lack of understanding about how important this issue really is and what a priority it is in the community. If it does not indicate that, it indicates the lack of political will regarding the priority needed to tackle these problems. Too little, far too late has resulted.

The failure to address practically the problem of aerial spraying is of particular concern. The only regulation that seems to receive even tacit support of governments is a vague requirement about pilots undergoing appropriate training, as if training will prevent spraying in wind or over houses and watercourses. Those who are trained may know what is appropriate, but whether they will exercise appropriate care is another matter.

Recommendation 45 of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia called for the development of a uniform approach to its regulation and, in the event that such regulations are not implemented, that aerial spraying should be banned. No uniform regulations are in place, nor will this legislation put them in place.

Equally, we as a community and as a government have refused to address the problems in the environment caused by uncontrolled and widespread use of pesticides in agriculture. This is not because of inadequate powers; it is pure lack of will. The current Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act states that the functions of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council are, amongst other things, to evaluate the effects of the use of chemical products. That is simply not being done. If it were, we would have a small army of people monitoring the effects of this stuff in rivers and waterways throughout the country.

Recently, we debated the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill, which was about labelling and the machinery set up to monitor the operation of the labelling system of the wine industry. If it is good enough for wine and brandy to receive proper monitoring of the standards imposed, why is it not good enough to have a proper monitoring system of the use of chemicals? I remember speaking on the Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill and realising as I spoke that here we had a special Act of Parliament, a whole bureaucracy and a bunch of inspectors authorised to ensure that what was in the bottle was what was described on the label. We think that is important for wine and brandy, but the other things we consume are not similarly labelled or policed.

If we were serious about our professed concern for the effects of chemicals on the environment, we would set up a register of complaints and treatments attributable to exposure to chemicals because significant numbers of people—far too many—are suffering from the fallout of the effects of chemicals.

Another area of immense concern not only to individuals, but particularly to municipal councils throughout the country, is the problem of what to do with waste chemicals. Recently, the Beaconsfield Council in northern Tasmania asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, how to overcome a particular problem it had in disposing of dangerous agricultural chemical containers. The Minister is reported to have sent the council a draft protocol for the management of containers. That does not help that council.

I noticed in a recent edition of NSW Farmers News that this concern is now shared by the farming community, to the point of recommending a deposit system on chemical containers to encourage the return of excess chemicals and containers. This Bill provides no indication that that will in fact happen, but it ought to, or else, as the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association believes, irreparable damage could be caused to the environment.

There are instances where that is demonstrable. A case in point in Tasmania, one which is famous and well recognised, is that of a driver of a roadmaking grader involved in a road building project near Scamander on the east cost. While travelling through reasonably easy country for road building, the driver encountered some mysterious barrels, some of which were opened by the passage of the grader. The driver suffered terrible consequences. He was unable to continue work, the symptoms were very difficult to diagnose and the materials were also difficult to identify. The poor man is unable to work in his previous occupation. Through no fault of his own, he had unearthed what are suspected to be unused containers and discarded containers of agricultural chemicals. They had been placed in the dump because there had been, and still are, inadequate procedures for the disposal of such things.
The Government, however, is saying that it is committed to cleaning up Australia's chemicals. I quote from the 1990-91 report of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is essential that there is a comprehensive system for the regulation and control of these chemicals in Australia which could not be achieved through market forces and which, accordingly, requires the intervention of Government.

The Democrats welcome that, but we want clear evidence that it is going to happen. Hence we will be moving amendments—not many, nor as strong as I think perhaps they should be.There are moments when we believe things are happening and progress is being made. On 7 December I gave notice that I would move that we note with approval that the National Health and Medical Research Council has recommended the phasing out of cyclodienes, a type of organochlorin which has previously been used to poison termites and funnel ants. I did so with some degree of satisfaction because the NHMRC had advised that, during the next two years, the poison should only be used in areas which are not easily accessible to humans, and the Australian Consumers Association and Greenpeace had both welcomed the recommendations, saying that improved building practices could stop destruction by termites without added chemical risks.

PARA.TAB: When I proposed that notice of motion in the Senate, I did so very happily and in a frame of mind of anticipating that this was going to happen. I have since been advised that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council has chosen to undermine the progress of those recommendations and I am very suspicious now about the future opportunities there. Yet several hours ago, while watching one of the late night programs on ABC television, we were shown in colour several alternative methods for building a house on mainland Australia. In Tasmania we do not suffer the problems of termites but the poor unfortunate souls on the mainland here seem to have a lot of fuss and bother with them. There we saw in colour some very simple alternative building methods involving the use of crushed granite, metal, woven steel mesh or cloth placed in the right places, and consideration being given to the problem rather than throwing chemicals about with little thought for what they might do if retained in the environment.

It is possible—it is not an economic difficulty; in fact, it is an economic advantage—to consider carefully the use of chemicals in our environment. I suggest that this Bill does little to encourage us to take those measures. It does little to make a firm commitment to reducing the use of unnecessary chemicals in our environment. I will be moving amendments in the committee stage which will attempt to redress its inadequacies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin to comment specifically on some shortcomings that I perceive in the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Bill, I would like to touch on some broader issues that I feel will need to be addressed by the Government in the near future. In her book, Signs of hope: working towards our common future, Linda Starke points to the increasing profile being given to the problems associated with the use and overuse of pesticides and fertilisers. She illustrates some initiatives being taken by other governments to minimise the use of pesticides and states, for example:

SPEECH.PARA: Some governments are moving beyond pesticide regulation. A 1987 law in Denmark, for instance, gives farmers financial support to develop or convert to organic farming. An Organic Farming Council was set up in July of that year to promote this agricultural method and monitor developments.
In the south-west of Western Australia, there is a developing competitive market for organic farming which I believe is very positive.

PARA.TAB: The role of integrated pest management in reducing dependence on chemicals was also discussed by Ms Starke. She gives an example of initiatives taken by the Indonesian Government when she says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Indonesian Government may have taken some of the boldest steps to support IPM. In late 1986 fifty seven pesticides were banned and a national promotion of less environmentally harmful pest control began. A year later, subsidies for the use of remaining pesticides on rice were cut, as the success of IPM became clear to more farmers.

I trust that our own Government has taken note of these initiatives by other nations to reduce the dependence of our agricultural industries on chemicals. Whilst the registration initiatives proposed in this Bill are laudable in themselves, they should properly be placed in the context of a broader move to ecologically sustainable agriculture.

PARA.TAB: However, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, sadly, does not appear to include any reference to the need to operate within the principles of ecologically sustainable development. As with a previous Bill we have been discussing, this omission reduces the credibility of the legislation. The final report of the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Group on Agriculture pointed to the fact that `chemicals are an issue in the context of ecologically sustainable agriculture'. It would therefore seem appropriate that the major Federal legislation dealing with the registration and use of chemicals in the agricultural and veterinary industries incorporates a reference to, and definition of, ecologically sustainable development.

I would like to state here that the incorporation of ESD principles into the Bill should be seen not as a hindrance to better economic performance, but rather as the creation of an opportunity for the Australian agricultural industry to create a reputation and a niche for the supply of pesticide free and healthy food to the rest of the world. By its very nature, this export opportunity will be sustainable and not driven by short term profit motives.

The other issue that I would like to touch on in this debate relates to the need for environmental monitoring and research into the ecological and health impacts of both agricultural and veterinary chemicals. One mechanism to fund such research was raised in the final report of the ESD working group on agriculture where reference was made to the possibility of placing a levy on chemical and fertiliser usage. This is consistent with the polluter pays principle, which has been advocated by many studies into the environmental problems facing both Australia and the planet as a whole.

In Sweden this approach has already been adopted. The Swedish Government's report to the UNCED conference which was held in Rio De Janeiro earlier this year pointed to the establishment of a chemicals inspectorate, which is responsible for both environmental and health aspects of chemicals. The report went on to say that the chemicals inspectorate is financed through charges on chemical products and pesticides. It should be pointed out that this call for monitoring and research should not be seen as an excuse for a business as usual approach by the ag-vet chemicals industry.

There is sufficient evidence already in existence to create considerable concern in the community about the health and ecological impacts of some agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The Government should be responding to these concerns by implementing major changes in the way that these industries are allowed to use the chemicals. The legislative approach is, however, limited and the Government should also be considering following the lead of the Danish Government in promoting organic farming techniques through some form of incentives scheme.

Finally, I would like to address briefly some issues relating to the administrative and decision making procedures to be adopted by the National Registration Authority. Whilst I was pleased that consumer groups are represented on the NRA, I was wondering about the importance of the inclusion of environment and conservation groups. There is no reference in the Bill to such issues as appeals procedures and the procedures for notifying decisions of the NRA and the rationale behind those decisions. I feel that it is important that the general public feel some confidence in such an important authority as the NRA. This can only be achieved through an open public consultation process.

I trust that these issues will be adequately addressed by the Government in the promised follow-up legislation in the Autumn session. In this context, I also trust that the matter of community right to know will be addressed. I refer the Senate to an article in the Green Left Weekly of 28 October 1992 where it comments that Australia lags on chemical right to know law. Australia has no community right to know legislation and only limited worker right to know provisions. The March 1992 final report of the independent Coode Island review panel investigating the Coode Island fire recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the government agree in principle to a legislated Community Right to Know to assist public understanding of hazardous materials and production processes.

So far no party—State or Federal—has done anything about this. However, I am please to note that today independent Senator Janet Powell tabled a draft private member's Bill, the Toxic Chemicals (Community Right to Know) Bill; hopefully to receive some attention in reference to this legislation. I conclude by urging that the opportunity provided by this Bill, to deal responsibly with the use of chemicals within the agricultural and veterinary practices, should be grasped.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

SPEECH.PARA: AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 14, page 5, paragraph (2)(b), omit "2", substitute "1".
2.Clause 14, page 5, subclause (2), add at the end the following word and paragraph:
"and
(f) one director has experience in environmental protection.".
I will not elaborate on the amendments as I think they are self-explanatory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on these amendments of the Australian Democrats at almost 3.55 a.m., in the further saga of this late night session on these particular issues. Whilst we are looking at the issue of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, I think it would tax many of us to know the sorts of chemicals that are obviously affecting all of us at this hour of the morning.

PARA.TAB: One particular amendment needs to be looked at very carefully because the night owls of the Democrats who always want to come out at these ungodly hours of the morning to do their bidding and to look after their mates, are very obviously reflected in this amendment. The Democrats are moving an amendment to the Bill which enables an environmentalist to sit on the board of the National Registration Authority. The Bill clearly sets out that there are to be members appointed to the Authority from a wide range of industry sectors, including two directors having experience in the regulation of chemical products under the law of a State or Territory. I would have thought that many of the people suitably qualified under that clause would have had considerable environmental experience and not necessarily have to be identified with the words `environmental protection'.

There are to be two directors who have experience in the industry. Of course, the Democrats are seeking to reduce that number to one as a trade-off in this amendment. I would have thought that any directors recruited from industry would hold tertiary qualifications, and it ought not be assumed that anyone who comes out of industry does not have a great deal of simpatico and identification with the environment. There is to be one director who has experience in the protection of the interests of the consumers. Again, I would have thought that many people eminently qualified in that area would be well experienced in environmental protection.

The Bill sets out that there is to be one director who has experience in primary production. Certainly, anybody who comes from that particular industry already has a very close environmental link. There is to be one director who has experience in occupational health and safety as an officer or employee of an organisation of employees. Again, anyone working in that field is eminently qualified and competent in the areas that naturally have an impact on the environment. The Bill also clearly sets out with whom the authorities should consult. These include persons who are involved with industry, the Commonwealth or State governments, persons with interests in matters pertaining to the industry, including of course, the scientific community, and persons who either have a particular interest in consumers or in the protection of the environment.

The coalition is of the view, firstly, that the Democrat concerns have already been addressed in this Bill and, secondly, that such an appointment to the Authority is totally unnecessary, due to the fact that chemicals are already required by law to be registered in Australia and have to pass through stringent environmental testing. This is really just another pitch by the Democrats for a job for the boys for one of their members or someone who holds a strong view—perhaps someone associated with Greenpeace or another like-minded organisation—for a particular government sponsored position in a paid area. I believe the Bill already adequately covers the issues that Senator Bell is seeking to incorporate through this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In deference to the hour I was hoping to be brief on this. I moved without glorification or vilification. I must rise to counter some of the baseless accusations that have been shovelled in my direction. The fact is that we have a demonstrated inadequacy by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council which I will demonstrate shortly. The Democrats were trying to ensure that such an inadequacy was not repeated in relation to the composition of the body that is being proposed here.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that the NHMRC made recommendations which I alluded to earlier and it is a fact that the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council released a press release on 8 December soon after I had made the observation that the recommendations of the NHMRC were to be welcomed. In responding to those recommendations, the press release by the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council says in part that the Council had given consideration to the recent Duggan report on organochlorin insecticides, that it would like to see all these persistent chemicals removed from use and replaced by a suitable alternative and that—and I emphasise this—the matter is controversial and complex and therefore the Council will be seeking further advice before taking a definitive position.

I suggest that that demonstrates that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council did not have within it the expertise to recognise the inherent quality of the recommendations by the NHMRC. I suggest that before we construct another body to replace this Council we ensure that it has the capacity to not get bogged down seeking further advice and that it has that advice within its very own boundaries. That is why we have proposed this amendment. I recommend that the Committee seriously consider this amendment. That is why I refute the motives which have been ascribed to me by Senator Tambling.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly in support of the amendments. I think it is a sad reflection on the priority given to these Bills that they run so low as to come last. I believe the Democrats are severely disadvantaged by having to place amendments at the end of the sittings, with neither this place nor the other likely to give them any attention at all.

PARA.TAB: I want to place on record my support of the amendments. Both Government and Opposition should make no mistake: the community is gravely concerned about the health and environmental implications of what we do. To ignore that is to their own detriment and peril. I go no further. I just wish to support these amendments and place on record my disappointment that they have not already been incorporated in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept these amendments. There has been wide ranging consultation. The Government decided that the membership of the board should be drawn from the principal stakeholders in agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Some groups argued that the scientific adviser should also be on the board. While the Government understands the reasoning behind that, it is firmly of the view that decisions on ag-vet chemicals should be taken by people who are the principal stakeholders in the scheme.

PARA.TAB: In making its decisions the board will have access to the assessment of each agency involved, including the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, on environmental issues. If it needs further information or clarification of difficult issues, the board will be able to seek additional advice from the appropriate adviser. This is not to say that the Government is downgrading the importance of the environmental advice and input.

Recently, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy established a committee to provide a more formal mechanism to canvass the views of various Commonwealth agencies involved in the ag-vet scheme. The Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency is a member of that committee. Again, to ensure that environmental issues are given appropriate priority, CEPA has been made a member of the Commonwealth-State committee responsible for the effective coordination of Commonwealth and State components of the national registration scheme. Because of that we believe that this amendment is not necessary.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President—
—Be a bit brief.
—I will indeed. We are here for the third time in 12 months debating important workers compensation legislation in the dying hours of a Senate sittings, indeed, at 4.15 on this Friday morning.

PARA.TAB: This happened just hours before the Christmas recess began at this time last year. It also happened just before the winter recess on the last sitting day in June. Today, on our last sitting day for 1992, we are here again debating important workers compensation legislation in the form of this Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill 1992.

The Liberal and National parties are opposed to the central purpose of this legislation, which is to extend Comcare's tentacles into providing workers compensation for privatised former government business enterprises and for sections of the private sector, and will oppose those sections of the legislation giving effect to that. In the committee stage we will move amendments to prevent this extension of coverage. We also believe that Comcare should be fully privatised. Separately from those amendments dealing with Comcare's coverage, we will move committee stage amendments to assist the future privatisation of Comcare.

Given the lateness of the hour, having agreed with the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook) to take this course of action, and having stated the position of the Opposition with regard to this legislation, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard our arguments against the legislation.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Comcare system as it presently stands, underwent certain reforms in the recent past which have been touted by Comcare as basic reforms.
Those reforms limit some of the benefits which were available under the system, and modified some of the procedural aspects of the system.
They have been presented by Comcare as having basically altered the way in which Comcare is administered, and having also basically altered the benefits available under the system.

The real position however, when looked at in comparison to the reforms which have been made in NSW and which are about to be made in Victoria, is that those reforms can be more properly characterised as tinkering about the edges of the problems which exist.
The compensation provisions under Comcare are excessively generous in comparison with the State systems.
Certainly, administrative changes have been made in Comcare in accord with the recommendations of the Brown inquiry.
However, the cost-saving changes from the Brown recommendations have not seen the light of day.
The fact is, that the level of benefits is a major part of Comcare's cost structure.
The benefits provided for the public sector, under Comcare, remain better than provided by other systems for the private sector.
State governments have a number of problems with this Bill.

These include that the Comcare proposal was developed without prior consultation with the States. States are concerned at the lack of consultation and major implications for State workers' compensation schemes.
They made this clear at the Labour Minister's meeting on 30 October 1992, following earlier meetings of officials on 9 September and 1 October 1992 which failed to clarify issues of concern.
I am told that even Minister Cook's Labor colleague, the Minister of Labour in South Australia, Bob Gregory, gave him a real touch up at the meeting.
However, all States considered that the extension of Comcare outside privatised Commonwealth organisations is unnecessary and have raised a number of fundamental issues.

At the recent Labour Minister's meeting, it was noted that States/Territories did not object to the concept behind the Commonwealth proposal of making the administrative burden on major corporations much less across Australia and having much greater uniformity between the States (seen as very sound objectives). But that this needed to be done in a much more considered way and with consultation.
But the Commonwealth proposal introduces another layer of self insurance which is unnecessary and complicates, rather than simplifies, insurance and benefit arrangements.

All States are concerned that Comcare has not yet developed self insurance licensing criteria and is unable to clarify how boundaries will be defined between the extended coverage available under Comcare and State legislation.
The work cover board in NSW does not support the Comcare proposal as currently presented.

The Government's proposal raises major concerns for Workcover arrangements at State level in regard to the potential cost impact on State schemes and premiums, licensing arrangements for self-insurers, benefit anomalies, and the impact on occupational health and safety and dispute resolution services.

These concerns are shared by State governments, the administrators of State workers' compensation schemes and employers. The general view of employers is that the proposal is ill-considered in detail and apt to destroy the integrity of State schemes.

First among contentious issues causing States and employers to oppose this legislation is their questioning of its constitutionality. This persists despite the opinion of the Commonwealth acting Solicitor-General, Dennis Rose Q.C., that the proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 are a valid exercise of powers under section 51 (XX) of the Constitution.
Secondly, are its benefits.
The legislation will create two classes of workers and benefit entitlements within an industry, resulting in a further anomaly in workers compensation benefits at an industry level.
Comcare provides more generous benefits after 26 weeks (70 per cent of normal weekly earnings until age 65).
Employers who swap jurisdictions will have to administer both Workcover and Comcare benefit systems, because of existing Workcover claimants, and bear any consequent increase in administrative costs.
The legislation envisages there will be one scheme for workers in large national corporations and one scheme for those who work in locally based companies.

The consequence of such a proposal is that two workers in the same industry, within the same State or Territory, would receive different financial burdens, in terms of premiums and compensation payments.

Given that it has been a very strong point of contention that commonwealth government employees have been treated differently from the rest of the Australian workforce for many years, it would seem a grave mistake to exacerbate that sort of situation throughout every State and Territory.
Thirdly, is the potential impact on the cost and financial viability of State schemes.
The likely cost impact on State systems cannot be assessed until Comcare can provide a clear definition in regard to competing industries and licensing requirements.

However if many large employers leave the State system to take up the Comcare option this will reduce the premium pool remaining to fund certain industry sectors in the States' schemes and could increase premium levels for employers remaining in that sector.
There would also be pressure on the State schemes to match the higher benefits provided by Comcare, with a further consequent increase in State scheme premiums.
It is my understanding that the Federal government has failed to undertake any research into this aspect of the proposal.
Fourthly, are concerns regarding occupational health and safety.
Under the legislation, occupational health and safety will remain a State responsibility which will create an anomaly in the administration and funding of occupational health and safety services.
Employers fund the administration of occupational health and safety services via the Workcover levy.

The Commonwealth proposes that licensing arrangements will require corporations to contribute to State occupational health and safety programs. However it will be the responsibility of States to legislate for and collect such monies.
This is administratively cumbersome and likely to be unenforceable by the States.

The proposal in effectively separating compensation and rehabilitation away from occupational health and safety, heads in exactly the opposite direction of State systems, which recognise the importance of integrating occupational health and safety, rehabilitation and compensation services basic to prevention and rehabilitation objectives.
Certainly employers want a single regulator of occupational health and safety, rehabilitation and compensation.
Fifthly is the issue of transferability.

The Commonwealth proposes that organisations will be able to transfer to national coverage, through Comcare self insurance, and revert to the State system if they choose. The mechanism for achieving transferability and administering outstanding claims has not been clarified. States are concerned that Comcare fully supervise any self-insurer they license and the resulting claims run-off.
The legislation does not appear to absolve State systems of responsibility for the past.
But practicality demands that there be only one regulator.
It is essential to look at the totality of any particular individual's claims.
A State system would be very wary of accepting anyone back from Comcare coverage.
Sixthly, is the matter of licensing.

Criteria for licensing self-insurers have yet to be developed. It appears that this will be left to Comcare and regulated under a ministerial discretion, as criteria are not specified in the legislation.
Comcare has advised it will consult with States on the licensing policy which is proposed to be finalised by early 1993.
It is not acceptable for this legislation to pass with such an important matter unresolved.
It is important to know where the boundary lies between the State and Comcare systems.
This remains unclear, with Comcare either unable or unwilling to say what the self-insurance rules will be.
Where indeed do the boundaries lie for the private sector to come under Comcare?
If Ansett joins because it is allowed to as a competitor with the privatised, former Government business enterprise, Qantas, can the rest of the TNT Group?
And what about Compass?
If Australia Post joins, what about private career firms?
So there is real concern about the uncertainty relating to the boundary definitions of industry competitors of present and former, now privatised, Government business enterprises.
Related to this is the inconsistency of the `all in or all out' condition of coverage with the so-called level playing field, which this proposal purports to create.
`All in or all out' prevents competition between the States which is essential to maximise any benefits, achievable from a level playing field.
`All in or all out', prevents some State branches of national enterprises being under State compensation systems, while other branches are under Comcare.
For example, Qantas in Queensland could not remain under the State scheme there, while Qantas elsewhere moved in under Comcare.
This entrenches a lack of competitive efficiency.
It also raises the question of what happens to smaller companies operating in only one State, who nevertheless compete with national firms.
Will Comcare take them on?
This in turn raises possible constitutional problems.

If the proposal to offer self-insurance does not extend to smaller companies operating within States, nor to some trading between States, then the claim to be producing a level playing field is fundamentally flawed.

This proposal will not create a `level playing field' as claimed. A level playing field should provide uniformity in benefits which strike a rational balance between equity for workers and affordability for employers and allows States to compete against the Commonwealth for coverage of other Government national enterprises.
At the present time, a genuinely level playing field would see coverage move from Comcare to the State systems.
As I said earlier, benefits under Comcare are more generous than under most, if not all, State systems. Thus lower costs would be achievable through the State systems.

A level playing field should be achieved by the Federal Government working with the States to achieve national consistency in benefits, premiums, occupational health and safety, and subsequently opening up competition for service delivery to the States.

It is a question of the most appropriate way to get to a level playing field or uniformity in benefits. A far better way than this Government's back door method through this legislation is to bring the systems together cooperatively, as is already happening.
Employers are not convinced of Comcare's competitiveness based on average premium rates. They need a comparison of industry rates being offered for targeted industries.
Seventhly, there is concern about claims management.

There is widespread belief that self-insurers under Comcare should remain responsible for claims management. But under this Bill, Comcare will offer a claims management service under its self-insurance arrangements.
This is contrary to, for example, New South Wales Workcover's licensing policy which requires employers to manage claims effectively as a necessary component of operating as a self-insurer.

Several large NSW self-insurers have informally indicated their opposition to this aspect of the proposal. It is an important matter of principle that self-insuring employers manage employees claims and deal directly with those employees.
Only if employers insure with an external organisation should their claims be managed externally.

With regard to the eighth matter, liability, all States are apprehensive at a failure of a Comcare self-insurer could affect State employers and some financial contribution could be required from insurers/employers in each State. This would not be acceptable.

Employers are concerned about the failure of the Federal Government to check its unfunded liability in workers' compensation. This is reinforced by earlier qualification of Comcare's accounts by the Auditor-General regarding whether past claims are fully funded. The annual report presents claims rate figures that are quite horrendous.
Claims in Australian Airlines and Australian National Railways have been worse than the Newcastle dockyards.

Despite Comcare's claim that it is fully funded against liabilities, there appears to be no provision for the future. Premiums only reflect past claims paid. It is virtually impossible to assess the organisation's efficiency.
The ninth issue regards dispute resolution.
The question of which jurisdiction will determine workers' compensation claims and disputes has yet to be resolved.
Honourable senators should also be aware that this legislation extending Comcare coverage effectively pre-empts the outcome of the proposed Industry Commission inquiry into workers' compensation.

Treasurer Dawkins has referred workers' compensation arrangements in Australia to the Industry Commission as part of its 1992-1994 forward works program. The Commission is required to report within 15 months.

Under the Commission's terms of reference, the Commission is required to report on the `institutional, regulatory, financial or other arrangements of governments in Australia which affects the efficient provision of workers compensation and rehabilitation services for injured workers'.

Under term 3(C) the Commission is also required to report on the relationship between workers compensation and other related arrangements such as accident liability insurance, remedies available in common law and the regulation of workplace safety by governments.

Territories have cooperated with the Federal Treasurer in refining the draft terms of reference for the inquiry. Clearly, any changes to Comcare should await the outcome of that inquiry. Indeed, it would be appropriate for the proposals contained in this legislation to be referred to the Industry Commission for examination under terms of reference 3(B) instead of this Bill proceeding.

Furthermore, I understand that an alternative proposal was recently put at a meeting of senior officers in Canberra. As I understand it, this proposal was premised on the assumptions of furthering the objectives of micro-economic reform and improving the competitiveness of Australian industry.

There is certainly some merit in considering a proposal for workers' compensation arrangements that are consistent across the nation. This alternative proposal would seem to alleviate the major concerns of the Government, in that it would neither create different classes of employers and employees, nor would it have a significant impact on the financial viability of State and Territory schemes.

Investigation and development of this alternative proposal would involve all States, Territories and the Commonwealth in a joint and cooperative approach. This is a far more palatable approach than the current one which is an unwanted incursion by the Commonwealth into State jurisdictions.

I also understand that under the heat of opposition to the legislation, the Government has agreed not to implement its proposals regarding private sector coverage by Comcare until a Commonwealth-State working party has reported.

So we have a Government asking this Senate to pass legislation the implementation of which has been referred to a working party which is to report back to the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee.
But this Government has lost the trust of the Australian people.
It does not deserve the trust of this Senate.
Legislation should not be passed prior to that working party report or the Industry Commission report.
There is absolutely no community demand for the major proposals enshrined in this Bill.
On the contrary, there is fierce opposition—opposition from State governments and their workers compensation agencies and opposition from employers.

The only support seems to come from Comcare, seeking to expand its scope, size and power and Minister Cook's mates in the trade unions, who will undoubtedly seek to use their industrial muscle, to intimidate employers into the Comcare system because of the higher benefits it may provide for union members.
This piecemeal and divisive approach should not proceed and that will be the intention of our committee stage amendments.
The ultimate solution to workers compensation issues is to privatise Comcare.
Our other amendments will keep clear the path for that in the future, under the next Liberal National government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I would be somewhat misguided if I sought leave to incorporate my remarks in Hansard because in fact I would like to begin by reminding the Senate of what was said in the second reading debate by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) in the other place. The important thing to note about this is that the honourable member—
—I think Senator Bell would do better without the cheer squad.
—I seek to remind the Senate that the honourable member led his contribution by saying that he rose to lead the debate on the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment Bill—
—It might be worthwhile if Senator Schacht found another seat for a little while. I am not sure how that is going to be translated into Hansard.
—Let us regain composure. The honourable member reminded us that he was leading on behalf of the National and Liberal parties and in part of his speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of this Bill is to allow the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act to cover certain corporations outside the Commonwealth public sector for what are, it must be said, very practical and supportable reasons. It would cause unnecessary complications if privatised Government organisations were unable to compete under current Commonwealth arrangements. By the same token, it could be seen as unfair if private corporations competing against recently privatised government agencies were not able to avail themselves of the same compensation regime if they so chose. In any event, I think the outcome is rather unlikely.

The honourable member then continued to tell us of the benefits of the scheme and how wonderful it was. I think there can be no greater authority than that which is given by the honourable member for Gwydir, who then told us that the coalition would not be opposing the Bill. In light of that, I think the advice that we were given at that stage should lead us to recognise the virtues of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats, however, have been particularly concerned. We thought that the advice that was given by the National and Liberal parties in the lower House was advice which was not particularly well founded, nor was it particularly applicable to this Bill. We were concerned that in fact the Bill could achieve several problems for those who had been attempting to get proper workers compensation cover.

The Democrats had drawn the attention of the Senate previously to problems with licensed Workcare coverage—workers compensation coverage which was provided by Telecom. That licensed coverage was supposed to be supervised by Comcare and we have in the past illustrated the inadequacies that had existed. I am pleased to say that many of those inadequacies have been addressed subsequent to our raising that in the Senate. Nevertheless, it seems that this Bill could have been introduced with undue haste, without being assured that potential licensees had the capacity to deliver a full and comprehensive coverage.

There was another problem that we saw with this legislation. We suspected that the motivation of the administering body may not reside in delivering an effective and equitable scheme of coverage to potential clients but, rather, may be motivated more by seeking to make a commercial profit or operating a commercially viable operation. Those fears made us examine the legislation very carefully, and we have since been assured that our fears are misplaced. We hope that that assurance is so. I do not think that I need to labour the point any longer. The point is made. We will be supporting the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

I might single out Senator Grant Chapman for special praise and mention. He has performed a stunning act tonight, one that is breathtaking and awe-inspiring in its simplicity and almost persuasive in its argument. I admire his action. I will quote it far and wide as a principled and sensible reaction in the circumstances. Regrettably, I am not persuaded by it, but at some other time I might be. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

2.Clause 5, page 2, paragraphs (b), (c), (d), (e) and (h), omit the paragraphs.

The purpose of amendments Nos 1 to 11 is to exclude from the legislation the capacity of Comcare to provide cover for privatised former government business enter-prises and for other private sector corporations. As was spelt out in my speech in the second reading debate, there is a wide range of concern about the proposal of the Government to allow Comcare to undertake this purpose. That concern has been expressed by all the State governments—Labor, Liberal and coalition—by employees, by a number of employer groups and also by a number of the State Workcover instrumentalities.

PARA.TAB: Amendments Nos 12 and 13 are the amendments to which I referred in my speech in the second reading debate regarding the intention of the Federal Liberal and National parties to privatise Comcare.
