I noticed that in his speech in the second reading debate, Senator Bell justified the support of the Democrats for the legislation as it stood on the basis of the remarks of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) in the other place. I simply indicate that the remarks made in the House of Representatives with regard to this legislation simply indicate the folly of guillotining legislation through the other place without allowing adequate time for its consideration and debate. Although we believe this is not as desirable a situation as would have been achieved had the first series of amendments been passed, these amendments are a second best option.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, Senator Reid asked me a question about whether the membership by senators of statutory bodies to which they are appointed by the Senate could constitute the `holding of an office of profit under the Crown' within the meaning of section 44 of the Constitution. There has not been time to obtain a formal, written legal opinion on this, but I have had the relevant authorities examined, including the recent judgment of the High Court on the subject, and it is clear that these appointments do not create any such difficulty. The offices concerned are not `under the Crown'; they are statutory offices to which the Senate makes appointments, and it appears that they are also not `offices of profit'.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT HOUSE DEPARTMENT: PUBLIC LIABILITY CLAIM

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon, during the debate on the public liability claim by the Speaker, the Honourable Leo McLeay, Senator Hill asked me if I was aware of a certain statement given to lawyers concerned. I responded that, as I had not read the file, I was not aware of the document, but that I would make inquiries about it. The Secretary of the Joint House Department has now provided me with the document in question, which I table. In doing so, I reiterate that I have not read the file and I have not seen any document except the one just tabled and those provided to Senator Hill this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I thank you for promptly seeking out that document and tabling it. You have given me the opportunity to peruse the document. It would seem from the contents that the circumstances were slightly different from that which I had—

TALK.START.PARA: —Slightly?

—I will tell Senator Ray the difference, and he can make his own judgment. The circumstances differed from what I had been informed of, and which I asked if you would investigate. I put to you that I had been advised that Mr McLeay had been advised directly by the staff of Joint House that the bicycle might be unsuitable for a person of his weight. It now seems that Joint House gave that advice to a staff member of Mr McLeay.
—That is not what you said.

—I am reading from what I said. Mr McLeay required the bicycle to be delivered to his rooms in Parliament House. So it is somewhat different, but I do not know that it is so different in the consequence, because it still seems that at least the staff of Mr McLeay were made aware of the danger in relation to the bicycle. In fact, from the document just tabled by the President, the staff member of Mr McLeay is reported to have replied, when given this warning, `We know all about the bikes'. The staff member then required that the arrangements go ahead. According to that document, the staff member offered warnings on a further two occasions.

TAB.TAB: So the facts seem to be now established, Mr President. To the extent that they differ from what had been put to me and what I put to you to investigate, I regret this. I might add, however, that the Speaker, in his press release—to which I think the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) might have been referring—was suggesting that I had that information at the time that I asked the question. This was not the case. The information was provided to me by the President in the form of documents, after I had asked the question.

PARA.TAB: The only other point I wanted to make was that the Speaker refers to allegations of wrongdoing. There have been no allegations of wrongdoing. Up until now the matter has been simply one of establishing the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are all anxious to avoid prejudging this matter. Quite clearly it is a matter of public interest and concern because public moneys are involved. As Senator Hill has just pointed out, in considering whether concerns were conveyed to a staff member of Mr McLeay, it is also very important to know whether those concerns were then relayed by the staff member to Mr McLeay himself because that would materially affect his knowledge, his awareness of the condition of the bike, and the circumstances under which it should be ridden. It would therefore be a material circumstance to be taken into account in assessing the way in which any settlement might be negotiated.

PARA.TAB: Once again, as Senator Cooney would be aware, the plaintiff has to prove his case. If there are evidentiary deficiencies or suggestions that somehow he was aware that there were problems with the bike in question, then that obviously must affect the prospects of success or even the chances of a reduction for contributory negligence. That would then be reflected in any offer made.

I stress that the only material that has been made available is the file provided by the Joint House Department. The Speaker has made it clear that he regards himself as having nothing to hide and he wants all the documents made publicly available. Therefore, we are awaiting further material from the Australian Government Solicitor.

If one simply looks at the material that is contained in the file kept by the Joint House Department, all that one finds in relation to the measure of damages is a single medical report and a single legal opinion. The medical report is one from an orthopaedic surgeon who examined the plaintiff on a couple of occasions prior to an operation conducted by a neurosurgeon. We do not know whether the orthopaedic surgeon examined him subsequently, but certainly there is no medical report to that effect. There is certainly no opinion from the neurosurgeon.

Those are critical matters in making any sensible judgment as to the extent of any injury or any continuing disability and certainly any residual consequences from the operation. One would clearly need to be in possession of a series of medical reports, not only from the plaintiff but, of course, independent medical assessments made by doctors commissioned on behalf of the defendant. None of those medical reports are available.

If one then looks at the legal opinion, one finds that that does not even refer to a medical report. It simply makes some very scanty references to the plaintiff's alleged state of health and then proceeds to suggest that somehow this claim is worth $30,000 to $50,000. As we know, the matter was settled for approximately $50,000 for general damages, plus medical expenses, plus legal costs. It was settled right at the top of the range.

The material also indicates that at all times the defendant was bending over backwards to settle the matter as quickly as possible. There was never any serious attempt to investigate the question of liability and there was certainly no attempt to negotiate in the normal sense, which means making a lower offer than one ultimately expects to be able to resolve the matter for. The Department simply took a figure, offered it, and then paid it into court, and Mr McLeay took it.

If one reads the final correspondence, one finds the absolutely laughable proposition that, because Mr McLeay had asked for $100,000 and the Department got out of it for $50,000, it got a very good settlement. One might as well say that if McLeay had asked for half a million and we only gave him $200,000 we would have done even better because we would have got more than a 50 per cent discount. Quite clearly, there is very scant material available to justify anything like a $50,000 payout for general damages. After all, as Senator Herron, who knows a lot more about this than I do, would confirm, on the face of it the medical evidence suggests that there was only a very limited disability in terms of limitation of movement of the arm. Mr McLeay chose not to pursue physiotherapy on more than four occasions. Quite clearly, that exercise would have assisted his cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not always.

—Not always, but what one usually does is try to see how it goes. If it does not do any good, that supports one's case. But when one does not even bother, it suggests that somehow one is not really serious about remedying the matter.

PARA.TAB: Another thing I find quite extraordinary is that this accident happened on Anzac Day. Mr McLeay went to see his general practitioner, a Dr Rosemary Crowley, on the same day, was referred to the specialist and saw the specialist the following day, by which time he had been to see his solicitor, who had written a letter to the gymnasium section of this House, asking them to hold on to the bike as evidence. In other words, Mr McLeay was incredibly speedy in pursuing his legal rights but not so speedy in pursuing any attempt to resolve his medical condition to the extent that he had a capacity to do that by undertaking physiotherapy.

He claims that he cannot play tennis and he was not able to pursue his intention to take up golf. Do honourable senators like that one? In other words, it was not as if he was a champion sportsman cut down in mid-stride. All that he was denied was the opportunity to take up golf. One might as well say he was denied the opportunity to pursue a career as a league footballer or anything else that he turned his mind to. That is another matter. He lost his seat and he has got another one which has about a 4 or 5 per cent safety margin, so he is not doing too badly. To a certain extent that would affect the question of future economic loss and, of course, they were trotting out arguments about whether he would be able to resume his position as an organiser, as though that is some sort of honourable profession. I would have thought his chances were limited as a Telecom technician. But that was not pursued. This matter was resolved on the basis of general damages for pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life. All I can say is if I had been acting for the plaintiff, on that medical evidence I would have grabbed $10,000. Indeed, there are people in this place who would not have even made a claim.

The important thing is that we need a lot more material and I think the public does too in order to be in any way satisfied or persuaded that this claim was worth anything like $50,000. In those circumstances it is a matter of very real concern to us that the President did not become involved. Quite clearly, the Speaker is not able to effectively give instructions to the Crown Solicitor or the Government Solicitor and therefore he should not only have stood aside but someone else should have been in there conducting the matter on his behalf.

As Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out earlier today, it puts the head of the Department, Mr Bolton, in a very invidious position. It is almost impossible for him to make a sensible judgment. Certainly, if he was so minded to make an offer on the low side, or to try to pursue genuine compromise, he would be exposed to enormous indirect pressure. That is why I think we need to know more about why the President, who presumably was aware at a fairly early stage that Mr McLeay had been injured, and that he was bringing proceedings, did not then intervene to ensure that the matter was conducted very much at arms length. By that I mean in such a way that someone was able to give sensible instructions. As it turned out, Mr Bolton simply handed it over, washed his hands of the matter, and I suppose one can understand that. It was then left on the implied basis that they would get out of this as quickly and as expensively as possible. That is not in the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know. In the case of Senator Bolkus, I suppose it is money. He would have settled for a lot less. All I can say is that there is a lot further to go before any public concerns are assuaged. I trust that we will be provided with much more material in the very near future, so that proper judgments can be made on the matter.

—The evidence that has been presented to us has been quite inadequate. Senator Ray said earlier that there are two aspects—whether there has been due process on the one hand and whether the compensation has been adequate for the injuries sustained. In all of the evidence produced to us there is only one medical report and that was from a doctor who saw Mr McLeay on a preliminary matter. The report was written six months after the original injury.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of interesting aspects in the evidence that has been presented to us. Mr McLeay's total out of pocket expenses were in the vicinity of $600 for medical expenses and $2,600 for hospital expenses. He gets $65,000 for that. There are no other medical reports. There was not even one from the operating neurosurgeon. A second opinion has not been presented to us, at all. In my professional experience, I have never heard of this occurring. We have not been given anything that justifies the compensation of $65,000 for something of this nature. He suffered an undisplaced fracture of the elbow. He must be the only member of the New South Wales Right to break his arm and to then get $65,000 from the taxpayer.

There is a lot more evidence that has to be produced in this case to justify that expenditure, and you, Mr President, are not absolved of this. You have washed your hands of this. You have dumped this on the Secretary of the Joint House Department and said that you do not want to know about it. Mr President, that is not good enough. You are the officer responsible for the governance of this Parliament, and you said you did not want to know about it. You are the joint head of this Department, and it is not good enough to say that it is the responsibility of the Secretary of the Department. He is the responsible officer but he cannot be given the responsibility for the expenditure of $65,000 of taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that at 5 o'clock in the morning this issue is ending with a whimper, rather than a bang. We discussed this matter earlier in very constrained time circumstances after Question Time. I will finish making some of the points I started to make then. I will also repeat some of the points. The fundamental point to be made and to be answered—
—You don't like him.
—Order!
—The fact that I might or might not like Leo McLeay does not mean that I am going to sit here and see the sort of rafting job that it is being done—
—You are going to hang in there whether he's guilty or innocent.

—Not at all; but there are certain facts in this matter that should be put on the record and the intervention and interjections of the honourable senator will not deter me from putting those on. The first and fundamental question we did address this afternoon is: does Mr McLeay in fact have the right to pursue a legal remedy or not? So the answer generally is yes, he does.

PARA.TAB: Is he the same as everyone else who works in this building? Probably not, on the basis that he holds one of the two most senior positions in the Parliament—not necessarily in the Government, but in the Parliament—and therefore this whole matter would have to be dealt with by Mr President and Mr Speaker in a very much hands-off manner. One of the factors that has been raised is that this matter should have gone to the Joint Committee. No-one over there has yet named one case of compensation that has gone to the Joint Committee over the years. No case—and there have been compensation cases in this building—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many cases have there been where the Speaker has claimed?

—Honourable senators want two rules; they want one rule for everyone else who works in this building and one rule for the Speaker. No other compensation case has gone to the Joint Committee, but they want this one to go.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr President, these people opposite do not want a rational discussion on this; they just want to shout me down. That is all they want to do. They do not have an open mind. Here we have the great rigged jury of all time that will not listen to any counter arguments whatsoever. The Liberal Party-National Party Star Chamber is now in session and they want to shout down anyone who wants to make any points about this case.
—Why didn't he take responsibility for his own actions?
—Senator Walters is the worst of them, baying away in the background, yelling out judgments and snide, sleazy interjections right throughout the night.
—I raise a point of order. I do not mind a bit of colour, a bit of dash and a bit of flair, but Senator Ray has for the last three minutes—
—I wish you would provide some.
—Order!
—Senator Ray has reflected upon the integrity—
—You ought to talk about reflecting on integrity.
—Order!
—Mr President, if you will allow me to make the point—
—Keep a straight face.
—Order!

—Mr President, I am sure you do not need me to provoke you to make the obvious observation, that Senator Ray is reflecting upon the motives of those on our side. It is contrary to Standing Orders. I am sure I do not need to remind you of the standing order to which I refer and I ask you, if you are not prepared to ask him to withdraw, to ensure that you counsel him for future comments.
—At 5 a.m. in the morning, I think it would be better if it was withdrawn. I ask honourable senators from both sides, please cease interjecting.

—I withdraw, Mr President. When this matter was raised in the chamber by Senator Hill in his questions to you initially, Senator Hill twice said in that speech, `I have heard a rumour around the building that Mr McLeay was on an exercise bike', implying that it was a fixed bike. The second rumour he ran in this chamber was, `I have heard that Mr McLeay went outside and constructed the exercise bike'. He did not have an exercise bike; he did not construct the bike, but that was the rumour run in here the other day. Basing these speeches simply on rumour without substance can be very damaging. I will come to the more damaging one in a moment.

PARA.TAB: We have established, and no-one has disputed it here, that Mr McLeay had the right to pursue a legal remedy for what he thought was a wrong. That is not in question, so we accept that. The second area we move to is: was the process right? First of all, Mr McLeay did not have direct dealings with Joint House. Mr McLeay had his solicitors—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Godfather! He doesn't have direct dealings! For crying out loud.

—On this issue, no, he has not. If there was any evidence of that, Senator Crichton-Browne, if there was the slightest evidence of that, it would have been produced by Senator Alston tonight—it has gone through the papers—or by someone else.
—A wink is as good as a nod to a blind horse.

—That is right. I acknowledge that interjection. I make the assertion, on behalf of Mr McLeay, that he had not had dealings with Joint House on this, and honourable senators opposite immediately infer he has, but have not produced one piece of evidence on that. Mr McLeay properly went through his solicitors and had his solicitors deal with Joint House and later with the Government Solicitor. I do not believe anyone, other than Senator Crichton-Browne, would contest that. In a letter from the Joint House Department to the Australian Government Solicitor, dated 20 December 1990, the following was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that this matter be seen as being dealt with at arm's length and away from any possible allegation of political influence.
In other words, the Joint House Department was well aware that it would be very difficult for them to make a judgment on someone who was their joint-titular boss.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Speaker doesn't influence the Secretary!
—Not in this matter, senator, because the adjudication and the judgments are then made by the Australian Government Solicitor.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—No, they're not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they are. They have put the matter in the hands of the Australian Government Solicitor, as one should do. Throughout this, when one reads the correspondence, the proper procedures were dealt with in that relationship between the Joint House and the Government Solicitor.
—You are not doing too well, Robert.
—When Senator Walters wants to get to her feet and walk outside this chamber and make an allegation—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No; because not one of those opposite will walk outside this chamber and say that Mr McLeay placed pressure or influence on the Joint House Department. Not one of those opposite will go out and do that. Yet the snide interjections all imply that. An absolute of this chamber is that none of those opposite will go outside and say that—not one of them will go outside and say that. In reading the correspondence, Senator Alston, as a barrister, obviously would put one interpretation on the correspondence. But one of the clear things that comes out in the correspondence is how the Joint House Department and the Government Solicitor tried all sorts of methodology to do over Mr McLeay. That stands out in a lot of the correspondence backwards and forwards. It is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Can we define that future employment for Mr McLeay as an officer of profit under the Crown . . . therefore you would have a reduced superannuation.

All those sorts of legal methods, which are part of the adversarial system, I admit, were tried in this case by the Australian Government Solicitor to either defend or reduce the claim of Mr McLeay. Absolute evidence is there for those who read that correspondence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did he not take responsibility—
—Order! Senator Walters.
—I now move to Senator Hill's two statements today. If ever I have heard a dissembling set of explanations I have heard it here, because Senator Hill put the best gloss on it in his second speech.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I have been tempted to ask this question before. I wonder might I ask for your guidance. `Dissembling', by a normal interpretation of the English language, means to be misleading, to tell an untruth and to lie. With respect, I ask you to make a ruling, if you will.
—I do not regard that as unparliamentary. But can I point out again: there have been three speakers heard in relative silence, and I ask that Senator Ray be given the same privilege.

—Mr President, I was moving on to the two statements by Senator Hill: one that he addressed to you and one where he made a sort of partial withdrawal. I still do not accept the way he withdrew that and the implications he left. But I do accept one thing. I would make no allegation that Senator Hill today, when he addressed the questions to you, had any actual knowledge of what was in the files. Any other imputation in that regard I would reject because I am quite sure he would not have.

PARA.TAB: But what did Senator Hill say to you today, Mr President? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that a woman from the health centre was on duty when the Speaker, Mr McLeay, came in to hire the bike and she refused to let him have the bike because he was more than 100 kilograms in weight. I am further advised that the Speaker later, undeterred, went back to the health centre during the lunch break so that he could hire the bicycle from another person who was unaware of the weight limit.
No more serious charge in these circumstances could be made than that.

PARA.TAB: I note the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation ran the charge in full on the ABC news tonight. I also note that Senator McMullan walked into this chamber 15 or 20 minutes later to put down a categorical denial. No coverage was given by the ABC to the denial.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not true at all.

—I am talking about the 7 o'clock news. Later in the ABC's news items in the course of the night, senator, Mr McLeay's denial comes. I thought I would contact the ABC to find out why it would not acknowledge Senator McMullan's denial at least. The first explanation was that it did not have the time to alter the story. This is a story from 3.30 p.m. on! The ABC's second explanation was: `We missed it. We did not know he said it.' I find that disappointing on the part of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill's accusation was a most serious one because the implication of it was that the Speaker personally went down, was personally informed of these matters, returned to his office, then deviously waited and went back down and tricked someone else. Now, when we read the file we see that the fact is that Mr McLeay did not go down to the health centre. Mr McLeay did not make one trip, did not make two trips; he did not go down there!

TALK.START.PARA: —So he sent a lackey down.
—You see, you are definitely over the edge, senator, when you start to make such statements.
—That is the way he treated them.
—No! You referred to the Speaker's staff member as a lackey. So much for your democratic attitude, Senator, that you refer to an employee here as a lackey.
—Go and get on your bike.
—That may be the way you treat your staff!
—You are not in the classroom now!
—That may be the way you treat your staff.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—That may be the way you treat your staff but the fact is that if Senator Hill bothered to read the file properly and bothered to tell the truth about it, he would realise what the file says. All the conversations and contacts over this matter are over the telephone; and you know it. But you did not get up. You have read the file and you did not have the courage, the decency, to get up and say so.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr President, we can all understand the feigned indignation of Senator Ray, defending an indefensible case, but there is no excuse for not directing his remarks through you.
—Order!
—Mr President! A point of order.
—Order! Is this the same point of order?
—No.
—On the point of order that was raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, I ask Senator Ray to address the Chair but I also ask you, Senator Herron, to cease interjecting.

—Mr President, my point of order is that it is ten past five in the morning. I have demonstrated many times to you before the bizarre behaviour of this Senate. The effect of being present here at ten past five in the morning is illustrated by the bizarre behaviour of both Senator Ray and myself, Mr President.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I accept the psychological analysis from Dr Herron but I do not accept his political view. When Senator Hill has read the file and comes in here and puts down only one or two sleazy accusations without acknowledging that some of the accusations that have been put down here—
—A point of order, Mr President. I believe that the word `sleazy' is not parliamentary.
—Come on. Let us have a withdrawal.
—Order! Look, I asked Senator Ray to withdraw the expression before. I did not rule it unparliamentary but I thought we might get a better debate.

—I withdraw, Mr President. How would one describe the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate coming in at ten past three yesterday afternoon and circulating a rumour and an allegation that the Speaker personally went down to the health centre, tried to hire a bike, was refused and then snuck back down hours later and, in a deceptive manner, hired a bike. That is the sort of allegation that we are dealing with, senator. That is the deception that we are dealing with. As soon as Mr McLeay refutes that, as soon as all the files are produced to refute that, you do not come in here and say: `I am sorry, Mr McLeay, that we have made criticisms of you, but we will not retract the previous allegations that we made against you that were base and false, as it turned out.
—You do not think in the press release he should have said that his staff member got the advice and not him.
—He has cooperated in releasing all the files that were available.
—No, that is not true.

—In the first instance, but I will return to that point in a moment. The publicity given to the accusation that Senator Hill made, which he believed was based on good information, did the Speaker immense damage when it was carried across the news broadcasts in this country. When it is not true, Senator Hill's technique then is to say that there are a lot of unanswered questions. That really ends up being the ultimate cop-out.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I have dealt with that matter by Senator Hill. I believe he was wrong to make those allegations, but I do not believe he made them knowing them to be false. I accept his word on that. Nevertheless, they were made and I do not think they have been properly and fully retracted here this morning.

Firstly, the question of medical reports has been raised. My understanding is that those medical reports that exist—I say it is my understanding—with the Government Solicitor are not within the knowledge and ken of the Joint House Department, the President or the Speaker. It makes it rather hard for them suddenly to produce them out of the air and table them here at any stage.

Secondly, there is the degree of ridicule that Senator Alston put on the Speaker, saying that he rushed straight to his solicitor as though nothing had happened. I know from the people who were around at the time of the incident that Mr McLeay was in immense pain. I do not think it should be put on the record that that was in fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —So the last thing you would think of doing is running off to a lawyer.
—Wouldn't you take an aspro rather than go to your doctor?

—That is the honourable senator's allegation. He should consult his colleague about when someone breaks his elbow whether he take an aspro—maybe that is Senator Crichton-Browne's particular matter. A large part of the contribution this morning also has concentrated on whether it was a fair amount or not. That is precisely why the matter was referred to the Government Solicitor for adjudication. That is precisely why the Government Solicitor—I think I am right, and Senator Cooney can probably verify this—sought an opinion from a Mr Stretton of Blackburn Chambers to evaluate all the evidence and make a recommendation. That was another hands off, and it is quite clear that he recommended the range of money, and that the eventual settlement was within that range of money.
—Just! Just!
—This was in terms of damages, I do not think that included—
—No, from memory it was $45,000 to $67,000. I do not think that included—
—Stretton's advice?
—Yes—
—It was $30,000 to $50,000 for general damages.

—Yes, and added to that are legal fees and medical fees, so I think we agree it is within the ambit. It is, therefore, the Government Solicitor who makes those judgments. I do not make a judgment; I am not an expert in compensation. I do not know what the relativities are and what all the factors involved are. But I know one thing: this chamber is no expert in that; this chamber should not set itself up as a jury for trying to evaluate what the proper areas were. I do not want to delay any further other than to say that I believe, firstly, that Mr McLeay had the right to pursue a matter of compensation Secondly, I think that the process undertaken by Joint House to leave it essentially as much as possible in the Government Solicitor's hands was a correct one.

PARA.TAB: Those who read the record properly and read the correspondence between Joint House and the Government Solicitor will see they use most of the legal tricks and the adversarial system that they have at their command to either defeat Mr McLeay's claim or to lessen it as much as possible. It is, of course, the duty of government—no matter how much the claim is justified—in its adversarial system to try to fight it out as much as possible.

Finally, this chamber has seen a lot of allegations in the last two days, many of which have been totally disproved. Therefore, when people get up and say they want more questions answered, more rumours attended to, I just caution them on the fact that they have been wrong on several occasions with regard to this, and this chamber should not be used to run every rumour around the building or as an excuse to throw mud. If honourable senators want to concentrate on the general principles then that is the function of this Parliament, but by just coming in here and throw around unsubstantiated rumour and muck, without a proper and adequate apology when it is disproved by just asking more questions, they are not doing this chamber any good whatsoever. A couple of people interjected and said, `What am I doing on my feet defending someone who I have always had a close relationship with?'. All I can say is that I think he has been treated abysmally in this particular matter and if any honourable senators had been treated in the same way I would have defended them equally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I appeal to people from both sides of the chamber: it is now twenty past five in the morning and we have been sitting since 9.30 yesterday.
—Under standing order 191 I claim to have been misrepresented by what Senator Ray has said in respect of some matters he raised in his comments earlier.
—You have got the floor.

—Senator Ray suggested that I had claimed that the Speaker had spoken directly to Mr Michael Bolton. I did not claim that at all. What I claimed by imputation was that, by the strength of the Speaker's character, as a result of his relationship with Mr Bolton, as a result of Mr Bolton's general demeanour towards him and the Speaker's knowledge of him, Mr Bolton could not ever be held to be perfectly immune from the influence of Mr McLeay. To that extent, Mr McLeay should have sought to find a separation between himself and Mr Bolton in terms of the decision that was to be made. The obvious way of doing that was through the Committee. He chose, for reasons which are not obvious to me, not to do that. I conclude by saying—

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I find this an extraordinary attempt at a personal explanation about something that was apparently an aside during Senator Ray's speech. I do not believe that Senator Crichton-Browne is addressing himself to a personal explanation. I ask you to bring him to order and for him to direct his remarks to that matter alone.
—Yes. I think Senator Crichton-Browne should confine his remarks to those areas where he believes he has been misrepresented and not carry on a debate.

—Absolutely. I have done that. I conclude by saying that it ought to be remembered that we did not learn of this matter from the Speaker. We learnt of this matter in spite of the Speaker, and what we know about it did not come from the Speaker but from sources other than the Speaker. He has not been open and frank in respect of these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of other points from the file that need to be on the record. The problem with this matter is that when you are dealing with a Presiding Officer and a sensitive matter such as this, not only does it have to be scrupulously carried out but it has to be seen to be done in that fashion as well. Quite frankly, the file does not show that that was done.

PARA.TAB: The accident took place on 25 April 1990. There was a file note stating that on 10 April 1991 the strategy by the Government Solicitor was that they should seek to settle the matter with no admission of liability. There was the question also of whether the manufacturer of the bicycle should be held liable in the matter. The way that that is normally dealt with is that when the writ or statement of claim is issued there would be a joining in of the manufacturer as a co-defendant. If one settles on the writ at a very early stage, of course, that does not take place.
There is a file note also on 17 April 1991 further stating what the strategy was to be, and the strategy is written as this:

SPEECH.PARA: McLeay's solicitors will be issuing a formal claim. The Australian Government Solicitor, Sienkowski, has spoken with them. Once this is done, the settlement negotiations can be concluded fairly quickly. Aim is to settle against McLeay and then look at the manufacturer for some indemnity. Sienkowski to put this to me in writing. In accordance with that strategy, process was duly issued in September 1991. Settlement was then recommended—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. A number of senators are speaking in the aisle over there, interrupting the flow of debate and, as I have been called to order tonight for that same offence, I ask you to call those senators to order.
—I have often asked people to resume their seat or leave the chamber. Many people occupying this seat do that.

—The flow of the debate was interrupted by Senator Faulkner. To continue, the process began in September 1991. There was an instruction that was subject to Mr Bolton confirming it. The file note is dated 25 November 1991. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Sienkowski rang to advise that Mr McLeay's solicitor had advised that Mr McLeay wished to accept the offer of $55,000. After deducting medical expenses already paid, the balance was $51,205.55. After confirming with Mr Bolton, I advised Mr Sienkowski to proceed with the offer. He will send a form 12 and seek to recover some of these costs from the manufacturers. Payment was duly made then on 26 November.

To put it mildly, the speed with which this matter was processed was quite out of the norm. There was another matter concerning somebody in this chamber. The accident took place in 1988. Settlement was not effected until this month, indeed 48 hours ago, and it was settled at the court door where proper process was issued and where normal court proceedings were gone through.

PARA.TAB: The injury was far more serious than the Speaker's. I do know what the figures were, but that perhaps is for somebody else to disclose and not for me to deal with. It was a far more serious accident, with the same sorts of figures, and the case was conducted from 1988 to 1992. There was no speed, no little notes, and none of the ease with which the Speaker's matter was resolved.

The difficulty is that Mr Bolton is responsible to the Presiding Officer. The difficulty is that there was no bringing in of the Joint House Committee. There seems to have been no arm's length negotiations. That is the whole problem with this sorry mess. It may well be that the injury was such that the settlement figure was appropriate. It may well be that proper processes could have been gone through and the same result would have been come to but, quite frankly, this is not what could be called a normal legal case. It does not match up with another case of which I am fully apprised where somebody was also in a position such as this.

That is why this matter has been raised. That is why people are angry about it. They feel that it was not properly conducted and dealt with. An advantage has been given to somebody who was in a position of authority and who perhaps exercised that authority. Whether or not that was done, I suppose we will never really know. What we do know is that the person who benefited was in a position of authority over the person who exercised the authority to settle. Mr Bolton issued that authority to settle. Those dates speak for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some remarks ought to be made in reply to what has been said by honourable senators opposite. What has been bandied across the chamber today, from both sides, is an interpretation that each side has put on a set of facts. Both sides have acted as advocates. It can hardly be suggested that honourable senators opposite are going to bring to this issue a mind that is clear of particular perceptions. They hope that there may be political advantage to be gained. There is no denying on this side that we are going to go to the aid, if it were necessary, of the Speaker.

PARA.TAB: What we are doing is exchanging perceptions. The actual facts of the matter are probably not greatly in dispute. The Speaker was injured when a bike collapsed under him. It is quite clear that that was negligent. The people who supplied the Speaker with the bike knew that it was a dangerous thing to do. An experiment was carried out which showed that the bike collapsed. I understand what honourable senators opposite are saying. They do not dispute that there was negligence. What is disputed is the amount that was paid to the Speaker. Honourable senators opposite say that the amount of just over $50,000, with costs, was too much.

What I can say about the way it was handled is that there is no doubt that the Speaker got a settlement which was a very good settlement. That was done on the basis of an opinion from a Mr G. Stretton which no doubt honourable senators have got hold of. There was no suggestion that Mr Stretton was in any way under the influence of Mr McLeay. Mr Stretton is a solicitor or a barrister who is in private practice. Mr Stretton is a barrister or a solicitor who was briefed, as I understand it, by the Australian Solicitor, the old Crown Solicitor. They are the facts that we have got to work with. Honourable senators opposite put an interpretation on that and say, `Look, that is all consistent with the Speaker using improper influence'. That is the real charge being made, that of improper influence either in terms of reality or, as Senator Bishop touched on, improper influence that can be at least constructively placed upon the Speaker.
The fact of the matter, and nobody has denied it, is that the Speaker was entitled to sue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hey, Barney; I have just done my leg in. What do I get?

—Let us say that Senator Alston had injured his leg very badly. Why should Senator Alston not sue if he has a serious injury? So the real problem is the extent of the damages; the way it was dealt with and the extent of the damages. This matter was dealt with by obtaining an opinion and, as I understand it—I have listened carefully to this whole debate—nobody has attacked the opinion of Mr Stretton. I do not know Mr Stretton. Honourable senators have not got up and said, `Mr Stretton, you were wrong in this. You approached this with mala fides and in some way you have given your opinion under the influence of the Speaker'. I have not heard it suggested at all from the other side that Mr Stretton was under the influence of the Speaker. I have heard it put that Mr Bolton was under the influence of the Speaker, but he did not make that assessment of damages.

PARA.TAB: It was Mr Stretton who was at arm's length not only from Mr McLeay but also from the Parliament because he is outside the Parliament. I am happy to be corrected upon that but, as I understand it, he is a person who runs a private practice and he was the one who made the assessment. It was on the basis of his assessment that everything flowed. Can honourable senators opposite show me that Mr Stretton was in some way acting improperly? They have to show that it is more than making a generous assessment, they have to show that he in some way acted improperly because he was under the influence of the Speaker or because he wanted to curry favour. That has not even been alleged.

So it is not Mr Bolton who is in the firing line, as it were; it is Mr Bolton acting on the advice ultimately from the Australian Government Solicitor and that office acting on the advice of Mr Stretton and that coming through to Mr McLeay. If Mr McLeay is offered an amount of money, why should he not take it? If Mr McLeay is told that his injuries are worth that much, why should he not take it? If Senator Alston gave advice to a client which was overgenerous advice—and in the old days he used to give advice, as I remember, and we would say that it was outrageous and then he would go and get the amount claimed—nobody criticised him for that. What they were saying is, `There is Richard Alston doing well again'. I would imagine, with great respect, that Senator Alston would have put a bigger figure on this, and come down, of course. If Senator Alston, as a responsible barrister—which he was, and a very good one, may I say, and one I always respected—gave that advice, he would have expected it to be accepted. That is what this is all about. Why should a person not take the advice of counsel?

Senator Alston says that he does not refer to the report. That is a criticism of the counsel who was involved. If counsel has written a bad opinion, perhaps one could criticise him for that. But if counsel writes an opinion that says, `Offer this much', and that much is offered, then why should not the person to whom it is offered say, `Yes, I will have it.'? That is what has happened here. The only way one can get over the problem is to somehow impugn Mr Stretton. He is the fellow who has to be hit on the head, as it were, not Mr Bolton. Mr Bolton is simply taking the advice he gets from the Office of the Australian Government Solicitor, which gave its advice on the basis of what Mr Stretton said.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Stretton gets his advice from the instructing solicitor.

—Hold on a minute. Everybody gets instructions. One has to work on one's instructions. I hope the honourable senator never went out and investigated his own cases. Of course he goes forward on the basis of the medical reports provided to him.
—He doesn't form his own opinion.

—He has been willing to get out and give an opinion and that is what he has come up with. On the basis of that opinion, the system goes into operation and they say to Mr McLeay, `We will offer you this much', and he says, `Thank you very much. I will take it'.
—No, he didn't. He asked for more.

—He asked for more, but in the end he settled at what was offered. They said, `We are going to pay in'. I do not know whether they actually got to paying in or whether they threatened to pay in, but as soon as they threatened to pay in he said, `All right, I will weaken; I will give it away; I will surrender; I will run up the flag'. Instead of fighting on as we might have thought a courageous person would, he weakened and settled at the figure.
—Would you have given a discount for liability?
—No. I looked at this. They were in possession of the bike, and it was a bike that they knew was not suitable. They warned the person in McLeay's office and said, `This bike is perhaps not suitable'.
—Not for the Robert Rays of this world.
—No, it is not for the Robert Rays of this world. If they gave it to Robert Ray, he would be able to sue.
—Do they have two bikes?

—I have seen Senator Colston at the gym. There would be no problem on liability in this case because of the knowledge that these bikes are not built for big people. With the evidence that they had warned somebody in the Speaker's office, it is quite clear that they had knowledge of the unsuitability of this bike. In supplying the bike, clearly there is negligence.
—Did the staffer tell Leo?

—Senator Kemp puts his finger right on it, because there is no evidence that the Speaker ever knew anything about it. Even if he did know that there may be some problems with it, it was still provided by a person who had the control of the bike and knew about the bike, so I do not think there would be any contributory negligence. One could certainly argue that there was not. There is just no evidence that he did know. There is no evidence at all in any of this material that Mr McLeay ever knew of the danger of this bike, whereas there is clear evidence that the person who provided the bike knew all about it.
—When you are making an offer, why assume he didn't know?
—I do not know. I have to sit down because it is getting a bit late in the morning. All I say is that Mr Stretton is the fellow who those opposite have to get to.
—The jury is asleep.

—Of course it is, because they know that the case is all over. They know that, if anybody is to be blamed, it is Mr Stretton. I am not going to blame a man who is obviously a person of note in the community. I am not going to condemn him. I think it is an opinion that he has got together well. He has given that advice and Mr McLeay—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He might have done that but there is no evidence that he has done that. They say, `Here is the offer on the basis of our opinion', and he says, `I will take it'. Now everybody comes and says, `You have got some sort of influence over Mr Bolton'. Of course he has, but what Mr Bolton did is irrelevant in this case. It is not Mr Bolton's problem: it is the Australian Government Solicitor's problem. There is no evidence that the Speaker had any influence at all over the Australian Government Solicitor and, as I keep saying, there is no evidence that he had any influence over Mr Stretton.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I am going to sit down. I do not invite Senator Alston to get to his feet but I will invite him later to say where there is any evidence to show that the Australian Government Solicitor or Mr Stretton was in any way influenced by Mr McLeay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim that Senator Robert Ray misrepresented me.
—That was a while ago.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I would wait until the end of the debate. Senator Ray believes I should have done it earlier. Perhaps I should have. He made the comment that I had claimed that there was some sort of pressure put on Mr Bolton by the President. At no stage did I claim that. Senator Ray knew that I did not. He knew that the only interjection I had made was: why did Mr McLeay not take responsibility for his own action? That is all I have said and that is all I continue to say.

—There are two very disturbing matters about this incident. One, as my colleagues have pointed out, is that Mr Stretton's advice, as I understand it, was $30,000 to $50,000. It was settled right at the top of the range, which is very unusual. Even Senator Cooney would have to agree to that. The other thing is probably more disturbing. I do not know of the incident myself but, from what I heard of Senator Bishop's address to the Senate, there was another case. The facts of that case are somewhat similar yet it was not settled nearly as neatly, as quickly or as precisely. It dragged on for a long time. The injuries were quite severe. It did not seem to flow through with the same sort of speed and expertise as this one did.

PARA.TAB: I am not in a position to say anything further than that in relation to the facts but I do say that this is the most disturbing part of the issue. Here we have two cases that were quite similar. One was dealt with expeditiously. It just so happened that that was the case of the person in charge of the defendant. In the other instance, the person was not quite so fortunate. One case was settled expeditiously, at the top of the range; the other one dragged on and on and got a fairly poor settlement. I think that that is very disturbing and it requires some further investigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate for speaking at this late hour and I will be very brief, but for the second time today I find myself required to stand up to correct the record because Senator Macdonald has been poorly advised by Senator Alston and has unwittingly misinformed the Senate. There was reference to a figure of $30,000 to $50,000 in the course of calculating the damages liable. But let us have a look at what Mr Stretton said. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In my opinion then, the plaintiff's range of damages is between $40,794 and $67,000. I recommend an early payment into court of $55,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for the lot.
—He said that there should be $30,000 to $50,000 plus various other things; he recommended $55,000. Let us get some accurate figures on the record.

—I have a very brief comment on this. As has been mentioned by everybody else, the hour is late. It seems to me that the statements which have been made in this chamber this evening and earlier today have shown that there are very serious matters and problems which have emerged.
—What are they?

—Senator Faulkner can read the Hansard. Senator Robert Ray, in his comments, said that we had to make sure that the process by which this matter was dealt with was appropriate. I think that, in view of the comments that Senator Alston and my colleague Senator Herron have made, it is not clear that the process was appropriate. The second matter is whether the outcome of that process was appropriate. Again, it is very clear from the matters that have been brought forward by Senator Herron that there are questions to be asked about the outcome.

PARA.TAB: This is probably the last hour of sitting before we rise before the next election. I believe that these are serious matters and I believe that the public would want a full inquiry and investigation into these matters. I suggest to members of the Australian Labor Party that, when they look at the newspapers tomorrow and in the following days, the public will have a lot of questions about what has occurred, the process by which the Speaker's case was determined and the extraordinarily generous outcome to that case. I put it to honourable senators that this is a serious matter.

I do not have a particular solution as to how this can be investigated. I understand that the President has been very careful to make sure that he was not directly involved in this case. I do not know whether that was an appropriate course or not. Let me put it to the President that now this has emerged into the public arena and now that there are a number of issues which I believe require further inquiry, I would like to hear from him in the light of what has been put forward in this chamber this evening. What action, if any, does he propose to take and how does he see his responsibilities now these particular matters have arisen?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a psycho battle.

—Senator Faulkner happens to be a member of the New South Wales Labor Party, which I would have to say does not have the best reputation in some of these matters—to put it mildly. I put it to him that there are going to be a lot of questions from the public. The President is one of the joint heads of the Joint House Department and I believe that the President is now in a position where he has to determine what is the best course to take. I put it to you, Mr President, that you should not be bullied or howled down by those opposite. I think it is most appropriate that you reflect on the particular action which should now occur.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman—Mr President, I raise a point of order. There were several senators seeking the call to speak on the adjournment when you put the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop was making some comment about reports and I put the motion that had been moved by the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan). It is not as though this is a unique procedure.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—Mr President, a point of order. Does your ruling mean that the Senate is unable to wish the staff and other people in this place a merry Christmas? Does it mean that we do not get the opportunity to thank those people who have looked after us all year for their service and the good job they have done. I refer to the Clerks, the attendants, the dining room—all those people we normally thank?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In reply to a point of order which was a speech, if this motion is carried, the Senate will adjourn.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senate adjourned at 5.57 a.m. (Friday) until Tuesday, 23 February 1993 at 2 p.m. or such other time as may be determined by the President.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following documents were tabled:
Coal Research Assistance Act—Determination—1992—No. 1.
Pasture Seed Levy Act—Declaration—1992—No. 1.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 27 February 1992.

PARA.TAB: With reference to the extent to which the Government's Newstart program has been assisting long-term unemployed professional people to retrain and thereafter re-enter the work force:
(1) Is Newstart designed to assist all the long-term unemployed whatever their age, educational level, and previous career.
(2) How many people whom the Department of Employment, Education and Training classifies as "professional workers" are registered with Newstart.
(3) How many of these people hold two or more degrees or diplomas from recognised tertiary education institutions.
(4) How many of these people hold higher degrees (and are therefore ineligible for assistance under AUSTUDY).

(5) Are Job Clubs, on-site training, and short courses at private colleges and Technical and Further Education Colleges of limited use in allowing professional people to retrain and/or find suitable employment.

(6) Why does the Commonwealth Employment Service offer "bridging" training for professionals with overseas qualifications but no equivalent service for long-term unemployed professionals forced by the labour market to acquire additional qualifications.

(7) Is the Secretary of the Department of Employment, Education and Training aware that under subsection 613(2) of the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, he/she has the power to require or permit a recipient of the Newstart allowance to undertake a full-time university course.

(8) Bearing this provision in mind, how many people in receipt of the Newstart allowance have been required and/or permitted to undertake a full-time university course in order to upgrade or supplement their qualifications.

(9) How many long-term unemployed professional people have been made aware that they are able to negotiate Newstart Activity Agreements whereby they can be permitted to return to full-time university study and still be eligible to receive the Newstart allowance.

(10) Will steps be taken to ensure that long-term unemployed professional people who need to return to full-time university study are able to continue receiving the Newstart allowance for the duration of their course.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, provided they are in receipt of Newstart Allowance (NSA).

(2) It is not possible to give an accurate figure of how many `professional workers' are registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), as the codes which cover the `professional' categories also include a number of non-professional occupations.

(3) The capacity to record this information became available on Jobsystem on 20 May 1992. However it is not possible to access this information for survey purposes as it is recorded in free text format, meaning that it is recorded as comments in a field, and not as retrievable codes which are normally used for surveys. Therefore, the information is only recorded for the purposes of having more extensive client information on hand, enabling the CES to refer the client to appropriate training or work.
(4) As per (3).

This recognition would permit successful candidates to practise their profession in Australia. This provision does not permit overseas professionals to acquire additional qualifications beyond those they already had in their country of origin.

(7) The Social Security Act provides the Department of Employment, Education and Training with the discretion, delegated from the Secretary of the Department of Social Security, to require or permit NSA recipients to undertake educational courses. In this context, guidelines were developed in consultation with the Department of Social Security for CES staff which provide for the approval of clients on NSA undertaking only short term vocational courses. This is consistent with the Government's purposes in providing NSA, being that beneficiaries must be unemployed and undertaking activities designed to lead to employment as soon as possible.

The established form of income support for people wishing to pursue courses of full-time study, as opposed to short term entry-level vocational courses, is AUSTUDY. AUSTUDY is intended primarily to assist students to complete their secondary education and to obtain an initial post-secondary qualification.
FTA is the Government's income support mechanism payable to disadvantaged clients to undertake a range of DEET labour market programs which provide vocationally oriented skills in short term courses.

The CES guidelines are designed to assist staff in their application of the Social Security Act and are intended to ensure that only appropriate vocational training (not full-time education as such) is approved under NSA, so that course approval does not cut across existing AUSTUDY and FTA policy. The guidelines also ensure that decisions to approve any courses being undertaken while on NSA are consistent with the Government's purposes in providing income support for educational purposes (AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY and Formal Training Allowance (FTA)).
(8) Nil.
(9) Nil, as this would be contrary to policy (see 7).

(10) No. However I have asked the Department to review the inter-relationship between AUSTUDY, FTA and JSA/NSA in order to identify any inconsistencies in policy and gaps in provision, and to clarify their respective roles.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 23 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Piparwar Coal Project in Southern Bihar, India:
(1) Has the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) carried out a social or environmental impact analysis of this project; if so, what were the results of this assessment;
(2) Does the project comply with environmentally sustainable development principles for aid funding;
(3) What process of consultation was carried out with the local community;
(4) Will there be a requirement for sections of the local community to be relocated as a result of the project;
(5) What is AIDAB's assessment of the effect of mining operations to the Damodar River;
(6) Does the project include provision of funding for the rehabilitation and reforestation at Piparwar.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development has advised me that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) AIDAB is currently preparing a comprehensive review of social and environmental impact mitigation measures taken for the Piparwar coal project. The results will be available shortly. As partners in this undertaking, Australia is also monitoring the project to ensure that our involvement conforms to Indian legislative requirements.
The Government of India has in place its own environmental control process. The main pieces of environmental legislation which apply to the Piparwar project are the:
Environment (Protection) Act 1986—to cover all environmental aspects related to water, air and land and their interrelationships;
Forest (Conservation) Act 1980—to conserve forests and to review use of forested land for other purposes;
Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act 1981—to prevent and control pollution of ambient air.
Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution ) Act 1974—to prevent and control pollution of rivers and other water sources.

In addition, the Government of India has formal procedures for the acquisition of land as well as the determination and payment of compensation to people displaced by land acquired for coal mining projects.
Under Indian law, all environmental planning and works for the Piparwar project are the responsibility of Coal India Limited.

As an integral component of the proposed mine development the Australian contractor, White Industries, prepared an environmental management plan as part of its Technical Feasibility Study Report in 1987. This outlined the methods by which the required environmental safeguards for pollution management and land rehabilitation would be incorporated into the proposed mining, coal handling and coal preparation operations. The White Industries plan was incorporated in the formal environmental management plan prepared by the Central Mine Planning and Design Institute (CMPDI—a subsidiary of Coal India Limited), which also covered socio-economic factors (especially displacement of people) as well as environmental monitoring and budget allocations for environmental management and rehabilitation and compensation for displaced persons.

The Government of India has advised that the relevant subcommittees of the Environment Department have assessed the plan against the requirements of the Environment (Protection) Act 1986 and recommended it for approval.
CMPDI is monitoring the implementation of the Environmental Management Plan. The Indian Government has advised us that the project is proceeding in accordance with the environmental management plan.

(2) AIDAB's Interim Policy Statement on Ecologically Sustainable Development recognises that development requires greater energy supplies and that in the short-term most countries in the Asia-Pacific region must be expected to increase their use of fossil fuels to meet increasing energy demands. In these circumstances, the introduction of efficient mining technologies with a high level of attention to environmental protection and rehabilitation is considered critical.

India is a large developing country with approximately 250 million people living in abject poverty. The World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other international development agencies all share the Government of India's view that access to adequate supplies of energy will be a key factor during the Eighth Development Plan period (1992—1997). Without adequate supplies of energy it will be very difficult for India to lift its standard of living.

However, India does not have access to large indigenous supplies of oil. In fact, India's current economic crisis is to a significant degree a result of the need to import oil to meet the needs of industry. India is therefore determined to develop fully its coal resources.

India's existing coal mines are generally inefficient and highly polluting. India therefore stands to benefit greatly from the Piparwar project which will introduce Australian open-cut coal mining technology. This will significantly improve India's capacity to develop its coal resources with the least possible damage to the environment. The Piparwar mine is, in fact, the first mine in the Karanpura coal fields to incorporate built-in anti-pollution and environment management systems which are compatible with accepted international standards.
(3) Protracted negotiations with local villagers have been carried out to negotiate the possession of land required for the project.

Progress on land acquisition and resettlement of displaced persons is being closely monitored including through discussions with all relevant parties. The most recent AIDAB monitoring visit indicated that there is a willingness on the part of village communities to shift to new sites and cooperate with the project. However, outstanding issues which remain to be resolved include compensation and land classification. Given the obvious complexities of the situation there is good progress towards resolution of these issues.

(4) Five villages are within the project area boundary. Three of these five villages are within the area of mining operations and infrastructure and the approximately 460 families within these villages will need to be progressively relocated.

The Government of India's compensation program for families displaced by the mine provides for alternative house sites with suitable infrastructural amenities (roads, water supply, electricity, wells and drains), a lump sum grant towards housing costs and a relocation allowance. 300 unskilled or semi-skilled employment opportunities created by the project are reserved for members of families which have been displaced by the mine. Families which are unable to obtain employment in the mine for at least one of their members will receive a subsistence allowance for twenty years.

(5) The Piparwar project incorporates a comprehensive water management plan similar to that used at the Ulan mine in New South Wales. AIDAB's assessment is that this plan is sufficient to ensure that the effect of mining operations on the Damodar River will be minimal.
The general principle adopted is containment of water on the site through an extensive closed circuit system. The main features of this plan are:
the separation of runoff potentially contaminated by mine development from runoff from unaffected areas
the direction of potentially contaminated runoff to settlement ponds
the direction of washery wastewater to settlement ponds and the return of settled tailing to the open pit
the collection and treatment of sewage with final disposal by spray irrigation
reuse of collected water for site purposes.

Mining operations will not affect the groundwater system. The area is rocky terrain with weathered rock cover overlying the rock strata and there is not a continuous aquifer. There is local recharge during the monsoon and groundwater levels are seasonably variable.

(6) The mining method being demonstrated by White Industries involves progressive rehabilitation during mining operations. The mine will be developed as a series of parallel strips with the mined out areas being reclaimed progressively throughout the mining operation. This process includes: removal and stacking of topsoil, clearing of overburden and backfilling in the adjacent mined out area, respreading of topsoil, levelling for planting.
It is this technology which is being demonstrated to Central Coalfields Limited for subsequent application after White Industries' involvement in the project ceases.
The Government of India has responsibility for the actual reforestation and has allocated budget resources for this purpose.

Tree planting has already commenced. A pilot scheme has been undertaken with the Bihar State Forestry Department to determine appropriate species for planting in this area. A model of what the rehabilitated land will look like has been constructed on the site where an area of excavated land has been successfully replanted with local varieties of trees.

The Commonwealth is not involved in details relating to individual APRA holders which are matters for the universities themselves as self-governing institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 16 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it correct that there is a case in Sudan where Pastor Mattaboush, who was convicted in 1986 of crimes against Islam arising from his evangelical work, is still serving a thirty year sentence in El Obeid Prison.

(2) Is it correct that the four Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA) guerillas, one of whom Pastor Mattaboush was found guilty of harbouring in his home, have since been released under a general amnesty.
(3) Has the Australian Government raised this case with the Government of Sudan; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following is provided in answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) According to the most recent information obtained by the Australian Embassy in Cairo, which is accredited to Sudan, Pastor Mattaboush was being detained in prison in El Obeid although there are unconfirmed reports that he has since been transferred to Koba prison in Khartoum.

(2) Our missions in Africa have actively sought information from a variety of sources on the circumstances of Pastor Mattaboush's incarceration and his present welfare. Despite this, they have so far been unable to ascertain any information additional to that mentioned above, nor of the situation of the four Sudanese People's Liberation Army guerillas referred to in the question. Amnesty International Australia has confirmed that Pastor Mattaboush had been sentenced for allegedly harbouring a member of an armed opposition group but has no further information on his present situation. The Australian Embassy in Cairo has noted in the context of this case that over the past twelve months Christian leaders in Sudan have come under intense scrutiny from Sudanese security for speaking out against the Government of Sudan's appalling human rights record.

(3) The Australian Government has made representations to the Government of Sudan, through the Australian Embassy in Cairo, seeking information on Pastor Mattaboush's case and his welfare. The Government of Sudan has not responded to these representations. The Australian Government is deeply concerned at the deteriorating human rights situation in Sudan. We have made a number of representations to the Government of Sudan, in particular concerning the grave human rights situation in Juba. We have also been active multilaterally in trying to ensure that the international community is fully seized of the situation. At the 47th General Assembly of the United Nations in New York the Third Committee has adopted a strong resolution, co-sponsored by Australia, which among other things calls for the Commission of Human Rights to consider at its next session (CHR 49) the appointment of a Special Rapporteur to examine the human rights situation in Sudan. This result reflects growing international concern about the human rights situation in Sudan and places further international pressure on Sudan to improve its human rights record.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 16 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will Australia's ninth report to the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination be tabled; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The report will be tabled during the first parliamentary session following the report's lodgment with the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 25 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is there a register administered by the Commonwealth which records Australians affected with genetically acquired physical and mental abnormalities; if so: (a) where is it located; (b) when was it established; (c) who administers the register; (d) for what purpose was the register established; (e) what information in regard to the relatives of an individual affected by the genetically acquired abnormality is recorded on the register; and (f) from what sources is the information recorded in the register acquired.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: A register which records Australians affected with genetically acquired physical abnormalities is maintained by the National Perinatal Statistics Unit, an External Unit of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.
(a) The register is located on computing systems maintained by the National Perinatal Statistics Unit located at the University of Sydney.
(b) The data base was established in 1981.
(c) The National Perinatal Statistics Unit administers the register.
(d) It was established to provide incidence data on major structural birth defects and chromosomal abnormalities.

(e) The information collected regarding the parents of the child varies between States and Territories but generally includes parental age, country of birth and/or ethnic group, marital status, previous pregnancies.

(f) Information is acquired from notification forms of State and Territory health authorities, death certificates, notifications from cytogenetic laboratories, midwives' data collections, pregnancy termination notifications, autopsy and pathology reports.
